In precolonial Nigeria, the ooni was a religious leader and a warlord. In the colonial era, he was one of many traditional leaders coopted by the British in their system of indirect rule. The current holder of the title, Oba Okunade Sijuwade Olubuse II, rides in a cream-colored 240D stretch Mercedes limousine with a purple and white license plate that says: "Ooni of Ife." When he appears in public, usually clad in gold brocade and slippers, an official trumpeter blasts out a loud riff. As a direct descendant of the progenitor of the human race, the ooni does not grant interviews. But he is mindful of the value of media exposure. To that end, he has retained Basha Alperin, an American woman with media experience. "I do video for the ooni," explains Alperin. She shoots videotape of the ooni receiving petitioners in his palace in Ife, performing religious ceremonies (there are some 400 gods in the pantheon of the Yoruba religion) and traveling on official business. In independent Nigeria, traditional rulers such as the ooni have almost no official power. Most Yoruba are Christian or Moslem. The ooni himself is a millionaire businessman who juggles religious and entrepreneurial obligations. (His late predecessor, a church-going Anglican, was not above using his influence to line his pockets. As head of the Ife District Native Authority, he gave an exclusive concession to exploit Ife Forest to a timber company he partly owned.) It is possible, given enough cash, to buy a traditional title. Many wealthy businessmen have spruced up their image by adding "Chief" or "Oba" to their business cards. Yet Nigerians continue to respect traditional leaders, whose vague authority has survived the colonial administration, two civilian regimes and five changes of military leadership. "No government has ever succeeded in reaching rural areas without using the traditional leaders," says Information Minister Tony Momoh. In the current military regime, obas -- even obas who bought their titles -- are seen by the government as legitimate spokesmen for the demands of local communities. Contradictions rest easy with Nigerians, for whom economic, social and political collisions are the stuff of everyday life. The most striking of these contradictions is the coexistence of the country's masochistic appetite for self-condemnation and its chest-thumping nationalistic pride. Titles of popular books by Nigerians include: "Another Hope Betrayed," "The Trouble With Nigeria" and "Always a Loser -- A Novel About Nigeria." A recent newspaper column about national ineptitude was headlined: "It wouldn't be Nigerian if it worked." Nearly four years ago, the federal government came up with WAI -- the War Against Indiscipline. Unique in Africa, WAI amounted to a government admission that Nigerians are intolerably rude and messy. WAI posters were distributed throughout the country, urging people to stand in line, pick up their garbage and be nicer. In a country that blames itself for squandering billions of dollars in oil revenue, self-flagellation has become a national rite. O. Gbola Ajao, who teaches at the College of Medicine in Ibadan, wrote recently to the New Nigerian newspaper: "Some years ago we were asking about developing a tourist industry in Nigeria. What a laugh! How will any foreigner in his right mind want to come for vacation in a place like Nigeria? Even those of us born there are always looking for one excuse or another to get out of the place." Yet, even as they subject themselves and their leaders to withering condemnation, Nigerians have been extraordinarily intolerant of outside criticism or advice. "Nigerians are not rational," says Tony Momoh, principal spokesman for the military government of Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida. "We would prefer to go hungry to being told what to do. I can't think of any other African country doing such an irrational thing. But there is more to a Nigerian than reasoning." For more than five years, Nigeria rejected a loan from the International Monetary Fund that was conditioned on economic reform. The IMF's demand that Nigeria's currency, the naira, be devalued was popularly viewed as an imperialistic attempt to castrate the country. Other reforms, which threatened the perquisites of the politically powerful middle class, were portrayed in the local press as the sneaky schemes of greedy westerners. When the Babangida government seized power after a bloodless coup in 1985 -- as unpayable foreign debts mounted and oil revenues continued to shrink -- it became clear that prideful opposition to economic reform would bankrupt the country. Unable to overcome Nigeria's pride, Babangida outwitted it. In one of the neatest economic maneuvers in African history, the general told the IMF that Nigeria didn't want the loan. Then, as the country rejoiced in having told the IMF where to go, the military government implemented an IMF-style reform package that western economists describe as the most comprehesive on the continent. The package has led to a liberal rescheduling of foreign debts and eased Nigeria's financial crisis. The reforms, which penalize the urban elite in favor of farmers, are far stricter than officials from the IMF or World Bank say they would have dared demand. And Babangida, a former tank commander with an engaging smile, has sold them to his country as "our structural adjustment program produced by Nigerians for Nigerians." Thus far, with Nigeria's pride appeased, both Babangida and the reforms enjoy wide popularity. In postboom Nigeria, money is tight. With devaluation of the naira, the price of automobiles, foreign schooling and international air travel has increased three-fold. Austerity is a dreary and unavoidable fact of life. But Nigerians seem determined not to let the dreariness get out of hand. In Lagos, Nike Marinho designs and sells formal wear for weddings, birth ceremonies, funerals and installations of obas. The clothing is of traditional design, brilliantly colored, individually tailored, intricately beaded. A bargain outfit for a man or woman costs $ 300 to $ 500. An expensive outfit can run $ 1,200 or more. Marinho says her customers feel obligated to buy three or four outfits for a marriage or a funeral, affairs that usually involve several gatherings over two or three days. She acknowledges that her customers have far less money than they used to. But she says they still buy three or four outfits, often borrowing the money. "We Nigerians are gullible for dressing up," she says. Olagoke Olabisi, dean of the engineering department at Lagos State University, recently purchased four new outfits to wear to the four gatherings commemorating the death of his father. The clothes cost more than Olabisi could afford, he says. Asked if anyone would notice if he were to wear an old outfit or even wear a new outfit twice, Olabisi replied: "I would notice."

COUNTRY: UGANDA (99%); KENYA (92%); RWANDA (92%);
TEXT: Six months ago, a small-time Ugandan smuggler who sold five gallons of gasoline in neighboring countries could make three times more in one day than a Ugandan Government minister received as a monthly salary. With cans of fuel strapped to rickety bicycles or balanced on top of their heads, Ugandan peasants would travel across the border to Kenya or Rwanda and easily get $20 for gasoline for which they paid the equivalent of $2. Back in Uganda, they could sell the foreign currency at the black market rate of 16,000 Ugandan shillings to the dollar, reaping a net profit of 288,000 shillings. This allowed them to purchase scarce commodities like soap, sugar and cooking oil. A Government minister's monthly salary last January was about 90,000 shillings, and the minimum monthly wage was 10,000 shillings at the official exchange rate, which was not enough to buy a stem of bananas or two pounds of sugar. Business these days, however, is not as profitable for the illegal traders. The price of gasoline, which was set artificially low, has been increased by 50 percent to bring it closer to the commodity's real market value, thus diminishing the incentive for smuggling. Agricultural Economy Sought In this and other ways, the Government of President Yoweri Museveni is attempting to resuscitate an agriculturally based economy shattered by years of war, mismanagement and corruption. Last January, a year after Mr. Museveni seized power, prominent Ugandans and Western donors said the state of the economy was the most serious issue facing the Government but that the President had offered few concrete strategies to deal with it. Some of Mr. Museveni's early policies were criticized as having had a disastrous effect on Uganda's fiscal condition. But since then, economic specialists say, the President has come to terms with the need for bold measures to improve the economy. He has reached new loan agreements with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank that require tight monetary policies. His Government has devalued the currency by more than 75 percent, introduced a new shilling worth 100 old shillings and levied a 30 percent tax on all money converted from old to new in a move to reduce the overall money supply. The old currency had been made almost worthless by spiraling inflation and a huge gap between official and black market exchange rates. Mr. Museveni has also announced increases of up to 500 percent in prices paid to farmers, as an incentive to revive agricultural production. The Government currently derives two-thirds of its income from coffee exports, which account for 95 percent of Uganda's export earnings. Civil Servants' Salaries Up Mr. Museveni also doubled the salaries of civil servants to restore some of their lost purchasing power. Uganda is to receive $310 million in aid from major donor nations over the next year, $50 million more than the country had sought to finance imports of essential raw materials, spare parts and capital goods needed to get idle productive capacity employed again. The Paris Club of bilateral and multilateral aid donors has rescheduled all the debt repayments Uganda should have made in the current financial year, saving the country $66 million. Uganda's total debt service liability had been running at about $200 million a year, which represented about half of its export earnings. ''The economic reforms represent an intellectual and policy watershed,'' said one Western diplomat familiar with the economy. ''The President had intensive dialogues with the I.M.F. and World Bank that had the quality of a graduate seminar in economics and he is deeply committed to these reforms. The Western donors did not beat him up and make him cry uncle.'' But Ugandan economists, Western diplomats and others agree that it will take years to pull the country from its economic quagmire. Mr. Museveni inherited a treasury of only about $500,000 in foreign exchange, the result of profligate spending on arms and staggering corruption in the Government headed by Milton Obote, the former leader against whom Mr. Museveni's forces fought a four-year bush war, and Maj. Gen. Tito Okello. Mr. Museveni's National Resistance Army ousted Mr. Okello's Government in January 1986. From 1970 to 1985, according to Government statistics, the country's agricultural output fell by 30 percent and industrial output by more than 50 percent. Per capita income declined by more than 40 percent. A study by an international labor organization showed that Uganda's factories were operating at less than 20 percent of capacity because of a chronic shortage of foreign exchange to buy imported raw materials and spare parts. ''It won't be easy, no matter how sound our economic policies,'' a Uganda economist said. ''The economy is still shrinking, but in Uganda, we should try to look at the bright side for a change. Three years ago, the gross domestic product fell about 3 percent. Last year, it shrank by less than 1 percent. That has to be considered good in Uganda.''

COUNTRY: BURKINA FASO (96%); AFRICA (96%); UNITED STATES (92%); FRANCE (79%); ETHIOPIA (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: The young man in striped socks and jogging shorts with a referee's whistle around his neck looked familiar. It was Capt. Thomas Sankara, 38 years old, the President of Burkina Faso, refereeing a soccer match here between his even younger ministers and a team of local farmers. The voice on the national radio sounded familiar. It was Captain Sankara, before a national commission, detailing his assets: one nine-year-old Renault, one refrigerator, three guitars, six bicycles, $560 in the bank, a weekly salary of $110 and $2,200 outstanding on his home mortgage. Shunned by Older Leaders Unorthodox, outspoken and apparently uncorrupt, Burkina Faso's impatient young President is shunned by Africa's older leaders as the continent's enfant terrible. But to much of Africa's younger generation - young Africans who have known only the disappointments of the independence era - Captain Sankara is an angry young man to their liking. ''Sankara incarnates African youth,'' one essayist wrote glowingly in a recent issue of Jeune Afrique, a regional magazine. ''Elevated, poised, incisive. It's the style of the black man of the modern age. After so many cruel deceptions and wounds inflicted on Africans by so-called 'revolutionary' leaders, I cannot help but be sympathetic to the style and thought of Thomas Sankara.'' When Captain Sankara, then a 33-year-old parachutist, seized power four years ago, when the country was still known as Upper Volta, he told his eight million citizens that the old ways were over. Third-Poorest Nations There was little debate that the old ways had failed. According to the World Bank, Burkina Faso ranks as the third-poorest nation in the world, ahead of Ethiopia and Bangladesh. Locked 300 miles from the sea in the heart of sub-Saharan West Africa, this dry Arizona-size nation has seen little progress in 27 years of independence. First, Captain Sankara waged war on corruption. He sold all the luxury cars of the previous regime, decreed the fuel-efficient Renault 5 (marketed in the United States as Le Car) to be the standard car for ministers and instructed all ministers to fly economy class. A year after taking power, his Government changed the name of the country to Burkina Faso, which means ''Land of Upright Men.'' Attacking the state bureaucracy, he cut civil servants' wages, slashed their housing and transportation allowances and abolished a head tax the peasantry used to pay to support the civil service. Finally, to wake up the bureaucrats, he ordered them to take up weekly athletics. President Sets the Example ''There is a choice to make - either we continue to give more than 60 percent of the budget to 25,000 civil servants - 0.3 percent of the population -or we decide to look at the rest of the masses,'' he said. Setting the example, the President took a salary cut and started playing soccer with his ministers Saturdays. ''I earned a certain salary in the old army,'' he said recently, talking about some unhappy professionals who have left Burkina Faso. ''I lost this salary because of the revolution. If I wasn't with the revolution, I would have fled too.'' Early on, he sent a clear signal on corruption. Theft From African Bank In 1984, evidence mounted that three officers of a major West African development bank had stolen $22 million in deposits. One of the officers pledged to repay the money, and most West African leaders showed little inclination to pursue the matter. But, by chance, in October 1984 Burkina Faso took the rotating chairmanship of the bank. Captain Sankara returned from a meeting, with the three bank officers handcuffed aboard his plane. Today, the men are serving 15-year jail terms in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso's capital. An indefatigible and often erratic advocate of change, Burkina Faso's young President also turned his energy to changing his desert nation's ancient society. Interest in Women's Rights In a dizzying series of decrees, he shut nightclubs, banned prostitution and banned begging. He set up ''solidarity compounds'' to teach artisan skills to beggars and prostitutes. Recently, he proposed holding a world conference on prostitution in Ouagadougou. Captain Sankara's concern over prostitution is part of a wider interest in women's rights. Women hold one-quarter of the ministerial portfolios here - budget, culture, health, family affairs and tourism and environment - taking what is probably the highest proportion of Cabinet posts in any African country. Burkinabe often complain that the country pays dearly for the President's hasty decisions. For example, earlier this year the President announced a self-sufficiency campaign. Fruit imports were banned and citizens were ordered to appear at official events dressed only in clothes made of local homespun cotton. But the import ban threatened to set off a tariff war with Burkina Faso's major trading partner, Ivory Coast. Migrant Burkinabe workers pick most of Ivory Coast's fruit. The national cloth is not as durable as imported cloth, and national looms are unable to keep up with the demand. 'Imperialists' Are the Demons To keep up with flagging revolutionary fervor, Captain Sankara speaks his mind in public, flaying the West in language that most other African leaders dropped years ago. His major demons are ''the imperialists'' and ''the local bourgeoisie.'' In Maore, the language spoken by half of Burkina Faso's population, these terms translate, respectively, as ''the bad whites'' and ''the white blacks.'' It is unclear exactly who the imperialists are. Half of Burkina Faso's national budget is paid by foreign aid. Ouagadougou is believed to have one of the highest concentrations of aid agencies in the world - 110 are officially registered. Opposition From Unions ''We see through all that imperialist talk - we know who gives all the aid -France, Germany, the United States, Canada,'' said one Burkinabe who says he is hostile to the revolution. Organized opposition to Captain Sankara and his revolution comes mainly from the civil service trade unions. In July, Amnesty International reported that 30 union members had been arrested. By this month, most had been released, Government officials say. Addressing the unionists, the national radio used its standard phrases. It spoke of ''the need to put an end to the feverish agitation of these sorcerer's apprentices and hardened criminals, the darlings of international imperialism.''  Visas for French Citizens On the international scene, there is little friction between Burkina Faso and the Reagan Administration, despite the left-wing speechmaking. France, the former colonial power here, has also learned to live with Captain Sankara's verbal sparring. In November, Burkina Faso was the only member nation to boycott the regular conference of French-speaking African countries in Togo. More recently, Captain Sankara started requiring visas of French citizens - a move designed to retaliate against new French visa requirements, which many Africans see as discriminatory. Captain Sankara also took on the French airline U.T.A. and threatened to withdraw its landing rights in Ouagadougou if the company did not stop flying to South Africa. The threat was later dropped. Last November, when President Francois Mitterrand stopped in Burkina Faso to try to patch things up, Captain Sankara startled guests at a state dinner by dressing down his guest for ''neo-colonialism.''' Retorting that his host was ''young and impertinent,'' President Mitterrand placed his prepared speech in his pocket and delivered an impromptu one-hour reply. He concluded: ''Sankara is a disturbing person. With him it is impossible to sleep in peace. He does not leave your conscience alone.''

COUNTRY: NIGER (99%); LIBYAN ARAB JAMAHIRIYA (95%); CHAD (94%); UNITED STATES (94%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); FRANCE (91%); COTE D'IVOIRE (79%);   LIBYA (95%);
TEXT: President Seyni Kountche of the West African country of Niger died of a brain tumor in a Paris hospital today after 13 years in office. The 56-year-old President was flown to Paris on Saturday for his sixth hospital visit since suffering a mild heart attack last December. A few hours before the President's death, the Niger radio announced that Col. Ali Seybou had been named acting head of state because of Mr. Kountche's ''very worrying'' state of health. Colonel Seybou, Chief of Staff of the army, was a cousin of the former President. With the death of Mr. Kountche, the United States and France lose a quiet ally in Chad's war against Libya. Niger, a largely desert nation of about six million people, shares a 250-mile border with Libya. Mr. Kountche, who served for 12 years in the French colonial army, was suspicious of Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Relations at a Low Level Since taking power in a coup in 1974, the conservative Niger leader kept relations with his northern neighbor at a low level. Mr. Kountche was said to resent Libyan broadcasts to Niger in local languages, and he accused Libya of training Tuareg groups to destablilize his Government. The Tuaregs are a nomadic, fiercely independent Berber group. Last December, it was reported that France secretly used Niger's military airfield at Dirkou to parachute arms and supplies to Chadian Government forces in the Tibesti Mountains of Chad. The airfield was renovated by American engineers in 1984. Today, President Francois Mitterrand said he regretted the loss of ''one of the most loyal friends of France.'' Last weekend, the African leader was flown to Paris in a plane provided by the French President. During his tenure, Mr. Kountche weathered three coup attempts, and Niger's new leader is expected to face challenges to his power. The country he inherits is one of the poorest in the world. According to the World Bank, the per capita income is $200 a year, the 10th lowest recorded. Twice Ravaged by Drought Twice in the last 20 years, the thinly populated nation almost twice the size of Texas has been ravaged by drought. Mr. Kountche took power at the height of the 1969-1974 drought, promising to end corruption in the distribution of food aid. But during the next drought, in 1983, a group of young officers, charging that corruption and nepotism was rife in government, took part in an unsuccessful coup In recent years, the United States has been the main food donor to Niger. President Kountche visited Washington in 1984 and Vice President Bush visited Niamey, the capital, in 1985. The major source of recent growth in Niger has been uranium, the nation's largest export. In 1971, Niger's uranium mines in the Air mountains went into production under the management of Somair, a uranium mining company controlled by the French Atomic Energy Agency. In the oil crisis of the 1970's, uranium prices rose and Niger enjoyed a small boom. Since then, uranium prices have fallen sharply and Niger has had to reschedule its debt payments.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); AFRICA (92%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: This country is a long-suffering student in the free-market school of how not to be an economic basket case. For four years it courageously has done what the western financial experts said it must do. It has stopped wasting money on white-elephant projects and begun paying farmers prices that give them an incentive to grow food. It has lifted price controls and devalued its currency. That is one view of Zaire, supported by mountains of economic reports and many very long speeches. There is another, decidedly more cynical view, also supported by many observers here. It goes like this: Zaire is a den of unregenerate thieves. Its president and top ministers mouth the free-market lingo that the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Reagan administration like to hear, while continuing to fill foreign bank accounts with loot. No government project is begun without payoffs. Payoffs are so ubiquitous and so exorbitant that many projects are never completed. Civil servants regard extortion as a part of their job description. The murky truth about Zaire, sub-Saharan Africa's second largest country, seems to be that both of these views are true and false. Corrupt Zaire is reforming as never before; reforming Zaire is still corrupt. The IMF and World Bank were invited back to Zaire in 1983, after several years' absence, to rescue this country from unpayable debts and its own venality. Their advice, after four years, appears to have taken some of the bite out of what many Africa scholars call the "kleptocratic" state. But not even the western economists who designed and help implement the reforms are willing to say they see a new dawn of good government. "If you think structural adjustment is going to turn Zaire around, you are a bit naive," said one western economist who monitors reform here. "Corruption is an ethic. An economic program does not and cannot change a social malaise." What reform has wrought here in this vast, resource-rich country is a mixed bag. Western governments have agreed not to tempt Zairian officials with more kickback-generating big projects, such as hydroelectric dams or office centers, which the country does not need and cannot afford. And yet, according to a well-informed western diplomat, a public hospital in Kinshasa was completed this year at 200 percent of cost -- 100 percent to build the hospital, 100 percent for payoffs to government officials. The government has ordered that farmers be paid prices that are high enough to motivate them to grow food. Where the prices have been paid, there has been an impressive increase in food production. And yet many middlemen across rural Zaire refuse to cut their exorbitant profits and do not pay fair-market prices to farmers. Consequently, those farmers refuse to grow more food than they need for their families. Zaire remains a food importer in spite of its enormous agricultural potential. The new minister in charge of economic policy is a brilliant, hard-working and honest technocrat who western diplomats agree is the best-qualified Zairian ever to hold such power. And yet the country's authoritarian president, Mobutu Sese Seko, recently saw fit to dispatch a government-owned DC8 airliner to Venezuela 32 times to pick up 5,000 sheep for his private farm. In the halls of the United Nations in New York and in a number of western capitals there has been a lot of sympathetic rhetoric this year about the intractable economic problems of poor African countries such as Zaire. A recent report on Africa's economic crisis appealed to western governments to help the African countries that have "courageously" implemented reform programs. The report said that even as these countries have tried to correct past mistakes and rebuild their economies, they have suffered "a calamitous decline." They have been hit, the report said, with a double whammy of unpayable debts and falling commodity prices, which have dropped to their lowest levels in 30 years. Zaire exemplifies this bad luck. The government says that in the past four years it has paid $ 2 billion in interest on its $ 6 billion foreign debt. This is a quarter of its export earnings over that period and half of the government's budget. Debt payments devoured most of Zaire's new loans from the IMF and the World Bank. In the process, Zaire, which the World Bank lists as the ninth-poorest country in the world, became a net exporter of hard currency. While this was going on, the price of the country's main export, copper, collapsed. Consumer prices rose and life for the common man in Zaire, always miserable, became more so. The country was "risking a social explosion," according to a senior Zairian official. This was not what the U.S. government and other sympathetic donors had in mind when they pressed structural reform on Zaire. Accordingly, this past spring the country was given a debt reprieve. The Paris Club, a group of western creditor governments, granted Zaire six years' grace on its bilateral debts and extended payment periods for up to 15 years. The agreement was, according to an official in Zaire's Ministry of Finance, "without precedent. No country in Africa had been treated as generously before." Since the spring, the World Bank has promised Zaire $ 165 million in loans to support imports. The IMF has come up with another $ 142 million loan, half of which does not have to be repaid for 10 years. Zaire's bad economic fortune and its four years as a quasi-faithful student of structural reform were important factors in its receiving this money. But there was something else involved. This government has friends in Washington. "Our main interest is making sure that this big country, as big as all of Europe, does not fall to pieces, endangering the stability of all of central and southern Africa," said one senior western diplomat here. The United States, which has had a long and secretive relationship with Mobutu's government, is first among those western countries that have kept Zaire from falling to pieces. Last spring, a senior IMF official in Washington reportedly resigned in protest because the U.S. government was pressing the fund to ease lending conditions for Zaire. Sources here say the U.S. government was also a major force in the Paris Club's decision in May to reschedule Zaire's debts. U.S. foreign aid to Zaire is now about $ 60 million a year, the second-highest figure in sub-Saharan Africa. The quid pro quo for American largess goes far beyond Zaire's efforts at free-market reform. It is tied to the country's western orientation and its strategic position in southern Africa. Zaire is the largest, most consistent ally of the United States in the region. The American Embassy in Kinshasa is one of the largest on the continent. U.S. military forces regularly conduct maneuvers in Zaire. According to diplomats here and officials in Washington, Mobutu's government has allowed the Central Intelligence Agency to use the southern Zairian air base of Kamina to airlift arms to rebels fighting the Marxist government in Angola. Representatives of the rebel Union for the Total Liberation of Angola (UNITA) have a secret but semiofficial status at Kinshasa's international airport. A witness saw them meet a commercial airliner there last month and usher foreign journalists around customs and immigration officials. They took the reporters to a private aircraft at the airport and flew them to the war zone in southern Angola. Mobutu has categorically denied any role by Zaire in helping to supply or support the South African- and U.S.-backed UNITA rebels. When asked what the UNITA people were doing at Kinshasa's airport, Zaire's minister of information, Mandungu Bula Nyati, insisted that they were not there. "It is not possible. It cannot be possible," he said. Thomas M. Callaghy, an assistant professor of political science at Columbia University, is one of a number of specialists on Zaire who take the cynical view. He argues that the Mobutu government has adroitly used U.S. strategic interests in southern Africa to keep open the spigots of western money. At the same time, he says, it blocks substantive reforms that would cut into corrupt practices among Mobutu's inner circle of ministers. Shortly after the IMF and World Bank returned to Zaire for another try at economic reform, Callaghy wrote: "There is little in the history of Zaire's economy . . . that would lead most observers to conclude that Mobutu is seriously undertaking substantial economic reforms. Indeed, the corruption and mismanagement which have been associated with Mobutu and his ruling elite are the very elements which keep them in power." Economists and diplomats here who have watched the reform process firsthand in recent years say that Callaghy's bleak view is now only half right. One economist acknowledges that "everything we try to do stops when it cuts too close to the bone" -- meaning Mobutu, his family and his senior ministers. Another says "the solution for getting the most out of your money is not to come here at all." But there is a consensus among western officials directing assistance programs in Zaire that some of the broadest avenues for graft have been closed. As one diplomat said, "Leakage in the system has gone down significantly since 1983. Reform has weeded out those who are there only to steal money." The biggest leak for years was in the revenues of Gecamines, the state mining corporation. In the past, millions of dollars in copper and cobalt revenue disappeared without a trace. Now those revenues are accounted for in a procedure supervised by the World Bank. Besides plugging leaks in the "kleptocratic" system, many western donors are trying to steer clear of the system. They target small-scale aid directly at rural areas, where 70 percent of Zaire's 35 million people live. Most of the money is spent to solve the country's most acute problem, transport. "This whole system puts limits on how far reform can go," said a western diplomat. "You work with what you got."

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (96%); AFRICA (95%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Through a car window, a Lagos ''go slow,'' or traffic jam, offers a snapshot of the diminished fortunes of Nigeria, the giant of black Africa. Five years ago, freeways here were clogged with cars bought during an oil boom. Today, traffic clogs behind cars that break down because owners cannot afford spare parts. Traffic also slows when the police set up checkpoints to look for armed robbers. Increasingly, newspapers say, these bandits come from the newly poor middle class. Some Peddle Their Wares Outside the car window, a ''go slow'' victim invariably encounters nimble young men peddling their wares to a captive market. Recent offerings ranged from videocassette tapes to bikini underwear. These are the hallmarks of Nigeria today - entrepreneurial hustle amid economic depression, a fraying social fabric amid a liberalizing political climate. With a gross national product larger than that of South Africa and a population that accounts for one in four black Africans, Nigeria has always played out African trends on a grand scale. As newly independent African countries suffered from instability, this West African nation was one of the shakiest, enduring six coups and three presidential assassinations since independence in 1960. As tribal pressures strained Africa's new nations, Nigeria was torn by the continent's most violent tribal conflict - the Biafra War of 1967 to 1970, in which about a million people died. As development became the new religion, Nigeria put its faith in oil, earning $100 billion in a decade. But oil prices crashed, and Nigeria found itself with a $21 billion foreign debt, an urban population dependent on foreign imports and a rural population that could no longer feed the nation. #2 Courses of Action ''The party was over,'' Remi Ilori, a Nigerian newspaper columnist, wrote recently. ''We awakened to the reality that we had spent colossal sums of money feasting. The tables had to be cleared - so many plates of unfinished food, so many empty bottles of beer.'' Nigeria has embarked on two courses that, once again, are being watched with interest across Africa. Both involve controlled liberalization - one in politics, the other in economics. On the political front, the President, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who was wounded in the Biafra War, announced plans last summer for a phased return to civilian rule by 1992. Determined to create ''a new political generation,'' the gregarious army general moved in September to ban virtually all former politicians from running for office. ''The basic idea is that Nigeria starts with a clean slate,'' said Ray Ekpu, the editor in chief of Newswatch, an independent weekly. The blanket ban met with little outcry from Nigerians. Widespread corruption marred two earlier experiences with civilian rule. A voter registration campaign in recent weeks met with so little interest that state governments threatened to withhold the salaries of civil servants who did not register. ''People still nurse the fear that politicians with their sugar-coated tongues will soon abandon them once voted into power,'' Jimoh Ojedele, a civil servant from Ibadan, said of the low turnout. The next events on the President's political calendar are local elections, which are to be held Dec. 12 on a non-party basis. These elections are to be followed by a constitutional convention, the formation of two political parties, state elections, a national census and a presidential election in 1992. ''It's going to be a rough five years for Babangida to get through,'' a senior Western diplomat here said. Some Nigerians, like Ola Balogun, a film maker, believe that Western-style democracy will not take root in an African society like Nigeria's. ''You are going to have the shadow, but not the substance,'' said Mr. Balogun, who resigned last spring from a board advising the President on Nigeria's political future. ''I think we have to fail a third time before we try something really different.'' Instead of Western-style political parties, Mr. Balogun suggested forming a parliament composed of representatives of groups that traditionally commanded respect in Africa - clans and professional guilds. Just How Many People Live in the Country? A major obstacle to creating a Western-style democracy here is expected to be the carrying out of a national census. Most estimates put the population at 105 million, but no one knows for sure. The last accepted census was in 1963. Two others were canceled because of charges of fraud. Counting heads bears directly on what may become the explosive issue in Nigeria in the late 1980's - religion. Although no one knows whether Nigeria has more Moslems or Christians, most heads of state since independence have been Moslem northerners. But recently, growing Islamic fundamentalism has strained Nigerian religious tolerance. Fundamentalist leaders have called for making Nigeria an Islamic state and for imposing sharia, or Islamic law, throughout the land. Last March, religious animosity boiled over in the north. Three mosques were desecrated and about 100 churches were burned. Stung by the destruction, Christian leaders are raising money to rebuild. ''The Christians are not going to pull out from the north,'' Anthony Olubunmi Okogie, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Lagos, vowed in an interview. ''If one hair of a Christian is plucked out, we will pluck out a Moslem hair. If care is not taken, there will be an eruption.'' Religious polarization, Nigerian commentators warn, could lead to a two-party system where one party represents the Moslem north and the other the Christian south. With the collapse of Nigeria's oil boom, the fundamentalists are believed to have increased their appeal. In early November, President Babangida threatened to silence radical religious leaders, warning, ''Religious bigotry and zealotism have not helped to provide answers to the failures of the past.'' The Facts of Life In Dollars and Cents The fate of General Babangida's political program is inextricably linked to the performance of his economic program. When he took power in a coup two years ago, Nigeria was, in the words of a recent Finance Ministry report, ''on the verge of external bankruptcy.'' Its credit sources had dried up. With the United States traditionally the largest buyer, oil has accounted for 95 percent of Nigeria's exports. But because of dropping energy prices, oil revenues fell from $25 billion in 1980 to $5.6 billion in 1986. At the same time, a million new people joined the labor pool each year. Many Nigerians and Westerners agreed that radical surgery was needed, but nationalist sentiment precluded turning to the International Monetary Fund. Instead, the Government ostentatiously rejected an I.M.F. loan, and then adopted a ''structural adjustment program'' that was far more radical that what the fund would probably have imposed. Fixed exchange rates were abolished and the value of the national currency, the naira, was allowed to float. It dropped from even parity with the dollar to the current rate of well over four to the dollar. Commodity marketing boards were abolished, allowing producer prices to rise. Production of cocoa, cotton and palm oil rebounded. ''The program is an impressive success,'' a European banker here said. As the devaluation suddenly put a true price on imported goods, middle-class Nigerians found that they could no longer afford foreign cars, shopping trips to London and university education in the United States. The next round of austerity is expected to cut deeper. Prices of gasoline, electricity, telephone service, rail travel and mail are to increase soon as Government subsidies are withdrawn. Few Nigerians deny that the present prices are low. A Nigerian pays 65 cents a minute to call London. A Briton pays $1.60 a minute to return the call. At 32 cents a gallon, gasoline here is one-tenth the price of gas in neighboring Chad. Indeed, gas stations near Nigeria's borders routinely sell three times as much as interior stations, oil industry officials say. With the cheapest jet fuel on the west coast of Africa, foreign jetliners never leave Lagos without filling up. Many Nigerians argue that bad service justifies keeping prices low. ''Lagos is roaring again,'' residents say, alluding to the noisy backyard generators that well-to-do residents fire up to cope with daily power cuts. The state power company is generating only 40 percent of capacity. Telephone service is among the worst in West Africa. Of 240,000 lines in this city of five million, 150,000 are working. Businessmen routinely resort to sending telexes or messengers to communicate across town. Although the World Bank plans to provide almost $1 billion in coming years to rehabilitate Nigerian telephone, power and water systems, the coming rate increases have prompted angry debates in the Nigeria's newspapers, among the liveliest in Africa. ''Nigeria's public utilities have a history of mind-boggling waste and inefficiency, overmanning and a corrupt bureaucracy,'' said an editorial in one daily, The Nigerian Tribune. ''In 27 years of independence, this country cannot boast reliable telephones, regular power supply, piped water.'' From the other side, another newspaper, Daily Sketch, inveighed: ''Our Structural Adjustment Program was dreamed up by foreign-based and -dominated financial institutions. Not a few Nigerians believe it is a ghastly nightmare.'' A Poor Climate For Foreign Investors A third part of the economic liberalization - foreign investment outside the oil sector - has yet to materialize. ''Unfortunately, no significant private investment, Nigerian or foreign, is yet in sight,'' Richard L. Kramer, the local director of Arthur Andersen & Company, said at a recent symposium in Lagos. ''The present Government inherited a negative foreign investment climate, which caused almost total lack of foreign investment during the entire past decade.'' According to the World Bank, Africa has the lowest rate of foreign investment of any area in the world. With its huge internal market, Nigeria should be magnet for foreign investment. But businessmen complain of a climate that scares away investors: a 50 percent limit on repatriation of profits, requirements of up to 80 percent Nigerian participation, a hostile and slow-moving bureaucracy, and poor utility service. ''You can talk to top Nigerian officials today who still think that Nigeria is an attractive place. They have no idea what it takes to bring in foreign investment,'' said an American businessman with several years' experience here. ''They have a center-of-the-universe mentality, but 100 million poor people is not a great market.'' Kalu I. Kalu, Nigeria's American-trained Planning Minister, said in an interview that the Government intended ''to create a climate conducive to foreign investment.'' But he added, ''There is always that scare: If we open up, we are going to be dominated by foreign capital.'' A 'Jerusalem' For Diaspora Blacks As Nigeria seeks to pull out of six years of unbroken economic decline, Nigerians are trying to resolve a basic psychological conflict - between the need to mesh smoothly with the rest of the world and their pride as the home to one out of five blacks in the world. Playing to Nigerians' self-image as the world's future black superpower, Bolaji Akinyemi, Nigeria's Foreign Minister, urged his countrymen earlier this year to develop a ''black bomb.'' ''Nigeria has a sacred responsibility to challenge the racial monopoly of nuclear weapons,'' he said. Since then, talk of developing a nuclear weapon has died down. Mr. Akinyemi recently relaxed in his official residence and outlined his view of Nigeria in the world. ''Some of us dream of Nigeria being to blacks in the diaspora what Jerusalem is to Jews in the diaspora,'' he said. He noted that Nigerian ambassadors - often the only representatives of black Africa in many world capitals -are instructed to reserve a third of their guest lists to ''blacks in the diaspora.'' ''We are acutely aware that if we make it in this country, it will shine on the image of the international black community,'' he said. ''If we fail, we will have dented very badly the image of the international black community.''

COUNTRY: AFRICA (97%); BOTSWANA (94%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (92%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); LIBERIA (79%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: On a continent where dictators who call themselves democrats routinely rig elections and jail their opponents, the following event actually took place: Kenneth Koma, leader of the Botswana opposition party, took the floor of the National Assembly to argue that the government's new budget was short-sighted and elitist. He spoke bluntly, barbed his words with sarcasm, pulled no punches. When he finished, there was none of the usual African shakedown. No one threatened, arrested or tortured Koma. He was not exiled to his home village, nor was he forced to flee the country. Government toadies did not question his patriotism or suggest he was serving "foreign masters." He was not harassed, ticketed or forced to pay bribes. His party was not banned. His remarks were even reported in local newspapers. The most punishing blow was struck when the minister of finance suggested that Koma should be more specific. Can this be Africa? Considering the 30-year devolution of democracy across much of this continent, something extraordinary has taken root in this desert nation in southern Africa. A multi-party democracy has been built here on the traditional values of a non-violent, moderate people who believe in speaking their piece. "We have always tolerated dissent. It is something ingrained in our culture," said Botswana President Quett Masire in an interview. Political scientists who study modern Africa regard this government as honest, humane and responsive. To appreciate the oddity of an honest African government without civil strife that prides itself on tolerating dissent, one needs to look around at contemporary standards of democracy in sub-Saharan Africa. At last count, 38 of the 45 countries of the region were one-party or no-party states. The political norm is near-absolute power in the hands of someone who was never elected. Leadership usually changes when military coups kill or chase the big men out of the country. The Freedom House, a New York-based research organization, says Africa, along with the Middle East, has less democracy than anywhere else in the world. African states make frequent unflattering appearances in Amnesty International's annual list of governments that torture political enemies. Civil war, corruption and famine are endemic. By any measure, sub-Saharan Africa is the poorest region in the world. The most significant economic fact on the continent is that most countries that are marking their first quarter-century of self government have become poorer -- on a per-capita basis -- than they were at independence. Democracy's bleak record is easily seen by taking a look around at recent African elections: In Liberia, President Samuel K. Doe held an election in late 1985, lost it badly and then had the offending ballots burned. He later jailed his opponents. In Zaire, President Mobutu Sese Seko presides over uncontested elections in which he wins 99 percent of the vote. To insure power, Mobutu shuffles his ministers every few months -- between cabinet offices, exile and jail. To buy off challengers, Mobutu allows his ministers to pilfer government money. In Kenya, the secret ballot in primary elections was replaced last February with public queuing for candidates. Many voters were intimidated and scared off. As a result, several articulate government critics were squeezed out of parliament. No one dares run against President Daniel arap Moi. In Senegal, the reelection of President Abdou Diouf last March was followed by charges of fraud, riots and the arrest of the main opposition candidate. Sudan held a relatively fair and open election in 1986 but the results were rendered moot because half the country was cut off by civil war. The war continues and the country is still sawed in two by ethnic and religious hatred. "Free-dom," was the rallying cry of Kwame Nkrumah, the school teacher cum liberator whose idealism and fiery rhetoric transformed the British colony of the Gold Coast into independent Ghana. For Africans under colonialism, most of whom had no property, money or position, Nkrumah's cry was a magical incantation, a call to war, a one-note song of salvation. Its justness was undeniable, its momentum all but inexorable. "The wind of change is blowing through this continent," said British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan in 1959, "and whether we like it or not, this growth of national consciousness is a political fact." By the late 1950s and early 1960s, most of the colonies of sub-Saharan Africa had become independent states. They rushed headlong into independence, following Nkrumah's dictum: "Seek ye first the political kingdom and all else will follow." Nearly 30 years later, it is painfully clear that "all else" -- democracy, honest government, prosperity, free speech -- does not follow. But independent Africa is still very young. Its institutions are changing and its people are racing to catch up with the developed world. Many political scientists see Africa as a unique laboratory for sorting out the economic and social factors that either foster or strangle democracy. "Democracy in Africa is an experimental process in a new generation of countries," said political scientist Richard Sklar in a speech to the African Studies Association. "We should study this process not only to learn about Africa, but also to refresh our knowledge about the meaning of democracy itself." If the governor of the state of Iowa were to become a greedy dictator, jailing his critics without trial, helping himself to the state treasury, demanding that Iowans hang his picture in all public places and worship him as an infallible demigod, it is likely he would attract attention from specialists in the study of state government. By the same logic, Botswana, an island of democracy in a sea of dictatorship, intrigues specialists in African politics. This coming August an international conference will be held in Gaborone. It will conclude a "Democracy Project" that has been analyzing why a tolerant, responsive government has developed here. That research, along with the findings of political scientists who have worked across Africa, suggests three major factors that underlie the success of democracy here. The first is money. For a Texas-sized country with only one million people, Botswana has lots of money. Along with South Africa and the Soviet Union, it has the largest reserves of diamonds in the world. Its high-quality diamonds in the past decade have catapulted it from being one of Africa's poorest countries to one of its richest. According to government figures, per-capita income has increased more than five times in the past 10 years -- from $ 290 to $ 1,680 a year. Annual economic growth has averaged 12 percent. By African standards, these figures are astonishing. In the rest of the sub-Saharan region in that time, the average standard of living has fallen, according to the World Bank. Most Africans have become poorer. "Liberal democracy founders in a rising tide of tears and social disrepair," notes Africanist Richard Sklar. "People will not settle for redistribution of misery and poverty. Everything depends upon the timely creation of wealth and wealth-producing assets . . . ." Botswana's money has allowed generous spending on programs that benefit the mass of the population. Close to half of government spending goes to development. Access to schools and health clinics has become a given, even in remote rural areas. During the severe seven-year drought that just ended, a government-financed relief project prevented any starvation and allowed only a slight increase in malnutrition. According to John Holm, a political scientist from Cleveland State University and the director of the Democracy Project here, what is particularly impressive about the government's use of its money is its concern for "social justice." Holm and several political leaders here note that Botswana is able to funnel its diamond money to the masses because of strong cultural links between government and society. In contrast, in Zaire, where African scholars refer to "the government as predator," those links do not exist and billions of dollars in copper earnings have been funneled to private Swiss bank accounts. The second major factor that makes democracy work here is that the 22-year-old national government and the centuries-old Tswana tribal system have a lot in common. "Traditional Tswana values of public discussion, community consensus, nonviolence and moderation are critical elements of a democratic political culture," says Holm. Quett Masire, the country's president, explains that "Batswana are used to their type of democracy where every man is given an opportunity to have his say. It doesn't matter who he is, he can opine. At the end of the day, what seems sensible, no matter who said it, is taken as the resolution of the debate." Nearly every village in Botswana has a local laboratory for democracy. Called the kgotla, it is a community meeting held in front of the chief's house. By tradition, chiefs did not make major decisions without listening to villagers at the kgotla and, if possible, finding a consensus. Holm says that the ruling Botswana Democratic Party "has, if anything, amplified on this tradition in that government officials -- both civil servants and politicians -- discuss all new policies with the local community before any local implementation. They also seek to get a consensus behind their proposals. If one does not emerge, the program is likely to be reformulated or sometimes terminated." Members of the National Assembly, who elect the country's president, travel thousands of miles a year attending kgotlas in their districts and listening to local grievances. Parliamentarians who don't travel, don't get re-elected, according to Holm. Smoothing the way for all this democracy is ethnic, linguistic and cultural homogeneity among the nine Tswana tribes. This is a luxury enjoyed by few African countries, many of whose boundaries have roped together mutually antagonistic tribes with differing languages and religions. The final factor that keeps democracy working in Botswana, according to Holm and local politicians, is honesty: It's government leaders have not stolen the store. "For this system to work, the head of the government must behave in a way that earns respect. He must not do things that are shameful," says opposition leader Kenneth Koma, the man who is not and does not expect to be harassed when he criticizes the government. "For the last 20 years, they -- the leaders -- have been behaving in a way that is worthy." For all its democratic traditions, Botswana's class structure remains one of the most elitist in Africa. The people who run the government, the president and nearly every senior official, are wealthy cattle owners. Wealth in the country is distributed extremely unevenly. More than half the country's cattle -- the most important social measure of wealth -- are held by 5 percent of the population. Opinion surveys in Botswana for the Democracy Project have found that voters are exceptionally conservative and that they are made nervous by too much political conflict. About 40 percent of rural voters say they would prefer to return to the old chieftain system in which a chief, in the words of one African scholar, is "at once ruler, judge, maker and guardian of the law . . . ." According to Holm, modern democracy in Botswana, as led by a wealthy and paternalistic group of cattle owners, somehow has meshed with these conservative yearnings. "The new political elite has taken over the traditional kgotla from the chiefs and allowed citizens to use it to voice local concerns," Holm says. Holm says what holds the hybrid system together is respect for the rule of law. As opposition leader Koma concedes, officials with power do not abuse it. "This is one of the most law-abiding places in world," says Holm. "If you are driving with a car full of Batswana and you make an illegal U-turn, everyone gets very quiet. They feel guilty for you." Blaine Harden covers Africa for The Washington Post.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (96%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: A drop of sweat slipped onto his brow, perhaps from the heat, perhaps from nervousness, as Nakambo explained how lucky he was to find a job as a private school teacher that pays $10 a week. ''If I were still teaching at a public school, I would be earning just three dollars a week,'' he said, leaning forward in an ocher-colored armchair in his small cinder-block house in the Cite district of Kinshasa, the capital. Ten dollars a week pays for no more than his rent and the two staples in his family's diet: corn and cassava. Yet Nakambo seems better off than most of the 35 million people in this huge Central African nation. At least he can sometimes purchase extras with whatever he earns teaching French to the children of diplomats. With Africa's largest expanse of forest, 13 percent of the world's hydroelectric capacity and huge mineral deposits, Zaire has immense potential. It also has a reputation as one of the world's most egregious examples of economic mismanagement. Formerly the Belgian Congo, Zaire was self-sufficient agriculturally when it became independent in 1960. It now imports over one-fourth its food. Per capita income in Zaire, which is the size of the United States east of the Mississippi, is just $180 a year, 10 percent of the 1960 level and the eighth lowest in the world. In parts of Kinshasa, the infant mortality rate is 20 percent. More than one-third of the nation's children die before the age of five. Economists, diplomats and Western businessmen ascribe these woes to a long list of factors: rampant corruption in the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko, estimated by the State Department to be worth $5 billion himself; a failure to maintain roads and basic services; extravagant spending on grandiose projects; wide-scale capital flight by the nation's rich, and such external factors as low commodity prices and high interest rates. While President Mobutu, who seized power in 1965, gets high marks for having woven together a nation out of 200 often-feuding tribes, his economic leadership receives far lower grades. According to the World Bank, Zaire's per capita income fell by 3.9 percent a year from 1973 to 1985. Only war-torn Nicaragua did worse. A Society Mismanaged, Repressed and Corrupted ''The political repression is nothing compared with the economic incompetence,'' one Western business executive said. But many economists and Western diplomats note that because Zaire is a repressive, one-party state, Government leaders from the President on down have felt little pressure to improve the situation. Indeed, they enrich themselves from it. Some academic studies have found that only 40 percent of Government funds go to the projects for which they are targeted. Some business executives say 10 percent is a better estimate, with Government officials pocketing the rest. Corruption is so endemic that postal workers often refuse to deliver mail unless they receive a monthly bribe, while phone company employees have been known to disconnect customers' phones unless they receive their ''metabeesh.'' Zairian generals frequently keep their subordinates' pay, and as a result some soldiers shake down private citizens to avoid going hungry. Relatives of Government officials are said to be heavily involved in diamond and ivory smuggling. ''The corruption pattern starts at the very summit of the system,'' said Crawford Young, a University of Wisconsin professor and co-author of ''The Rise and Decline of the Zairian State.'' ''The extent of Zaire's corruption may not be unique, but it is a leading practitioner of the art.'' President Mobutu, whose father was a cook and whose mother was a hotel maid, has 11 homes in Zaire and reportedly owns a 16th-century castle in Spain, a 32-room palace in Switzerland, luxurious residences in Paris and on the French Riviera, and lavish homes in Belgium and the Ivory Coast. He often sends military planes to South Africa to pick up exotic plants and to South America to pick up sheep for his palace in Gbadolite, which has been dubbed ''Versailles in the jungle.'' When confronted with accusations of corruption, the 57-year-old Mr. Mobutu says he is a victim of disinformation and adds that the United States and other countries have corruption, too. ''Everyone is sitting here watching this country deteriorate rapidly,'' said one Western diplomat. ''The thing that needs to be pressed is corruption; but if you press too hard, then you start to destabilize things, and the Big Man doesn't want that.'' Mr. Mobutu has repeatedly blamed civil strife and such external factors as weak commodity prices for the the country's falling standard of living. Declining copper and coffee prices did, in fact, take a serious toll. So did the high interest rates of recent years, which significantly increased Zaire's payments on its now $7 billion foreign debt. Pain Without Gain: A Fling With the I.M.F. The economic situation and debt burden grew so serious that Zaire rescheduled its debt numerous times and repeatedly invited the International Monetary Fund to help manage its economy. In 1983, working with the I.M.F., Zaire slashed its budget deficit, brought down its inflation rate to 20 percent from 100 percent and devalued its currency. Zaire won praise for trying to put its economic house in order. But the measures could not bring instant success. Although price controls on farm goods were lifted to encourage production, for example, a lack of passable roads to ship their goods to market made it unwise for many farmers to plant larger crops. Other measures exacted a heavy toll. The Government laid off 40,000 teachers, slashing education spending to 8 percent of the budget from 24 percent. Wage increases for civil servants trailed far behind inflation, pushing them to seek bribes. ''There are the very rich and the very poor, and austerity plans certainly make things worse for the poor,'' said one banker. In late 1986, Zaire renounced its austerity program, asserting that the $500 million it repaid each year was too painful and was causing a net outflow of funds. Within months, the budget deficit skyrocketed and inflation was back to 100 percent. This decimated purchasing power: the currency, called the zaire, traded at 16 cents in 1983 but is worth a little more than half a cent today. The nation's rich deposited their money in European banks to prevent the emaciation of their holdings. As a result, domestic investment plummeted. Foreign investors were frightened off by inflation and the fact that they pay too high a share of taxes because Zairian businesses often bribe their way out of paying. After coming under heavy criticism from the West, Zaire agreed again last spring to follow an I.M.F. program, but only after winning more favorable repayment terms. Zairian officials and executives complain, however, that since they are plagued by low commodity prices their nation cannot regain economic momentum without substantial debt forgiveness. Today, whatever optimism economists and diplomats felt in 1985 has given way to a deep pessimism that it will take years before Zaire can creep meaningfully forward. There is one bright spot, in the view of many diplomats and foreign bankers: President Mobutu has named a respected economist, Sambwa Pida Mbagui, former head of the Bank of Zaire, to be Prime Minister. Many diplomats say President Mobutu, who often changes prime ministers every six months, has never had a man of such ability as prime minister. Nevertheless, one Western businessman, echoing the views of many others, said: ''If Sambwa really institutes reforms, he will step on so many toes that the high-level jackals will tear out his hide and he'll go down, too.'' An Economy Shorn Of Expertise Many of Zaire's economic woes began in 1973 when Mr. Mobutu launched ''Zairianization,'' under which European-owned businesses were seized and given to Zairians for token compensation. Many of the businesses went to the President's family and cronies, and within two years, Zaire's economy had shrunk by 15 percent. The new owners often had no idea how to manage their holdings. When President Mobutu was forced in 1975 to invite the Europeans back to run the businesses, there was often not much left to run. Another major cause of Zaire's debt burden was President Mobutu's ''edifice complex.'' In downtown Kinshasa, he built a steel-and-glass skyscraper, dubbed the World Trade Center, much of which remains empty. He ordered construction of the $250 million Maluku steel mill, even though Zaire has little iron ore. The mill closed soon after it opened when Zairian officials discovered that they could import steel for half the cost of producing it. The biggest project was a power line running 1,000 miles from the Inga Dam east to the vital Shaba region, whose copper and cobalt produce 60 percent of Zaire's export earnings. The power project was supposed to cost $200 million, but its final price tag, inflated by graft, approached $1 billion. The line was built even though many advisers said it would have cost less than $70 million to erect a new dam in Shaba, but Mr. Mobutu wanted the line so he could cut off all power to often-rebellious Shaba, once called Katanga, if it were to cause trouble again. ''The main obstacle to development is the state,'' said one Zairian political scientist. ''As long as we don't have democracy, we can't control investment projects like the Inga-Shaba line because there is no one to stop the Government from doing foolish things.'' Development experts say Zaire would have been far wiser to spend money to maintain the roads and promote agriculture. In that way it might have been able to remain self-sufficient in food and to reduce its heavy dependence on mining. Road maintenance has been so abysmal that the 1,100-mile drive from Zaire's Atlantic coast to its eastern border, which once took two days, now takes three weeks and is often impossible during the rainy season. ''Transportation is a very, very difficult problem,'' said Dennis Chandler, director of the United States Agency for International Development office in Zaire. ''There's not a whole lot of priority put on maintenance, and that's a weak link in a country this size.'' Sugar-Free Existence: The 'I-Get-By' Life When the teacher Nakambo was asked how he could pay for electricity and clothes, he responded: ''Je me debrouille.'' Probably the most popular phrase in French-speaking Zaire, it means, ''I get by, I manage, I improvise.'' In this nation of debrouillards, getting by means forgoing any number of niceties. If Nakambo could afford it, he would pay the 12 cents to take a bus to work, but instead he walks the four miles each way. Before the latest spurt in inflation, breakfast consisted of bread and sugared tea. ''Sugar we no longer buy. It's too much of a luxury,'' said Nakambo, who did not want his full name disclosed. His house differs little from tens of thousands of others in Kinshasa's endless Cite district: some thrown-together cinder block walls, a sheet of corrugated metal above, a few plaster partitions within. They create a dark, modest living space cluttered with a 20-year-old refrigerator, an old sewing machine, several chairs and a sofa. The eight-by-ten-foot windowless kitchen doubles as a bedroom for his five children. Nakambo's wife, Malaika, occasionally uses the sewing machine to make children's dolls in richly-colored African wraps, which she tries to sell to foreigners. She also used to sell ices to schoolchildren, putting sugared water into long, thin plastic sacks and freezing them. But she can no longer afford sugar and the refrigerator needs a new motor, which she says would cost about $100. While his family scrapes by, Nakambo's biggest fear is of serious illness. A few months ago, a cousin had to have her appendix removed. The operation and hospital stay cost $100, equal to three months' income for many Kinshasans. ''You have to pay off the guard just to be allowed into the hospital,'' Nakambo said. ''Then you have to pay off the nurses to make sure you're looked after. They have to survive too.''

COUNTRY: SUDAN (96%); UNITED STATES (94%); AFRICA (94%); ETHIOPIA (93%); AFGHANISTAN (79%); SOMALIA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%); ANGOLA (79%);
TEXT: As if civil war, a $12 billion debt, locusts and drought were not enough, the Sudan now finds its capital inundated by an overflowing Nile. In just two days this month, six times as much rain fell on Khartoum as in all of 1987. One and a half million Sudanese are now without shelter, food or clean water. A shaky Government, overwhelmed even by normal administrative tasks, has little hope of coping with this calamity. The fortunes of Africa's largest nation once seemed far brighter. In the 1970's, oil-rich Arab neighbors wanted to turn this bridge between black Africa and the Arab world into a breadbasket. As with other grand schemes in the Sudan, this one gave way to corruption, mismanagement and relentless ethnic strife. Nothing speaks more poignantly of the distance the Sudan has traveled from such high hopes than the fact that 300,000 Sudanese now seek refuge in the nation Westerners have come to identify with human misery - Ethiopia. No one factor caused the Sudan's many ills; no outsider can cure them. But one piece of the tragedy makes it especially hard to handle all the others: civil strife. War between a Moslem north and a mostly Christian and animist south takes $2 million a day from resources badly needed elsewhere. This pattern of civil strife and natural disaster recurs throughout the Horn of Africa. Ethiopia's civil wars have raged for 27 years. In Somalia, strife that re-ignited in May killed 10,000 in a month and sent 300,000 also streaming into Ethiopia. Internal differences create these conflicts; but all sides have their foreign backers, and superpower rivalries heighten the polarization. The U.S. and the Soviet Union are now encouraging belligerents in Afghanistan, Cambodia and Angola toward mediation and national reconciliation. That same message might help in the war-devastated Horn. Of course such talk is of no immediate use to the hungry. The Sudan's plight has deepened so quickly that most Americans are barely aware of it; emergency aid for flood victims is needed desperately. Additionally, this latest disaster might at last spur Washington toward an adequate commitment to sustainable development in Africa. A first step might be to honor overdue commitments to multilateral agencies like the World Bank that have already proven to be effective conduits for aid. As calamities recur in Africa, so does this refrain: The long-term solution is to help Africans become economically self-sufficient. With international cooperation spreading across the globe, it is possible to entertain fresh hope. Meanwhile, humanitarian relief is needed, and urgently.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); KENYA (92%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Post reporter Blaine Harden, writing from Nairobi last Saturday, said that Africa must share the blame for its own poor economic performance. Harden's analysis refers to the "growing clamor over culpability in Africa's decline," and implies that the industrial nations should not be so ready to accept responsibility. He points out that government interference, inefficiency and corruption in Africa have discouraged foreign investors -- and reduced the very flow of resources the Africans claim is their due. Some of the clamor Harden refers to took place recently in New York, where the United Nations has been reviewing an international recovery effort designed to remedy the deteriorating economic situation in Africa. According to the Africans and the United Nations, things have gotten worse in the past two years, not better, because the industrial countries have failed to live up to their promises of more financial assistance to the African nations. The Africans maintain that they have performed on their side of the deal with the donor countries -- a deal made back in 1986 at a special session of the U.N. General Assembly -- by undertaking dangerous economic reforms. Conditions imposed by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank closed down inefficient government-run agricultural organizations and monopoly businesses and eliminated subsidies. Many Africans have lost their jobs as a result. Consumer prices have risen, especially in the politically volatile cities, where, in several countries, riots have broken out. Africans complain that the donor and creditor nations promised to find relief for Africa's foreign debt burden, but it continues to grow to the point where, in many cases, debt service payments exceed foreign assistance. And net resource flows from the industrial nations to Africa have actually declined since 1985, although they were slightly up last year. Thus, in spite of reform, Africa's per capita gross domestic product continues to fall. Part of the original 1986 understanding was that the Africans would not insist on bringing global debt relief plans and commodity pricing schemes into the recovery program, but would instead undertake reforms in return for a best-efforts promise by the industrial countries to increase foreign aid and deal effectively with debt on a case-by-case basis. Some Africans now want to go back to their demand for a global debt solution and a better deal on their commodity exports. In addition, many Africans want to do away with the strict conditions applied by the IMF and the World Bank, on the grounds that these donor-imposed economic reforms have unacceptable political consequences. Are the Africans right? Did we renege on our promises? Or are the Africans themselves as much to blame? The truth is that we did what we said we would do -- the best we could. It just hasn't been good enough. So, too, the Africans did what they said they would do -- engage in economic reform. It just hasn't worked as well as we all hoped it would. The fact is that we have slightly increased net resource flows to the continent, and a series of debt relief measures has been undertaken, ranging from the Baker plans, through the expanded lending by the Bank and the Fund to the proposals at the Toronto Summit. There is movement on the debt front, and the Africans should be pleased with the general direction, if not with the immediate results. Rhetoric aside, there does seem to be a building consensus on the kinds of next steps that both Africans and their industrial partners should take. Both agree that significantly more resources for economic growth must be liberated from the debt trap; after the U.S. election, progress might be made on this front. Both agree that concessional assistance should increase; the World Bank and Japan are the most likely sources. And no one will quarrel with the proposition that there is much the Africans themselves can do to improve the investment climate. More importantly, the beginnings of a consensus on conditionality and on the nature of economic reform seems to be in the making. Many believe that some of the economic reforms have tried to go too far too fast. We need to get back to basics in Africa -- more emphasis on fiscal integrity, mobilization of African resources for development, agricultural reform and -- to buffer political repercussions and address urgent social needs -- more spending on health, education and employment programs. These are the right directions. Let's stop blaming each other for less-than-perfect performance and get on with the economic recovery of Africa. The writer is a former deputy assistant secretary of state for African affairs.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (92%);
TEXT: The Kenyan government has banned an aggressive business magazine that for two years broke an unwritten rule of journalism in black Africa. The Financial Review did not play it safe. It published detailed articles about alleged corruption and mismanagement at high levels in the Kenyan government. The weekly, with a circulation of about 15,000, named officials allegedly involved in illegal or unethical business practices. It focused on what the magazine's 36-year-old owner and editor, Peter Kareithi, described as "very serious flaws in national economic management." The banning order comes at a delicate time for the international image of Kenya, a poor, debt-burdened East African country whose economy is dependent on tourism and international aid. In Washington, the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa is marking up legislation that conditions future U.S. aid to Kenya on State Department certification that human rights -- including freedom of the press -- are respected. Proposed aid for next year totals $ 70 million. Pending low-interest loans and grants from the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and Japan, totaling more than $ 380 million, are conditioned on Kenya's following through on promises for free-market economic reform. The reputation of this closest ally of the United States in East Africa has been impugned by well-documented reports of human rights abuses, including police torture of political dissidents. A prominent human rights lawyer, Gibson Kamau Kuria, who sued the government on behalf of torture victims, was detained for nine months and had his passport taken away. Last week, Rep. David Obey (D-Wis.), who chairs a House subcommittee on appropriations, vowed to cut off all aid to Kenya if Kuria was not given back his passport. In the Financial Review case, a minister of state for internal security, who works in the office of President Daniel arap Moi, released a document here Friday that said the magazine "is declared to be a prohibited publication." The document did not explain why. The banning order came three days after Attorney General Matthew Muli criticized the magazine for "carrying mischievous stories implying that the government has taken over and nationalized" the property of Kenya's wheat millers.
