Muli demanded an "unconditional" retraction and apology. Editor Kareithi said, "Much as we wish to comply with your request for apology," the facts of the government's actions against the milling companies gave him "difficulties" in knowing how to do so. The story focused on sweeping new regulations published April 10 in the official Kenya Gazette. The regulations empower the government-owned grain board to commandeer private grain storage facilities "at such times as the board may direct, and at such remuneration as the board may determine." The Financial Review quoted several outraged milling company executives. One asked: "What is the world coming to? How can a parastatal [government agency] which has never been known for its efficiency and which has been a constant source of misery to farmers be given such sweeping powers as to control the nerve center of the milling industry?" Governmental protests last week against the magazine article did not dispute its facts. The minister for supplies and marketing, William ole Ntimama, said the article was "written by people who have no interest of this country at heart." The assistant minister for national guidance and political affairs, Shariff Nassir, said, "Although there was press freedom in Kenya, editors should not be left to write whatever they wanted." Kareithi bought the review for $ 37,000 in 1986. In an interview, he said, "We must have known from the beginning what was going to happen, but we were encouraged by government statements about the responsible exercise of freedom of the press. We wanted to demonstrate that it was possible for a Kenyan-owned publication to take bold steps. We wanted to encourage other Kenyans." Kareithi was picked up by police in December and interrogated for a day about stories that displeased the government. The editor said he apologized and returned to work. "The past year has literally been a nightmare for me and my staff. When we sat to discuss a cover story, most of our discussions were not about how to get information, but rather how to report it objectively and honestly without getting in trouble," Kareithi said.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (96%); UNITED STATES (95%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (94%); KENYA (92%); BURUNDI (92%); SOMALIA (92%); SOUTH AFRICA (79%); MOZAMBIQUE (79%); PALESTINIAN TERRITORY, OCCUPIED (79%); LIBERIA (79%); ASIA (79%); SUDAN (79%); CENTRAL AMERICA (68%);
TEXT: THE issue of human rights was high on the agenda at meetings last week between President Bush and President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire. Mr. Mobutu rejects criticism of his rights record as interference, and he asserted last week that human rights conditions in his impoverished country had improved substantially. But members of Congress, led by Representative Ronald V. Dellums, the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, have not allowed Mr. Mobutu to brush aside the criticism. While Mr. Mobutu was in Washington, the House of Representatives passed a foreign aid bill that explicitly links assistance to respect for human rights in Zaire and six other African countries: Burundi, Kenya, Liberia, Mozambique, Somalia and the Sudan. The newly assertive mood regarding human rights in Africa is in no small measure a result of efforts by black members of Congress. Having denounced South African apartheid, many Congressmen say they want to hold Mr. Mobutu and other black African leaders to an equally strict standard of human rights. Members of the Congressional Black Caucus maintain that their human rights advocacy is particularly effective. 'The Same Standard' ''We feel African nations need to be held to the same standard of human rights as any other nations,'' said Representative Donald M. Payne of New Jersey, a member of the caucus. ''The U.S. often has not been strong enough in expressing concern when African leaders have infringed human rights.'' Holly J. Burkhalter, the Washington director of Human Rights Watch, a private group, said that black members of Congress had taken the lead in criticizing persecution in such countries as Zaire, Somalia, Burundi and Kenya. The legislators have not focused on Africa alone, she added. ''They have been active on human rights issues in Central America, Asia and the occupied territories'' of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, she said. Mr. Dellums has introduced a bill that would cut off Zaire's military aid, which totals $3 million this year. It would also funnel economic aid to Zaire through private organizations, church groups and international bodies like the World Health Organization. ''It does not benefit the United States to be identified with such a corrupt and repressive regime,'' the bill says. Mr. Dellums's conclusion that ''political rights are not respected'' in Zaire echoes the State Department's finding in February that arbitrary arrest and torture were common. Since then, the department said last week, Mr. Mobutu has ''taken a number of steps to correct abuses.'' But State Department reports on Zaire generally substantiate Mr. Dellums's concerns and were another reason that President Bush raised the issue with Mr. Mobutu. Three committees of the House of Representatives have held hearings on human rights in Africa this year. Walter E. Fauntroy, the delegate from the District of Columbia, convened one such hearing to investigate whether the United States should oppose World Bank loans to Somalia because of evidence of political killings and the torture of prisoners there. In addition, the foreign aid bill the House passed last week says that in deciding whether to provide assistance to Burundi, the President should consider whether it has reversed ''patterns of ethnic discrimination against the majority Hutu.'' Burundi has reported that at least 5,000 people were killed last year in clashes between the Hutu and members of the minority Tutsi tribe, which dominates the Government. A Reduction in Aid The bill would allow no more than $3 million in military assistance for Zaire in the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. The Bush Administration had requested $9 million, but the Foreign Affairs Committee cut the request in view of what it said were ''widely acknowledged gross human rights violations.'' The State Department cited ''recurring'' reports of torture and arbitrary arrest in Somalia, and it noted that ''public expression of dissenting views'' is not allowed. Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania, has led Congressional efforts to put economic pressure on Ethiopia to stop violating human rights. He has proposed sanctions, including a ban on imports of Ethiopian coffee and a halt to new American investment and loans there. Ms. Burkhalter of Human Rights Watch said that African leaders often seemed to pay more attention to black members of Congress than to white lawmakers or to human rights groups. The criticism, she said, ''cannot be dismissed as racism.''

COUNTRY: BENIN (96%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); AFRICA (92%); FRANCE (90%);
TEXT: This was to have been a week of celebration in this sliver of West Africa as workers removed the cover protecting a new bronze statue of Lenin. As it happened, President Mathieu Kerekou unexpectedly chose last week to proclaim that Marxism-Leninism would no longer be the state ideology. The statue was unveiled anyhow, but not with the solemnity that Government officials thought the occasion deserved. Within hours of the President's announcement, several hundred demonstrators, some armed with clubs and hammers, converged on Lenin Square, burned the drapes covering the statue and tried to tear it down. Marchers then snaked through this old French colonial city, chanting slogans calling for the President's resignation. Similar demonstrations were reportedly held by several thousand people in Porto Novo, the capital city, Abomey and Ouidah. Though badly scarred, the statue here stands. But remaining uncertain is the future of Mr. Kerekou's 17-year-old military-installed Government, which Western diplomats here say appears in danger of collapse. Calm With an Edge For now, the decision by the authorities to crack down by imposing a ban on all public demonstrations ''until further notice'' seems to have quelled visible dissent. But on nearly every major thoroughfare, men in brown uniforms lugged automatic rifles and submachine guns. Moreover, the authorities are preparing for a possible new round of protests on Monday in Porto Novo when memorial services are held for former President Sourou Migan Apithy. Mr. Apithy, head of state from 1970 to 1972, was placed under house arrest after the 1972 military coup and released in 1981. He then went into exile in France, where he died on Dec. 3. Behind the protests is the dire condition of the economy of Benin, which changed its name from Dahomey in 1975. Those who took to the streets complained that Mr. Kerekou had not gone far enough with reforms. The Retreat From Marxism For several years, in fact, Mr. Kerekou has been retreating from efforts to fashion a doctrinaire Marxist state. Many unprofitable Government enterprises have been sold, and private financial institutions have opened. But Western diplomats and assistance officials here say that encouraging signs of economic liberalization have done little to reverse years of corruption and mismanagement. The state treasury is widely thought to be all but bankrupt. Indeed, earlier this year, the American Embassy's annual economic report - usually a diplomatically worded document - described conditions here this way: ''Since the early 1980's there has been a dramatic deterioration in Benin's economic performance, facing Benin's leaders with the worst economic crisis of the country's 27-year history.'' The Problems Since Independence When Benin gained independence after nearly a century of colonial rule by France, there were few predictions of prosperity or political stability. For one thing, this country - about the size of Pennsylvania and bordered by Nigeria on the east, Togo on the west and Burkina Faso and Niger on the north -has virtually no natural resources. The people of Benin were among the best educated in French colonial Africa, and before independence they worked as civil servants throughout the region. But between 1963 and 1972, the country endured 4 coups, 10 attempted coups, 12 Governments and 6 Constitutions. With such instability, economic activity stagnated, and by the time of the fifth takeover, by Mr. Kerekou, a young French paratrooper, poverty was widespread. Dramatic Shift in Mid-1970's In November 1974, President Kerekou decided that the country's 3.3 million people needed a Marxist revolution, and the Government nationalized several key companies, as well as banking and insurance services. But Benin's brand of Marxism-Leninism, while often repressive, had its accommodating side. Government ministers, including President Kerekou, fell over each other to greet Pope John Paul II during an African pilgrimage a few years ago. Much of the commercial enterprises remained in private, profit-making hands. And the French influence is still omnipresent; at the Sheraton Hotel, a business the Government controls, the truffles and camembert are flown from Paris, the wine is impressive by African standards and the lobby reverberates with the sounds of French Christmas carols. But for most people in Benin, life is full of aggravation and deprivation. In 1987 the gross national product was only $310 per person, as measured by the World Bank. This year, it is expected to be slightly lower. The Threat From the Left For now, Western diplomats say, the biggest threat to Mr. Kerekou's regime is not the youthful demonstrators who called for his resignation this week, but a small group of leftist extremists. The Communist Party was officially banned in the early years of the Kerekou regime. But in September, yielding to pressure from international donors to improve human rights here, President Kerekou granted a general amnesty for party members. By most accounts, the Communist Party's complaint with Mr. Kerekou is that he has not been tough and doctrinaire enough. Western diplomats say the party was a significant force behind the recent demonstrations.

COUNTRY: SOUTH AFRICA (97%);
TEXT: When South Africa created its black homelands and pushed four of them into nominal independence, it did not anticipate that they would hatch a maverick like Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa. General Holomisa took power in Transkei in a bloodless coup in December 1988 with a pledge to root out the corruption that became endemic under its previous leader, George Matanzima. Now the military ruler looks like a loose cannon on the deck of apartheid's ship of state. Within the last two months, the 34-year-old chief of the 4,000-member Transkei Defense Force has shattered the collaborationist image that caused Bantustan leaders to be held in disdain at home and overseas. And Pretoria can do little to muffle him without undercutting its position that Transkei is a sovereign nation. Transkei's radio station was the only one in South Africa to broadcast the mass rally near Soweto on Oct. 29 that welcomed home seven political prisoners prominent in the outlawed African National Congress. On Nov. 5, General Holomisa gave his approval to a politically charged funeral at home for the reburial of Sabata Dalindyebo, a tribal chief loyal to the Congress who died in exile after being deposed by the Matanzima regime. National Congress Rally On Nov. 26, General Holomisa authorized and himself attended Transkei's own rally on behalf of the African National Congress, at which Walter Sisulu and other released leaders spoke to a crowd of more than 70,000. The general suggested that the congress might some day open an office in Transkei. He has freed local political prisoners and lifted restrictions on some groups supporting the African National Congress. And there is an unconfirmed report that he secretly met its leader, Oliver Tambo, abroad. The country's 10 ethnic homelands were spawned by the Nationalist Government as a means to reduce the number of blacks living in South Africa on grounds that they belonged in their own tribal areas. Four such homelands -Transkei, Bophuthatswana, Venda and Ciskei - were declared independent, a status recognized only by South Africa and one another. The homelands depend almost totally on South Africa, providing migrant labor for its mines, factories and farms and collecting more than $2 billion a year in subsidies from Pretoria. General Holomisa suggested that Transkei's inhabitants might want to rejoin South Africa and, without consulting Pretoria, has invited political, civic and social groups to send representatives here on Feb. 7 to decide whether to hold a popular referendum on the issue. Responding to Changes In an interview, General Holomisa said he was only responding to the changes that President F. W. de Klerk, whom he will meet next month, had introduced in South Africa. ''The precedent was created in the very country that produced apartheid,'' the general said in an interview in his office in Umtata, Transkei's capital. But General Holomisa made clear that he was positioning his homeland to take advantage of a shift in the political wind by opening a dialogue with all parties, not least the African National Congress. ''If South Africa is changing course, I think it is for everybody to exploit and promote the situation,'' General Holomisa said. Phathekile Holomisa, an Umtata lawyer, said his brother's actions were consistent with the tradition of the Xhosas, the largest black ethnic group in South Africa after the Zulus. ''Chiefs generally listened to the people,'' said Mr. Holomisa, who inherited a Xhosa chieftainship. ''They were never dictators.'' He is regarded as closer to the African National Congress than the general and visited its headquarters in Lusaka last August with a delegation of traditional leaders from South Africa. First Independent Homeland ''I feel that most people are against the independence of the Transkei and regard themselves as part and parcel of South Africa,'' he said. Transkei, an area the size of Denmark bordering the Indian Ocean, was the first homeland to be made independent on Oct. 26, 1976. Last year, Pretoria gave Transkei about $350 million, or more than 40 percent of its annual budget. General Holomisa said 600,000 migrants out of a Transkei population of more than three million worked in South Africa. One reason why many blacks do not like to live in the homelands is that the standard of living and social services in the homelands remains much lower than in the rest of South Africa. ''We still have overcrowded hospitals,'' General Holomisa said. ''We still don't have enough to build schools.'' He complained that black neighbors like Mozambique and Lesotho, where the African National Congress was legal, were receiving economic help from South Africa, which wants to improve its standing on the continent. Pretoria's charity, he said, should begin in the homelands. 'A Sort of Raw Deal' ''They still pump billions of rands into neighboring countries which have not banned these organizations,'' General Holomisa said. ''We would like to operate like they are doing.'' Because Transkei was perceived abroad as a puppet state, he said, it suffered from the Western economic sanctions imposed on South Africa and could not get loans from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, while other African countries were eligible. ''We are being punished by this tag 'independent,' so we have been given a sort of raw deal,'' General Holomisa said. The Transkei leader recently legalized local branches of some anti-apartheid organizations restricted by the South African Government, including the United Democratic Front, the Azanian People's Organization and the Congress of South African Students. ''If South Africa is shifting the goal posts because it's no longer talking the Verwoerdian language,'' said General Holomisa, alluding to the late Prime Minister, Hendrick Verwoerd, the architect of apartheid, ''we'll shift our goalposts so we don't aim at the wrong target.'' A Non-Aggression Pact General Holomisa has yet to lift Transkei's own bans on the African National Congress or the Pan-Africanist Congress, a rival black liberation movement, though he suggested that he would do so eventually. And he said nationalist guerrillas could never operate out of Transkei, as they have from Zambia or Angola, because of a non-aggression pact imposed by South Africa. ''One of the reasons we couldn't unban the A.N.C. or the P.A.C. is we were afraid it might be hijacked and fall into the wrong hands,'' he said, referring to those who might undermine his regime. ''In Transkei, we need to identify who is who, otherwise it will get out of hand.'' The initial reaction in the Transkei to the idea of rejoining South Africa has been 70 percent favorable, the general said, though he would leave the decision on a referendum to the conference in February. ''Otherwise, they will accuse us of taking them at gunpoint,'' General Holomisa said, joking about his military rule. Mr. Holomisa, the general's brother, said he knew the South African Government was not happy with what was happening in Transkei, By contrast, Andrew Mlangeni, one of the political prisoners recently released by Mr. de Klerk, hailed General Holomisa at last month's rally as ''the spiritual brother'' of the congress's guerrilla wing Umkhonto we Sizwe, or Spear of the Nation. General Holomisa seemed uncomfortable with the compliment when asked about it, but his tacit encouragement of the anti-apartheid movement seems to have increased his domestic popularity, already high because of his reputation for honesty and plain living. ''It gives people a feeling of not being excluded as part of a homeland, but being included as part of the struggle in the country,'' said Dr. Zola Dabula, a physician in Umtata who helped organize the rally for the African National Congress. ''Everybody wants to be seen to be allied with progressive structures.'' Seeks Supporting Role General Holomisa said the South African Government, the African National Congress and the Pan-Africanist Congress would still play the primary roles in determining the country's future. But Transkei and the other homelands, he said, should prepare for a supporting role. He has invited other homeland leaders to a meeting in Umtata on Jan. 22 and 23. ''Not everyone goes to the battle,'' General Holomisa said, citing a Xhosa proverb. ''There will always be old people and children to look after homes and cattle. When the warriors come back, they don't shun those people.''

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); KENYA (93%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (93%); CANADA (92%); LATIN AMERICA (79%); GHANA (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); FRANCE (78%); GERMANY (78%);
TEXT: The United States today formally agreed to forgive all economic-assistance loans to Kenya, as part of an effort to give economic relief to Africa, including some of the continent's poorest countries. The debt-relief effort, which was announced last July, is also aimed at rewarding African countries that have started to tighten their belts to improve their weak economies. The United States Ambassador here, Smith Hempstone, signed an agreement that covered $44.7 million of Kenya's total outstanding debt of $175 million. The remaining $130 million will be forgiven over the next two years, if Kenya adheres to an economic reform program reached with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Total of $735 Million In all, the United States has pledged to cancel debts of $735 million owed by 12 sub-Saharan African countries. The per-capita incomes in those countries range from a low of $150 in Zaire to a high of $390 in Ghana. The debt forgiveness reflects continuing concern about declines in Africa's well-being. ''Over all, Africans are almost as poor today as they were 30 years ago,'' the World Bank said in a major report in November. Of the 44 countries of black Africa, more than half are severely in debt and have structurally weak economies, the World Bank said last month in an assessment of world debt. The economies are weak because of heavy dependence on volatile commodities, like coffee and tea, for exports; rapidly growing populations, and very little investment. Many of the economies have also been buckled by official corruption. Differs From Reagan Policy The decision to forgive the United States' debt is part of a policy adopted by the Bush Administration last year to do more to help the poorest countries. The Reagan Administration had refused to go along with some other Western nations, notably Britain, France, Canada and West Germany, which began canceling the official debts of sub-Saharan countries after an economic summit meeting in Toronto in 1988. The Reagan Administration chose instead to give the countries more time to pay. By the end of 1988, the foreign debt of sub-Saharan Africa was about $140 billion, the World Bank reported. In comparison with Latin America's debt of hundreds of millions of dollars, the sub-Saharan debt is relatively small. But unlike the Latin debt, much of which is owed to commercial banks, Africa's is mostly owed to governments and multilateral agencies like the World Bank. Economists have pointed out that the annual cost of servicing Africa's debt is about $12 billion. As poor as it is, Africa continues to be a net exporter of resources, paying more in debt service than the total of what it receives in foreign aid and earns from commodity exports, according to the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa. Don Harrison, deputy chief of the Planning Analysis and Research Division at the United States Agency for International Development, said that servicing the debt consumed much of the foreign exchange needed to purchase goods and services and supply investment capital for economic growth and development. Kenya Among the Better Off Of the 12 countries where Washington is forgiving its loans, Kenya is one of the most prosperous, with a per-capita income of $330. But even so, Western donors including the United States have expressed concern at the Kenyan Government's growing reliance on foreign aid to pay for spending and budget deficits. The donors have also informed the Kenyans that the Government is seeking too many large-scale commercial loans from abroad for items like aircraft for the national airline and a 60-story office tower. The United States is canceling its economic loans for countries including Nigeria, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Cameroon, Malawi and Madagascar. Some of the loans, dating back 25 years, when Kenya obtained independence from Britain, were granted largely for spending on public works.

COUNTRY: FRANCE (99%); AFRICA (98%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (94%); COTE D'IVOIRE (93%); GABON (92%); CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC (79%); EUROPE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); GERMANY (79%); SENEGAL (79%); NIGER (79%); ASIA (79%); CHAD (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (53%);
TEXT: France is sending signals that it intends to reduce its role in its former possessions in sub-Saharan Africa and that it expects governments in those countries to move toward greater democracy and respect for human rights. Three decades after granting formal independence to its sub-Saharan African empire, France is trying to shed its image as an all-knowing, often generous and sometimes interfering Big Brother in favor of more distant and traditional diplomatic relations, according to officials and analysts. "Now France is fundamentally getting rid of the colonies in favor of normal state-to-state relations," said a French official here. "We still have historic responsibilities here and thus seek no sharp break." In keeping with this new image, France was careful to appear no more than a concerned bystander when demonstrations and strikes recently swept through former colonies as economically, politically and geographically diverse as Gabon, Niger, Senegal and Ivory Coast. Although French troops still are stationed on African soil, they have been non-interventionist, unlike when they restored overthrown President Leon M'Ba in Gabon in 1964, deposed Emperor Bokassa in the Central African Republic in 1979 or helped stop foreign invasions of Chad and Zaire, the analysts said. Government corruption, human rights violations and economic mismanagement in its former colonies have helped weaken the close links that France maintained in these countries to boost its image as a world power and ensure the survival of French as an internationally important language. The policy, which critics called neo-colonialist, appears to have outlived its usefulness for the French, who long justified their hands-on approach by contrasting the benefits of convertible currency and law and order backed by French army garrisons to the economic disorder and violence elsewhere in Africa. Events in Eastern Europe and the prospect of German unification provided an additional rationale for shifting France's limited resources nearer to home -- or to Asia with its promise of better return on investment. French Prime Minister Michel Rocard has said that "France has no moral right nor political intention to drop Africa," and other French officials have echoed his statement. They also have hinted that greater democracy -- and greater respect for law -- are overdue in France's former possessions in Africa. With African agricultural exports sagging and French business retrenching, leaders of these countries have few illusions about Paris's assurances that private investment will take the place of what was once the world's highest per capita aid program. That program brought with it tens of thousands of French officials, businessmen and technicians. With the passing of the Cold War, African leaders are less able to invoke China, Cuba, the Soviet Union or the United States as competitors to France for influence in Africa. In a recent op-ed article in the Paris newspaper Le Monde, a French African specialist criticized French officials for keeping silent about well-documented abuses in the former colonies "for fear of endangering delicate bilateral relations." He argued that French aid "had reached the ultimate point of perversion" by "maintaining crazy regimes and parasitical structures" that have become "the surest obstacles to development." France also has learned the usefulness of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. French officials have discovered that IMF demands for austerity measures can be conveniently invoked to refuse the appeals from African leaders for more funds that for three decades often were answered in Paris.

COUNTRY: UGANDA (99%); UNITED STATES (93%); ASIA (79%); AFRICA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: For sale or repossession: $1 billion worth of commercial buildings, tea and coffee plantations, residences. Location: war-battered African country, now rebuilding; World Bank favorite. Contact: scandal-ridden Government agency. On the face of it, the impoverished Ugandan Government, broke because of a sharp drop in coffee prices and the cost of trying to repair its economy, should be able to make a fortune from nearly 7,000 properties seized from Asian owners 18 years ago by Idi Amin. Indeed, the best buildings in the capital, Kampala, stand dilapidated and encrusted in dirt from war and neglect, awaiting either their old owners or new ones. But despite urging from the World Bank and the United States, both enthusiastic backers of President Yoweri Museveni, the Government's action to divest itself of the confiscated properties is proving extremely slow. The properties include virtually all of downtown Kampala, as well as potentially high-grade farms and tea plantations. All told, according to a Washington concern, the Privatization Center, which valued the properties on the basis of potential revenue, the real estate is worth $1 billion. Pride or Prosperity?  At stake in the Government's move to turn the property back to private hands, say Western donors and many senior Ugandan officials, is the recovery of this East African country. Without the rehabilitation of this property, these officials say, the engine of the economy will never get started. Yet for many Ugandans, there is something much deeper at stake: the reappearance of the dominant Asian trading class that ran the economy before the 1972 expulsion. About 80,000 Asians were expelled by General Amin because of what he called ''economic imperialism.'' Most of them were Indians, and they dominated the trading and economic life of Uganda, causing enormous resentment among the Africans not only because of their wealth but also because they were thought to have taken on the air of superiority. Since the expulsions, all the property owned by the Asians have been put in the hands of the Departed Asian Property Custodian Board, a Government body with no money to keep up buildings since fallen into disrepair, without water or working sewage systems. Many have been rented at low rates to political favorites. The Ugandan press has almost daily revelations about corruption at the board. Amid increasing scandal, the head of the board was recently forced out. Attracting Capitalists Ugandans in decision-making positions say they know that they have two choices. The first is to encourage the Asians to return and bring with them the capital and entrepreneurial skills the country lacks. About 100 Asian families are thought to want to return because they can see the money-making potential. The second choice for the Ugandans is to continue the current situation of making it extremely difficult, through red tape and bribes, for the Asians to come back. This would mean much slower economic growth but would insure that African Ugandans hold the upper hand, albeit in a tumbledown economy. Many Ugandans are said to look nervously toward neighboring Kenya, where they know about 70 percent of the economy is dominated by Asian families. Mr. Museveni's position on the confiscated properties is not clear. ''At first, Museveni was taking the position the all the properties should be distributed among all sectors of society and not to foreigners,'' said a Western official urging speedy divestiture. ''Where he is today, I don't know.'' Asian Ugandans who have come back from Britain, Canada or Australia also detect ambivalence from Mr. Museveni. Mumtaz Kassam, now a British-trained lawyer, was a 16-year-old schoolgirl when her Ugandan passport was torn up by Amin immigration officials in 1972. She has been working for the last few years to reclaim 45 properties that belonged to her parents and uncles. Effect on 'His People' ''I think Museveni is very sincere and has good intentions,'' said Miss Kassam, who met the President at a session of the Uganda Women Lawyers Association. ''But he also has reservations about the Asians, because a lot of his people will be hurt.'' For example, said Miss Kassam, who now practices law in London, the Third Deputy Prime Minister, Abubakar Mayanja, had been given the right to work a dairy farm that belonged to one of her uncles at the time of the expulsion. About 30,000 of the Asians living in Uganda chose to take Ugandan passports instead of British passports at the time of independence from Britain in 1962, only to be expelled 10 years later. As one of those who chose to be Ugandan, Miss Kassam feels that she and her parents and uncles - also Ugandan passport holders at the time - should be able to regain their properties. After nine years of trying to complete the task, first started by her uncle, Miss Kassam recently won back the family sock factory. She drove to the industrial area to look over the plant. It had been idle since 1972, but the machines, decrepit and partly broken, remained. An engineer was on his way from India. ''Uganda is currently importing all its socks,'' she said. ''We want to start making them here - starting with the army.'' She would like to remain in Uganda herself.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); UNITED STATES (92%);
TEXT: In an unusually broad attack on corruption, a prominent church leader charged Saturday that misuse of power for economic gain had become the norm among Government officials. The issue had until recently been treated rather gingerly in public. But the Archbishop of the Church Province of Kenya, the Rev. Manasses Kuria, told an Anglican congregation that the situation had become so bad that the ''organs of state machinery'' were seizing property from ordinary people. ''Unless God rescues Kenya, we shall sink,'' said the Archbishop, who until the last few months of political upheaval here had been reserved in his remarks about the Government. Corruption has become ''institutionalized,'' he said, echoing a complaint of foreign investors here. The Archbishop's admonition came as an Anglican bishop declared his financial wealth - mainly land acquired through a $32,000 loan from the church - and called on all public and church officials to do the same. Church leaders have been at the forefront of the campaign for a more open political system in Kenya. The country's President, Daniel arap Moi, is one of the few remaining major leaders south of the Sahara who still adamantly oppose a multiparty system. Three prominent politicians who called for a multiparty system have been detained without charges for more than a month. The crackdown in July attracted more international attention when Gibson Kamau Kuria, a human-rights lawyer representing two ministers who were detained, sought refuge in the United States Embassy here. Washington eventually negotiated his departure from the country. Four people have been charged with trying to bring down the Government. In court hearings last week, they complained of inhuman jail conditions. The Government freed four lawyers who had been held without charges. Churchmen, the one group of critics unscathed by the Moi Government's crackdown, are looking for ways to keep up the pressure on officials, people familiar with their strategy say. They have added a cleanup of Government corruption to the church's other political demands - the dissolution of Parliament, new elections with candidates from numerous political parties, and a limit on the number of terms allowed a president. Instead of opening the door to a multiparty political system, Mr. Moi appointed a commission to study possible reforms in Kenya's sole political party, the Kenya African National Union. The commission, headed by Vice President George Saitoti, has been traveling around the country to hear suggestions for change from party members as well as critics. Last week corruption became an open topic of discussion. At one session, a cabinet member and a local party chairman whose names were not disclosed were accused of taking thousands of acres of land for themselves. Reports of Property Seized Three residents of the Embu district told the commission that the minister and party officials had seized land that had been set aside for people without property by Kenya's former president, Jomo Kenyatta. Such outspokenness, especially before a public body, has been unusual in Kenya in recent years. The commission is to submit a draft proposal to Mr. Moi on possible reforms in the Kenya African National Union by Aug. 31. In another sign that the question of official corruption is coming to the fore, The Sunday Standard newspaper published a long article today on its investigations into land dealings by a former cabinet minister and two serving senior public servants. The World Bank and the United States Government have said that official corruption is hindering economic development here. The testimony and complaints to the commission have raised expectations. The question now is whether the limited reforms that the commission and Mr. Moi are expected to approve - the reintroduction of secret ballots in primary elections and an end to expulsions of members from the party -will satisfy the pressures for accountability and for an open political system.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); AFRICA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: IF YOU took a quarter-century worth of His Excellencies the African Leader and tossed them in a blender, you would come up with a Big Man like this: His face is on the money. His photograph hangs in every office in his realm. His ministers wear gold pins with tiny photographs of him on the lapels of their tailored pin-striped suits. He names streets, football stadiums, hospitals and universities after himself. He carries a silver-inlaid ivory mace or an ornately carved walking stick or fly whisk or a chiefly stool. He insists on being called "doctor" or "conqueror" or "teacher" or "the big elephant" or "the number-one peasant" or "the wise old man" or "the national miracle" or "the most popular leader in the world." His every pronouncement is reported on the front page. He sleeps with the wives and daughters of powerful men in the government. He shuffles ministers without warning, paralyzing policy decisions as he undercuts pretenders to his throne. He scapegoats minorities to shore up popular support. He bans all political parties except the one he controls. He rigs elections. He emasculates the courts. He cows the press. He stifles academia. He goes to church. Yet more than 150 leaders, many of them "President for Life," have come and gone as the continent has been sucked downward in a spiral of declining per-capita food production and unpayable foreign debt, of civil war and rampant corruption. Africa was poorer at the end of the 1980s than it was when Big Men first usurped the authority of tribal chiefs and welded it to the power of the modern nation-state. At first blush, then, the reign of Daniel arap Moi in Kenya does not seem so destructive. After all, Kenya is an island of sanity in comparison to its East African neighbors, and Moi does not sanction the public mutilation of his enemies or write books about African utopia. Instead, he is a stolid, slow-speaking, not-very-bright Big Man who deftly uses the tools of his trade -- payoffs and coercion -- to stay in power. Yet it is precisely because of Kenya's success that Moi's rule has proved so pernicious. The logic of Moi's survival has been a recipe for national stagnation. His survival requires constant manipulation of the Big Man levers. His need to bleed the business community and grab all political power for himself is inversely proportional to his legitimacy. Since he comes from a tiny tribe, has little personal charisma, was never elected president and cannot reasonably expect to rule with the consent of the Kenyan majority, he needs larger and larger amounts of money to reward supporters, more and more power to silence enemies. According to the government's own press releases, Kenya must break its dependence on coffee, tea and tourism. There is no other palatable option. All the arable land is already planted. Game parks are severely overcrowded, and poaching has decimated elephant and rhino populations. But Kenya does have a competitive edge. It is well placed to become a manufacturing and service industry hub for East and Central Africa. It has the best port, the best roads, the best climate, the best work force, the best communications network, the best international reputation and the most vigorous free-market tradition in East Africa. To run with these advantages, the country desperately needs foreign and domestic investment. To compete internationally, the government has to reward efficiency rather than sycophancy. The law has to provide a level playing field for industry. These economic imperatives, which are the sine qua non of any country competing in the world marketplace, do not suit Moi's Big Man system. Wealth that Moi does not control is dissidence. Prosperity is far more destabilizing than stagnation. It should come as no surprise, then, that Kenya's economy -- outside of tourism, coffee and tea -- is dead in the water. Manufactured exports have declined in the 1980s and a parade of foreign manufacturers has pulled out. Almost no new ones have come in. Every year 150,000 young people flood into Kenya's job market. But industry generates only 3,000 new jobs a year. A diplomatic cable sent to Washington by the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi cited a pervasive pattern of "favoritism as well as corruption in the Government of Kenya's treatment of the country's industries." What grows is what Moi controls: government. In the first seven years of the 1980s, the number of government employees grew at an annual rate of 5.4 percent -- faster than the population, faster than the private sector, faster than the gross national product. It makes no economic sense. But it is perfectly consistent with Moi's need to buy loyalty. In the Moi years, an ethic of corruption has percolated deep into the civil service. In the mid-1980s, a friend of mine who works in the Finance Ministry told me with great pride that his mid-level civil servant colleagues were highly motivated and relatively honest. By the end of the decade, he despairingly said that "every bureaucratic bottleneck is now presided over by somebody asking for money." Kenya's descent into greed is by no means unique. Nor, by African standards, is it exceptionally venal. Yet Kenya is an African nation that has an opportunity not to unravel, and each day, as the population grows, as Moi's rot spreads, the window of opportunity closes. The future of 22 million Kenyans (in less than 20 years it will be 44 million) is being squandered to preserve one boring unelected president. The simplest cure for Big Man disease in Kenya, as across black Africa, would be Moi's replacement with a new, improved Big Man. If such a leader commanded personal authority he did not have to buy, if he were willing to operate within a framework of laws, if he exploited Kenya's potential for accelerated industrial growth, and if he was convinced of the need to resuscitate parliament and other decision-making bodies that allowed Kenyans to participate in their own governance, then the decline of Kenya could be turned around. On a trip to Ghana I asked military leader Jerry Rawlings -- who is a new and improved Big Man -- what is the best treatment for a slowly disintegrating country like Kenya. "An enlightened dictator," he whispered. The dismal history of leadership in independent Africa, however, suggests that the odds are against Moi's successor being an enlightened despot, a philosopher king. Gibson Kamau Kuria, the gutsy Kenyan lawyer whom Moi jailed, vilified and this year forced into exile, told me again and again that Africans must learn not to place their future in the hands of a big chief, who may or may not turn out to be benevolent. Big Man disease, he said, can only be cured by vigorous institutions that limit individual power while increasing popular participation in government. To that end, Western governments and multilateral lending agencies may be able to play a supporting role in preserving or rebuilding Africa's democratic institutions. In that spirit, a top World Bank official recently urged the Kenyan government to do more to bring about democratic change. The power of the West to influence policy in poor African countries grew enormously in the 1980s. The poorer Africa became, the more it had to accept conditions on aid. Outsiders have become the architects of economic policy in much of black Africa. Kenya is particularly beholden to the West. The IMF demands devaluation of the Kenyan shilling and Kenya devalues. The choice is simple: reform or no loan money. For the time being, at least, Kenya has a legal tradition and democratic institutions. Both are wobbly, but they still exist. There are still large numbers of trained and committed people who believe in the rule of law and the usefulness of parliament. These individuals, however, are helpless in the face of Moi's one-man state, which is propped up by hundreds of millions of dollars in aid and tourist money. What they desperately need is for Western donors to insist on free elections in the same way that they insist on a rationally valued currency. The U.S. Congress acted properly when it voted recently to freeze $ 15 million in military aid, linking its resumption to political freedom. After an explosion of of international press criticism in 1987, Kenya's Big Man temporarily stopped his police from torturing people. He even stooped so low as to grant me -- a journalist whom he once described as "serving foreign masters" and using "dirty words" -- an interview. He did so for the sake of continued aid and to preserve an international reputation that keeps the tourists coming. Considering Moi's weak political base, his paranoia, and his boundless greed, my bet is that he also will stop stealing elections, bullying judges, and dismantling the constitution. That is, if he has no other way to get the money. Blaine Harden, Warsaw bureau chief for The Washington Post, previously was based in Nairobi. This article was adapted from "Africa: Dispatches From a Fragile Continent," published by Norton.

COUNTRY: BENIN (95%);
TEXT: Anxious voters lined up before dawn this morning in front of polling stations here and across Benin to cast ballots in this tiny nation's first free presidential elections in nearly three decades. The head of the republic's election commission said tonight that no official results would be reported until Tuesday. According to unofficial reports, the turnout among the two million eligible voters was high, as much as 80 percent in some places. The total population is about four million. A second round of voting will be held on March 24 if none of the 13 candidates receives more than 50 percent of the vote. Most political commentators believe that the Prime Minister, Nicephore Soglo, a former senior official of the World Bank who helped engineer Benin's transition from strict Marxist orthodoxy to a multiparty democracy, will almost certainly finish first. Mr. Soglo's backers won 11 of 64 seats in parliamentary elections last month. Mr. Soglo's main rival is Benin's current president, Mathieu Kerekou, a former military commander who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1972. In December 1989, yielding to rising popular discontent, Mr. Kerekou proclaimed that Marxism-Leninism would no longer be the state ideology. Two months later, a coalition led by Mr. Soglo effectively stripped Mr. Kerekou of his powers, although he was allowed to retain the title of president. Moves Toward Democracy Subsequently, Benin became the first nation on the continent to remodel its political system along the lines of the Western democracies. Since then, at least 12 other governments have taken steps toward pluralistic systems. If Mr. Kerekou should lose, he would be the first African president to be forced from power by an electoral defeat since independence movements began nearly 30 years ago. Although widely criticized throughout Benin for his years of raw autocratic rule, Mr. Kerekou has cast himself in the campaign as a candidate of experience and stability.  The former governing party, the People's Revolutionary Party of Benin, has spent freely and hinted that the military may reassert control if the election appears rigged. Riot policemen were deployed in large numbers outside polling stations in much of the country, but no violence was reported. Here in Porto Novo, Benin's capital, many people said they were grateful for Mr. Soglo's leading role in tranforming Benin into a multiparty democracy and were casting their votes for him. "For 17 years during Kerekou's rule we lived as if we were in a box," said Julienne Sagbo outside a polling booth. "Soglo helped us climb out of the box," she added.

COUNTRY: BENIN (95%); EUROPE (92%); AFRICA (92%); CANADA (79%); FRANCE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); GERMANY (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (67%);
TEXT: Early returns in Benin's presidential election suggested today that a runoff might be necessary between Prime Minister Nicephore Soglo, the front-runner, and the Marxist-Leninist President, Brig. Gen. Mathieu Kerekou, whose power was eclipsed more than a year ago but who made an unexpectedly strong showing in Sunday's voting. The incomplete returns showed Mr. Soglo receiving 36 percent of the vote and General Kerekou, 26 percent. A third candidate, Albert Tevoedjre, received 14 percent of ballots cast. Since no candidate appeared headed for a majority, a runoff between the two top candidates, which would be held March 24, appeared almost certain. Final results of Sunday's balloting are not expected until Tuesday. The vote here has been closely watched because it was supposed to mark the advance of democracy in a region more accustomed to autocratic, single-party rule. Opposition Surprised For that reason, the impressive showing by General Kerekou, 57 years old, who ran the country for nearly 18 years until February 1990, stunned many opposition leaders and their supporters. Some Western analysts said the results called into question the seriousness of Benin's quest for greater democratization. Voter turnout appeared to be heavy, early reports said. International observers from Canada, France, Germany and the United States said that the voting appeared to have been freely conducted, with no evidence of vote-rigging or intimidation. In his campaign, General Kerekou, who seized power in 1972, offered himself as the candidate of stability and experience. Mr. Soglo and the 12 other opposition candidates made the election largely a referendum on the President, portraying him as a discredited relic from Benin's authoritarian past. If he should lose in the runoffs, General Kerekou would become the first president on the African continent to be forced from power by an election defeat. This country of 4.4 million people, once a French colony, gained independence in 1960 as Dahomey. In 1975, it changed its name to Benin. Eastern Europe as Example Popular unrest, inspired in part by the upheaval in East European Communist countries, forced General Kerekou to give up power last year but not his title. Mr. Soglo, 56, a former World Bank official, then took over as Prime Minister of an interim Government. The preliminary election results displayed the enduring power of regional and ethnic loyalties in West Africa. As the early returns came in last night, General Kerekou established a strong lead based on his support in the mostly rural and agrarian northern interior, which is also the region dominated by his ethnic group, the Somba. But Mr. Soglo surged ahead late this morning, when the results from the coastal and southern regions, Benin's administrative and industrial centers, were reported. "Many people voted for Kerekou," a Western diplomat said, "merely because he was their chief for 18 years, and a great deal of respect and fealty goes with that position, no matter how he rules. They don't care whether it's a single-party or multi-party system; it's all the same to them."

COUNTRY: KENYA (96%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: The week before he was shot to death near his home in western Kenya last year, foreign minister Robert J. Ouko was preparing a confidential report for President Daniel arap Moi about a multimillion-dollar construction project in which a top Kenyan official allegedly demanded and received a $ 3 million bribe from an Italian contractor, a key witness has charged at an official public inquiry into Ouko's slaying. Dorothy Randiak, a sister and confidante of Ouko and one of the last people to see him before he was slain in February 1990, told the inquiry Friday that Ouko confided to her that Energy Minister Nicholas Biwott secretly had been given a 15 percent commission on a $ 20 million deal to complete construction of a long-stalled molasses plant in the western city of Kisumu. Ouko, a frequent critic of corruption in the Kenyan government, was described as livid over the alleged bribe and was writing a comprehensive and candid report about the project for Moi at the time of his murder, Randiak declared. She said she did not know what became of the report. No suspect has been arrested in the slaying. The six-month-old judicial inquiry has galvanized the attention of this tightly controlled East African nation, where public mention or discussion of high-level official corruption is virtually unheard of. The verbatim record of the inquiry is published each day in Kenya's three daily newspapers. Randiak's testimony came one day after she first linked Biwott to the case, charging that Ouko had claimed that "talking about corruption in Kenya was the same as talking about Mr. Biwott." Biwott's lawyers, protesting that Randiak's testimony amounted to hearsay and slander, attempted to prevent her from testifying this week. Their efforts were rejected. As a crowd listened raptly in the packed Kisumu town hall, Randiak claimed that enmity between Ouko and Biwott ran deep and stemmed chiefly from the latter's attempts to scuttle Ouko's efforts to complete the molasses plant, a decade-old project designed to employ hundreds of Kenyans in his home district. Ouko recommended to Moi that the contract to complete the plant be given to an Italian consortium, described by the envoy as "credible" and "competent." However, Randiak said, Ouko complained to her that every effort he made to finish the project was frustrated by Biwott, "unless he was given a cut." She said Ouko told her that Biwott had pressured the treasury and the Ministry of Industry to snub the Ouko-recommended group. Meanwhile, she charged, Biwott closed a separate deal with a different Italian firm, which paid Biwott a bribe. Biwott, who like Moi belongs to Kenya's minority Kalenjin tribe, is considered a shrewd businessman and powerful political associate of the president. Biwott's energy portfolio reportedly includes some of the most lucrative enterprises of the government. An influential member of the ruling party, Biwott is well-regarded by many ordinary Kenyans. But privately some Kenyans see Biwott as a preeminent symbol of questionable ethics in the Kenyan government. Ouko's death came shortly after Moi and several other Kenyan officials visited Washington to seek increased private investment here. Many foreign companies have pulled their investments out of Kenya in recent years, complaining that so many Kenyan government officials demand bribes that business is no longer feasible here. The Biwott controversy comes at a time when many international aid groups, led by the World Bank, are pointing to a lack of political and ethical accountability in African governments as a critical factor in the continent's free fall to economic ruin during the past 20 years. Biwott has not commented publicly on the charges raised in the judicial inquiry. How far the judicial inquiry will be allowed to proceed publicly by the Moi government remains to be seen. For now, in a country where public dissent and criticism of public officials is rarely tolerated, many observers are perhaps most impressed by the outspokenness of several witnesses so far.

COUNTRY: KENYA (98%); UNITED KINGDOM (97%);
TEXT: The Foreign Minister of Kenya, whose charred body was found in the bush 20 months ago, was murdered because he knew too much about high-level corruption in the Kenyan Government, the British detective in charge of the investigation into his death said today. The detective, John Troon, who was with Scotland Yard at the time of his investigation, told an official Government inquiry, "I ascertained there was a corruption motive, and I explicitly say so." Mr. Troon read excerpts to the inqui ry from the voluminous report he completed after investigating the death of the Foreign Minister, Robert Ouko. The report was never made public by the Kenyan Government. He is the star witness at the inquiry which has been sitting for more than six months. Help From Scotland Yard "Allegations of corruption particularly against the BAK group of companies are important," Mr. Troon said, reading to the hushed crowd in Kisumu, the major town in western Kenya where the inquiry, headed by a judge, is taking place. Scotland Yard was asked by the Kenyan Government to investigate the death of Mr. Ouko, a popular Kenyan politician and internationally respected diplomat whose body was found near his home in western Kenya in February 1990. He had been shot in the head at close range with a single bullet. An earlier investigation by the Kenyan Government suggested that Mr. Ouko had committed suicide, a conclusion that was greeted with derision by many Kenyans, partly because the body had been burned. The Kenyan Government has not commented on Mr. Troon's testimony, which comes as the Kenyan Government faces increasing complaints by Western aid donors about corruption. Donors meeting in Paris on Nov. 25 under the auspices of the World Bank will decide the level of aid for Kenya next year. A number of them are expected to tell the Kenyans that there will be cutbacks because corruption is preventing the aid from reaching the people it is intended for. Both the British Government and the World Bank have said they have canceled plans to invest in the energy sector because the Minister of Energy, Nicholas Biwott, could not be held accountable. Ten days ago, Mr. Biwott was shifted from the Energy Ministry to the Ministry of Manufacturing in a Cabinet shake-up by President Daniel arap Moi that still appeared to leave Mr. Biwott, Mr. Moi's closest colleague in the Government, in a commanding position. Mr. Biwott was among a list of Kenyan ministers named at the Ouko inquiry last week by another British detective, Kenneth Lindsay, who said Mr. Biwott had demanded a 10 percent commission from a Swiss-based agricultural and industrial group, BAK. The company planned to renovate a molasses plant in Kenya, according to letters by a company director, Marianne Briner-Martens, that were read by Mr. Lindsay. Other officials demanded commissions from the company, Mr. Lindsay said. Among them was the Finance Minister, George Saitoti, who will lead the Kenyan delegation to the World Bank meeting. The demands for commissions on the work planned by BAK amounted to 50 percent of the cost of the project, according to the letters read by Mr. Lindsay. Affadavit by Brother Mr. Troon said today that during his investigation he had found out that Mr. Ouko seemed to be unusually troubled after returning to Kenya in February 1990 from a trip to Washington with Mr. Moi, Mr. Biwott and other Kenyan officials. The testimony today by Mr. Troon, who is expected to be on the stand for more than a week, seemed to give added credence to an affadavit sent to the commission by Mr. Ouko's brother but not admitted into evidence. The brother, Eston Barak Mbajah, who fled Kenya last year and now lives in the United States, said in the affadavit published in The London Observer two weeks ago that Mr. Ouko had quarreled with Mr. Biwott in Washington over the extent of corruption by senior Government officials. While in Washington, Mr. Moi had cautioned Mr. Ouko not to interfere, the affadavit said. On his return to Kenya, Mr. Ouko was told by Mr. Moi "to go to his home in Koru and stay there until further notice," the affadavit said. Mr. Troon also said today that Mr. Ouko had been advised to take a rest at his home. Days later Mr. Ouko's body was found.

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); AFRICA (94%); EUROPE (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); UNITED KINGDOM (92%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (90%); SOMALIA (79%); FRANCE (77%);
TEXT: On the eve of a meeting between Kenyan officials and donors of vital foreign aid, President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, one of Africa's most prominent remaining autocrats, is facing unparalleled pressures for political reform both at home and abroad. Domestically, an opposition newly emboldened by democratic movements elsewhere in Africa has seen its support grow visibly as it confronts the repression by the Moi Government. Internationally, growing disgust with the corrupt practices of the Government has led foreign benefactors to pull back, a development likely to pose great peril to Kenya's fragile economy and heighten discontent. Conditions for Aid On Monday in Paris, the Western donors and the World Bank will meet to decide the amount of aid they will grant Kenya next year. In the past week, the principal donors -- the European Community, Britain and the United States -- have shown rare cohesiveness in condemning Mr. Moi's clampdown on the opposition and have indicated that they are likely to condition aid on Mr. Moi's willingness to move toward political pluralism. Yet thus far Mr. Moi has refused to yield. While few predict that he will remain obdurate indefinitely, he has in the past proven tenacious and adroit in the face of political challenges. One of the arguments that Mr. Moi repeatedly uses to justify his one-party rule is that a multiparty system would degenerate into tribal warfare. There are three major tribes in Kenya -- the Kikuyu, the Luhya and the Luo. The 67-year-old, barrel-chested Mr. Moi is a member of one of the country's smaller tribes, the Kalenjin. "We have been having ethnic groups all over," Mr. Moi said last month in a rare interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation. Tribes and Parties "See what is happening in Somalia. It has 102 clans, which means you can have 102 parties. In Zaire, 265 parties to represent 265 tribes. You cannot really develop the country with such divisions." But critics say that Mr. Moi exaggerates tribal divisions in Kenya by continually referring to his opponents as "tribalists." Kenyans who have worked closely with Mr. Moi describe him as "paranoid" about the possibility that Kenya's largest tribe, the Kikuyu, will unseat him and unravel his large, illegally gained fortune. In a veiled attack on Mr. Moi, Simon Nyachae, a former political colleague and head of the civil service until 1987, suggested in an advertisement in a Kenyan newspaper last week that recent violence between Mr. Moi's Kalenjin tribe and the Luo, Kenya's second-largest tribe, was deliberately fomented by the Government, a view held by many others. Mr. Nyachae is a member of the Kisii tribe. Many urban Kenyans, particularly those between 20 and 40 years old, say that tribalism is less pervasive in Kenyan society than it was 10 years ago. Advocates of a multiparty system also note that since no tribe has more than 25 percent of the population, there would be a need for coalitions in a democratic Government. Mr. Moi came to power through tribal politics. He was chosen in 1967 as Vice President by Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya's first president and a Kikuyu. Coming from the Kalenjin, a pastoral people who inhabit the Rift Valley west of Nairobi, Mr. Moi was thought to provide Mr. Kenyatta a neutral screen against the tribal pressures of the Kikuyu and the Luo. Unlike Mr. Kenyatta's first vice president, the charismatic Oginga Odinga of the Luo tribe, Mr. Moi was a rather bland personality who posed no threat to Mr. Kenyatta. When Mr. Kenyatta died in 1978, Mr. Moi succeeded him. Many sophisticated Kenyans believed that he would not last long as President. But on coming to power, Mr. Moi adopted a high-profile populist style, travelling into rural areas and identifying himself with the ordinary people. At the same time, he organized the rapid promotion of his ethnic compatriots and he gradually stripped the Kikuyu, widely regarded as the entrepreneurial class, of their dominance in the Kenyan economy. In 1982, Mr. Moi appointed a longtime Kalenjin friend, Nicholas Biwott, to the job of Minister of Energy, giving him command over a large section of the Kenyan economy, including many big development projects involving foreign investors. Over recent months, Mr. Biwott became a liability Mr. Moi could no longer handle. Both American and British diplomats complained to the Moi Government about Mr. Biwott's personal profiteering from his job through kickbacks and expropriations. As the allegations of corruption against Mr. Biwott mounted, he was named by a British detective in testimony last week as one of two "prime suspects" in the February 1990 slaying of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko. Mr. Moi was forced to drop Mr. Biwott from the Cabinet. Opposition Parties Banned Mr. Moi survived a 1982 coup attempt staged by the Air Force and thereafter did all he could to consolidate his power. His first reaction was to ram through a constitutional amendment that made law what was already reality: a one-party state with his Kenya African National Union as the only legal party. "I would like ministers, assistant ministers and others to sing like a parrot after me," Mr. Moi said in 1984. "That is how we can progress." In the 1988 parliamentary elections, Mr. Moi replaced the secret ballot with queuing, a voting system under which voters stand behind the picture of the candidate of their choice. Voter turnout was low -- largely because people were intimidated by the system of voting. Moi. While strengthening his political power and enhancing his personal wealth, Mr. Moi has left the Kenyan military relatively untouched. By African standards, the army is quite small -- about 20,000 for a population of 25 million -- and quite professional, Western military experts say. Recruitment is heaviest among Mr. Moi's Kalenjin tribe, but promotions appear to be largely based on merit, the experts say. How Mr. Moi is going to deal with the extraordinary pressures that are cascading in on him is not clear. His decision last week to arrest 12 opposition figures and to send riot police with tear gas and truncheons to stop several thousand people from reaching an opposition rally angered already disaffected Western donors and strengthened a disorganized opposition. The United States and Germany were further antagonized by the Kenyan Government's accusations that their embassies here had tried to take opposition leaders to the rally in embassy cars. Germany recalled its Ambassador. The American Ambassador, Smith Hempstone, called the allegations "lies." The current Foreign Minister, Wilson Ndolo Aya, , called the outspoken Mr. Hempstone a "racist." As the political atmosphere has become more charged, the economic situation continues to deteriorate. Rural farmers are complaining about inflation and openly blaming the Government. In the cities, unemployment "is soon going to become a threatening problem of security," Mr. Nyachae warned. Last week, The Weekly Review, a magazine that has been supportive of Mr. Moi, talked about the need to "manage change," a concept that it seemed to suggest was out of Mr. Moi's grasp.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); UNITED STATES (95%); AFRICA (92%); CANADA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%); JAPAN (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%); FRANCE (73%); GERMANY (71%);
TEXT: The United States and other aid-donor nations told Kenya today to introduce political and economic reforms and improvements in human rights or face major cuts in aid in six months. The warning to the Government of President Daniel arap Moi, which has been widely accused of corruption and political repression, amounted to a rare, publicly acknowledged intervention by aid donors into the domestic political affairs of a developing nation. Governments and international lending institutions that give foreign aid usually link aid strictly to economic reforms, although political motivations are often seen behind aid programs. The talks took place as Mr. Moi came under growing political pressure, largely as a result of a public judicial inquiry into the 1990 slaying of Kenya's Foreign Minister, an opponent of corruption. As officials met here, Mr. Moi today ordered the arrest of two close associates who have been linked to the killing. However, Mr. Moi also suspended the public inquiry. [Page A9.] "We sent a very strong message," said John R. Westley, a member of the American delegation and head of the Nairobi office of the Agency for International Development. "I don't think it's ever happened before -- no performance, no money in certain areas." The 12 donor governments, which include Britain, Canada, France, Germany and Japan, criticized what they called the Moi Government's misuse of public funds. They also called for respect for human rights and backed opposition demands for greater pluralism in the one-party state. The donor Governments said that while Kenya would continue to receive aid, they were refraining from their annual practice of making specific pledges of assistance. Instead, they imposed a stern, six-month probation period on the East African nation, linking full aid to reforms and improvements in human rights. $800 Million a Year Donor nations and international institutions like the World Bank have given Kenya about $800 million in development aid over each of the past two years -- a figure equal to perhaps a third of the Kenyan Government's annual budget, although not all aid counts as Government budget revenue. This fiscal year, Washington plans to grant $48 million in aid for agriculture and other economic programs, but American officials say that aid next year could be less that half that level unless reforms are forthcoming. Kenya has long been one of the largest recipients of aid in Africa south of the Sahara because in the past the former British colony was a bright spot for economic development and political freedom in Africa. But in recent months aid donors have reconsidered their aid to Kenya as repression has grown and economic policies have stumbled. Foreign aid is considered vital to the economically struggling country of 29 million people, which has one of the highest population growth rates in the world. In recent years the assistance has helped Kenya compensate for its chronically large external payments deficit, which in 1990 amounted to $476 million. Over the past month, the Moi Government has arrested top opposition figures and used guns and batons to break up a pro-democracy march. Mr. Moi and close associates of his in the Government are widely believed to have become wealthy men over the years. Arrest of Two Colleagues Two of Mr. Moi's closest associates, former Energy Minister Nicholas Biwott and and Hezekiah Oyugi, a former head of internal security, last week were publicly named in the Kenyan judicial inquiry as prime suspects in the slaying of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko, who was reportedly investigating high-level corruption. Toward the end of today's meeting, delegates learned that the two men were arrested today. In their communique, the donor nations said, "Delegates underlined that good government is a prerequisite for equitable economic development and would therefore be a major factor influencing aid allocations." With economic growth slowing and inflation climbing, the donor nations called for slashing the budget deficit, reforming the bloated civil service and privatizing many state enterprises. They also called on Nairobi to reduce capital flight and increase private sector confidence. Consultation in Six Months The donor nations said that in six months they would consult again about aid to Kenya. Several delegates said they were optimistic that President Moi, facing strong pressure at home and abroad, had finally become serious about political and economic reform. "What Kenya's partners were saying was we would like Kenya to maintain its leadership position," said Callisto Madavo, director of the World Bank's Eastern Africa Department. "We think that some of these issues that came up in the recent past could undermine that leadership. The donors are not walking away from Kenya. What the donors are saying is that a number of areas must be addressed." Kenya's Vice President and Finance Minister, George Saitoti, said he was "very much satisfied" by the meeting, commenting that it was helpful to have a frank exchange between donor nations and Kenyan officials about its policies and problems. He also said that he was heartened that the donor nations said they would continue granting aid to his nation, even though they threatened cuts in aid. Mr. Saitoti is among the officials named in the Kenyan judicial inquiry as having demanded bribes from foreign companies seeking business in the country. At a news conference, Vice President Saitoti repeatedly asserted that his Government was serious about introducing a multi-party system and rooting out corruption. "The basic point is Kenya is not opposed to transformation to a multiparty system," he said. Later he added that it was clear that the donors "want us to speed up the reforms on the political front and economic front."

COUNTRY: KENYA (97%); FRANCE (94%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%);
TEXT: Kenyan police today arrested a powerful former cabinet minister and an ex-security chief for questioning in the slaying last year of the country's popular foreign minister, and President Daniel arap Moi abruptly disbanded the independent commission that was investigating the slaying. The dramatic arrests, however, were not enough to persuade Kenya's main international aid donors to keep the country's badly needed foreign assistance flowing. At a meeting in Paris, the World Bank today suspended aid to Kenya for the next six months and warned Moi's government that any further support would be contingent on progress toward democracy and the eradication of corruption. After two days of meetings in Paris between Western financial officials and a Kenyan delegation to review aid requests for the coming year, the World Bank issued a declaration saying that "levels of aid for Kenya depend on clear progress in implementing economic and social reform." In Nairobi, the arrest of Nicholas Biwott, who was fired last week from his position as industry minister, and Hezekiah Oyugi, a former chief of internal security, marked the latest chapter in a bizarre case involving high-level corruption, a brutal killing and allegations of a government-wide coverup. Until Biwott was fired last week, after being named as a prime suspect in the murder, he had been considered one of the most politically and financially powerful men in Kenya. Three others also were arrested, including two provincial officials and a lawyer for Oyugi. None of the five had been formally charged, officials said tonight. The investigation into the February 1990 killing of foreign minister Robert Ouko has embroiled Moi's government in a growing political scandal, at a time when the ruling party already faces increasing pressures from democracy advocates at home and from Kenya's international aid donors abroad. The Ouko case has taken on soap opera dimensions in Kenya, with the three English-language newspapers printing daily transcripts of the proceedings. One newspaper, the Nation, printed a special afternoon edition to report today's arrests and Moi's move to disband the commission. The commission had become a serious source of embarrassment for the government as witnesses -- including retired Scotland Yard detective John Troon, who investigated the case -- testified to high-level corruption and the involvement of senior Kenyan officials in the slaying and coverup. Diplomats and pro-democracy opposition leaders said the arrests seemed aimed at assuaging key World Bank aid donors meeting this week in Paris, who had made political reforms and an end to high-level corruption two of their main demands for continuing economic assistance to Kenya. Ouko had been investigating government corruption at the time his body was found shot and burned in a field near his home in western Kenya. The unsolved case had come to symbolize for many the government's inability or unwillingness to tackle the problem of widespread graft. But shortly after the arrests were announced, the World Bank announced the suspension of Kenya's aid payments. Kenya's foreign aid is currently about $ 900 million, making it the country's main source of foreign exchange, well ahead of tourism receipts and revenues from coffee and tea exports. In its statement today, the World Bank said Western governments "underlined the importance of the rule of law and respect for human rights, notably the basic freedoms of expression and assembly." The Western countries refused to make commitments for any aid in 1992 but noted that Kenya's case would be reviewed in six months to see if any new reforms would merit the restoration of assistance. Western economists here said the aid cutoff is likely to have an immediate and dramatic impact because those funds constitute a major portion of the government's operating budget. In addition, Kenya owes its foreign creditors $ 5.4 billion, according to World Bank figures. In ordering the arrests, Moi also seemed to be trying to repair the damage to his government's credibility caused by Ouko's killing. One diplomat said the move might amount to a "house cleaning" attempt by Moi before he calls for new elections sometime next spring. Others said the president may have been trying to slow the momentum of the scandal. Opposition leaders quickly dismissed the arrests as a "gimmick," saying Moi wanted to deflect attention from the fact that he was disbanding the investigating commission before its probe was complete. By closing down the commission and turning the matter over to the police, the critics said, Moi has guaranteed that the investigation will stop at Biwott and Oyugi and not reach higher into the embattled Kenyan government. "The investigation has been hijacked," said the Rev. Timothy Njoya, a leader of the democracy movement here. "We have no faith or confidence in the police."
