"To make matters worse, the international donor community and multilateral agencies -- the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund -- continue to insist on economic policy reforms which have manifestly failed to generate recovery, while imposing huge social costs." In a speech last May, James Gustave Speth, director of the United Nations Development Program, argued that it was in developed nations' self-interest to help Africa. If they do not, he said, disease, poverty and environmental degradation in Africa will ensure that "our own shores" will be affected by "illegal aliens, refugees, drugs, crime" and other problems from Africa. But he also noted that most nations' attention is focused elsewhere. Russia, once a looming military presence in the Horn of Africa and patron of leftist regimes from Ethiopia to Mozambique, has all but withdrawn from the continent. The United States, which was heavily engaged in Africa as a counterweight to the Soviets, has "no strategic interests in Africa," according to Pentagon doctrine. Among the industrialized nations, the United States ranks last in percentage of gross national product devoted to African aid. Except for diplomatic involvement, Britain, Belgium and Portugal mostly disappeared from Africa when they surrendered their colonies there. Japanese investment is minimal. Among the major powers, only France remains actively committed in Africa, with troops in seven countries, extensive economic and political ties and effective control of the currency of its former colonies in West Africa. "We have intervened in Africa whenever an unacceptable situation had to be remedied," former French president Valery Giscard d'Estaing once said -- a comment that applied perfectly to the recent, two-month French military intervention in Rwanda. So thin is U.S. political and economic interest in Africa that one of the panels at a recent White House conference on Africa was devoted to the subject of "constituency building" -- how to get more people to care. Donald McHenry, former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said the United States has "a general responsibility [for Africa] in the interests of mankind, and given the melting pot nature of our society it carries something of a special interest as the origin of 10 or 12 percent of our population." But McHenry suggested that direct U.S. interest in Africa is limited to heading off disasters such as the Rwandan refugee crisis, because "when disaster occurs, man-made or nature, we are going to end up paying for some of it." U.S. policy makers and some independent analysts say South Africa is capable of vigorous economic growth that will also contribute to the development of its neighbors. But "whereas South Africa and the southern African region increasingly command our attention for both economic and political reasons, much of the rest of the continent is becoming more marginal in terms of U.S. national interest priorities," said Walter H. Kansteiner, White House Africa policy director in the Bush administration. Western thinking about sub-Saharan Africa appears generally divided along the lines of optimism vs. pessimism. The optimists see a new generation of realistic African leaders adopting economic and political reforms that could lead to peace and prosperity. They also see indigenous peace and human rights movements increasingly asserting themselves and putting pressure on leaders to abandon repressive policies. The pessimists see an accelerating slide into the chaos and anarchy tearing apart Somalia, Rwanda, Sudan, Liberia and Angola. In both views, what happens to Africa in the coming decade is largely up to the Africans, not to the foreign powers that for decades manipulated Africa for their own ends. The most pessimistic prospect was offered by Robert D. Kaplan in an apocalyptic article in the February issue of Atlantic Monthly, "The Coming Anarchy." According to Kaplan, overpopulation, crime, corruption and the ready availability of weapons will doom virtually all of West Africa to lapse into malarial anarchy. He predicted a breakdown of civilization as "foreign embassies are shut down, states collapse, and contact with the outside world takes place through dangerous, disease-ridden coastal trading posts." Envisioning a lawless era in which the writ of government will not extend to the African interior, Kaplan said Africa "faces cataclysms that could make the Ethiopian and Somalian famines pale in comparison." President Clinton and each of his senior foreign policy advisers have read Kaplan's article, a White House official said recently. According to White House National Security Adviser Anthony Lake, an Africa specialist, the challenge facing the outside world is figuring out how to help Africa avoid the nightmare predicted by Kaplan and achieve instead "a culture of tolerance, a flowering of civil society and the protection of human dignity throughout the continent." But the tools available to achieve that lofty goal do not include an increase in direct U.S. aid, which is holding steady at about $ 800 million a year, much of it directed at South Africa. Instead, U.S. policy envisions a new political and economic climate in Africa that will encourage indigenous development and foreign investment. Some analysts dismiss that as pie in the sky. But others -- including the U.N. Development Program's Speth and Michael Clough, Africa policy specialist at the Council on Foreign Relations -- argue that U.S. and other foreign aid in the past has done more harm than good as Africans squandered it on extravagant projects and arms purchases. Clough, who was Africa issues director for the Clinton transition team, wrote in his book "Free at Last?" that the bulk of U.S. assistance to Africa during the Cold War went to six countries: Ethiopia, Kenya, Liberia, Somalia, Sudan and Zaire. "By any standard, this is not a list of African success stories," he wrote. Clough said in an interview that the argument over aid funding levels is "absurd" because amounts available will never be enough to make a significant difference. That being the case, he said the Clinton administration's evolving long-term approach, stressing human rights and free markets to stimulate economic growth and thus head off disasters such as the one in Somalia, "makes sense in Africa." But he questioned whether it can succeed, because "there is very little political payoff" in Africa and "nobody except Lake cares about Africa anyway." Optimists about Africa said in interviews that it is necessary to distinguish between failed states such as Somalia and old-fashioned African "big man" dictatorships such as Togo on the one hand and the more open, stable countries with new pragmatic rulers on the other. This list includes Benin, Eritrea, Mali, Zambia and Uganda as well as South Africa. Africans "want the same things everybody else wants," said Vivian Lowery Derryck, president of the African American Institute in New York, and they are throwing their support to leaders and movements that hold the promise of delivering. She predicted that Sudan and possibly Zaire will break apart, but she said there are several countries where "pragmatic" leaders have come to power and where it is reasonable for foreigners to consider investing. "There is a new class of African business people emerging who are not victims of the past," said Frank Savage, a prominent African-American financier whose Alliance Capital Corp. has set up an Africa investment fund. "They were born after independence. All they want now is a higher standard of living." "You would be amazed at how many countries have adopted structural adjustments" that make them economically attractive, he said. "It may still be a little early for a lot of investors, but it's time to look at countries that may be investor-friendly," such as Ghana, he said. Savage said the worldwide "commodity cycle" is favorable to Africa as prices rise in a general economic recovery. A test of his evaluation, and of Africa's interest for potential investors, is scheduled for mid-October, when a major international oil and gas conference assembles in Cape Town, South Africa. This event -- of a type common in Houston, London and Singapore but virtually unknown in Africa -- will bring together oil and gas executives and government officials from all across Africa to assess the natural gas potential of Mozambique, offshore oil exploration in Cameroon, recent natural gas discoveries in Namibia and a score of similar issues. Invitations to this conference from its sponsor, the authoritative trade journal Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, stress that "many African nations are actively promoting investment through extensive deregulation, privatization and divestment policies." That is just what the Clinton administration likes to hear, but often does not. "The policies this administration supports are not necessarily supported by African leaders," an administration official said. "Democracy, open markets, the development of indigenous human rights groups, rural empowerment -- these are not necessarily what African leaders want. They imply political development." But Africans increasingly understand the need for popular participation in political and economic life, said Roble Olhaye, Djibouti's ambassador to the United Nations. "They know corruption, nepotism, waste and human rights abuses have to go," he said in an interview. "That is the order of the day."

COUNTRY: AFRICA (96%); COTE D'IVOIRE (93%); NIGERIA (93%); SENEGAL (79%);
TEXT: For 30 years, the African Development Bank has dispensed advice and lent money in volumes that place it second only to the World Bank among international lenders for Africa's economic development. But the World Bank's effectiveness has been questioned lately in the face of sharp declines in the economies of many African countries. And as the African Development Bank has prepared for the election of a new president, bitter exchanges over allegations of corruption have nearly overshadowed a critical debate over lending policy. Futhermore, African members of the bank and the industrial nations that provide 35 percent of its $24 billion capital are in a tense debate over the need to restructure the bank's approach to lending. Although the corruption allegation have been simmering for months, they only became public when the departing president, Babacar Ndiaye of Senegal, circulated a memorandum last week to the governors, the top supervisory body, charging shady dealings by bank directors. In his memo, Mr. Ndiaye portrayed many of the 18 directors as more concerned with their own finances and perquisites than with African development. He contended that many spend their time flying around the world with their families on "disguised missions" at the bank's expense, conducting private business while collecting fat indemnities for travel and health care, and he said some launder money from their personal enterprises through the bank. Mr. Ndiaye also criticized their activities at the headquarters in Abidjan, a striking three-winged skyscraper that is the anchor of this city's skyline. Though he did not identify which of the directors, 12 Africans and 6 Westerners, he considered guilty of such practices, insiders say the allegation involved both African and non-African board members. Mr. Ndiaye's assertions drew a blistering written rebuke from the board, which saw them as "worrisome changes in the behavior" of an embittered president. The board said his actions would have a "destabilizing effect on the institution." The bank planned to choose Mr. Ndiaye's successor on Thursday in an election in Abuja, the capital of Nigeria [Five rounds of voting on Thursday ended in a stalemate, with no candidate obtaining a majority, Reuters reported from Abuja.] Beyond the trading of accustions looms a broader debate over lending policies that may determine whether the bank can remain an important player in the continent's finances. The bank's members are in arrears for $600 million in loan repayments, which critics say is largely due to loans for poorly conceived and supervised projects. This unpaid debt, and the insolvency of other countries, has left only 14 of the 52 African member states eligible to borrow under current policies. African member have said an increase in capital is vital to meet the needs of the world's poorest continent. But donor countries say they will provide more money only if they are given more say in management. The United States, which provides 6 percent of the bank's capital, more than any other non-African member, supports that position. The bank, which provides loans at both commerical and subsidized rates to African member countries, was founded in 1963 by 23 nations. Since 1966, it has lent over $29 billion. Many Africans already feel marginalized in a world where everything from interest rates to commodity prices are determined in faraway financial capitals. But the donor nations say the bank can draw on the outside support it needs only if it becomes more rigorous in its management. "The Western powers do not want the African members of the A.D.B. to decide on their own who should get a loan from the bank," said B.O. Tonwe, the director from Nigeria, the largest African shareholder. "That is the main struggle going on here." Mr. Tonwe said donors were increasingly using their financial influence to impose political criteria on lending, penalizing countries like his own, which have fallen out of favor internationally over questions of democracy and human rights. [Angered by Nigeria's refusal to withdraw its candidate from the election for a new president, donor nations agreed after votes Thursday in Abuja to suspend talks on a much delayed replenishment of funds for subsidized loans, Reuters reported. The Nigerian had been running third, with 19 percent of the vote.] But Western members say good management, not politics, has guided their actions. One foreign director, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said bank executives were often more concerned about directing money toward their own countries than in examining projects for their return on investment.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (92%); LATIN AMERICA (79%); ARGENTINA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); EUROPE (79%); HAITI (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (72%); EASTERN EUROPE (57%); FRANCE (56%);
TEXT: WITH THE arrival of James D. Wolfensohn this month, the World Bank will have at its head a man well-equipped to deal with what is arguably the most destructive economic condition hurting low- and middle-income countries -- flight capital. I'm talking about money that moves out of developing and transitional economies into Western bank accounts by means illegal or undocumented. This is not the same as Western speculative capital that flows in and out of emerging markets. That's perfectly legal. Flight capital is hot money from African, Latin American, eastern European and former Soviet countries surreptitiously passing by collusive and illicit means into New York, Miami, London, Paris, Hamburg and Swiss banks. In the process, it distorts free trade, negates foreign aid, worsens inflation, diminishes tax revenues, undermines structural adjustment, delays and imperils democracy and firmly entrenches poverty. Shouldn't a situation that has bled hundreds of billions of dollars, perhaps a half-trillion, from the world's poor receive diligent attention? Theoretically, yes, but how do you solve a problem that most political and economic leaders scarcely want to admit exists? Published financial statistics provide no reliable measure of flight capital, but privately conducted analyses indicate that its magnitude is on the order of $ 50 billion to $ 80 billion annually.  This exceeds the yearly total of foreign aid appropriations of Western governments. Furthermore, a dollar remaining in a developing economy is easily worth several dollars of external assistance. If more money comes out as flight capital than is allocated as foreign aid, and if the deleterious impact of flight capital is a multiple of sums spent on foreign aid, then something is very wrong with the way we are dealing with development issues. Flight capital has impoverished many countries and virtually destroyed others. Zaire has been squeezed back into the 19th century through the disappearance from official coffers of billions of dollars in mineral revenues and external aid. Argentina has experienced flight capital since the 1800s. South Africa suffered from a large flow of flight capital over the past decade, as political violence grew and majority rule approached. Russia has exported so much flight capital -- an estimated $ 50 billion over five years -- that it is difficult to find much evidence of the funds thus far provided by the West. Between Papa Doc, Baby Doc and the generals, Haiti has been bled dry. The list goes on. There are three principal means by which flight capital moves across borders. Black market currency deals coupled with petty smuggling is the smaller part of the problem. Official misappropriation, that is, theft by government officers is a bigger problem. When a dictator, for example Zaire's Mobutu, wants to stash money overseas, he may simply direct the central bank to effect the transfer, usually out of an offshore reserves account. A corrupt leader without dictatorial powers may use a middleman to negotiate the transaction, usually in return for some official concession or contract. Both result in depletion of the country's external reserves, enhancement of the leaders' foreign wealth -- and no questions asked by recipient Western financial institutions. At roughly $ 10 billion to $ 20 billion annually, official misappropriation is not insignificant, and this figure does not include any of the oil-rich kingdoms and sultanates where what is and isn't flight capital is rather moot. The most widely used but deeply concealed means of generating flight capital, however, is trade mispricing, a common element in international transactions. It is particularly preferred in the private sector because it is invisible and tax free. Typically, the owner or manager of a business conspires with the overseas seller of imports or buyer of exports to include an undocumented commission ("kickback," "tangenti," "dessous-de-table") on the transaction, and the excess funds generated are deposited into an overseas bank account. For example, most traders dealing with Central and South America know that, more often than not, bananas come out with invoices showing less than the real price while linerboard to manufacture export cartons goes in over-invoiced. And, of course, mispricing and misappropriation frequently come together, as with a $ 7 million shipment of U.S. wheat that ended up costing Ivory Coast $ 70 million. Manipulation of trade values occurs on some 30 to 60 percent of import and export transactions of many countries, especially in Latin America and Africa. Commission levels commonly range from 5 to 15 percent. Diversion of 100 percent of the proceeds of some exports out of Russia and other republics of the former Soviet Union is especially troubling to these economies at the present time. Drainage out of poorer countries and transitional economies by the mechanism of trade mispricing alone is on the order of $ 30 billion to $ 50 billion annually. For years, World Bank and IMF officials have sold economic reform programs to poorer countries using the argument, among others, that with correct economic policies flight capital accumulated overseas will in reasonable measure flow back. To the contrary, it is evident that, once out, flight capital rarely returns. The only significant exception is Mexico, largely because it is the only Third World country bordering on a major industrialized democracy. One big reason why few people want to deal with flight capital is that blame lies with both those who generate it and those who solicit and receive it. Flight capital is cooperation among the world's powerful for exploitation of the world's weak. The fact is that for every illegal dollar, pound, franc or mark that moves out of poorer countries, there is a Western trader, manufacturer or financier that directly or indirectly facilitates its receipt. How, then, is it possible to curtail this problem, when many vested interests in richer and poorer countries prefer the status quo? Five reforms would help to ground flight capital: Require the World Bank and IMF -- and urge other international institutions and aid donors -- to strengthen provisions in their own contracts to make flight capital arising from multilateral and bilateral funding onerous and improbable. This will set a tone that will eventually affect private contracts as well. Require countries receiving World Bank and IMF funding to adopt measures that maximize the transparency of trade transactions, such as trade inspection services coupled with uncomplicated buyer/seller declarations. Removing the invisibility of kickbacks removes most kickbacks. Encourage multinational corporations worldwide to adopt policies barring over- and under-invoicing. Securing orders at the expense of the poor forestalls market growth and is in the long term self-defeating. Influence Western bankers -- at the minimum -- to cease soliciting flight capital from foreign countries. Leave bank secrecy laws in place but forego abetting the outflow of money contrary to most nations' laws. Urge Western governments -- with the United States taking the lead -- to combat official misappropriations by more readily freezing the assets of corrupt leaders in or out of office. By contrast to the rest of the developing world, the East Asian private sector has -- for reasons both civic and cultural -- participated far less frequently in illegal transfers of money into Western bank accounts. The Asian decision to keep money at home or in investments that bring profits home has given birth to sound economic policies that protect and multiply retained wealth. While trickle-down economics is at work in Asia, however, trickle-out economics is at work elsewhere. Unfortunately, the East Asian model is not at this time transferable to Africa, Latin America and former communist states. And a disservice is done to other countries by blithely ignoring that flight capital is an overarching reality for much of the globe. Addressing this problem in a sustained manner can correct a serious distortion in the global economy, maximize the benefit of declining foreign aid expenditures and within a reasonable time reverse the course of poverty's growth. Raymond Baker, director of Overecho Associates, has worked extensively on development issues in Latin America, Asia and Africa.

COUNTRY: SOUTH AFRICA (99%); AFRICA (98%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); EGYPT (88%); GHANA (79%); BURKINA FASO (79%); KENYA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); MALI (79%); GUINEA (79%); FRANCE (75%);
TEXT: At the turn of the century, Cecil Rhodes, one of this country's early statesmen-tycoons, dreamed of building a railroad from Cape Town to Cairo. He never realized his vision. Succeeding where Rhodes fell short, a South African entrepreneur, Hans Harwinkels, is linking the far corners of the continent with microwave signals instead of steel. In little more than two years, he has built a pay-for-view satellite-television empire whose programming is beamed from South Africa to Egypt and 40 countries in between. "African countries have been liberalizing their markets, and this has allowed us to push north, east and west with pretty good speed," said Mr. Harwinkels, chief executive officer of the entertainment broadcaster Multichoice. Multichoice has a lot of company. With apartheid dead, South Africa's pent-up entrepreneurial energy is exploding all over Africa. South African industry is rushing in to build railroads in Zaire, sink mines in Ghana, put up hotels in Kenya and provide the entire continent with enough jets and telephone lines to help revitalize its sagging economy. South African trade with the rest of Africa is booming, with exports up 50 percent in two years to nearly $2.5 billion in 1994 and imports tripling to $664 million from $220 million. South Africa's expanding presence is displacing much of the economic and cultural influence long wielded by France and the United States. Economists say the trend is accelerating, with important implications for the future of a continent that many in the West have written off as hopelessly poor and corrupt. "Our politicians may not have fully grasped this, but for our business people it is fully realized that the rest of Africa is our hinterland," said Erich Leistner, an economist at the Africa Institute in Pretoria, a private research group. "Already, 25 percent of our manufactured goods go to our neighbors. We are going to become more and more involved, from railways to airlines, from mining and water supply to power, and the politics will just have to follow." To some, it is ironic that post-apartheid South Africa's impact on the rest of the continent is more economic than political. When President Nelson Mandela took power last year, some supporters abroad expected him to become a bold force for political change, denouncing human-rights abuses and promoting democratic movements elsewhere in Africa. Instead, he has kept a low profile, making it clear South Africa does not want to play big brother to its neighbors. The emissaries of South African capitalism, by contrast, seem to be everywhere. Representatives of South Africa's huge mining industry are crowding the hotels of West African capitals in a race to tap rich new mineral markets. The mining companies are prospecting for deposits and contracts in Zaire, Burkina Faso, Guinea, Mali and several other countries in West Africa. Just last month, for example, the Johannesburg Consolidated Investment Company announced it was teaming up with a Ghanaian mining company to take over a formerly Soviet-run gold, silver and platinum mine at Kalana, in southern Mali. Companies in other industries are also extending their reach: *South African hotel companies are investing in tourism ventures in Kenya, Tanzania and other East African countries. Protea Hotels has taken over ownership or management of 82 hotels in 11 countries as far afield as Tanzania and Egypt. "We began discussions in some of these countries as long as six years ago, when there was still a lot of distrust of us," said Otto Stehlik, executive chairman of the company. "Now we have a good laugh about the way we talked to each other." *South African Airways has begun hiring out management, maintenance and supply services to airlines in Tanzania and Uganda and has opened discussions with others in Malawi, Namibia and Zambia. And South African airplane brokers are selling used aircraft all over the continent to African carriers too poor to buy new jets. *South African telephone companies are bidding to overhaul national networks with new fiber optic lines or cellular systems. NZ Telecoms Ltd. has been modernizing phone services in Botswana, for example, and Telkom is prospecting for contracts in several countries. *The electricity company Eskom is rehabilitating the power grids of Mozambique, Angola and Lesotho, and has plans to integrate them with South Africa's electrical network. *South Africa Railways is working to upgrade the ports of Beira and Maputo in Mozambique to relieve congestion in South Africa's major seaport at Durban. *South African Breweries last year bought half of Tanzania's formerly state-owned breweries and is building a bottling plant in that country. One measure of all the commercial activity is the runaway success of Air Afrique's new route linking Johannesburg and Abidjan, capital of the West African nation of the Ivory Coast. After less than a year in service, the flights have higher occupancy rates than the Abidjan-Paris or Abidjan-New York connections. Most African countries seem to be heartily welcoming South Africa's commercial invasion, coming as it does in the face of flagging interest in the West. Several governments have even begun to advertise their World Bank-mandated privatizations of state companies in South African newspapers, hoping to find bidders in the continent's most powerful economy. South African businesses take a homey approach in negotiating with African governments: though large by African standards, they argue, they are less threatening than the American and European multinationals. And their headquarters are nearby in case of trouble. "We want local partners and build joint ventures, and the word has been spreading in Africa that we are good people to do business with," said Mr. Harwinkels of Multichoice.  For France, the former colonial power that has maintained the strongest ties to the continent, all this reeks of a plot by the English-speaking business world to supplant it in Africa. The French newsletter Lettre d'Afrique recently warned of "increasingly aggressive financial, industrial and commercial competition, in particular by Anglo-Saxons and Japanese, in league with South African firms." Indeed, nowhere has South Africa's penetration of new markets in Africa been as spectacular as in French-speaking Zaire, formerly ruled by Belgium. As Western companies have withdrawn from Zaire in exasperation over its corruption and chaos, South African concerns have moved in, seeing its mineral wealth and huge needs for new roads and railways as economic stepping stones to the rest of the continent. Pointing to a map of central Africa in his office, the eyes of Jan van Deventer, South Africa's Ambassador to Zaire, light up as he speaks, Rhodes-like, of South African companies restoring the Lubumbashi-to-Kananga line in Zaire, a project under way, and of building lines linking that line with the towns of Kalemie and Kindu, a project under consideration. Taken together, these undertakings would link South Africa by modern rail with every country of the continent as far north as Tanzania, replacing costly truck routes and slow-moving lake barges. Big South African mining companies are also moving into Zaire. Since De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. got involved in a diamond-mining project known as Birim River in Ghana 14 months ago, production has soared 55 percent. Other mining companies are hoping to resuscitate Zaire's dying copper industry, once the world's largest. The Anglo American Corporation of South Africa said it was considering taking a major stake in the Tinke Fugurume copper mine in southern Zaire. And an international consortium that includes Anglo American, the Engelhard Corporation of the United States, Fimalac of France and Swipco of Switzerland is reportedly negotiating to take control of Zaire's state-owned Gecamines, once the world's largest copper and cobalt mine. South African companies are also eyeing Zaire's huge hydroelectric potential. Mr. van Deventer, the South African Ambassador, sees almost limitless opportunity in Zaire and the rest of sub-Sahara Africa. "You are talking about being able to get South African consumer goods to African markets, where there is a strong demand for them, and evacuating African minerals to South African markets, where we have considerable expertise," he said. "If you've been to Kasai you could cry to see that they don't grow much of anything in some of the best farmlands in the continent," he said. "If Zaire could get its logging industry going, we could take quite a bit of that production. But first you have to be able to get there." But for South Africa to take full advantage of opportunities like these, experts in regional affairs say, it will have to begin engaging the rest of Africa politically far more than it has done so far. Under Mr. Mandela, South Africa has shied away from peace-keeping tasks in places like Angola and Rwanda, hoping to avoid being cast in the role of savior. Critics of this approach say that as much as they can understand a desire to avoid becoming the bearer of all of Africa's burdens, Mr. Mandela should use his immense prestige to foster stability and democratic change in Africa. Of Africa's leaders, only Zimbabwe's President, Robert Mugabe, has been received here on a state visit. And earlier this year, officials in many African countries were surprised when South Africa declined to join the African Development Bank, a regional lending institution. Although President Mandela made a brief stopover in Nigeria last year to plea for the release of the jailed winner of elections there, Moshood K. Abiola, his Government has been mostly quiet about the political crisis there and in Zaire. "High-profile people like Mandela should be spending as much time in African capitals as in Europe and America," said Tom Lodge, a political scientist at the University of Witswatersrand. "At the end of the day, we are not going to get much from Washington, or Paris or London. This is where the future lies." Graph/Map: "Moving In" shows major investment projects in other African nations by South African businesses since the end of apartheid. (pg. D1)

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); AFRICA (94%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: In the world according to Nigeria's military rulers, the United States is carrying out a plot hatched long ago to destroy black Africa's most populous country. In addition, the government insists that it did not annul the June 1993 presidential election, which was to return the nation to civilian rule. And one more thing: Nigerians snared in wrongdoing abroad are not really Nigerians. They are posing as Nigerians because they long to be identified with West Africa's most powerful country. With a blitz of revisionist history, Nigeria's military has undertaken to combat international outrage after it executed nine opponents, including playwright Ken Saro-Wiwa, last month. The campaign has included a video titled "Not in Our Character," a flurry of rallies -- including a Million Man March -- and creation of a 50-man committee whose main task is to buff Nigeria's image. Those in power "engage in a total distortion of facts," said Nosa Igiebor, editor of Tell, an opposition magazine. "They portray themselves as victims, and they actually believe that. All of this is supposed to be a substitute for substantive changes." Such campaigns are nothing new to the estimated 100 million people of Nigeria. During nearly three decades in power, military rulers repeatedly have fashioned similar efforts to fight foreign critics. The most recent was the War on Indiscipline and Corruption that Gen. Sani Abacha launched after taking power in late 1993. But that effort did little to distract foreign governments and human rights groups, who continued to lambaste the regime as one of sub-Saharan Africa's most abusive and corrupt. That criticism reached a zenith last month after Abacha's Provisional Ruling Council confirmed death sentences on Saro-Wiwa and the others, convicted in connection with the slayings of four traditional leaders last year. The nine were hanged 10 days after their trial ended. Threats of sanctions that accompanied the resulting international anger goaded Nigeria into its propaganda war, the centerpiece being a huge pro-government demonstration earlier this month. Dubbed Nigeria's version of the Louis Farrakhan-led Million Man March on Washington in October, it featured hundreds of thousands of Nigerians descending on Abuja, the federal capital. Officials maintained that the march was planned by ordinary citizens, although the government arranged for the participants to fly free to the capital, provided food money and placards and promised some demonstrators up to $ 50. Many demonstrators admitted they did not comprehend their placards; some held them upside down. Nigeria has made the United States and Britain primary targets of such rallies. Nigeria's most severe Western critics, they threatened stiff sanctions and recalled their ambassadors after the executions. "America wants to control us," said Walter Ofonagoro, the minister of information and culture, during a session with foreign reporters this month. "The Cold War is over, so they think we have to obey whatever they tell us." Ofonagoro, Ivy League-educated, described a "secret trade war" that he said the United States is waging against Nigeria. As for the persistent perception that the country's military rulers annuled the 1993 vote, "The courts canceled the election," he said. The reported winner, businessman Moshood Abiola, was imprisoned. "The judge said the vote was rife with irregularities. It was not a free and fair election," said Ofonagoro. In fact, then-ruler Ibrahim Babangida, who had repeatedly pushed back the vote, wiped out the election, charging that the proceedings were a fraud. The action prompted the United States to halt aid. Nigeria's rulers also are scrambling to cleanse the image of Nigerians living abroad. In recent years, hundreds have been arrested on drug charges and for engaging in fraudulent schemes, making many countries wary of awarding them visas. But in the video "Not in Our Character," Col. Ike Nwosu suggested that there has been a mistake. "What has happened," the colonel said, "is that people want to associate themselves with being Nigerians, with the result that when they want to engage in nefarious activities they use Nigeria as a cover." The video, which purports to provide historical context for Nigeria's economic and social crises, acknowledges that the nation is far from perfect but asserts that malfeasance and corruption are "not in our character." The video blames economic woes on "internationally imposed economic policies," a slap at World Bank and International Monetary Fund efforts to help Nigeria right its economy during the 1980s. The video also assails foreign governments for criticizing Nigeria's stumbling attempts to establish democracy, calling such nations "disingenuous and dishonest." The narrator insists that it took the United States and Britain "centuries . . . to produce viable liberal democratic institutions." Ultimately, the narrator says, "most of the problems that confront Nigeria today are rooted in our colonial history." Nigeria gained its independence from Britain in 1960; the military has held power for most of the time since then. The propaganda efforts stretch down to an area of southern Nigeria known as Ogoniland, the oil-rich region of Saro-Wiwa and the others executed. Officials in Rivers state, where Ogoniland sits, have invited reporters in to investigate accusations by members of the indigenous Ogoni ethnic group. The Ogonis contend that a rush to extract oil had resulted in environmental devastation of their homeland and that they had been deprived of any economic benefits deriving from the oil production. In an interview, Col. Dauda Musa Komo, the Rivers state administrator, said the government "is not in a defensive mood. . . . We just want people to know the facts." Later he added that "military-bashing has become a fashionable thing. . . . But there is no truth in the accusation that the military [are in charge] just because they want power." Igiebor, the magazine editor, said of the government's public relations effort, "Ordinary Nigerians are not moved by these shenanigans."

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); AFRICA (93%); EASTERN AFRICA (93%); UGANDA (92%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: When President Daniel arap Moi flew to Uganda last week for talks with other East African leaders, he traveled in luxury aboard a brand-new private jet that the taxpayers of this cash-strapped country bought last month for about $50 million. As the jet lifted off from the airport, it banked over the rutted and potholed two-lane highway from Nairobi to Mombasa, Kenya's major port. A vital artery for business, the road is perhaps the most visible symbol of the dilapidated state of the country's infrastructure. On good days, the going is bumpy. On rainy days the road is impassable. Some opposition leaders and diplomats here assert that the jet and the road illustrate what is wrong with the Government's economic priorities: a longstanding tendency among politicians to let personal prestige outweigh the public interest. President Moi purchased the jet, a sleek Dutch-made Fokker, at the same time that his Government was seeking a $50 million low-interest loan from the World Bank to repair the road. Since newspapers disclosed the purchase of the jet in November, Government officials have argued that the expense is justified because in the past the President has had to take one of Kenya Airway's two jets out of service every time he travels. The airplane is one of several expenditures not listed in Kenya's budget that have jeopardized aid from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, as well as from other countries, diplomats and officials at international development banks said. The officials and diplomats, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the jet and two other budget-busting projects of questionable worth have come up during talks this week between the Government and a joint mission from the Bank and the I.M.F. The two sides are trying to hammer out a plan for economic reform that would allow the I.M.F. to release hundreds of millions of dollars in blocked aid. The stakes are high for Kenya, an economic engine for eastern Africa. Hanging in the balance are $200 million in direct aid from the I.M.F. and nearly $166 million in loans from the World Bank for roads and other infrastructure projects that are needed to attract foreign investment. The talks are also being watched by Western countries, including the United States, and several have said the I.M.F.'s decision will be a bellwether for them. Only a fraction of the $800 million donor countries pledged to Kenya in November 1994 has been disbursed because of the stalled negotiations, diplomats said. Neither the I.M.F. nor the World Bank would comment on the talks. But diplomats and people familiar with the talks say the main sticking points have been the Government's inability to stamp out official corruption and the kind of pork-barrel and prestige spending typified by the President's new airplane. Besides the jet, the Government is spending about $85 million to build an international airport at Eldoret, the heart of the President's home state in eastern Kenya. Parliament never approved the project -- the money was tucked away in a special debt service fund in this year's spending plan. It was also hidden from World Bank auditors who scrutinized the budget until a newspaper reported its existence. The Government has argued that the airport is needed because of an economic boom in the area. The growth there has been fueled in large part by flower merchants, who now truck their goods to Nairobi, over pitted roads, for air shipment to Europe. In another deal done without competitive bidding or legislative approval, the Government recently awarded a multi-million-dollar contract to a French company to manufacture identification cards. Paradoxically, the controversies over the airport and the jet come to light as Kenya has made big strides over the last three years toward improving its moribund economy. Last week, the Government suspended a score of high-ranking port officials on corruption charges. Urged by the I.M.F., it has also eliminated import licenses, squeezed the money supply and liberalized trade. As a result, interest rates are down, and the economy grew by 5 percent in 1995, after several years of stagnation. Inflation, which had hit 100 percent in 1993, stayed below 7 percent in 1995. But the population continues to grow faster than the economy, local economists said. So Kenyans, with an average annual income of $1,200, are in reality getting poorer. "It's a mixed bag," said one diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "They would not have achieved what they achieved last year if they hadn't been doing certain things right. But the question is, would they have had 8 percent growth without the corruption."

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (95%); UNITED STATES (92%); EUROPE (79%);
TEXT: When members of the Ogoni people began attacks three years ago on Royal Dutch/Shell's oilfields in Nigeria, the company appealed to the country's military Government for protection. The results, senior company officials now acknowledge, were utterly disastrous. To crush the unrest by the Ogoni, who complained of environmental damage to their territories and demanded money for the oil extracted there, Nigeria sent its notoriously brutal "mobile police" and mounted a campaign of repression that included laying waste to whole villages. Last November the military Government of Gen. Sani Abacha executed the most prominent Ogoni, Ken Saro-Wiwa, after he was found guilty of inciting a riot that led to the killing of four pro-Government chiefs. His trial was widely condemned as a sham in Europe and the United States. Now, Royal Dutch/Shell is on trial in the court of public opinion. Critics here and abroad accuse the company of colluding in the brutal oppression of local people, of polluting Ogoniland and of failing to speak out against the execution of Mr. Saro-Wiwa. Several countries, including the United States, are contemplating sanctions against Nigeria. A coalition of human rights and environmental groups is planning a worldwide boycott of Shell's gasoline and other products. Even London's Royal Geographic Society, not usually the most militant of groups, has dropped the company as a patron and returned a $60,000 donation. The Saro-Wiwa case has set off a debate reminiscent of the one over economic relations with South Africa before majority rule. Some critics of the Nigerian Government say that by refusing to cooperate with it, companies like Shell could hasten the return of democracy, or at least avoid complicity with corruption and denial of human rights. An examination of Shell's actions in Nigeria, assembled from interviews with officials of Shell and the Nigerian Government as well as dissidents and human rights groups abroad, from separate tours of Ogoniland with officials and dissidents, and from a review of official and corporate documents, brings out these broad points: *Although Mr. Saro-Wiwa has been widely portrayed as a gentle, pipe-smoking eco-martyr, he was a far more complex figure, an ambitious -- Ogoni political rivals say ruthless -- leader. His movement focused on ecological protection after calculating that this would have appeal in the West, but its main goals were to win the region autonomous power and a share of its oil revenues. *Nigeria's leaders saw the Ogoni movement as a step toward separatist war, like the fierce conflict over the Biafra region in the 1960's. The response was ferocious. One internal Nigerian Army memo outlining the Government's strategy called for the "wasting" of "leadership cadres, especially vocal individuals." *Shell gave Nigeria an important pretext for violence when it specifically asked the Government to send the mobile police -- known locally as the "kill-and-go mob." Shell paid for the transportation and salary bonuses of some troops -- ostensibly oilfield guards -- who committed the abuses. *There is evidence of significant pollution in the region in which Shell has pumped oil, but it is not as dire as portrayed by Shell's critics. A 1995 World Bank study concluded that while the pollution angers local residents, the impact on human health "is not expected to be substantial." The report added that "given the low environmental and health impacts, the actual future benefits of reducing oil pollution are low." *Shell, despite the urging of Western diplomats, declined until the last moment to lend its voice to the international campaign for clemency after Mr. Saro-Wiwa was convicted of murder in a secret and clearly rigged trial. But it is far from clear that Shell's influence would have saved the writer and fellow activists hanged with him. Shell officials fervently deny doing anything more than trying to protect company personnel and equipment and say they had no control over the actions of the Nigerian security services. They said it was not unusual for companies seeking protection to pay transportation costs and salary supplements for troops living outside their barracks. "We were not there," said Egbert Imomoh, Shell's top manager in Port Harcourt. "We don't know what happened." Shell officials say they have begun a major study to assess environmental damage in the region. But senior company officials said Shell's image had been dealt a serious blow by the events in Nigeria. "Saro-Wiwa's execution was a disaster for us," said Alan Detheridge, Shell's West African coordinator. Nonetheless, the company brushes aside suggestions that it should pull out of Nigeria, or at least freeze the $3.8 billion natural gas project it is pursuing there. The World Bank announced soon after the executions of Mr. Saro-Wiwa and eight other Ogoni activists that it would not proceed with negotiations to provide money for some of the project. "All we can pull out are our 270 expatriate staff," said Mark Moody-Stuart, one of four managing directors of Royal Dutch/Shell, in an interview in his London office. "The Nigerians can run the oil industry on their own and buy help on the market," he said, adding that "the French would replace us in a flash." The Roots Big Profits, Political Rivalry For nearly four decades Shell has been pumping oil in Nigeria's delta region, to its own enormous profit, and to the benefit of Western countries that have been ready customers. Shell produces roughly half of Nigeria's oil, a commodity that accounts for some 90 percent of the country's foreign exchange and a steady stream of revenues for Nigeria that have often been siphoned off by corrupt officials. The operations are strategically important to the company, which lacks enough reserves of high-quality crude to meet the requirements of its refineries and gasoline stations. Shell takes for itself 257,000 barrels of the 900,000 barrels the company pumps daily, giving Nigeria the rest. Nigeria is also lucrative for Shell. Nick Antill, an analyst with the London securities house Barclays de Zoete Wedd, puts Shell's Nigerian profits at $170 million to $190 million a year. "That's nearly 10 percent of total exploration and production profits, which is significant," he says. Little, if any, of these profits trickled down to Ogoniland. The Ogoni campaign against the company began in 1990 when a group of conservative traditional leaders formed the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People to win statehood, more money and better environmental protection for the Ogoni. Garrick B. Leton, a former federal minister, became the first president. Mr. Saro-Wiwa, then 49 and a successful writer and TV producer, was appointed spokesman. The movement persuaded the Government to create an Oil and Minerals Producing Areas Development Commission to channel money to these regions, with an initial promise it would get 3 percent of Nigeria's $10 billion annual oil income, later raised to 13 percent. But Mr. Saro-Wiwa favored a more confrontational approach to Shell and the federal Government, Mr. Leton said in an interview at his spacious Port Harcourt house. And the two men fell out in a dispute over tactics tinged with class rivalry and personality differences. The movement was founded by "rich traditional leaders with big houses in Port Harcourt," said Botom Mitee, a supporter of Mr. Saro-Wiwa whose brother was also tried for murder but acquitted. But Mr. Saro-Wiwa, though he had grown affluent during his years as a local administrator and trader, "identified with poor Ogoni in the villages." Against its official leaders' wishes, Mr. Saro-Wiwa set up new branches of the group under his control, including a youth wing called the National Youth Council of the Ogoni People. Leadership of this group won Mr. Saro-Wiwa a following among Ogoni impatient with traditional leaders. But Mr. Leton said the group became Mr. Saro-Wiwa's "private vigilante army." At Mr. Saro-Wiwa's urging, the movement demanded $10 billion in oil royalties and enviromental compensation from Shell and the Government in December 1992. Shell attributes Mr. Saro-Wiwa's success in gradually taking control of the movement and radicalizing it to the continuing poverty of the Ogoni, as promises of more federal aid never materialized. Most villagers still lack even electricity and piped water. For this, Shell blames the Government. In 1992 Mr. Saro-Wiwa allied the Ogoni movement with the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization, a group based in The Hague that strives to give minority groups access to international organizations. He carried his campaign to the United Nations and canvassed support in Europe and the United States. He designed an Ogoni flag, wrote a national anthem and began signing his letters as "president and spokesman of the Ogoni people." The struggle for control of the Ogoni movement between its traditional leaders and Mr. Saro-Wiwa came to a head in June 1993 over his plan to draw attention to the Ogoni plight by boycotting a Nigerian presidential election that was supposed to mark the country's return to democratic rule. Mr. Letun and other founding fathers of the movement opposed the boycott, were outvoted and resigned, allowing Mr. Saro-Wiwa to take over the group's presidency. Mr. Saro-Wiwa's campaign against Shell and the federal Government angered Nigeria's military leaders, who said they feared he was stirring up secessionist feeling in the oil-rich east, 20 years after Biafra's unsuccessful breakaway bid. The Violence Countercharges And Confusion In late 1992 Shell asked the Government to send troops to protect its operations from recurring vandalism. But dismayed by continuing vigilante attacks and the ferocious crackdown, Shell withdrew from the region in early 1993, asking the authorities to protect the installations left behind. The violence continued. Soon after Shell left, an oil pumping station here was set afire and destroyed, and the other four stations in Ogoniland were damaged. Ogoni leaders and the military accuse each other of being responsible. The blazing oil left behind a landscape of charred trees and blackened earth. Even today, nothing grows. The next year, according to an internal memo obtained by Nigerian dissidents, the company specifically asked the military Government to deploy its mobile police. What happened in those months of upheaval is a matter of deep dispute. The Government, in its official account, asserts that vigilantes with ties to Mr. Saro-Wiwa's youth group spearheaded attacks against Shell installations and murdered 40 Ogoni opponents. Mr. Saro-Wiwa's brother, Owens Saro-Wiwa, and a report by a delegation from the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization to Ogoniland in Febuary 1995 give very different accounts of these incidents. Owens Saro-Wiwa acknowledges that vigilante lawlessness existed in 1993. But he says most of the vandalism was carried out by soldiers, who stole generators and corrugated iron sheets for profit during their campaign against the Ogoni. Internal military documents show the Government hoped that by crushing the Ogoni protests it would persuade Shell to resume operations in the region. In May 1994 the commander of an internal security task force, Maj. Paul Okuntimo, wrote to his superior, Lieut. Col. Dauda Komo, the Military Administrator of Rivers State, which includes Ogoniland. The message, later obtained by dissidents, said "Shell operations still impossible unless ruthless military operations are undertaken." It called for "wasting targets cutting across communities and leadership cadres, especially vocal individuals." It detailed special allowances for the troops and suggested applying "pressure on oil companies" to help pay the costs of the operation. Owens Saro-Wiwa estimates that the attacks largely destroyed about 30 Ogoni villages, killing some 2,000 people, although there is no independent verification. By then Shell had already abandoned its operations in the region, declaring that it was unwilling to work in conditions of civil unrest and military oppression. Mr. Detheridge, Shell's West African coordinator, said the company would not return "until we have the local community on our side." On May 21, 1994, Nigerian security forces detained Ken Saro-Wiwa in the Gokana region of Ogoniland while he was campaigning for election to a constitutional conference and took him to Port Harcourt. The Government says Mr. Saro-Wiwa told his youth supporters, in a statement that included a reference to the paramount chief's meeting place: "The vultures who connived with the security forces to stop me from addressing you are now meeting at the Gbenemene's Palace Hall in Giokoo sharing money sent them by the federal Government in an effort to thwart my bid for the constitutional conference. Go to the meeting place and deal with the vultures." His supporters say Mr. Saro-Wiwa never made that statement, though they concede that he used similar language several months earlier. According to the Government, a crowd of several hundred Ogoni youths attacked the small meeting hall where chiefs and elders were gathered, massacring four with rakes, iron bars, stones and planks. Today the slain chiefs' blood is still splattered on the walls and floor, which is littered with stones and chunks of concrete used to crush their skulls. The burnt-out remains of two of their cars are slowly being swallowed up by vegetation outside. The four murdered men -- Albert T. Badey, a former secretary to the state government, Chief Edward Kobani, Chief Samuel M. Orage and Chief Theophalos B. Orage -- were on a list of 10 "vultures" that Mr. Saro-Wiwa made public the previous October because of what he said was their opposition to his agressive campaigning for Ogoni rights against Shell. The Government insists that Mr. Saro-Wiwa and eight others incited the murders. Mr. Saro-Wiwa's supporters say the killing was done by Government agents to incriminate the Ogoni leader. What few outside the Nigerian Government disagree about is that Mr. Saro-Wiwa's trial was a travesty, its outcome preordained and his sentence more a reflection of Nigeria's harsh politics than any judicial process. Mr. Saro-Wiwa was tried before a mixed military-civilian court with no right of judicial appeal. Two prosecution witnesses later retracted evidence and said the Government bribed them. Mr. Saro-Wiwa was hanged on Nov. 10. Nineteen more Ogoni are awaiting trial for the same killings. The Responsibility A Lost Cause From the Start? Critics of Shell contend the company has considerable influence over the Nigerian Government and could have done much more to prevent the hanging. The company disputes both assertions. Initially, when Mr. Saro-Wiwa was put on trial, Shell refused to intervene with the Nigerian authorities, saying "the company does not get involved in politics." In a statement issued last Oct. 31, after Mr. Saro-Wiwa was sentenced to death, Shell acknowledged that it was being pressed to use its influence to secure clemency but declined to do so, saying, "It is not for commercial organizations like Shell to interfere in the legal process of a sovereign state such as Nigeria." The company also implicitly accused Mr. Saro-Wiwa of supporting violence, saying in a statement at the time of sentencing that while the Ogoni movement claimed to be nonviolent, "this is not our experience." Shell's stance brought protests from Mr. Saro-Wiwa's friends. And on Nov. 2 the company issued a new statement that omitted the accusation of abetting violence. But it expressed no regret at the death sentences and again refused to intervene. Only after Mr. Saro-Wiwa's appeal for clemency had been denied did Shell's chief executive officer, Cor Herkstroter, fax General Abacha requesting a pardon. Mr. Detheridge insists that Shell's relationship with Nigeria has to be based on business considerations, not political ones. "We can offer advice and we can point out the consequences of an action," he said. "But we do not lecture or try to give orders because we do not interfere in politics and government." Owens Saro-Wiwa says he met three times during the trial with Brian Anderson, Shell's top executive in Nigeria. He quoted Mr. Anderson as saying it would be "difficult but not impossible" to get his brother freed, provided the Ogoni movement called off its campaign against the company. But he said his brother refused this offer, replying that the campaign against Shell would end once he was free and the company agreed to negotiate with the movement. Mr. Anderson then broke off contact with him, Owens Saro-Wiwa says. In a videotaped interview issued by Shell, Mr. Anderson denies ever having made such an offer, but confirms that he met with the condemned man's brother. Britain and the United States privately urged Shell to help save Mr. Saro-Wiwa. Mr. Moody-Stewart of Shell said, "Of course we pointed out to Nigerians the risk of sanctions." On Nov. 8, the day General Abacha rejected Mr. Saro-Wiwa's clemency plea, President Clinton's special envoy to Nigeria, Ambassador Donald T. McHenry, urged executives of American companies with interests in Nigeria to apply one form of leverage that he thought might work: to explain to Nigeria's leaders that carrying out the executions could invite international sanctions. While Mr. McHenry says he does not know whether the companies followed his advice, some of them, including the American oil companies Mobil and Chevron, say they did warn their partners about the international repercussions of proceeding with the hangings. American and British diplomats in Lagos as well as a senior Nigerian diplomat said the campaign to save Mr. Saro-Wiwa never had much chance. The military, they said, was adamantly unwilling to bow to foreign pressure a second time so soon after General Abacha spared the former head of state Olusegun Obasanjo from execution for conspiracy in May. "The military are a macho bunch," said the Nigerian diplomat. "They couldn't give way a second time. The two incidents were too close in time. If they had been further apart we might have saved him." The Pollution Low Standards, A Few Regrets Sitting in his comfortable top-floor office at Shell Center on the south bank of the River Thames with 17th-century naval paintings on the wall and a view of the Houses of Parliament, Mr. Moody-Stuart said he was not sure whether anything could have been done to avert the hanging. But he does says the whole crisis in Ogoniland could have been avoided. "What I regret is that we did not launch our Niger River Delta Environmental Survey six or seven years ago," he said. He added that if there had been an agreed analysis and action program when the Ogoni movement was founded, "it would have taken a lot of heat out of Ken Saro-Wiwa's campaign." Shell is now setting up such a commission, at a cost of $4.5 million, to assess the delta's environmental needs. But the project is off to a shaky start. In November Prof. Claude Ake, a representative of the delta communities, resigned in protest at the executions and because he doubts the commission's impartiality. Ogoni activists like to describe how, after four decades of oil pumping, their 400-square-mile ancestral land is host to 96 oil wells and five big pumping stations, where vast quantities of natural gas are burned 24 hours a day, dirtying the air and lighting up the countryside. They complain of leaky oil pipes crisscrossing their land and hindering farming. They complain, too, of frequent oil spills that destroy crops and pollute the creeks where the Ogoni fish. While calling this an exaggerated picture, Shell concedes that environmental standards at its oilfields in the Niger delta are lower than in Europe or America. "It's a question of priorities," said Dick van den Broek. "Nigeria is a poor country. How much should it spend on enviromental protection?" As majority partner, the Nigerian Government must pay 55 percent of all environmental spending, Shell points out, and it has been reluctant to sacrifice profits for costly environmental protection. Mr. Saro-Wiwa indicated a keen awareness of the international political appeal of environmental issues in his last book, "A Month and a Day: A Detention Diary," saying of a visit to America: "What that trip did was to convince me that the environment would have to be a strong plank on which to base the burgeoning Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People." Neither Shell nor the Nigerian Government has conducted a comprehensive environmental impact study of its operations in Ogoniland or elsewhere in the Niger delta. A 1995 World Bank study, "Defining an Environmental Strategy for the Niger Delta," concludes that while the oil industry has caused environmental damage, "oil pollution by itself is of moderate priority when compared with the full spectrum of environmental problems in the Niger Delta." Many of these, it says, stem from a fourfold population rise since 1958. The study cited oil leaks into the delta waters, saying they indicate "poor or no treatment of effluents" by Shell and other oil companies. Many Ogoni leaders say their main complaint is poverty. "Backwardness is what is wrong with us," says Charles Kpakol, chairman of the Gokana local government council, one of three Ogoni regional authorities. While appointed by the Government and opposed to Mr. Saro-Wiwa's Ogoni movement, he is still critical of the federal Government for spending too little in Ogoniland. A chart on Tuesday with an article about accusations that Royal Dutch/ Shell had condoned a Nigerian Government crackdown against members of the Ogoni people misstated the volume of Nigeria's oil production. It is 1.8 million barrels a day, not 1.8 billion.  An article on Feb. 13 about the role of Royal Dutch/Shell in Nigeria misstated actions of the Royal Geographical Society in London. While some of its members urged the society in January to sever its links to Shell as a corporate patron, the society has not broken ties or returned any Shell donations. COUNTRY: BENIN (96%); AFRICA (96%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); SOUTH AFRICA (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); MADAGASCAR (79%);
TEXT: COTONOU, Benin, March 1 Wherever President Nicephore D. Soglo has gone the last few days, whether pressing the flesh in roadside campaign stops or dancing briefly during a festival in the coastal city of Ouidah, he has been eagerly greeted by supporters with cries of "five more years." But what makes Mr. Soglo's run for re-election extraordinary in a continent where 18 or more national elections will be held this year -- the most since the dawn of African independence from European colonialism nearly 40 years ago -- is not its infectious, feel-good atmosphere. Instead, in contrast to scores of rigged presidential votes on this continent since the late 1950's, no one here is sure what the final outcome of Sunday's election will be. In fact, no one knows whether the incumbent, who faces six rival candidates, will even survive the first round. If Mr. Soglo were to lose, it would be virtually the first time a sitting president has lost power at the ballot box in sub-Saharan Africa, other than the historic election that ended white minority rule in South Africa in 1994. In countries like Central African Republic, Madagascar and Congo, sitting presidents lost elections only after being stripped of most of their powers. That power is truly at stake is not the only novelty here either. In a continent long bedeviled by ethnic rivalries, Benin has been able to put them aside. Instead, the campaign has focused to a great degree on issues that would seem more familiar to Westerners: The candidates have debated the role of the state in shaping the economy, how much should be spent for social services, and the appropriate role for the president's family in the life of the nation. "They are all running on fairly straightforward questions," one Western diplomat said. "Privatize, don't privatize, more of this, less of that. It is really rather remarkably about the issues." For its size, this tiny country of 5.5 million people has had a striking record of setting examples for its far larger neighbors. And many observers from both the outside world and elsewhere in West Africa, where a wave of democratization that began at the start of the decade appears to be petering out, are eagerly watching how Sunday's vote will turn out. In the past 30 years, Benin seems to have been near the head of the political curve for Africa. A military coup here in 1963, led by one of Mr. Soglo's uncles, was one of the first of many army takeovers that transformed Africa's political landscape in the early independence years and for years made Benin one of the continent's most unstable states. A Marxist-Leninist dictatorship was established in 1972 by Mr. Soglo's principal electoral opponent, the retired general Matthieu Kerekou. That made Benin one of the continent's first communist states. Benin set its latest precedent in 1990 when it organized the so-called National Conference, which peacefully stripped General Kerekou of his powers after 17 years of ruinous, repressive rule. It appointed Mr. Soglo, a veteran World Bank official, as interim Prime Minister, and set the stage for the country's first democratic, multiparty elections in 1991, which Mr. Soglo won. One by one, this country's neighbors -- Mali, Niger, Congo and Central Africa Republic -- began organizing democratic transitions modeled on Benin's experience. Longtime dictatorships were swept from power in all of these countries. However, the reform process began faltering when governments that were strong allies of France in countries like Gabon and Ivory Coast pre-empted calls for national conferences by holding multiparty elections that international observers widely regarded as rigged. Since then, many of Africa's elections -- like one last week in Equatorial Guinea that President Obiang Nguema won with 99 percent of the vote -- have been cynical affairs. These votes are intended to give entrenched dictators a veneer of respectability while exposing the leadership to little or no political risk. Other elections, like one just held in Sierra Leone, have taken place in the midst of long-running civil wars and have been watched over by armies reluctant to surrender power to civilians. "In Benin we have democratic institutions that have been functioning for five years, including a Constitutional Court that has already proven its autonomy and an independent electoral commission that is unique in francophone Africa," said Christopher Fomunyoh, director for West Africa of the National Democratic Institute, a private American organization that promotes democracy. "This is going to be a true test of whether these institutions can survive and grow, encouraging other countries to take the democratic path established by Benin, or whether there will be a rollback," said Mr. Fomunyoh, who is leading a delegation of 17 observers here. "Whatever happens, Benin will be a determining factor in the intellectual discussion that is already under way about whether democracy can survive in Africa." Since a military coup overthrew an elected Government in Niger last month, Benin has been surrounded by undemocratic neighbors -- from military-ruled Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, to even smaller Togo, where President Gnassingbe Eyadema has ruled with an iron fist and the sympathies of France for three decades. In an editorial this week, L'Horizon, a newspaper here, said of this situation, "The Atlantic Ocean is our only sure neighbor now." For his part, Mr. Soglo acknowledges the enmity his country's democratic turn has earned him. "When I went to Japan for the coronation of the Emperor, another African leader, who I will not name, said to me: 'You are Soglo, the one who is creating so much disorder for Africa.' " In an interview today in the National Palace here, Mr. Soglo, 62, said: "I have grown used to the insults." What is more, the President contended, neighboring countries that he would not name have been arming and training troublemakers and sending them to Benin in the last year. He said that he suspects it was such outside agitators who fired an anti-tank weapon at a newly built international conference center in November, just days before Benin was to hold a biannual summit of French-speaking nations there. Rather than back down, Mr. Soglo has made a campaign theme both of the country's democratization under his leadership and -- an even greater novelty -- his record in implementing a classic program of World Bank-style economic reforms. In many other countries where such reforms have been carried out, come election time, the leaders -- from Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to Jerry Rawlings of Ghana -- have sought to distance themselves from the liberalizing prescriptions of international lenders and to renew their nationalist credentials. Road-building and other new construction have taken off during Mr. Soglo's tenure, transforming Cotonou, which had been a desolately sandy and potholed place. "Soglo paid the functionaries and the functionaries, for once have been doing their work," said Francois Agbodo, a restaurant-owner in Ouidah. "Before, nobody got paid and nobody worked." But Mr. Soglo's critics have also seized upon economic issues in their campaigns. Mr. Kerekou, for example, whose socialist model during his years in office was widely considered here to have been an economic failure, has nonetheless gone on the attack, appealing to national pride to say that Mr. Soglo's privatization of bankrupt state companies has gone too far. To many observers, it appears that Mr. Kerekou's popularity derives mostly from the respect he earned for gracefully retiring from power at the demand of the 1990 National Conference and living modestly ever since. Mr. Kerekou is believed to enjoy strong support in his native northern Benin. Mr. Soglo's other main rivals, like Adrien Houngbedji, a former National Assembly president, have concentrated their criticisms on the need for social services, which these candidates say have been forgotten in the pursuit of an economic growth rate that is officially estimated at about 6 percent. Others have harped effectively on the high profile of Mr. Solgo's wife, Rosine, who enjoys a degree of influence that many compare to Hillary Rodham Clinton, and of other members of the President's family, who are often seen at official functions or who frequently do business with the state. Mr. and Mrs. Soglo often appear at state functions wearing twin outfits. The President raised eyebrows, diplomats say, at the Francophone Summit here, when he introduced his wife to 40 heads of state and government before mentioning the French leader, Jacques Chirac, whose country financed the gathering. Along with Mr. Kerekou, Mr. Houngbedji is widely considered among the most likely candidates to survive the first round and to face Mr. Soglo in a runoff two weeks later. For some observers, however, the combination of Mr. Kerekou's high name recognition and regional support and Mr. Houngbedji's effective introduction of social issues as a campaign theme make it uncertain that the President himself can survive the first round. The President's party, Benin Renaissance, lost control of the National Assembly last year. "What is so refreshing here is that anything can happen in this election," said one European diplomat of Sunday's vote. COUNTRY: FRANCE (98%); AFRICA (98%); WESTERN AFRICA (95%); COTE D'IVOIRE (94%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (93%); BURKINA FASO (92%); EUROPE (92%); BENIN (92%); TOGO (79%); SENEGAL (79%); NIGER (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); MALI (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (51%);
TEXT: Despite political turmoil and tightened international aid budgets, France's former colonies in West Africa have begun to shake off a decade of economic doldrums, benefiting from a temporary combination of good luck and monetary reform. World commodity prices rose suddenly in 1994, boosting economies greatly dependent on exports of cocoa, rubber, cotton, tropical woods and other primary products. As a result, seven former French West African colonies -- Benin, Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal and Togo -- posted average gross domestic product gains of 6 percent in 1995. Significantly, the economy of the group's locomotive, Ivory Coast, reversed years of recession and grew by 7 percent. These results were just what specialists predicted when France shocked 14 former sub-Saharan African colonies in January 1994 by forcing a 50 percent devaluation of their common currency -- the first realignment between the French franc and African franc since 1948. But just as specialists also had forecast, the overall performance of France's former Central African possessions was less impressive, even though they are potentially better off. No statistics on their economic performance have been issued for 1995, which experts interpret as an indication of unresolved political difficulties, bloated state payrolls and economic mismanagement. Many French-speaking African nations initially had feared the 1994 devaluation was the first step toward radical reduction of the generous aid that successive regimes in Paris had underwritten since the countries gained independence in 1960. French-speaking Africa had a record of government corruption, coups and stagnant growth, and France was confronted by its most serious economic crisis since World War II, a combination many analysts believed would lead the government of prime minister Edouard Balladur to carry out just such an agonizing reappraisal. But such fears disappeared last May when Jacques Chirac, a politician with a wide network of African friends, was elected president of France. So popular was his victory in French-speaking Africa that an Ivory Coast newspaper splashed the words "We Won" on its front page. Chirac single-handedly went to bat for Africa despite France's record unemployment, high interest rates and worrisome budget deficit. Alone among Western countries, France at his insistence virtually has maintained its level of assistance to the region at about $ 9 billion a year. That aid, largest among the Group of Seven industrialized democracies, is almost three times more than the slashed U.S. commitment. Last June, Chirac also forced reluctant European Union partners to renew for five years an annual $ 3.44 billion aid package for the southern hemisphere despite their preference for helping the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, who are themselves potential EU members. In return, the EU donors insisted on closely linking aid to African countries to their respect for democratic practices, human rights and good governance. The stipulations signaled that exasperated donors were no longer routinely willing to condone the excesses of authoritarian mismanagement, dictatorial rule and human rights abuses. Although the new toughness in European aid decisions seems to have brought a measure of reform, African specialists have urged caution, pointing to some backsliding on commitments to fair elections, multi-party democracy and rigorous financial accounting. Indeed, the Rwandan government was rebuffed when it expelled 39 international humanitarian relief agencies and asked the European Union to deliver directly the tens of millions of dollars in aid money the agencies had previously administered.
