On the human rights front, Cameroon, a haven for extremists from Rwanda's Hutu ethnic majority, arrested Col. Theoneste Bagosera last month on charges of instigating the murder of about a half-million members of the Tutsi minority in 1994. He and 11 other former senior Rwandan officials wanted by the International War Crimes Tribunal investigating the slaughter were to be transferred to The Hague to face trial. In another example, the International Monetary Fund froze aid negotiations with Niger immediately after a military coup ousted the country's first democratically elected president in January. The EU quickly suspended its assistance. France interrupted all but humanitarian aid. The coup leaders caved in this month, agreeing to set new, democratic presidential elections for September as the price for resuming the aid. Although Chirac was initially critical of the devaluation, once in office he embraced the Balladur reforms, subordinating bilateral French aid to acceptance of IMF and World Bank reforms aimed at cutting bureaucratic fat and straightening out tangled finances. Chirac also renewed France's commitment to further democracy, first enunciated in 1990. "The time of gifts is over," said a senior French specialist, explaining this year's 3 percent cutback in French aid. "The Africans know we cannot help them on the same scale as during the past 35 years." Officials tracking French African economies at the Paris-based Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development decry the region's lack of meaningful private capital investment. Joao Vale de Almeida, a EU spokesman dealing with Africa, said he is worried that the "lack of a success story" on the continent could lead to steep aid cuts when the present agreement expires in 2000. Stoking such pessimism is the failure of concerted donor efforts to force reform on France's former Central African possessions, which include the oil-producing states of Cameroon, Congo and Gabon. The Congo is potentially rich, but has mortgaged its oil revenues until 2012 and refused to reduce its bloated civil service and state corporation payrolls. The finances of Gabon are also precarious, as are those of Cameroon. All three countries have resisted full implementation of IMF reforms. In north-central Africa, Chad is only now emerging from decades of little wars, sometimes involving Libya, at other times pitting southern Bantu farmers against northern Saharan nomads. This month, a referendum approved a constitution providing for a strong presidency, in a significant step toward returning Chad to a state of law. But such a back-to-basics approach has limits, as the politics of Nigeria's tiny neighbor, Benin, demonstrated last month. One-time Marxist Mathieu Kerekou was elected president, despite a messy economic and human rights record in his 17-year reign ending in 1990.

COUNTRY: FRANCE (96%); CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC (95%); AFRICA (94%); CENTRAL AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (92%);
TEXT: BANGUI, Central African Republic, May 25 A French foreign minister in the 1970's used to be fond of saying that Africa was the last remaining place on earth where Paris could change the course of history by deploying a mere 500 soldiers. But a week after an army mutiny that turned into a cyclone of looting and protest against an unpopular Government and against French intervention, even the deployment of hundreds more French troops showed no signs of decisively tipping the balance in favor of the elected President, Ange-Felix Patasse. Today the looting moved from the city center, where nearly every business has been smashed and emptied, to the affluent neighborhoods on the banks of the Ubangi River, where most senior diplomats live. Throughout the day, canoes could be seen ferrying freshly stolen goods across the river to Zaire. French and American diplomats continued discussions today about evacuating scores of their citizens living in isolated parts of the country. Early today, thieves began ransacking American official residences and the residence of the World Bank representatives, among others, before they were chased off by patrolling troops. "What we are seeing, unfortunately, is just a total breakdown of law and order," said a Western diplomat. In the devastated city center, French soldiers crouched in defensive positions behind the bullet-pocked walls of businesses destroyed in the looting while hundreds of anti-Government protesters marched today for the third day, defying a ban on public gatherings and angrily denouncing the French presence here. A bit farther down the principal road, Avenue Barthelemy Boganda, rebellious soldiers, called FACA, or Armed Forces of Central Africa, stayed close to huge mango trees with their automatic weapons in case of an assault on their positions. Not far from the international airport, next to France's Central African air base here, another march was organized this morning. This one, in favor of the Government, drew a somewhat smaller crowd, and lacked the fervor of the anti-Government demonstration. Sentiment here seemed to weigh heavily against a leader whose tenure has been marked by incompetence and corruption. Many workers here have gone unpaid for months. Many people now blame the President for the deaths of at least a dozen mutinous soldiers and an undetermined number of others at the hands of French troops who swooped into action here on Wednesday. "What is tolerable in ordinary times becomes intolerable when people are hungry and they are not receiving their salaries," said one civil servant, explaining the outburst of popular anger that has destroyed much of this city. "When this happens, it suffices to tell someone that the President is responsible and people start lining up to take action." Another bystander, drawn to the conversation, said of the intervention: "We are not against an intervention per se, which has protected some people, but rather the form of intervention. "We would have liked to see the French come in here and help calm spirits and not wage a war. Now, people have died at their hands and these bitter memories will die hard." Others explained their support of the mutineers, whose leaders, enlisted men and junior officers, continued talks today with Gen. Bernard Thorette, the French commander. "The troops of the FACA were right," said Fernand Gretalita, a watchman on the main boulevard. "The President says he is going to form a broad-based government, but he should have done that long ago. Instead, he surrounded himself with cronies who were stealing money from the country pell-mell. "It is too bad that this all led to so much violence. Maybe the soldiers should have stayed in their barracks, but now the thieves in the Government must go." The army mutiny, the second in two months, grew out of an insolvent Government's inability to pay soldiers who were owed several months salaries before their first uprising.. Most other Government employees are owed back pay as well. Two years after a 50 percent devaluation of the local French-backed franc, purchasing power and living standards for almost all but senior officials have plummeted. "The soldiers, who go into the bush for a month at a time to defend our country from insurgents and poachers from Sudan and Chad and come back to town, are not paid," said Jose Yambi, who spoke near the demarcation line that separates French and rebel positions. "What do you expect them to do? And what of us, the people, who don't get paid and have no guns to back our demands?" From the start of this crisis, many residents have bitterly criticized the French, who have long wielded tremendous influence here. Gangs of angry youths, many wielding crude weapons, approached a visitor who walked the streets here today, but their threats evaporated once they were convinced he was not French. "What we were living was a disguised colonialism," said Appolonaire Bina Doumba, 31, who studied in France. "In every office where anything is decided here, you find a Frenchman. But these events represent an end of that era." Told that other French-speaking heads of state had applauded the French intervention in support of President Patasse, Mr. Doumba, broke out in a cackling laugh. "All of those heads of state support Patasse because they are all products of the same French-dominated system," he said as he showed visitors the French Cultural Center, which was burned down the other day. "What do they know about the Central African Republic? Nothing. "They do what they are told, just like our President, because they have all been bought by France."

COUNTRY: LATIN AMERICA (92%); AFRICA (92%); GERMANY (91%); KENYA (90%); SWAZILAND (79%); PAKISTAN (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); NIGERIA (79%);
TEXT: Two years in Kenya as director of World Bank operations there convinced Peter Eigen of what he had begun to realize when he focused on Latin America: corruption was endemic, and, to put it mildly, seriously undermining development. Since the World Bank was pouring billions of dollars into development, it seemed only natural that it should do something about it. Mr. Eigen's colleagues in Africa had also seen enough. The response was "enthusiastic," he recalled, when at a World Bank meeting in the African nation of Swaziland in 1990, he proposed that the bank work with governments and multinational companies to develop a code of conduct. But senior bank officials ordered Mr. Eigen to stop his anti-corruption efforts, saying they went beyond the bank's mandate, he said. He was not even to do it on his own time. With that, Mr. Eigen decided to take early retirement -- after 25 years at the bank -- and in 1993, he started a nongovernmental organization to combat corruption. Called Transparency International and headquartered in his native Berlin, the organization's goal, Mr. Eigen says, is to "rid society of corruption." Moral opprobrium toward bribery is nothing new. It goes back some 4,000 years, with prohibitions found on Babylonian tablets, John T. Noonan writes in "Bribes," an 839-page moral, historical and legal tome on the subject (Macmillan, 1984). A Federal judge on the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, Mr. Noonan is a member of Transparency International's advisory council. Unlike Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, which have discovered that their effectiveness in combating abuses comes through issuing reports criticizing governments, Transparency International practices "quiet diplomacy." In an effort to win favor with governments and companies, whose policies and practices it hopes to change, the organization stresses that it does not investigate or even expose reports of bribery. The organization acquired international recognition in a way that did not please all members of the board. In the spring of 1995, the German magazine Der Spiegel reported that Transparency International had ranked countries by their corruption, based on surveys by risk analysts and businessmen. This was just the type of information that the cautious Transparency board did not want to be made public. But some of the staff, convinced that a bit of sunshine is the best disinfectant, were delighted with the Spiegel article, for there was no longer a reason for Transparency International not to publish the list. Intended to be an annual report, the latest Corruption Index, issued last month, places New Zealand and Denmark as the least corrupt countries, with Nigeria, Pakistan and Kenya dragging on the bottom. Last year, Transparency's budget was just over $500,000, about a third of it coming from businesses, Mr. Eigen said, among them General Electric, Bechtel, IBM, Pfizer, Nestle and Westinghouse. Taking business donations leaves the organization open to criticism that its independence is compromised, that its watchdog's teeth may not be so sharp, its officials acknowledged. But that is not Mr. Eigen's major concern. "We worry more about taking government money," he said. The United States Agency for International Development supports the group, as do several European governments. A $10,000 donation from Ecuador, in 1993, fueled the organization's critics when it turned out that the money had come from a secret account, managed by Ecuador's Vice President at the time, Alberto Dahik, who preached against corruption at home and was chairman of Transparency International's advisory council. Under investigation in Ecuador, Mr. Dahik has resigned from Transparency and is now in exile in Costa Rica. After only three years, Transparency has chapters in 52 countries. One of the most important is the American chapter, based in Washington. It is heavily influenced by corporate boards and the United States Government, which desires to level the playing field for American businesses. The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, enacted in 1977, prohibits the payment of bribes to foreign officials; it is the only law of its kind in the industrialized world. It is not always easy working with so many diverse chapters, Mr. Eigen said, diplomatically. "It is a miracle that they have been brought under one umbrella, in particular a chapter as supportive and powerful as the American." But the group's hardest tasks are with European governments and businesses. In Germany, it is against the law for a company to bribe a German civil servant, but it is not against the law for a German company to bribe a government official in a foreign country. This is the law in most European countries. What is more, in Germany, Greece, Luxembourg and Belgium, foreign-paid bribes are fully tax deductible. In other countries -- France, for instance, a bribe is a legal business expense, but only part of it can be deducted, a limitation that Mr. Eigen hardly finds laudable.

COUNTRY: GHANA (95%); WESTERN AFRICA (93%); AFRICA (92%); BURKINA FASO (79%); COTE D'IVOIRE (79%); NIGER (79%); MALI (79%); GUINEA (79%);
TEXT: Just beyond the yellow "no trespassing" sign, a burly fellow who calls himself Jangu-man stood ankle deep in chemical-laced black muck. He scooped some of it into a wooden gutter with a dented old army helmet and washed it, letting promising particles gather into a porous brown cloth. Quicksand-like pits have claimed the lives of at least five young men working in the moonscape around the Obuasi gold fields this year, and security forces have killed three and arrested 17 others. But Jangu-man, whose name means "wild one," displayed the confidence of a giddy gambler with nothing left to lose, someone for whom the lure of gold was stronger than the fear of getting shot. Working on the run-off from soil that has already been processed with cyanide and arsenic at Ghana's leading industrial mine, Jangu-man is one of thousands of illegal gold miners across the country who often risk their health and their lives for a chance to strike it rich, or more often, just to keep themselves fed. The men gather around large-scale, licensed mining operations, living off what the big companies throw away or have not yet gotten to. There is plenty to go around, and Ghana, the former Gold Coast, is rapidly becoming a leading producer. Its Ashanti Goldfields Co. is now the world's 10th biggest producer, with its annual yield having grown in the past decade from 200 ounces to nearly 1 million. Ashanti, the only West African company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, is leading West Africa into a gold boom that could help the region pull itself out of years of economic decline. Ashanti's expertise is being sought by such regional nations as Mali, Niger, Guinea, Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso and others that have watched Ghana's growth rate climb and its status soar in international circles that have often looked on West African governments with disdain because of their historic reputation for mismanagement and corruption. But fears are mounting over the growing tension between the illegal miners and mining companies in Ghana, as unemployed youths become more desperate to grab a piece of the wealth they see being extracted from around their villages. Economic reforms inspired by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have helped to boost foreign investment here, but they have also inspired resentment among local inhabitants who have reaped little from free-market innovations. "There's no doubt that gold mining is precipitating a fairly steady increase in social tensions," a Western diplomat said. "This is not a trickle-down type of prospecting," he added. "It has enriched a small number of people at the top but certainly not that many at the bottom. "You see some fancy cars around town, nice houses, but the lower 40 percent of the population is certainly no better off than they were a generation ago," he said. At least 1,000 illegal miners, known as galamsey, a local word that means "sell it quick," armed themselves with blow guns, clubs, knives and machetes last month and attacked Ashanti security men who tried to run them off a particularly rich site. The miners also stole about 50,000 chickens from the company's poultry farm, ransacked the buildings and injured three policemen. "The whites, they are making all the money; the government must institute a law to employ the local inhabitants here," said Blay Marshall Wellington, a secondary school teacher in Tarkwa, a town south of Obuasi. Local residents complain that foreign mining companies overlook them in favor of employees from Accra, the capital. Gold extraction and processing, however, has become increasingly mechanized and often requires the skills of an educated work force. Few local youths are qualified for jobs at Ashanti, having discarded their pencils for shovels when they were as young as 10 years old. The galamsey have been prospecting since Ashanti was established 100 years ago. Their gold fever drives them to extremes even though many of them earn little more than a few dollars a month after laboring six days a week, from sunrise to sunset, in the tropical heat. Five galamsey died of carbon monoxide poisoning in March while trying to pump water from an underground trench. In April, a group of illegal miners ransacked a meteorological station for thermometers containing mercury -- a toxic element they use with their bare hands to process the gold. Mercury can penetrate the skin to lodge in body tissue and bone and can seriously damage the nervous system. In January, the military was called in to drive more than 4,000 galamsey from a forest reserve after they had cut down 55 acres of trees in two months while prospecting. "Even if there are a lot of jobs, I'd do this because I find this work very lucrative," said Anthony Yeboah, 35. "Farming is too hard. With cocoa it is five to 10 years before you have a product." The illegal miners sometimes find themselves ignored by their own communities even though they often bring more money into their villages than the big mines do. "One of the problems is when you are not with one of these companies people will not even look at you," said John Kweku, 21, an illegal miner. The government of President Jerry Rawlings has responded to the tension between the galamsey and mining companies by boosting security at the mines and granting more concessions to individual miners. In effect, the government seems to be trying to strike a balance between its use of tax revenues and foreign exchange generated by large-scale gold mining to boost development and its efforts to appease the galamsey so they do not scare off foreign investors. Ghana's gross domestic product has increased by an annual average of 4 percent over the past four years. Mineral exports have accounted for about 40 percent of the country's gross foreign exchange earnings since 1992, compared to about 15 percent in the 1980s. "This is one of the world's richest gold areas," the Western diplomat said. "With the new extracting processes, West Africa will be one of three or four of the significant gold-bearing areas in the world." Mining companies from South Africa, Australia, Canada and the United States that operate here often recruit their own security because many local police receive hush money from the galamsey. South African companies are particularly interested in keeping good relations with the illegal miners. "They knew enough that they couldn't do it a la South Africa or there would have been major trouble," said one South African miner, referring to racial tension there prior to the end of white minority rule in 1993. "You are running the risk of the sort of the political brand of 'Here come all those racist South Africans kicking all the locals off-site.' " Mining companies in Ghana routinely pay high compensation to communities displaced by surface mining. But the funds often end up lining the pockets of local chiefs and district assemblymen, not in the hands of the most needy. "It is only the galamsey that have saved the situation" in many communities," said school principal E.K. Ayensu. "And now the mining companies are asking them to move away from the concessions."

COUNTRY: GHANA (94%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Ambassador Ekwow Spio-Garbrah ["Up to Date in Ghana," letters, Jan. 15] represents a regime in Ghana that confuses constructive criticism with subversion, sees a conspiracy in almost every sentence written about Ghana and brands critics as "enemies. During a campaign tour on Nov. 6, President Jerry Rawlings blamed opposition leaders for "deliberately discouraging foreign investors to come into Ghana to invest." Now the ambassador blames "negative reporting." True, Ghana has "enjoyed an average annual economic growth rate of 4.5 percent for more than a decade." Though this rate is better than that of Liberia or Somalia, it is nothing to crow about. Subtract a population growth rate of 3 percent, and that leaves a miserly 1.5 percent rate of growth of per capita income. Even tiny Benin has registered a respectable 8 percent average growth rate in the past two years. The growth the ambassador bragged about has been aid-induced, not generated by investment. To attract and spur investment, the Rawlings government repeatedly has been urged to repair crumbling infrastructure, establish the rule of law, curb rampant corruption, rein in escalating government expenditures, arrest the excessive printing of the currency and desist from attacking private industries. It has not done so. The World Bank, which has provided Ghana with more than $ 2 billion in loans since 1983, now says it was a mistake to sell Ghana as a "success story." A December 1995 study by its own Operations Evaluation Department warned: "While Ghana has been hailed as a success story, prospects for satisfactory rates of growth and poverty reduction are uncertain. Agricultural growth is much slower than necessary and feasible, and may be slower than population growth. . . . Fiscal problems have resurfaced. Deficits are larger than is consistent with low inflation." Joe Abbey, the former Ghana ambassador to the United States and now executive director of the Center for Policy Analysis, has warned of "a full-blown economic crisis unless there is an urgent review of the level and quality of government spending." He lamented that "1995 presented one more year in a series of dashed hopes and frustrated expectations," adding that the current fears were based on the visible evidence of high rates of inflation, the fast depreciating nominal exchange rate, high interest rates, deceleration of economic growth and high unemployment. The ambassador would do well to look at his regime's own insane policies, rather than blame The Post's Stephen Buckley's "negative reporting." Alexandria

COUNTRY: ALGERIA (99%); UNITED STATES (92%); FRANCE (79%); GERMANY (79%);
TEXT: JANUARY was the cruelest month in Algeria. Cruel in its violence, including a car-bombing that killed 42 people in central Algiers; cruel in the cynicism of the assassination of Abdelhak Benhamouda, an influential union leader who had wanted to forge a new political party. And cruel, above all, for the promise of yet more killing that was contained in a ranting speech by the President in which he blamed foreign plots for all of Algeria's woes and vowed to "eradicate" the terrorists. The Algerian civil war, which pits a ruthless military-backed government against often barbaric Islamic guerrillas, is five years old. It has become part of the background noise of world affairs, rumbling on like Kurdish clashes but rarely registering on the world's consciousness -- that is, its television screens. The conflict began when an election that was on the verge of bringing political Islam to power was canceled by the military in January 1992; it has rendered Algerian democracy -- and hopes that a stable political center could form -- stillborn. Hocine Ait Ahmed, an opposition leader, recently spoke of a "Berlin wall" around the war, evoking how the Algerian dreams of the 1980's have died amid general indifference. That wall has been composed of many elements: the secrecy of Algeria's rulers, known simply as "le Pouvoir" or "the Power"; the intractability of a murky conflict; Western diplomatic inertia in a country where the choices appear particularly delicate, and the fact that Algeria's oil and natural gas have kept flowing to American and European companies. But as the recent violence suggests, the Algerian problem is festering to the point where it may prove harder to ignore. Its threat, just south of France, is clear: spreading Islamic militancy, a spillover of terrorism, a flood of refugees and the disruption of large oil and natural-gas supplies (into which American investment pours). A Hint of Opportunity But if this is a moment of crisis it may also be a moment when the West, whose options seem otherwise limited, could put some pressure on Algeria's leaders to restore a hope of democracy. Within the next few months, the country is due to hold its first parliamentary elections since the cancellation of the 1992 poll that nearly brought the Islamic Salvation Front to power. The party had brandished slogans like "Islam is the solution" to protest the corruption and economic mismanagement of Algeria's military-dominated regime. When the election was canceled, the party split into armed factions pursuing insurrection and a more moderate wing. How -- and indeed whether -- the new elections are held will test Algeria's direction and the West's readiness to encourage a democratic solution there. Breaking a long, and increasingly eerie, silence, French politicians of the left and right last week called for France to act. Lionel Jospin, the Socialist leader, said France could no longer provide "blind support" to President Liamine Zeroual's Government. And Valery Giscard d'Estaing, a former President, said the Islamic Salvation Front, now banned, should be allowed to participate in the election. The United States has maintained a determinedly low profile on Algeria since the war began. But tension between America and France over Algeria has been easing. French feelings that the Clinton Administration had been too conciliatory toward the Islamic Salvation Front have changed since the arrest late last year of Anwar Haddam, a prominent party member, in America. So a joint French-American initiative is technically possible, combining French economic leverage over Mr. Zeroual (France grants more than $1 billion annually to Algeria in subsidized loans) with the Clinton Administration's greater access to the Islamic Salvation Front. Opening the way for meaningful elections might entail a call on Mr. Zeroual to approach all parties, including the Islamic Salvation Front, in order to hammer out certain principles: the rejection of violence, respect for human rights, the elimination of torture, a commitment to the alternation of power through universal suffrage, a free press and respect for Algeria's Arab and Berber culture. the European Union's aid, debt relief, World Bank loans and the like, could all be used as carrots and sticks. But huge difficulties remain, all of them illustrated by the events of the last month. Mr. Zeroual's speech on Jan. 24 -- in which he raged against "criminals, traitors and mercenaries manipulated by external circles" -- was a textbook study in the closed mentality of Algeria's rulers. The very notion of open dialogue is generally foreign to them. In the speech, Mr. Zeroual ominously neglected to set a date for the new elections. The murder last week of Abdelhak Benhamouda was equally ominous. A prominent 55-year-old union leader and a determined opponent of Islamic fundamentalism, Mr. Benhamouda had been preparing to form a centrist political party. His last words to a friend, as reported in Algiers, were, "Kamel, my friend, they have betrayed us." One problem in Algeria is always to know who is killing whom. These words -- and the efficiency of his killing in central Algiers -- were widely seen as suggesting that the murder was the work of rival clans within "le Pouvoir," rather than of Islamic guerrillas. Finally, the barbarity of the car-bombings, throat slittings and other killings that have swept Algiers and towns nearby since the Muslim holy month of Ramadan started on Jan. 10 have illustrated, once again, the unconscionable methods of the violent factions that have splintered from the Islamic Salvation Front. It is unclear to what extent the Front itself -- its leaders dead, arrested or abroad -- is still a coherent political force. Still, the frustrated, largely silenced democratic yearnings of a broad Algerian center exist and could be buttressed by Western diplomacy. Those yearnings, and economic frustration, propelled people into the streets of Algiers in the late 1980's to push for democracy, at the same time as people in Central Europe protested against their own dictators and Marxist economic mismanagement. The Algerian democratic movement went nowhere. The country remains torn by latent ethnic tensions (a Berber minority represents perhaps a third of the population), suffers from decades of official corruption and is unsure what to make of its long French colonial history. It still seeks its true identity. The democratic opening that began in 1988 was largely about finding one. Still today, it appears, as Mr. Jospin said, that "democracy, in the end, is the only road to peace."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); SOUTH-EASTERN ASIA (79%); AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: THERE IS no one, as it seems, including the leadership of the World Bank, who does not think that organization urgently needs reform. Some point to the very mixed record of foreign aid. A recent study from the World Bank itself, in fact, notes that aid to governments that are following sound economic policies can be helpful, but that aid to regimes going in the wrong direction is wasted -- and too often the bank and other donors have poured money into the wrong regimes, for years and years. Moreover, thanks to the globalization of the economy, private investment flows to developing countries are five times larger than World Bank and all other official development assistance. From the fact of this energized private market, there are some asking: Who even needs official help? The answer to this last question is: lots of countries. The private flows go overwhelmingly to a dozen or so countries, mostly the fast-developing nations of Southeast Asia. Dozens more, in Africa and elsewhere, get almost none and still depend on official aid. Unfortunately, as the World Bank points out in an admirably candid self-portrait, it hasn't lived up to their needs. Not keeping up with the changing world economy "has resulted, over time, in a severe deterioration -- indeed a crisis -- in our effectiveness," the bank admits. Fully one-third of its projects end unsatisfactorily. Now, in what may prove the bank's last chance, it has launched a program of radical "renewal." Given how many reorganizations the bank has been subjected to over the years, it is not surprising that there is skepticism among many. But bank president James D. Wolfensohn has pointed this reform in the right direction. He is seeking to move people and resources from Washington out to the front lines. He wants more emphasis on health, education and rural development -- the social services essential to economic growth. He has recognized the need to fight corruption and build legal and financial institutions -- to help nations develop the conditions, in other words, that will attract those ever-growing private investment flows. Whether this latest reform succeeds will depend in large part on whether the bank proves able to help nations that are pursuing reform -- and walk away from corrupt regimes that aren't. That success is far from sure. But the United States, the bank's largest contributor, is right to support the effort. A thriving World Bank can promote U.S. interests throughout the world, relieving pressure on the U.S. bilateral aid budget and maximizing the impact of U.S. help.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); UGANDA (94%); UNITED STATES (92%);
TEXT: DURING HER recent trip to Africa, Hillary Clinton visited nations that belie the basket-case stereotypes often attached to the entire continent. In Uganda, for example, she praised that nation's democratization, its economic reforms, the "stunning growth rate" of its economy and its commitment to primary education for all. Whether Uganda can make good on that revolutionary promise of universal primary schooling is to a large extent being decided in Washington this week and next. Top officials from the Clinton administration and counterparts from other wealthy nations, meeting at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, are debating how to implement a debt relief initiative for developing countries. The terms of debate are dry, but what's at stake is the possibility of reform and renewal. Many developing countries are so burdened by debt that a huge portion of their national income, including the aid they receive, is immediately recycled to banks and governments to the north. Uganda spends about seven times as much on debt repayment as on primary education, while about one-third of its children can't go to school at all -- although education is a crucial prerequisite for development. Blame this heavy burden first and foremost on the poor countries themselves, and on the corrupt regimes that squandered aid year after year. Nations where such regimes still hold sway should be cut off. But last fall, with strong U.S. leadership, the world's leading lenders agreed that nations with a strong commitment to, and record of, reform should get some debt relief, or else even the best policies wouldn't save them. Now lenders will decide which countries will benefit, when and by how much. Some officials want to move slowly, either because they never liked debt relief in the first place or to use the promise of forgiveness as leverage to promote further reform. But reformers throughout the developing world need evidence that this debt initiative is for real -- that swallowing the medicine of economic reform really will bring rewards. For that credibility to be achieved, Uganda, with its long and impressive track record, should be given as much help as possible, and other deserving nations should follow swiftly behind.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (97%); AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); ANGOLA (92%); BELGIUM (90%); FRANCE (79%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); SWITZERLAND (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%);
TEXT: In more than three decades at the center of his country's political stage, Mobutu Seso Seke was nothing if not an extraordinary survivor. But his tenacity and resourcefulness finally failed him today as he stealthily left his capital, a defeated man. Mr. Mobutu has been called one of the world's wealthiest heads of state, a brutal dictator, an inveterate meddler in the affairs of neighbors and a colossal ego. His style, at once bold and vainglorious, was for an entire generation the very model of an African autocrat. Resplendent in his signature leopard-skin cap and carved wooden scepter topped with an eagle, Mr. Mobutu -- through his canny courtship of Western support, destabilization of his neighbors, systematic corruption and grandiose economic schemes -- left Zaire teetering on the brink of economic collapse. His cult of personality rose to such heights that for weeks at a time, Zaire's official press was forbidden to mention the name of any other Zairian than the President himself. Mr. Mobutu almost singlehandedly invented Zaire, even giving the country its name in replacement of the colonial name, Congo. But his personal appetite for luxury and wealth spawned a system of official corruption so rapacious that he leaves behind a country in ruin, where revenue from lucrative mines has been squandered or squirreled away in foreign bank accounts. Life in a vast country deprived of roads, health care, electricity, telephones and often education has reverted to a brutishness unknown since the 1940's. Still, even many of Mr. Mobutu's harshest critics acknowledge one achievement, and it is a major one in an Africa of artificially drawn states riven by ethnic animosities. Inheriting a land of more than 450 ethnic groups that had French as an official language but no commonly spoken tongue, Mr. Mobutu managed to forge a sense of nationhood in Africa's third-largest country as strong as exists anywhere on this continent. This was accomplished, in part, by successfully promoting the use of three major African languages -- Lingala, Swahili and Tshiluba -- to draw citizens together across ethnic lines. At the same time, Zaire experienced a period of extraordinary cultural creativity, in song, in dress and in art. This came about partly as a result of deliberate efforts to favor local influences over foreign ones, and partly because of the need of Zairians to survive by their own means in the absence of a functioning Government. Throughout a career that began at independence from Belgium, during the height of the cold war, Mr. Mobutu seemed to thrive on crises, buying off enemies when he did not kill them outright, and currying favor with Washington by allowing his country to be used as a base in wars against Soviet influence in central Africa. But the rebel leader Laurent Kabila's seven-month fight revealed Mr. Mobutu's army to be toothless and his Government an empty shell. In the end, the undoing of a man known as a master calculator resulted from a long series of costly misjudgments of a sick and aging politician well past his prime.  Rising Star A Helping Hand From the C.I.A. Mr. Mobutu's ascent began in September 1960, at the dawn of Zaire's independence, when he seized power during quarrels between the pro-Western President Joseph Kasavubu and the nationalist Patrice Lumumba, the country's first Prime Minister. Mr. Mobutu, a journalist and army sergeant, had been picked by Mr. Lumumba as chief of staff and prodded toward the center of the political stage by the Central Intelligence Agency, which had chosen him as its best tool for keeping the nation out of the socialist orbit. Although he has always denied it, many scholars believe that Mr. Mobutu helped organize the 1961 execution of Mr. Lumumba at C.I.A.'s urging. During the early independence years, the C.I.A. called most of the shots in Zaire. Nonetheless, Mr. Mobutu often frustrated his C.I.A. handlers. In the words of Smith Hempstone, the former American diplomat and journalist, Mr. Mobutu was in the 1960's "one of the weakest strongmen in history, a black Hamlet, plagued by indecision, unwilling to assume power himself." But when Mr. Mobutu finally seized power outright on Nov. 24, 1965, after American help enabled him to extinguish a series of regional uprisings by followers of Mr. Lumumba, he wasted little time putting his stamp on Zaire. By Zairian standards, Mr. Mobutu's early years in office were a period of relative calm, even if sporadic troubles continued here and there, notably in the Fizi-Baraka mountain range of South Kivu Province, where a sputtering rebellion led by one Laurent Desire Kabila refused to die. Beginning with his first speech after seizing power, Mr. Mobutu set a dictatorial tone, telling a large crowd gathered in a Kinshasa stadium that it had taken five years for the politicians to lead the country to ruin. "This is why on Nov. 24, 1965, the stupid struggle for influence in which political parties were engaged was ended," he said. "For five years, there will be no more political party activity in the country." Almost immediately, Mr. Mobutu established a brand of unchallenged one-man rule that lasted until 1990. Mr. Mobutu ordered the creation of a sole, powerful political party, the Popular Revolutionary Movement, making membership obligatory for all Zairians. In the early years, at least, he set out to attract the best and brightest of Zaire's small university community, eagerly soliciting their advice. With time, however, the effects of flattery and a growing taste for power took over, and the President's style of rule became both insular and absolute. Challengers, both imagined and real, often paid with their lives, like the four former Cabinet ministers whom Mr. Mobutu had publicly hanged before 50,000 spectators six months after he took office. As an unmistakable Mobutu style began to emerge in the late 1960's and early 1970's, it became clear that the Zairian leader's ambition was to fashion a great African state. Mr. Mobutu began to study other dictatorships, drawing freely from them. "This man has spoken; he has written, set forth orientation and decrees," Mpinga Kasenda, a former Prime Minister, said in a characteristic speech of the period praising Mr. Mobutu. "The sum total of his actions constitutes Mobutism, just as the sum total of Mao's actions constitutes Maoism."  All-Powerful Leader From Mobutu To Mobutism Mobutism quickly became the new national ideology, and since a constitution written expressly to please him provided the President unlimited powers, Mr. Mobutu's words took on the force of law. By 1970, with mineral revenues growing fast, Mr. Mobutu felt secure enough in his rule to make known his grandiose vision for Zaire. At an extraordinary party congress that year, he announced a bid for national greatness called Goal 80. The plan consisted of a 10-year program to double copper production, industrialize the country with steel mills and deep-water ports, and undertake a program of huge investments in Kinshasa, Kisangani and around the southern mining capital, Lubumbashi. The largest project of all was the Inga dam, near Kinshasa, at the time one of the world's largest hydroelectric dams, followed by the 1,110-mile-long Inga-Shaba power grid, spanning dense forest and empty savanna on its route to the copper-producing, independence-minded Shaba Province, which Mr. Mobutu's project aimed to make dependent upon electricity supplied from afar. When the World Bank refused to finance the project, believing it to be far too costly, the United States Export-Import Bank stepped in, in a gesture of political support for a man considered to be a vital cold-war ally. But within a few years, the heavy debt incurred for the $1 billion project, which has been operating since 1977, became a crippling economic burden. In 1971, Mr. Mobutu unveiled a new twist on the official ideology with a program known as "authenticity." Zairians were obliged to change their Western names to African ones, drop titles like Mr. and Mrs. in favor of "citizen" and abandon European dress for tunics for men and wraps of printed cloth for women. Mr. Mobutu sought to set the tone by replacing his given name, Joseph Desire Mobutu, with Mobutu Sese Seko Kuku Ngbendu waza Banga, which has often been translated as "the all-conquering warrior who, because of his endurance and inflexible will to win, will go from conquest to conquest leaving fire in his wake." Authenticity was followed, in 1973, by "Zairianization," a program that expropriated farms, factories and businesses belonging to foreigners, from Belgians who had remained since the colonial period to the Greek, Jewish and Pakistani traders who had dominated much of the country's small-scale commerce. As might have been expected, the nationalizations and handing out of businesses to politically selected Zairians were initially popular. It was not long, however, before things began to go badly wrong. With almost no prior experience in the businesses they inherited, many Zairians quickly sought to lure foreigners back to run them in their place. Others simply sold off their goods and failed to re-stock. Soon Zaire's economy was near collapse. One group of people, however, benefited far more than others, and in lasting ways, from the Africanization program: Mr. Mobutu and a small circle of relatives and friends. Takeovers under Zairianization were, in fact, but one of Mr. Mobutu's many sources of wealth. The scholars Crawford Young and Thomas Turner quoted 1978 Bank of Zaire estimates that 50 Zairian companies had illegally secreted some $300 million abroad. Eight of the largest of these companies were owned by Mr. Mobutu or his immediate family. The collapse of the economy under Zairianization did not force Mr. Mobutu to backtrack; instead, he rushed ahead into ever more radical measures that over time helped undo him. Returning home from a state visit to China and North Korea in 1974, Mr. Mobutu announced a 10-point program to eliminate what he called the country's 10 scourges. A food shortage, he said, would be ended by organizing agricultural brigades. Unemployment was to be ended by decree. Every community was ordered to begin building nursery schools, and employers were told to provide free uniforms and supplies for their workers' children. Marked by his experience of the Communist east, Mr. Mobutu grew ever more grandiose, and his cult of personality ever more intense. President Mobutu began to affect titles like the Helmsman and the Guide, and the news on state television opened with images of Mr. Mobutu descending from the heavens. While the economy continued to decline, it was not until the collapse of copper prices in the mid-1970's that Mr. Mobutu reluctantly began to change economic course. But by then, no one would lend to Zaire any longer, foreign aid programs were bring cut back sharply, inflation was galloping and the grand state that he had set out to build entered a long period of decay. According to histories of this period, Mr. Mobutu, seeing no way out of his country's economic and political crisis, briefly considered abandoning power when he took his family to Switzerland in March 1976. But he returned home to confront a series of major new crises, the most serious of which were invasions of Shaba Province in March 1977 and May 1978 by remnants of the Katangese rebel force that had sought independence for that region shortly after independence. The two Shaba invasions, both from Angolan territory, quickly revealed the battlefield ineptitude of the Zairian Army, and in both instances, foreign troops and American transport planes had to be summoned to put down the rebellions.  Regional Meddler A Finger in Affairs Of His Neighbors The tremendous mineral wealth of Shaba, with 80 percent of the world's cobalt reserves and 20 percent of its copper supplies, helped Mr. Mobutu secure international military and financial support. The West, and Washington in particular, also had been using Zaire as a weapons supply and staging area for support of the anti-Communist Unita rebel movement fighting the Marxist Government in Angola. Mr. Mobutu, acting with strong C.I.A. encouragement, had been assisting rebel movements fighting Angola's Marxist Government. The first involvement was a disastrous C.I.A.-backed effort to seize Angola's oil-producing Cabinda enclave, which began in 1975, the day before Angola achieved independence from Portugal. Mr. Mobutu's meddling in Angola, at the behest of Washington, set a pattern for the rest of his rule. He constantly kept a finger in the crises of neighboring countries, from Chad and Congo to Uganda and the Sudan. With its borders with nine other countries, Mr. Mobutu marketed his country to Washington and Paris -- obtaining economic aid and political support in exchange -- as a platform for interventions and covert operations throughout central and southern Africa. With the end of the cold war, Mr. Mobutu's relevance to Washington and most of the West declined sharply. In 1990, as a wave of democratic change swept much of Africa, Mr. Mobutu was forced to allow multiparty politics. A tumultuous national conference that drew from many parts of Zairian society convened and obliged Mr. Mobutu to accept his most determined political rival, Etienne Tshisekedi, as Prime Minister. When Mr. Tshisekedi sought to assert his control over state finances, however, Mr. Mobutu removed him from office, setting off a crisis that led to the first of two outbreaks of killings and looting in the capital by Government soldiers. Popular support for Mr. Tshisekedi was so overwhelming that Mr. Mobutu retreated from the capital, living for a time on his luxurious houseboat on the Congo River, and eventually in his palatial home in the northern town of Gbadolite. After the swift end of a second stint in office by Mr. Tshisekedi, officials in Washington, Paris and Brussels in 1994 engineered the appointment as Prime Minister of Kengo wa Dondo, a long associate of the President and former Finance Minister.  Mr. Kengo was supposed to govern for a year, and his mandate was to organize national elections, rein in galloping inflation and restore the authority of a decaying state. Despite unstinting Western support, Mr. Kengo's administration was widely seen as a disaster. Civil servants were unpaid for months at a time, no progress was made toward elections and corruption continued as blatantly as ever. Mr. Mobutu experienced a brief and unexpected return to international relevance with the 1994 civil war and mass killing in neighboring Rwanda. More than a million Rwandan Hutu, many of them participants in the killing of members of the Tutsi minority, fled into Zaire after a Tutsi-led insurgency seized power. Foreign governments and international aid organizations were obliged to deal with Mr. Mobutu, ending a period of diplomatic isolation. Relations with France, which had been a major backer of the defeated Hutu Government in Rwanda, nearly returned to their historic warmth. The end for Mr. Mobutu came with surprising speed, after Rwanda's Tutsi-led Government supported an uprising by Zairian Tutsi who had come under attack in eastern Zaire. In three weeks in October 1996, what had been a Tutsi uprising turned into a full-blown political rebellion against Mr. Mobutu led by Mr. Kabila. Once Mr. Kabila's newborn Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo seized the major cities of Zaire's far east, African patrons with scores to settle against Mr. Mobutu lined up to help the rebels with money, men and arms. The anti-Mobutu coalition came to include Rwanda, Uganda, Burundi, Tanzania, Zambia, Zimbabwe and, with major support provided toward the end of the war, Angola, where Mr. Mobutu had interfered the most in three decades of rule. When Bill Richardson, the United States delegate to the United Nations and President Clinton's special envoy, visited Zaire early this month to engineer Mr. Mobutu's resignation, the aging, cancer-ridden President asked him why, after years of loyal service and friendship with the West, he had been abandoned. "I said the mess you are in is not our mess," Mr. Richardson said. "You just didn't govern your own country." Chronology: "An African Dictator's Rise and Fall" OCT. 14, 1930 Joseph Desire Mobutu is born in Lisala, a town in the northern Belgian Congo. Adopted in infancy by a cook for local Belgian missionaries, he goes to missionary schools. 1950 Joins the Belgian-controlled colonial army, where he works as a journalist. He rises to sergeant major, the highest rank open to Africans. 1956 Leaves army and works as a newspaper columnist in Leopoldville, the capital. 1959 Takes part in conference determining independence of the Congo from Belgium. Returns to Leopoldville as riots for independence take place. 1960 Congo is declared independent from Belgium on June 30. Joseph Kasavubu becomes President and Patrice Lumumba the Prime Minister. Mobutu is named Secretary of State for National Defense. Within days of independence, the Government's control is compro 2/3mised by mutinies and local disturbances. Mobutu returns to the army, given the rank of colonel. On Sept. 14, Mobutu leads a coup removing both Kasavubu and Lumumba. 1961 Lumumba is killed under mysterious circumstances in January. Mobutu returns power to President Kasavubu in February. 1965 Mobutu ousts civilian Government in a bloodless coup and declares himself President. The next year he has four former Government ministers hanged for treason. 1970 Presidential elections are held; Mobutu is the only candidate. 1972 The year after Mobutu changes the name of his country to Zaire, he changes his own name to Mobutu Sese Seko Kuku Ngbendu waza Banga and urges all Zairians to assume African names. 1973 The Government seizes 2,000 economic enter 2/3prises owned by foreigners, with Mobutu profiting the most. 1978 French paratroopers help Mobutu defeat exiled Zairians invading from neighboring Angola. 1990 Mobutu orders a massacre of students at the University of Lubumbashi to quell growing unrest. Belgium, the United States and France cut off assistance and demand democratic reforms. Mobutu ultimately agrees to national conference on reforms but openly bribes supporters and sends the army after opponents. 1991 Appoints Etienne Tshisekedi, an opponent, Prime Minister after rioting in the capital but dismisses him 12 days later. 1994 Mobutu dissolves legislature. 1995 Opposition increases; Mobutu spends most of time at palace in Gbadolite in northern Zaire. Mobutu's troops battle opposition supporters, killing nine civilians and one army officer. 1996 Mobutu leaves for cancer treatment in Switzerland in July. In eastern Zaire, ethnic Tutsi led by Laurent Kabila rebel in September after local officials try to expel them. Mobutu returns to Zaire in December. 1997 Kabila's rebels sweep westward across Zaire. Mobutu-Kabila peace talks in May fail, and on May16, Mobutu gives up power. (pg. 7)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); AFRICA (93%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (92%); FRANCE (90%); GERMANY (90%); CANADA (79%); EUROPE (79%); JAPAN (79%);
TEXT: An investigation by the Financial Times of London (May 12, 1997) concluded that Mobutu Sese Seko stole $ 4 billion. This was provided by foreign aid agencies and in bribes by multinational corporations in return for exclusive deals. Meanwhile, despite untold volumes of diamonds and other natural resources in their midst, millions of people in Zaire languished in absolute poverty. Such human rights abuses are rampant in Africa, elsewhere in the Third World and in much of the former Soviet Union. Now there is an opportunity to secure change. This week U.S. Secretary of Commerce William Daley leads the U.S. effort at the ministerial conference in Paris of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) to secure agreement that the leading industrial countries should enact legislation to bar multinational corporations from paying foreign bribes. At the moment it appears that the other key Group of 7 countries (the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan) will publicly declare that they will go along with the U.S. initiative, but some skepticism may be justified. Agreements have been reached that the major industrial countries will all finalize a treaty by the end of this year to criminalize international bribery by multinational corporations and that the treaty will be ratified in 1998. But ensuring the timetable is kept and then ensuring there is enforcement may not be easy. For example, for quite some time the Germans and French have been dragging their feet when it comes to even supporting a very broad-based set of understandings. The anti-corruption issue is on the agendas because U.S. business has lobbied successfully to win administration actions that it claims can help create a "level playing field." The United States is alone in having a Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), which makes it a criminal offense for U.S. corporations to pay bribes abroad to win contracts. Companies have been caught, charged and, as Lockheed discovered a couple of years ago, fined up to $ 25 million for violating the FCPA. By contrast, Germany, for example, permits German firms to deduct their foreign bribes from their taxes. No wonder Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin stressed in a speech to World Bank ministers in late April that "I urge all countries that continue to extend tax deductibility to bribes to act expeditiously to eliminate that practice." Important as U.S. business interests are, there is more at stake in the anti-corruption initiative. Persistent corruption by major multinational companies across the developing world, and in Eastern Europe, has four particularly damaging effects: It distorts "fair" trade and makes a mockery of the concept of international competitiveness. It sustains corrupt autocrats in power (for example, look at much of the former Soviet Union, not to mention many African countries) and diminishes prospects for building democracy. It leads to a massive misallocation and waste of scarce public-sector budget resources, especially in poor countries, and so has dire human rights consequences -- in many countries palaces and sports stadiums are built while the rural and urban poor do not even have minimal health care and school facilities. It renders foreign aid programs ineffective. European and Japanese multinational corporations routinely pay bribes around the globe. After effective public criticism of its environmental and human rights policies, the Royal Dutch Shell group recently announced a new set of corporate values. But Shell avoided the bribery issue, perhaps because a lot of its business is in Nigeria, which is widely seen by business as the world's most corrupt country. Other leading European multinationals are just as shy as Shell. And no wonder, given the lack of evidence of sincere interest by European leaders in tackling the issue. The United States has done all the work, constantly pushing in the OECD and other forums and stressing that transparency in international contracting is vital. Strong anti-corruption statements by top ministers from other leading industrial nations have been noticeably absent. The new understandings on a treaty are a victory for the U.S. administration and worth applauding. But there is merit in striving now to cement the gains and keep the feet of OECD governments to the fire on this hot issue. Accordingly, the subject of international bribery should be on the agenda of the Group of 7 summit in Denver next month. President Clinton should put it on the agenda and secure some advance support for it. Calls by the president to the heads of the British and Canadian governments could just possibly win their support for a bold Denver declaration. British Prime Minister Tony Blair has, after all, started talking about giving U.K. foreign policy a humanitarian element. The U.S. needs allies in its campaign to curb corruption. Without them the leading Europeans and the Japanese are likely to continue their pro-bribery policies. The writer is vice chairman of Transparency International, a Berlin-based organization seeking to curb corruption in international business transactions.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (95%); SWITZERLAND (94%); CENTRAL EUROPE (59%);
TEXT: Swiss banks have uncovered little more than $ 3 million in assets belonging to Zaire's deposed dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, following a government-ordered search of accounts, the nation's chief banking supervisor reported today. The holdings, assessed in a review of more than 400 banks, amount to only a fraction of the multi-billion-dollar fortune that Kinshasa's new rulers say remains hidden in Swiss accounts. The result prompted fresh demands for a more intensive investigation to determine whether front companies, false identities or secret numbered accounts have been used to hide much of Mobutu's wealth. Switzerland's federal banking commission announced that six banks have identified holdings worth 4.8 million Swiss francs (about $ 3.4 million) that are clearly connected to Mobutu, his family, or people and companies associated with them. The assets include foreign shares, bonds, securities and a safe deposit box whose contents have not been revealed. But the new government in Kinshasa, headed by President Laurent Kabila, insists it has evidence that a substantial portion of the funds and resources that Mobutu siphoned out of the country during nearly 32 years in power may still be locked in Swiss vaults. Celestin Lwangi, justice minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, formerly Zaire, said last week that her government believes Mobutu has stashed 11 billion Swiss francs (about $ 7.7 billion) within a secret financial empire that he and his family established over the years in Switzerland. Other estimates, based on World Bank figures and Mobutu's former advisers, place his family fortune at closer to $ 4 billion. Daniel Zuberbuehler, deputy director of the Swiss banking commission, said he is satisfied with the findings and does not believe a further search is warranted. He dismissed the latest estimates from Kinshasa as "wild stories." "There are no billions," Zuberbuehler said. "Of course, they can say anything, but these would be dreams. It would be nice if Mobutu had billions here, but he has probably spent the money." After Mobutu fled his homeland last month and Kabila took power in Kinshasa, Switzerland impounded all the dictator's assets within its territory, including a 30-room villa near Lausanne with an estimated market value of more than $ 5 million. Bern also ordered a sweep of the nation's banks to trace any accounts linked to him or his relatives. Zuberbuehler said the bulk of the assets uncovered in the search is held at one Swiss bank in two large accounts. He declined to release the names of the banks involved and indicated they may face legal action. Since 1990, Switzerland has sought to impose tougher restrictions on banks to prevent money laundering by drug dealers and corrupt potentates. The new laws are part of an effort to clean up Switzerland's image as a haven for tainted money. But the nation's banks have been reluctant to dilute the traditions of discretion and secrecy that have brought them their best clients. The credibility of Swiss banks has also suffered because of controversies about the fate of looted Nazi gold and the dormant accounts of Holocaust victims. After insisting that they had made public all pertinent information, the banks have been embarrassed repeatedly by subsequent revelations. Jean Ziegler, a Socialist member of parliament and prominent critic of Switzerland's banking industry, charged today that Swiss banks are hiding the true extent of Mobutu's holdings in the same way they tried to deny they were hoarding Nazi gold or the assets of Holocaust victims. "The banks are lying once again to save their client Mobutu," Ziegler said. "It shows they have not learned anything from the scandal involving the Holocaust accounts."

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (93%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Every day, Western businessmen in suits and ties risk riding in creaking elevators at the Ministry of Mines, an imposing 20-story building on the main street of this capital. They wait on chairs with foam protruding from the cushions for audiences with officials of the new Government in order to buy the right to go into malaria-infested jungles. A Western mining executive, standing before a geological map hanging on the wall outside the minister's office, explained why. "This is all money," he said, his hand sweeping an arc over the eastern rim of this vast country, passing over symbols for cobalt, zinc, magnesium, iron, copper, diamonds and gold. The businessman would not give his name, nor that of his company. If he could have, he would probably have denied his presence in the country. His partner in front of the map would not utter a single word while a reporter was present. The stealth and secrecy reflect a fiercely competitive atmosphere here as mining companies vie for concessions in "potentially the wealthiest country in the world," as the man in front of the map called it. No mineral trader wants to let a competitor know where his lode is. An Australian mining executive said there might be 250 tons of gold, worth $3 billion, to be mined in Congo, the Central African giant formerly called Zaire. At the moment, the gold riches are virtually untouched, he said. Congo is believed to have 80 percent of the world's cobalt reserves. Its copper mines are said to be capable of yielding 500,000 tons a year; they now yield no more than 50,000. The wealth has always been here, of course. But the avarice of the country's longtime former ruler, Mobutu Sese Seko -- bribes were required to get in, and then a share of the action went to a Mobutu crony once business became profitable -- scared away foreign investors for decades. Now, after the collapse of Mr. Mobutu's rule, it is seen as a new day here for business. Laurent Kabila, who was sworn in as president last month after an eight-month push ending the country's civil war, has a guerrilla past and uncertain plans for the future. But his ministers talk like capitalists and have vowed to end corruption. "Everything I've seen shows they want to govern honestly, that they want foreign investment," said W. S. Turner, general manager of Anvil Mining, an Australian company that has signed a copper-mining contract with the new Government. "As long as that philosophy is there, we're happy to be part of it." The new Government has slashed the fee for a diamond trading license to $50,000 from $150,000. "We are trying not to be too greedy; we want to be humble," Finance Minister Mwana Mawampanga said. Besides, the state was not really losing anything in cutting the fee; the money, he said, used to go largely into the pockets of Mr. Mobutu and his friends, not into the treasury. There is also a desire for more companies to trade in diamonds. "We need competition, so our people get the best prices for their products," said Mr. Mawampanga, who has advanced economics degrees from Penn State and the University of Kentucky. One monopoly the Government says it intends to break is that of De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African diamond group under the Anglo American Corporation that was the only company to buy the production of the Congolese state diamond company during the Mobutu era. The Government has not yet decided what it will do with the diamond-mining company, the Societe Miniere de Bakwang, known as MIBA, or with the state mining company known as Gecamines. But officials said in recent interviews that the Government was exploring the possibility of selling large interests in both to one or more international companies. "We want a market economy," Mr. Mawampanga said. "But we want to ask those companies who come to invest in our country to be good corporate citizens." The potential for outside investment extends beyond the nation's mineral wealth, with staggering possibilities for public works contracts. In a country of perhaps 50 million people in an area comparable to the United States east of the Mississippi, there is less than 1,500 miles of paved road. Much of the country is not served by telephone. But for now, the focus of the action is in the ground. From Poland to South Africa, from Canada and the United States to Australia and Japan, the mining companies are coming, small, medium and large. The Ministry of Mines says possible investors include another Australian company, Rhodes Mining, as well as several Canadian ones like the Barrick Gold Corporation and the Caledonia Mining Corporation. A Government mining official, Jean-Claude Muyambo, said that many of the companies were trying to take advantage of the lack of experience at the Ministry of Mines. Mr. Muyambo, who is 32, was a human rights lawyer until the new Minister of Mines, Mututulo Kambale, a former professor of English at a teachers' college, asked him to help out. "They think they are smarter than we are," said Mr. Muyambo, whose dark suit, white shirt and tie would have blended in at a New York City law firm but who looked alien in his squalid office -- the carpets beyond threadbare, the walls stained and wires protruding from holes in the ceiling where there should be light fixtures. He said the companies proposed contracts that gave them the right to explore, mine and trade, while paying an amount based only on the right to explore. "When we tell them something is wrong with the contract, they think we want bribes," Mr. Muyambo said. With the stakes so high and Government officials so poor, how is it going to be possible to stop the corruption? "It's a very good question," Bernard Maneno, a senior official in the Ministry of Mines, said with a heavy sigh. But the Government will have to do so if it is serious about attracting foreign investment, Mr. Turner of Anvil Mining said. "On the technical side, the risks are very low," he said, adding that the mineral deposits were high grade, easy to find, easy to mine and easy to process. "The big issue, he continued, "is the political risk. The Government doesn't have to do very much to create the right political climate." A start for Mr. Kabila, Mr. Turner said, would be to create a multiparty democracy. That, he said, would help bring in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, whose financing may be required for large-scale mining projects. And a democracy could give rise to the rules and stable institutions that would spur business confidence in investing in Congo. But the new President has for the present banned political party activity and declared elections to be two years away. So for now, potential investors simply remain hopeful his Government will succeed, and that hope has encouraged all manner of participants in a new gold rush. The other day, Al Andersen, a missionary with the Baptist International Church of Congo, was in the Ministry of Mines in search of a concession. The church's land, it seems, holds a gold deposit. Where? Mr. Andersen, as if taking a cue from the big mining companies' approach, put his hands over the map to cover up the area, in a gesture of mock secrecy. "I don't want everyone to know where our mines are," he said. "Nobody else is here yet. All the big guys are over there," he said, pointing to the east.

COUNTRY: LIBERIA (94%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); AFRICA (92%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (79%); EUROPE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Charles Taylor, the warlord who started and dominated Liberia's brutal seven-year civil war, appeared today to have won by election the power he was unable to seize in battle. Early returns from Saturday's presidential vote gave Taylor a huge lead in what Liberians say was their country's freest balloting ever. With about 12 percent of votes counted, Taylor had 62 percent. His top rival, former World Bank and U.N. official Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, had 18 percent. It also appeared that Taylor's party would get a majority in a new legislature, which is being elected by a proportional representation of the nationwide vote. Final results are expected Wednesday. The credible election fulfills a goal of the United States and European and West African nations, which are trying to help rebuild the collapsed Liberian state. But Taylor's victory frustrates the longtime desire by many of those countries to keep him out of power because they see him as a corrupt and pompous authoritarian. Though incomplete, the results announced tonight appeared unlikely to be reversed. They came from disparate areas, including parts of Liberia where Taylor's opponents were thought to have important bases of strength and included no ballots from his own regional stronghold. The election represents an important step forward for a country riven by factional ethnic strife. But Taylor's apparent victory will raise immediate new concerns. If Taylor has proven himself Liberia's most popular political figure, in some circles he remains its most hated. During a war that killed an estimated 150,000 or more people and included brutality on all sides, human rights groups frequently reported atrocities by Taylor's forces, which included gun-toting children. In addition, Taylor has bitter enemies among Liberia's Krahn and Mandingo ethnic groups, and the commander of West African peacekeeping forces deployed here announced today that a government official, a Krahn, had confessed to participating this summer in a plot to kill Taylor. He said the man had repented and had been released after Taylor forgave him. International election observers withheld final assessments of the vote pending the completion of the count, but said it appeared so far to have been conducted fairly. Johnson-Sirleaf accused peacekeeping soldiers of casting votes for people too confused to vote themselves and of beating members of her party who objected, the Associated Press reported. Observers from the United Nations, the European Union and other groups had high marks for the way yesterday's balloting was conducted. Still, the control that Taylor's faction exercised in much of the country gave him huge advantages during the campaign. For years, his forces have run a quasi-government in much of the country, financing it by selling off the riches of Liberia's mines and forests. But a Taylor victory will have been won with more than his war booty. Taylor's persona as a powerful leader appealed to many who believe the country needs a firm hand following seven years of fratricide. A political analyst suggested last month that while a government run by Johnson-Sirleaf would be more honest and efficient, a Taylor administration might offer other hope of reviving the crushed Liberian economy. "A main disease of this country is an insular complacency," said Bill Frank Enoanyi, a columnist and public relations consultant here. While Enoanyi said he did not favor a Taylor presidency, he added that Taylor "is a hard-driving person" who could "jolt Liberians to work." Another root of Taylor's apparent victory is that, while he may appropriate the country's resources, he also is a master at highly public generosity. For example, Taylor won newspaper headlines last week when he paid $ 23,500 to charter an airplane for the Liberian national soccer team to attend the African Nations Cup tournament in Togo. The Liberian government had said it lacked the money to finance the trip. Taylor funds charities such as the Charles Taylor Educational and Humanitarian Relief Foundation and the Charles Taylor Peace and Unity Child Health Care Center in his home town of Gbarnga, about 90 miles northeast of Monrovia. During the campaign, these institutions stepped up programs such as soup kitchens and other forms of aid to the poor. Taylor has promised magnanimity in victory. On Thursday, a Taylor campaign advertisement promised that a Taylor-led government "will encourage the principle of voluntary inclusion of Liberians from other parties. . . . We sincerely invite all and look forward to [Johnson-Sirleaf] . . . and many others coming aboard for the betterment of Liberia." Taylor first came to prominence in Liberia as head of the government's General Services Administration under President Samuel Doe, who took power in a coup in 1980. When Doe accused Taylor of embezzling about $ 900,000 in 1983, Taylor fled to the United States. He was arrested after Doe applied for his extradition, and a U.S. investigation found evidence to support the embezzlement charge. But before his extradition was decided, Taylor broke out of a Massachusetts jail. He reportedly spent time in Libya before turning up at the head of a rebel force that invaded Liberia from Ivory Coast on Christmas Eve 1989. His insurgency reached the gates of Doe's presidential palace in 1990, but Taylor was denied power that year when a West African peace force was dispatched to Liberia and a rival faction seized Doe and killed him. In the years of warfare that followed, his forces established themselves as Liberia's dominant faction, but were never able to seize control of the capital from the Nigerian-led peacekeepers deployed here. The peacekeeping force, which was the principal obstacle to Taylor's taking power, was composed of troops from many West African states and has been financed principally with an estimated $ 500 million from Nigeria but also with more than $ 75 million from the United States. Last year, after attacks by Taylor and others on Monrovia prompted West African states to reinforce the peacekeepers, Taylor and the other warlords agreed to the peace process that resulted in Saturday's election. The peacekeepers are due to stay in Liberia for at least six months after the installation of the new government.

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); INDONESIA (79%); GERMANY (79%); PAKISTAN (79%); INDIA (74%); CENTRAL EUROPE (52%);
TEXT: For the second year running, a survey of executives and public opinion worldwide has found that Nigeria tops the list of the most corrupt countries to do business, an independent monitoring organization said in a report last week. The third Corruption Perception Index issued by the organization, Transparency International, listed Denmark as the least corrupt place to do business. The United States was ranked the 16th-cleanest country among the 52 nations surveyed for the 1997 report. Introducing this year's survey, Dr. Peter Eigen, a former World Bank official who is chairman of Transparency International, said his five-year-old organization "is not saying in this index that one country is more corrupt than another." "We are reporting how business people around the globe perceive levels of corruption," he said. The compilers of the survey acknowledge that some of their information comes from companies involved in corrupt practices. Some are large international corporations frequently criticized by developing nations for indulging or acquiescing in practices that the companies and their governments then condemn. Over the last few years, corruption has become a much more public issue as international aid organizations, like the United Nations Development Program and the World Bank, have warned developing nations that bad reputations are costing them needed investment. In a period of shrinking foreign aid, governments are also under pressure to withhold or reduce assistance because of the perception that a considerable part of the money spent is wasted on bribes and kickbacks. In May, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, representing the world's industrial nations, asked its members to agree this year to pass laws against corrupt practices and to put an end to tax deductibility for bribes paid in business transactions. Frank Vogl, vice chairman of Transparency International, said in an interview on Thursday that the founders of the organization have been surprised by the chord that their message has struck in many capitals, including in the third world.
