Transparency International has chapters in more than 70 countries and its headquarters in Berlin. It compiles its annual list using information gathered from its own Internet network and from studies made by major polling or risk-analysis organizations -- including Gallup International, the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy of Hong Kong and the DRI/McGraw-Hill Global Risk Service. The list, which is drawn up under the direction of Dr. Johann Graf Lambsdorff, an economist at Gottingen University in Germany, sets 10 as the cleanest score and 0 as the most corrupt. Nations are arrayed on the scale after information from four or more sources is averaged. Nigeria scored a 1.76 this year, substantially lower than the next country most frequently cited for corruption, Bolivia, at 2.05. Other countries scoring under 3 were Colombia, Russia, Pakistan, Mexico, Indonesia, India, Venezuela and Vietnam. At the top of the scale after Denmark, with a 9.94 score, business leaders consider Finland, Sweden, New Zealand, Canada and the Netherlands -- all with scores over 9 -- the least corrupt countries. Among other countries that scored higher than the United States, with a 7.61 rating, were Singapore, Ireland and Israel. The Transparency International list is limited to 52 countries because the compilers do not have enough sources of information to make a fair judgment on other nations, Dr. Lambsdorff said in a statement accompanying the report. At the Nigerian Embassy in Washington, Patrick Ayendi, the information attache, said that the perception of Nigeria as corrupt was no longer based on fact. "I can tell you very categorically that the present regime in Nigeria has fought corruption down to its barest minimum," he said. "At Government level, if any official is found to be corrupt in Nigeria, you are not only relieved of your duties, you are also prosecuted." He said the Government welcomed cooperation from other nations where accusations of corruption against Nigerians arise.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%);
TEXT: The International Monetary Fund, stepping up efforts to combat corruption in the developing world, has adopted a new policy of denying financial assistance to countries where graft threatens to undermine their economic recovery programs. And showing that it means business, the IMF -- which in the past has based most of its lending decisions strictly on economic criteria -- is cutting off a $ 220 million loan to Kenya because of the refusal of Kenyan authorities to clean up pervasive bribery and self-enrichment. Kenya's currency has plunged as much as 20 percent this week as a result. The moves are among the most significant in a series of recent measures taken against corruption by aid agencies, Western governments and international organizations. They come in the wake of criticism aimed at the IMF and other aid donors over the blind eye that they allegedly turned toward rampant bribe-taking in Zaire during much of Mobutu Sese Seko's 32-year reign. Mobutu's corruption and repression spurred a rebellion that toppled him in May, and the nation was renamed Congo. The IMF's new policy, enshrined in guidelines approved Monday by its board, does not mean that IMF money will be withheld from any country where payoffs are common. Rather, it amounts to a warning that the IMF may pull the plug on a country when it believes corruption to be so corrosive as to endanger the attainment of goals specified in a recovery plan. "Financial assistance from the IMF . . . could be suspended or delayed on account of poor governance," the guidelines state, "if there is reason to believe it could have significant macroeconomic implications that threaten the successful implementation of the program, or if it puts in doubt the purpose of the use of IMF resources." "The guidelines are very important," said Frank Vogl, vice chairman of Transparency International, an anti-corruption advocacy group. "It's long overdue that multilateral organizations involved in financing developing countries place on a par with macro policies the basic soundness of the government institutions with which they're dealing." The cutoff of the loan to Kenya, he added, "sends a signal, especially because the guidelines are being issued at around the same time." Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi blasted the IMF's decision as "purely political," according to press reports from Nairobi. The developments reflect a rising determination in Western capitals, especially Washington, to crack down on corruption. IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus and World Bank President James D. Wolfensohn have vowed in major policy addresses to take action based on research showing that bribe-taking by public officials tends to impede development, because scarce government funds are funneled into unproductive investments to earn payoffs. The guidelines state that the IMF should not "interfere in domestic or foreign politics" of a borrowing country. But they call for its employees to point out the economic consequences of corrupt practices that they may perceive during the periodic consultations they hold with government officials from the IMF's 131 member countries. And in the cases of countries borrowing from the IMF that have been judged to be seriously plagued by corruption, its staff might insist, for example, on "the removal of individuals from involvement in particular operations where corruption had occurred," according to the guidelines. The Kenya loan was suspended late last week because anti-corruption measures the government was taking "fall short of meeting the clearly expressed concerns of IMF member countries in the area of governance," according to an IMF statement. The suspension came just before the board's approval of the guidelines. An IMF official said the move was "probably the first time that we have said openly that governance issues were at stake" in such a decision. The suspension followed the Kenyan government's dismissal of its top customs official, Samuel Chebii, who is widely regarded as a crusader for cleaning up corruption in the nation's notoriously graft-ridden ports.

COUNTRY: KENYA (93%); HONG KONG (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); ASIA (79%); CAMBODIA
TEXT: At their last annual meeting for the world's finance ministers, the World Bank's president, James D. Wolfensohn, and the International Monetary Fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, announced that for the first time they would use their leverage with poorer nations to stamp out corruption and to promote better governance. As the finance ministers prepare to gather in Hong Kong next month for the next annual meeting, the first fruits of that new policy are starting to become visible. This month the Monetary Fund sent the Kenya shilling and the Nairobi stock market into a tailspin. It suspended a $220 million loan to Kenya after President Daniel arap Moi failed to create the powerful new anticorruption authority the fund had demanded and to reinstate Samuel Chebii, who had been dismissed as Commissioner for Customs and Excise. Mr. Chebii had earned a formidable reputation for combating graft, to the Government's evident discomfort. At the same time, the fund's executive board, which represents its member governments, formally agreed that all such assistance to third-world countries can be suspended as a matter of course in the future if government corruption is found to be having an adverse effect on a nation's economic development. The World Bank uses the faith and credit of its member countries to borrow inexpensively on financial markets and lends that money to poorer nations. The fund makes loans to distressed governments provided that they adopt policies it favors. While the fund said it was not changing its traditional view that reducing inflation, controlling Government spending and promoting "macroeconomic stability" remain the principal keys to growth, it made clear that it would put increased emphasis on fighting corruption and promoting better governance in countries it aids. Financial assistance "could be suspended or delayed on account of poor governance, if there is reason to believe it could have significant macroeconomic implications," state new guidelines on governance questions adopted by the fund's board earlier this month. The fund also showed a new readiness this month to interpret what it means by good governance quite broadly when it persuaded Romania to cancel a planned $1 billion purchase of 96 Cobra attack helicopters from an American company, Bell Helicopter, a division of Textron Inc. Romania had hoped the purchase of sophisticated American military hardware would speed its entry into NATO, although the alliance's secretary general, Javier Solana, said the purchase was unnecessary. The fund contended that such a large arms purchase risked disrupting the economic reforms to which Romania had agreed in return for a loan, by shifting money away from health and education programs that the fund considers more important for the country's successful transition to capitalism. Last year the fund also showed its teeth in Asia by suspending disbursements on a $120 million loan to Cambodia for six months after anticipated Government revenues from logging concessions did not materialize. Next month, it will be the World Bank's turn to publish a three-pronged plan for combatting corruption and promoting better governance. The bank already took the first step last year when it tightened procurement rules governing contracts financed by the $19 billion in loans it disburses annually, saying it will disqualify companies it considers corrupt and require those bidding for contracts to open their books to the bank's auditors. The bank also is to recruit more procurement specialists to oversee the awarding of contracts, at an annual cost of $13 million, and to encourage third-world governments to include a pledge in projects it finances to take steps to prevent bribery. Finally, it plans to step up assistance to governments developing anticorruption strategies. It is already helping several countries develop strategies, including Latvia, Tanzania, Uganda and Ukraine. Unlike the fund -- which usually makes just one loan to a government and which can suspend it at will -- the bank tends to have several loans outstanding at the same time in various sectors of any third-world country's economy where conditions may vary considerably. So it plans a more selective approach to delinquent countries, making decisions on its lending on a project-by-project basis until it is satisfied with the way they are all being run. "You will see us giving a much higher profile to governance and corruption concerns in a selective way, delaying disbursement until we are satisfied, or suspending it altogether" said Masood Ahmed, who is coordinating the bank's new policies in this area. In an early example of this approach, Mr. Wolfensohn recently delayed the $70 million second installment of a $150 million loan to a Kenyan energy project because of doubts about the way it was being run. He also delayed a health services loan to Kenya until the bank was satisfied with procurement procedures. The bank also has suspended operations in several countries where it believes its money is unlikely to benefit ordinary people because of endemic corruption and inefficiency -- including Nigeria, the Sudan, Congo and Afghanistan. In deciding to fight corruption and promote better government, both institutions have had to reinterpret requirements in their own bylaws that all lending should be based on economic considerations alone and should take no account of a country's politics. In its new governance guidelines, the fund makes clear that its judgments still "should not be influenced by the nature of a political regime of a country, nor should it interfere in domestic or foreign politics of any member." But it also concedes that staff "may need to be prepared to face some tension in the working relationship with country authorities in specific cases potentially involving corrupt practices." Both institutions now contend that corruption and bad governance are in themselves obstacles to economic development, as are poor education, inadequate infrastructure and an ineffective health care system, all of which they have previously accepted as within the scope of their responsibility.

COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); RWANDA (92%); AFRICA (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (92%); UGANDA (92%);
TEXT: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have provided the summer's most welcome change in the way global finance and business operate. But they have also furnished a jarring reminder to prognosticators that things often fail to work out as we think they will. Kenya is at the center of the international bankers' reforms and the failure of past conventional wisdom. Because of corruption, the two world financial institutions have suspended loans to the government of President Daniel arap Moi, who also faces bloody street protests because of his dictatorial rule. When I lived in Kenya in the early 1970s as Africa correspondent for The Post, there were two firm bits of conventional wisdom about that beautiful East African nation: One was that Moi, a politician of limited intellectual ability who hailed from a minor tribe, was a transitional figure who could not survive long as president. The other was that Kenya's resources, international visibility and dynamic society should enable it to overcome its crippling internal ethnic rivalries and become a great African success story. Neither prediction looks very good today. Moi's unshakable hold on power for nearly 20 years has been accompanied by a steady decline in the nation's stability and prosperity. There can be little doubt now that the two factors are intimately connected. When the Central Intelligence Agency commissioned an independent study on why states fail two years ago, political leadership was listed among the leading indicators of national catastrophe. East Africa today provides confirmation of this in several ways. Uganda and Rwanda, after enduring terrible bloodlettings and economic collapse, have emerged from their times of trouble with secure and assertive political leadership. Rwanda's Paul Kagame and Uganda's Yoweri Museveni have, through their support of change in the Congo, sketched the basis for a promising regional alliance that is likely to gain increasing international support. But they still must overcome the other failed-state criteria the CIA-commissioned study lists: infant mortality, population pressure, closed trade borders, weather, ethnic tensions and more. The study recommended an official "watch list" of countries that get in the trouble zone. It is unclear if the agency ever established such an indelicate document for policymakers. A Michelin guide to political turmoil could be a bestseller in international circles. But you can understand the agency's reluctance to acknowledge that it is watching for three-star hellholes to come. Imagine the hurt feelings, and expulsions of spooks, that would follow. Would a country like Kenya make such a list today, despite all the advantages it still has over its neighbors? It is a measure of Kenya's intrinsic strength that it has been going downhill every year for two decades in the eyes of many of its citizens, former residents and visitors, but still works as a center of global tourism and as a regional headquarters for business and international organizations. The pragmatism of founding President Jomo Kenyatta and his advisers -- as well as the munificence of Kenya's glorious wildlife reserves, tea and coffee plantations and seaside resorts -- gave Moi a substantial heritage to squander after he came to power in 1978, on Kenyatta's death. Moi had been chosen as Kenyatta's vice president in part to secure a tribal alliance between Kenyatta's Kikuyu and Moi's Kalinjin followers. The Kikuyu politicians who squabbled over succeeding Kenyatta let Moi come to power on the theory that they could easily manipulate him and toss him aside later. That was a disastrous miscalculation. Moi divided and conquered the Kikuyu, shuffling the army and internal security commands into the hands of his tribesmen and allies. He let corruption flourish to buy off his more pliable opponents, using harsher measures against others. But Moi's misrule is now being challenged in the streets of Nairobi, where his police killed five demonstrators in one recent protest, and in the board rooms of the world's leading international financial institutions. In a departure from past practice, the International Monetary Fund this month suspended a $ 220 million loan to Kenya because Moi failed to create a strong anti-corruption authority demanded by the fund. The World Bank has also recently delayed smaller loans to Kenya because of concern about corruption. This apparently coordinated squeeze on official corruption in Kenya -- and presumably elsewhere in the future -- is a welcome innovation. International organizations have for too long averted their eyes and treated corruption as an internal matter beyond their reach. Flagrant corruption that is tolerated or assisted by national governments is not a matter of sovereignty. It is a cancer on the international system as well as on the national state. It should be identified and fought far more quickly than it has been in the past. The predicament becomes even more acute as Russia and China pursue their efforts to integrate into the global economy. The forms of corruption that plague these two ex-centrally planned economies differ, but raise many of the same problems present in Kenya. Corruption on a national scale is a proper target for international condemnation and action as well as intelligence scrutiny.

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); UNITED STATES (92%); EUROPE (79%); JAPAN (79%);
TEXT: A Kenyan court charged 62 suspects today with robbery and violence during a raid on a police station that began a week of attacks around this port city that some observers said were politically motivated. Despite the political turmoil, the International Monetary Fund said it was sending a team to Kenya for talks on resuming aid. "To show our goodwill in this respect, I have asked a mission to leave immediately for Nairobi," the Fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, told reporters in Washington. He said the decision followed a personal appeal from President Daniel arap Moi. The I.M.F. suspended a $205 million, three-year loan to Kenya on July 31 citing concerns over corruption. The World Bank followed suit and delayed disbursements. Mr. Moi, 73 and in power since 1978, faces elections later this year for which no date has been set. He had accused the I.M.F. of acting on political grounds. The 62 suspects in Mombasa court were accused of robbing the police station at Likoni on Aug. 13, killing a policeman, stealing weapons including 40 rifles and damaging property. They were also charged with arson and taking an unlawful oath binding them to kill if called on to do so. The maximum penalty for robbery with violence is death. The accused included Amir Hamisi Ali Banda, prayer leader of a mosque south of Mombasa, and Ali Said Chidzondo, chairman of the unregistered National African Democratic Union. All denied the charges and were scheduled to appear again in two weeks. Security forces beat the opposition leader Raila Odinga and damaged his car today when he tried to visit the Likoni police station with other opposition activists, local journalists said. "One of them hit me with the butt of his gun on the side of my head," Mr. Odinga told reporters."This confirms our fears that the Government has something to hide." A police spokesman, Peter Kimanthi, said he was unaware of the incident. But he confirmed that the police had shot and killed a man at Tiwi village south of Mombasa on Wednesday. This took the toll from nine days of violence to 40 dead. Six policemen and seven civilians including five attackers were killed on Aug. 13 in the well-organized attack on the Likoni police station, just south of Mombasa. Mr. Kimanthi said the police recovered a rifle today and 50 rounds of ammunition and arrested 101 people, taking the number of arrests since Aug. 13 to at least 410. President Moi and the opposition have blamed each other for fueling tribal tensions on the coast. Missions of 10 European countries, the United States and Japan welcomed an agreement in principle by Government and opposition to start talks before elections. "We urge both sides to enter into dialogue in the spirit of compromise and with the commitment to agree on reforms necessary to ensure free and fair elections," they said in a statement. The attacks on the coast, the center of Kenya's tourism and its top foreign currency earner, have shaken the industry and tour operators say cancellations have increased. Tourism earned $465 million in 1996 and is Kenya's top employer. About 60 percent of last year's 770,000 tourists went to beaches to the north and south of Mombasa.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (95%); MOROCCO (94%); AFRICA (93%); SOUTH AFRICA (92%); FRANCE (90%); EUROPE (79%); SWITZERLAND (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (57%); BELGIUM (53%);
TEXT: Mobutu Sese Seko, 66, whose despotic and corrupt regime ruled Congo -- the country he called Zaire -- for 32 years before he was toppled in a civil war last May, died last night in Rabat, Morocco, where he had lived in exile since his ouster. Mobutu, who had long suffered from prostate cancer, was admitted to Mohamed V military hospital in late June for treatment of internal bleeding and never left; the official Moroccan news agency said Mobutu died there "after a long illness" but gave no further details. He had spent most of the final year of his rule in Switzerland and France, where he underwent surgery and intensive therapy in an effort to arrest the advancing disease. The Reuter news agency quoted diplomatic sources in Rabat as saying the former ruler's second wife, Bobi Ladawa, and other family members were at his bedside when he died and that Mobutu, a Roman Catholic, would be buried in Rabat's Christian cemetery. At the same time, however, the new Congo government did not rule out burial in the country of his birth. "Why shouldn't the body be repatriated?" Reuter quoted Information Minister Raphael Ghenda as saying. "While he was alive, we said we would be happy for him to return." Mobutu fled his capital, Kinshasa, on May 16, one day before a powerful rebel force led by Laurent Kabila marched into the city to claim victory in a seven-month civil war and supplant a reign of corruption that had made Mobutu a billionaire and left Africa's third-largest country and its 48 million people in poverty and chaos. France, a country he considered his second home, and several other nations in Africa and Europe refused to grant him political refuge before Morocco's King Hassan II agreed to give him asylum. Mobutu, a former army sergeant who rose to become commander in chief, president and one of Africa's patriarchal "big men," seized power in the former Belgian Congo by means of a coup in 1965. At the time, the country was reeling from almost continuous bloody strife that began when it gained independence five years earlier. Although over the years he had to contend with periodic insurgencies at home and invasions from abroad, Mobutu was credited with providing his mineral-rich and strategically placed homeland with a measure of peace and stability. During the Cold War, he was hailed in the West as a bulwark against communism. Mobutu stayed in office through political guile, the sharing of graft with colleagues and potential enemies, outright oppression -- including torture and murder -- and a marked ability for making himself seem indispensable. Twice during the civil war that brought about his downfall, he returned from France to a hero's welcome, assuring his people that his stature and presence alone would be enough to restore peace in the land -- a pledge the millions pinned their hopes on. Each time time he failed, and the war went on, ultimately to his eclipse. Throughout most of his career, Mobutu received crucial aid from foreign allies with varying strategic, economic, political and commercial interests in West Africa. His chief patron for much of that time was the United States, which provided about $ 2 billion in foreign assistance. In return, Washington got a secure base for operations in neighboring Angola, where Western-backed UNITA rebels were locked in a long civil war with a Marxist government supported by Cuban troops and Soviet arms. France and Belgium were key Mobutu allies in Europe. At crucial points, both sent paratroops to help him quell disturbances. So did Morocco. France was granted a base in his country for operations in Chad and elsewhere in its former African empire. At stake was a country that covers half the area of the United States, shares borders with nine other African nations and holds vast potential wealth. Its mineral resources include 65 percent of the world's known reserves of cobalt and large deposits of copper, tin, uranium, gold, oil and diamonds. The nation also was subject to enormous centrifugal forces that threatened to tear it apart since the day it gained independence. Its borders were drawn to settle rivalries between colonial powers without respect for ethnicity, language, culture, natural features or other factors that go into making a nation. With no tradition of statehood or economic reason to look to the central government, its regions tended toward autonomy. Mobutu sought to hold the nation together by making it more "authentically" African and by presenting himself as its creator and savior. In 1971, he changed its name, and that of the great river that runs through it, from Congo to Zaire. The following year, he changed his own name. The former Joseph-Desire Mobutu became Mobutu Sese Seko Kuku Ngbendu wa za Banga, which, according to an official translation, means, "The all-powerful warrior who, because of his inflexible will to win, will go from conquest to conquest leaving fire in his wake." Mobutu also made himself the object of a personality cult that would have done credit to any dictator. In the controlled news media he was referred to by such names as the Guide, the Father of the Nation, the Messiah. Television pictured him descending god-like from the clouds. His mother was compared to the Virgin Mary. His picture was everywhere. Always he was shown wearing his sartorial signature -- a leopard-skin hat and a high-collared, shirt-like jacket similar to those favored by China's Mao Zedong. Mobutu designed it himself to replace the Western jacket and tie with a garment he said was African, and he directed that Zairian men wear it on formal occasions. His hold over Zairians was almost mystical. In a land where superstition is an important part of the culture, it was rumored, for example, that the carved black walking stick he always carried in public had magical powers and was so heavy a normal person could not lift it. While deifying himself, Mobutu closed off avenues that might permit rivals to challenge him. The army was purposely kept weak, although there was a well-paid, well-armed military auxiliary called the Presidential Division. Until 1990, the only political party that was allowed to exist was the Popular Movement of the Revolution, described officially as "the nation politically organized." Politics aside, the defining characteristic of Mobutu's rule was corruption, and he was the chief beneficiary, gaining a fortune estimated at anywhere from $ 5 billion to $ 10 billion. Stealing was so widespread that the word "kleptocracy" was coined to describe the regime. In a speech in 1977, Mobutu described his country in terms that might have been taken from a World Bank report. "Everything is for sale, anything can be bought in our country," he said. "And in this flow, he who holds the slightest cover of public authority uses it illegally to acquire money, goods, prestige, or to avoid obligations." Graft was Mobutu's first choice as a way of rewarding friends and disarming foes. He suggested only that it be done discreetly. "If you want to steal, steal a little in a nice way," he once said. "But if you steal too much to get rich overnight, you'll be caught." Mobutu had extensive holdings in Zaire, as well as deposits and estates in Europe. For visits abroad, he sometimes chartered a Concorde. In the 1980s, he imported 5,000 sheep from Venezuela for one of his ranches; he did it by ordering a government-owned DC-8 to make 32 round trips between Caracas and Zaire. His most ambitious project was the rebuilding of Gbadolite, his ancestral village. In 1965 it had a population of 1,700; by the 1980s it was a city of 37,000, complete with modern water and sewage systems, street lights, telephones that worked and a palace, a luxury hotel and an airport capable of handling large jet aircraft. Mobutu often was compared to King Leopold II of Belgium, who in 1876 claimed the Congo as private property to be exploited for his private gain. The king extracted an enormous fortune in rubber and ivory while leaving a record of brutality that was virtually unmatched in the colonial era -- severed heads to quell any idea of resistance, severed hands as the penalty for failing to meet production targets. In 1904, Leopold was forced by outraged world opinion to abdicate, and the colony was annexed by the Belgian government. Nearly a century later, Zairians barely eked out an existence as they coped with the consequences of Mobutu's misrule. Under his leadership, a nation with seemingly unlimited prospects became one of the poorest in the world. By the late 1980s, per capita income was less than a tenth of what it had been at independence. In the 1990s, the degree of poverty dropped below measurable levels. Hyperinflation rendered the currency worthless. Barter was the usual means of exchange. The country's infrastructure collapsed. Only one paved road in 10 that existed at independence survived into the 1990s. There was no way to get the products of the country's once thriving farms to market. The Zaire River became virtually the only form of surface transportation, but there were few boats to ply it. Fifty percent of the country's children died by age 5. Schools and hospitals closed. But in the context of the Cold War, Mobutu's peculation and abuse of human rights counted for less in Washington than his anticommunist credentials. Mobutu first became an "asset" of the CIA in 1959 during a meeting in Brussels. He made his first visit to the White House in 1963, when he was still chief of staff of his nation's army, as a guest of President John F. Kennedy. President Ronald Reagan twice welcomed him to Washington and called him "a voice of good sense and goodwill." President George Bush entertained him at his summer retreat in Maine. By the early 1990s, however, the conditions that had made him a valuable ally had changed. The great rivalry between Washington and Moscow had been settled in Washington's favor. U.S. diplomats began to suggest that the time had come for Mobutu to step aside. But Washington also had to acknowledge that while it had done much to advance Mobutu's career, it could not bring it to an end when it wished. Mobutu was born in Lisala, in the Congo's Equateur Province, on Oct. 30, 1930. His father was a cook, his mother a hotel maid. He attended a Catholic school and then was selected by Belgian colonial authorities to go to the Institut d'Etudes Sociales de l'Etat in Brussels. In 1949, after a year of study, he returned home and joined the Force Publique, the colonial army. He rose to the rank of sergeant major, the highest available to a Congolese. In 1956, he turned to journalism and politics, working on newspapers and magazines in Leopoldville, now Kinshasa. In 1958, he joined the Mouvement Nationale Congolais, a political party founded by Patrice Lumumba, a left-leaning nationalist; the party's program was independence for the Congo. A year later, rioting broke out in the colony, and the Brussels government abruptly decided to grant independence. Little had been done to prepare for it -- out of a population of about 15 million at the time there were only 16 university graduates. In January 1960, a conference met in Brussels to work out details. The question of independence having been decided beforehand, the most difficult issue facing the conference was the form of the new state -- a strong central government or broad regional autonomy. Lumumba favored the former; representatives of the copper-rich province of Katanga, now called Shaba, favored the latter. Having been jailed for agitation, Lumumba could not attend the meeting. Mobutu went as his chief representative and successfully argued for a centralized regime. On June 20, 1960, Belgium transferred power to a coalition government in which Joseph Kasavubu was president, Lumumba premier and Mobutu defense minister. Eight days later, the army revolted and turned on its Belgian officers. On July 11, Katanga seceded under the leadership of Moise Tshombe. Subsequently, secessionist movements arose in Kasai and Orientale provinces, and the Congo was plunged into a crisis that seemed to confirm the worst fears of Africa's friends about the continent's ability to govern itself. For Mobutu, the situation provided a road to power. He gained it by exploiting disputes among his rivals. His first opportunity came less than three months after independence and involved Kasavubu and Lumumba. Over the president's objections, the premier appealed to the United States for help in ending the Katangan revolt; when he was refused, he turned to the Soviet Union. Moscow responded with arms and money. Meanwhile, the CIA station chief in Leopoldville cabled Washington that the Congo was "experiencing classic communist effort takeover government. Whether or not Lumumba actually commie or just playing commie game to assist solidifying power, anti-West forces rapidly increasing power Congo and there may be little time left in which take action avoid another Cuba." He was authorized to take steps to protect U.S. interests. In August 1960, the United Nations sent a military force to the Congo. European mercenaries assisted Katanga and Tshombe, while the Congolese army, brought under control by Mobutu after its mutiny in June, made up yet another force. As the summer wore on, Lumumba prepared to oust Kasavubu; on Sept. 14, before he could act, Mobutu staged a coup and announced that all politicians had been "neutralized." Lumumba fled the capital. Two months later, he was caught and turned over to Tshombe in Katanga, and, in February 1961, he was killed. In the communist world he was revered as a martyr; Mobutu and the CIA were implicated in his death. With Lumumba out of the way, Mobutu turned the government over to Kasavubu, who installed Cyrille Adoula as premier. The secession in Katanga lasted until 1963 and ended only after a war between U.N. and Katangese forces during which Tshombe fled to Spain. In 1964, however, Kasavubu fired Adoula and persuaded Tshombe to return to the Congo and take the premiership. The former leader of Katangese independence now became a champion of the central government with the responsibility of ending revolts in the eastern Congo. But he soon found himself at loggerheads with Kasavubu and was dismissed in 1965. On Nov. 25, 1965, Mobutu intervened again and led the bloodless coup that put him in power for nearly the rest of his life in the country he renamed Zaire. In 1966 and 1967, Mobutu had to put down revolts by Tshombe's former gendarmes in Shaba, and between 1975 and 1978, he was threatened by invasions of the region by forces of the opposition Congolese National Liberation Front, then based in Angola. In the same period, he sent Congolese troops to support the UNITA rebel movement in Angola. In the end, however, he began to lose his grip as a result of mismanagement and graft. As the economy declined, opposition increased. And as unrest grew, the regime cracked down harder and harder. In one incident, students were killed during a demonstration in Lubumbashi, the capital of Shaba. The United States responded by cutting off all aid except humanitarian assistance. As Cold War-era leaders around him began to fall, Mobutu hung on with promises of reform, but his vow in 1990 to hold multi-party elections was never fulfilled, and opposition marches were met with military force. In 1991 and 1993, riots by the Zairian army, which had not been paid, tipped the situation into free-fall crisis. Kinshasa and other cities were looted with heavy loss of life. As he grew ever more isolated, Mobutu spent most of his time in Gbadolite or living on a yacht on the Zaire River. In 1994, however, he regained a measure of support when he allowed international aid organizations into the country to care for more than 1 million refugees who had fled tribal warfare in Rwanda. The exodus began when extremists among Rwanda's Hutu majority went on a killing rampage against the Tutsi minority and massacred hundreds of thousands of them. A Tutsi-led rebel force then seized power, triggering a flood of Hutu refugees who feared Tutsi reprisal. Although many refugees returned home in 1996, an estimated 350,000 Hutus, uncertain of the fate awaiting them at home, remained in Zaire. There they exacerbated Kinshasa's relations with Zairian Tutsis, who joined forces with Laurent Kabila when he began his rebellion last October. Mobutu vowed again early this year to hold elections and said he would ask the voters to retain him in power -- determined, as he said, never to be called "the ex-president of Zaire." But the civil war and the relentless advance of Kabila's troops made the issue moot. On March 23 of this year, Mobutu met with reporters for the first time since returning to Zaire two days earlier with the promise that he would bring peace and order out of the chaos -- even as Kabila's forces were marching almost unopposed toward Kinshasa. "I am Mobutu, I am Mobutu," he intoned as he stood outside his mansion in a garden in which peacocks strutted. "I didn't come back to busy myself with my own interests and my own future, as you have been writing from time to time. I am here to concentrate on the higher interests of Zaire -- this is to say, our unity and out territorial integrity." It was a familiar refrain, but by the time he was driven into his final exile just weeks later, it was clear that few people were listening.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (93%); UNITED STATES (92%); ERITREA (79%); ETHIOPIA (79%); RWANDA (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); UGANDA (79%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (71%);
TEXT: CONGO PRESIDENT Laurent Kabila's refusal to permit a United Nations team to investigate alleged massacres of refugees in his country has presented the U.N., the United States and others with a new danger. Congo should not be isolated under its new leadership, with its people continuing to languish as they did under Mr. Kabila's predecessor, longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko. But the U.N., the World Bank and developed nations must make clear, in unison, that Mr. Kabila cannot expect the aid and trade his country needs as long as he stonewalls on these terrible massacre issues. Last May Mr. Kabila and his troops completed an astonishingly swift march across Zaire, as one of Africa's largest and most populous nations was then known, and toppled the corrupt and rotting dictatorship of Mr. Mobutu, who has since died. Most of the world's leaders welcomed Mr. Kabila's success, grudgingly at first and then more effusively once his victory appeared inevitable. Much help was promised for the rebuilding of Congo, which is rich in natural resources but poor by almost every other measure. But much alarm also was expressed at well-documented reports of ethnically generated massacres that had taken place during Mr. Kabila's campaign. Aid would depend on the new government's cooperation with investigations and humanitarian missions to remaining refugees, thought to number 200,000 or more. Since then, however, the U.N. has met with nothing but obstacles. U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan has gone a long way to accommodate Mr. Kabila's concerns -- too long, in the view of some critics. The U.N. replaced the leader of its human rights mission, at Mr. Kabila's insistence, and broadened the mission's mandate to include alleged crimes by Mr. Kabila's vanquished foes as well as by his own troops. Yet even so, Mr. Kabila has kept the team bottled up in the capital -- while evidence is reportedly erased. He now threatens to expel the U.N. team altogether. Apart from his troops' alleged complicity in the massacres, Mr. Kabila has some understandable reasons to stiff the international community. The world's rich countries ignored him and propped up Mr. Mobutu all these years, he may well feel; why should he play ball now? In addition, Congo's new president can be seen as one of a new, post-post-colonial generation of African leaders who are determined to establish true independence. The heads of Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda and Rwanda likewise see that dependence on foreign aid has gotten their countries nowhere, and they want to be more self-supporting. It's a trend that should be welcomed, one that offers real hope for long-postponed development in central and southern Africa. Still, all these countries remain poor and dependent on outside help -- if not traditional foreign aid, then investment, debt forgiveness and trade. The U.N., the World Bank and major donor nations need to work together to convince Mr. Kabila that he won't get such help if he doesn't cooperate on human rights and humanitarian aid. But as Oxfam International points out in a new report, that kind of threat won't mean a thing unless the donors also are prepared to offer substantial aid and incentives. If Mr. Kabila insists on isolating Congo, no one can stop him. But a united international community can make it very, very tough for him to do so.

COUNTRY: KENYA (96%);
TEXT: The political stalemate that has led to violence here over the last six months has been broken, after President Daniel arap Moi's agreement last week with opposition leaders on reforms that would level the playing field somewhat before the coming election. Opposition leaders and diplomats said it remained to be seen if the governing party would carry out the reforms as promised, or if the police and local officials would follow the laws once they were enacted. But as debate began on the bills in Parliament, hopes for a peaceful election began rising here in the capital as well as in the port city of Mombasa, where more than 50 people have been killed in ethnic clashes since August. "It looks like a big breakthrough," a diplomat said, insisting on anonymity. "The big question is: will the reforms be implemented in sufficiently good faith?" Diplomats said the proposed reforms are not mere window dressing. If passed, they would mark significant concessions by Mr. Moi, who only three months ago vowed that he would allow no political changes before the general election, which must be held by the end of this year. Mr. Moi, 73, has been in power since 1979 and is a product of the one-party system erected by Jomo Kenyatta, the country's first President. He resisted multiparty democracy until 1992, when domestic and international pressure finally forced Kenya's Government to change. But for the first free election in 1992, Mr. Moi's party -- the Kenya African National Union -- used the machinery of the state to undercut challengers. Mr. Moi garnered the largest block of votes, about 38 percent, because the opposition splintered along tribal lines and could not unite behind a single candidate. This year, the major opposition leaders vowed they would not take part in the election unless the rules were changed to give challengers a better chance and unless civil liberties were expanded. More than a dozen people were killed in prodemocracy demonstrations over the summer. The unrest undermined Kenya's tourist industry and battered its currency. With the economy reeling, Mr. Moi and his Cabinet appeared to be in trouble just a month ago. Not only was Kenya facing international condemnation for violently breaking up demonstrations, but it was also fending off threats from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to suspend aid because of official corruption. Over the last three weeks, however, moderate backbenchers from the governing party reached out to moderate opposition leaders in Parliament and found some common ground, politicians and diplomats said. Some older opposition politicians said the umbrella coalition that had organized the summer's protests had been taken over by radicals intent on overthrowing Mr. Moi rather than changing the Constitution. Many moderates in the coalition became disenchanted with the movement after protesters beat two police officers to death at a rally in early August. "I found out that we had reached a stage where, for us who were purely for reforms, we were being taken for a ride," said Martin Shikuku, an opposition party leader and presidential aspirant. "We folded up the umbrella, and we went into discussions, and the result is that we have managed to get much more than we envisioned." Later Mr. Moi endorsed the raft of reforms that moderates on both sides of the aisle had hammered out in Parliament. Diplomats say his change of heart appears to be motivated partly by the threat of a loss of foreign aid and tourism. But in practice, the proposed bills have also divided his political enemies and tripped up the coalition of civil-rights advocates, clergy and politicians who had been pressing for constitutional change. Some of the more radical civil-rights advocates and opposition leaders are still holding out for greater changes, saying the proposed reforms are cosmetic. But they are having trouble rallying support. A protest called last weekend to burn voter-registration cards drew only a handful of people. The reformers' umbrella coalition -- known as the National Convention Executive Council -- has called off strikes scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday. Among other things, the bills would do away with sedition laws that give the Government the right to hold people without trial for political reasons, and would grant greater freedom of assembly. They would also make the police department independent of the governing party and make it a felony for the police to harass or jail people on political grounds. The reforms would also expand the electoral commission to give opposition parties 10 more seats.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (95%); UNITED STATES (94%); EUROPE (92%); ASIA (92%); ERITREA (79%); RWANDA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); JAPAN (79%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (71%);
TEXT: U.N. AMBASSADOR Bill Richardson set off for Africa last week bad-mouthing his own chances of success. Yet the U.N. ambassador managed to secure from Congo President Laurent Kabila a promise to allow, finally, a U.N. investigation of massacres and human rights abuses. It's too soon to know whether these welcome words will be backed up with action. But it's not too soon for the United Nations, United States and other interested parties to take maximum advantage of the opening Ambassador Richardson and President Kabila have provided. "We are looking at a more coherent overall policy for the Great Lakes region," Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said yesterday. That's an urgent task. The turmoil that has rocked financial markets from Asia to North America to Europe in recent days has left Africa largely unscathed -- not because Africa is more economically sound but because it so much less integrated into the world economy. At a time like this, that might seem an advantage -- but it's not. While incomes in Asia have grown over the past two decades -- and will likely continue to grow despite the current troubles -- Africa risks being left behind altogether. Now, though, a new generation of self-made, self-confident leaders has come to power in much of the continent, from South Africa north to Eritrea. Their record is short thus far and mixed, but many of them proclaim a commitment to reining in corruption, promoting economic growth, fostering more responsive government and tying their nations to the world economy. The Great Lakes region at the continent's heart, and particularly Congo with its 65 million people, are crucial to this movement, and to Africa's stability. Mr. Kabila's performance thus far has been disappointing -- particularly his refusal to permit a U.N. inquiry into credible allegations of massacres and terrible mistreatment of refugees. He and others in the region are suspicious of the United Nations and Western nations, in part because they propped up the dictator Mobutu for so many years, in part because the West did little to prevent genocidal massacres in Rwanda in 1994. That resentment, however, cannot excuse Mr. Kabila's stonewalling. His progress makes possible a measure of progress in other parts of the West's relationship with Congo. The World Bank and International Monetary Fund should join with the United Nations, the United States, Japan and the European Union to fashion a constructive policy. One element must be relief from Mobutu's massive debts. Aid and trade must figure in too. This isn't something the United States can do alone, but it's something that isn't likely to happen at all without U.S. leadership.

COUNTRY: CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (93%); AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Mile 42 on National Highway No. 1 was the end of the line for Nsimba Ndona, who makes his living driving a truck hauling boards from the capital, Kinshasa, to Congo's only seaport, Matadi. At a point just shy of this town, Mr. Ndona's truck foundered in a sea of mud that swamps the route every year throughout Congo's long equatorial rainy season, putting him in the company of about 400 other drivers of heavy trucks now stranded along the 210-mile route to the sea. "We are waiting for the Government to do something," Mr. Ndona said. "It's up to them to make the decision to repair the road. My boss just tells me: 'Go. Do whatever you can.' " The situation of this driver is not unlike the situation of his country. Six months after the rebel forces led by Laurent Kabila routed the longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, Congo's new Government shows scant promise of cleaning up the economic wreck Mr. Kabila inherited. The Government's policies, Congolese and foreign business people who deal with it say, are a hodgepodge of 1960's third-world statism, 1990's World Bank liberalism and a no-holds-barred frontier capitalism, characterized by shady business deals struck with international mining tycoons. Most disturbing, they say, are signs that old habits of deep corruption are not dead. On Dec. 3 Mr. Kabila's Government will attend its first major meeting with international lenders in Brussels. Although Congo boasts one of the world's richest arrays of natural resources, after three decades of misrule by Mr. Mobutu it ranks as one of Africa's poorest nations. So the new President is clearly hoping for hundreds of millions of dollars to be made available to help begin the work of rebuilding the country's economy. The obstacles to any major new aid packages loom as large as the gulf between this country's reality and its promise. The hurdles range from a long-stalled investigation of wartime atrocities and restrictions on political liberties to a crippling $14 billion debt left over from the Mobutu era and a fast-spreading reputation for official corruption that is taking the bloom off Mr. Kabila's image as a nationalistic righter of wrongs. "There is little immediate prospect for an economic resurrection here," said one pessimistic Western diplomat. "Kabila may have taken over the country, but he has done very little so far to change the economic realities of the Congo. "Kinshasa, like just about every other city, is cut off from the rest of the country, except for a trickle of river traffic. What you are left with is not so much a national economy, but a collection of micro-economies, and the scary thing is that it is becoming difficult to see how things are going to get better." The daunting scope of the task ahead was acknowledged the other day in a rare press briefing given by a handful of Mr. Kabila's ministers. The ministers said the Government's top priority would be the construction or rehabilitation of 13,000 miles of roads -- a job that they estimated would cost $2.5 billion. One minister said $530 million was needed right away to buy 2,000 tractors and other supplies needed to restart the country's devastated agricultural sector. Hundreds of millions more will be needed, it was said, to construct electrification projects, to supply safe drinking water and to rescue the country's dilapidated health care system. "Our principal preoccupation is the welfare of the people," said Energy Minister Pierre Lokombe Kitele, adding that the Government wanted to focus on "ending the misery of people in the countryside, who should benefit from the riches of this country just as much as we do." But with the treasury empty and international development assistance still on hold, Mr. Kabila's Government has work to do at marketing its two most salable assets: the country's fabulously rich deposits of minerals -- copper, cobalt, zinc, diamonds and gold, among others -- and a huge oversupply of electricity from one of the world's biggest hydroelectric dams, at Inga on the Congo River. A few foreign investors have given Mr. Kabila's team high marks for its handling of business matters. "I have only dealt with two ministers: mining and finance," said Norman J. Gross, a Washington-based investor looking for deals in the mining sector. "I have found each of them to be straightforward and to have a genuine interest in the welfare of the people." But many other business executives and foreign diplomats said the Government has begun to cut corners in ways that for some already recall the worst of the Mobutu days. One supplier of electrical equipment, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Government officials placing an order for $2 million in goods had asked that they be billed $4 million, allowing them to pocket the difference. The businessman said that he had declined the request but that discussions were continuing. Others say they have been told that to get Government approval for their deals, they must deposit large payments in a newly created bank whose shareholders are widely reported in the local press to be close associates of Mr. Kabila. "There are a lot of new businesses out there where if you did right by Kabila in the past, a lot of opportunities open up to you," said one foreign businessman who has had extensive dealings with the new Government. "There are lots of deals that are being held up, ostensibly for reasons of paperwork, but which really have to do with money and connections. This has already begun to shake investor confidence pretty badly." The deal that is being most talked about in Kinshasa these days is one of the first that Mr. Kabila's team made -- even before it captured the capital in May -- and one whose threatened collapse could have disastrous consequences for the Government. Under an agreement signed in April in Lubumbashi, the capital of the southern mining region, a company registered in the United States, American Mineral Fields, agreed to invest $350 million over the next three years in a copper mining project at Kolwezi. The signing, before the fall of Kinshasa, was considered a major coup in the industry, and company officials say that on the basis of their agreement, they have spent more than $10 million on surveys and site preparation. But people close to the Government and people close to American Mineral Fields separately confirmed that when the company sought approval of a final tax convention that would allow exploitation of the field to proceed, it was urged to provide a large payment into a Kinshasa bank to seal an already signed deal. At the same time, people close to the company said they had been informed that Economy Minister Pierre Victor Mpoyo had begun discussions with the South African mining giant, Anglo American, for the same property that had been awarded to American Mineral Fields. Mr. Mpoyo failed to return several telephone calls seeking comment. "We have reason to believe that Anglo American has been interfering with our contract," said Jean-Raymond Boulle, the largest shareholder in American Mineral Fields and the man who struck the deal with the Kabila Government. "We have informed Anglo American of this and are reviewing our options." Mr. Boulle would not outline those options, but people close to his company say that if its contract for the Kolwezi mine is broken, American Mineral Fields will sue, potentially tying up huge tracts of mineral-rich land in litigation for years and giving Mr. Kabila's Congo an early reputation as a risky place for investment. "Remember, this was supposed to be a reformist Government," said one Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Tying up the crown jewels of the Congolese economy for a few upfront payments is hardly the message the world was waiting to hear." Map showing the location of Luila, Congo: Luila is on the highway that links Congo's capital to the ocean.

COUNTRY: KENYA (97%); UNITED STATES (94%);
TEXT: No one has to tell Bernard Mulei that the Kenyan economy is in deep trouble. He hawks tours to passers-by in downtown Nairobi, and these days tourists are as scarce as the endangered species he entices them to see. "High season, we used to get five or six tourists a day," he said, as he scanned the busy street for foreigners and found none. "Now you might get one. Some guys go two or three weeks without getting anything." A month after President Daniel arap Moi won re-election to a fifth term, his Government is facing the monumental task of putting back together an economy shattered by torrential rains, political upheaval, ethnic violence, a steep drop in tourism and the suspension of foreign aid. Diplomats have taken the opportunity in recent weeks to push Mr. Moi and his allies once again to take a stronger stand against official corruption, suggesting that a resumption of foreign aid and low-interest loans to Kenya might hinge on such actions. "Kenya's between a rock and a hard place economically," one diplomat said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "They really need this money. That's the only leverage we have." Some diplomats have also used their leverage to urge the Government to do more to stop ethnic clashes in the Rift Valley, which have taken at least 100 lives in the last three weeks. Coming after months of political tension and demonstrations, the violence has scared away investors and tourists, business leaders said. Though the election on Dec. 29 was generally peaceful, since then Mr. Moi's supporters from his Kalenjin ethnic group have clashed repeatedly in the Rift Valley with Kikuyu people, who by and large supported their kinsman, Mwai Kibaki, the runner-up. The police and local authorities have been slow to respond to attacks on Kikuyu families, diplomats said. The United States has been at the forefront in pressuring Mr. Moi to put an end to the violence. Last weekend, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, President Clinton's special envoy for democracy, visited the region where the killing has been taking place, talked to victims and then met with President Moi on Monday. In the meeting, Mr. Jackson said, he told Mr. Moi that regardless of how the violence began, the United States was expecting some "hands-on" leadership from Mr. Moi in bringing the clashes under control. He also urged opposition leaders, who have accused Mr. Moi of orchestrating the attacks, to "cool down provocative rhetoric." Mr. Jackson said that Kenya's economic recovery was being crippled by the violence, and he suggested that aid from the United States and American support for loans might be jeopardized. "There is a debate about who started it," Mr. Jackson said. "There can be no debate about whose responsibility it is to end it. The Government must do it." Mr. Jackson's visit came as Kenyan officials met with a delegation from the International Monetary Fund for the first time since the Washington-based lending institution suspended a $205 million low-interest loan to Kenya last July, citing rampant corruption among top officials. Issues in the talks included several promises Kenya made last August to persuade the fund to restore the loans, including a commitment to crack down on official graft and improve efficiency among civil servants. The fund's decision on resuming aid is seen as critical to Kenya's economic future. It is usually a guidepost for other donor countries, who together provide about $500 million in aid annually. A series of disasters have beset Kenya's economy in the last six months. Heavy rains and floods wiped out roads and bridges, twice cutting the main highway to the port of Mombasa in the last month. The rains have destroyed crops as well, crippling production of coffee, tea, corn, wheat, beans, rice and sugar. The drop-off has hurt exports and caused local prices to soar. The deluges have also caused epidemics of malaria and cholera, overburdening a creaking health care system at a time when nurses were on strike. The floods also contributed to an outbreak of Rift Valley Fever, a rare illness that has killed at least 600 people and thousands of livestock in the last three months. The political and ethnic turbulence before the December election also hurt this nation of game parks and beach resorts, where tourism is the largest earner of foreign exchange. Kenya's balance of payments was hit hard by a $280 million decline in tourism receipts because of ethnic clashes on the Indian Ocean coast in the second half of 1997. Then in January, when more clashes over land and political allegiances erupted between Kikuyu and Kalenjin ethnic groups in the Rift Valley, tourists and foreign investors continued to keep their distance. "Foreign investors are not very comfortable with the political situation right now," said Lincoln Ndwiga, a Nairobi stockbroker. "They are the big players. If they shy away, so do the local investors." To make fiscal matters worse, strikes in December forced the Government to agree to labor settlements with teachers and other civil servants that provided for a tripling of salaries, which is likely to add millions in unexpected expenditures to the $3.1 billion annual budget. "We definitely need an important infusion of foreign aid," the new Foreign Minister, Bonaya Adhi Godana, said. "Obviously we would be glad to have had it not only restored but increased." These problems would have been tough for any government to handle, but there is ample evidence that Kenya's has not been particularly well managed in recent years, diplomats and foreign economists say. The country's infrastructure has visibly crumbled in the last five years, despite millions of dollars in loans from the World Bank for improving roads. On average, the Government completes only about 3 percent of its capital projects each year, a fraction of the average for most countries.  Even though the World Bank has approved nearly $600 million in loans for major projects, it has been able to disburse only about $30 million because the Government has been so slow to get projects off the ground, officials said. In addition, Kenya's civil payroll is bloated with nearly 485,000 workers. The country is also paying horrendously high interest rates of more than 25 percent on its treasury bills and commercial debts. About a third of the budget goes for debt service, most of it to domestic banks. The budget deficit is expected to balloon to around 4 percent of this year's domestic output. Few resources are left over for building roads, hospitals, schools. "This is catastrophic," said one diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. "You can't develop a country with these kinds of numbers." Map of Kenya showing the location of the Rift Valley: The Rift Valley has repeatedly been hit by ethnic clashes.

COUNTRY: NORTHERN IRELAND (94%); NIGERIA (94%); UNITED KINGDOM (94%); HONG KONG (93%); INDONESIA (92%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (92%); INDIA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); CHINA (79%); PAKISTAN (79%);
TEXT: Nigeria Promises to Free All Its Political Prisoners Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations said that Nigeria's new military Government had pledged to release all remaining political prisoners, among them Moshood K. O. Abiola, who was jailed after apparently winning the presidential election in 1993.  A1 Northern Ireland Church Fires Arsonists believed to be members of a dissident Protestant group set fire to 10 Roman Catholic churches in Northern Ireland, causing fears that wider sectarian violence could return to the British province. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew to Belfast, visited one of the churches and met with Protestant and Catholic leaders of the Northern Ireland Assembly in an effort to dispel rising tension in the mostly Protestant province.  A1 Clinton in Hong Kong President Clinton, speaking in Hong Kong a day after the former British colony marked the first anniversary of its return to China, said that "cronyism, corruption and overextended credit," unchecked by competent financial regulation, had led to the Asian economic crisis that plunged Hong Kong into recession.  A10 Company to Pay Russia Taxes Russia's famously ineffectual tax men threatened to seize control of the nation's biggest and most powerful corporation -- and its executives' dachas, yachts and other perks -- unless it paid billions of dollars in back taxes. The company, Gazprom, gave in and agreed to pay $674 million.  A3 Sanctions on Swiss Banks Officials of the City and State of New York said that they would begin imposing sanctions on Swiss banks on Sept. 1, hoping that the two-month "cooling-off period" would persuade Swiss bank officials and lawyers for Holocaust survivors and heirs to reach a settlement.  A3 Doubt Cast on Pakistani's Story Iftikar Khan Chaudhry, a self-proclaimed defector from Pakistan's nuclear weapons program is not a scientist at all, but a low-paid accountant for a company that makes bathroom tiles, a director of the company said. Mr. Chaudhry, who is seeking asylum in the United States, told a number of reporters that he had been at an April meeting at which Pakistani military leaders decided to launch a pre-emptive nuclear attack against New Delhi.  A6 Aid to Indonesia Renewed The World Bank resumed aid to Indonesia for the first time since President Suharto was forced from office, approving a $1 billion loan and predicting that the world's largest industrial nations would soon announce another $6 billion in aid.  A7 Algeria to Allow Inspection Algeria, which has for months resisted outside efforts to investigate the violence that has killed tens of thousands of Algerians since 1992, has agreed to admit a high-level international political mission, the United Nations announced.  A6 More Floridians Flee Advance of Wildfires Hundreds more residents of Volusia and Brevard Counties in Florida fled towns threatened by wildfires, joining the more than 30,000 residents of those counties who were ordered evacuated Wednesday night, state emergency management officials said. A 140-mile stretch of I-95 was closed and the Pepsi 400 stock car race, scheduled for tomorrow, was postponed. No deaths and about 50 injuries have been reported. A1 Nerve Gas Report Retracted CNN retracted a report that the United States military used lethal sarin nerve gas during a secret 1970 mission in Laos that CNN said was intended to kill American defectors. A version of the report had been published in Time, which also issued a statement of retraction. A1 Freemen Leaders Convicted A Federal jury convicted the leadership of the anti-government Freemen movement on several charges, largely financial fraud, but was unable to reach verdicts on other counts including the conspiracy charge at the core of the case. A12 States Balk on Viagra Subsidy New York and Wisconsin said that they would defy a new Federal policy that requires state Medicaid programs to pay for medically approved uses of Viagra, the popular but expensive new impotence pill. A12 Simian AIDS Vaccine Fails Researchers reported at the World AIDS Conference that a vaccine made from a weakened simian virus and injected into monkeys had actually caused AIDS. A15 Tripp Continues Testimony Linda R. Tripp returned to a grand jury room in Washington and spent nearly seven hours apparently explaining her motives for secretly recording 20 hours of phone conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern who was once her friend. A16 Impasse for Apparel Panel A Presidential task force remains at stalemate over a number of pivotal issues on establishing a code of conduct for apparel factories, including the frequency with which those factories ought to be inspected and whether any ought to be in China. A16 High-Level Lapses Found Failures by the Marine Corps and the Air Force to pass along crucial information cast "substantial doubt" on whether the pilot of a plane that struck a ski lift cable in the Italian Alps in February could be convicted in a court-martial, though a court-martial should be convened for the pilot and the navigator, a Marine hearing officer said in a report. A18 The C.I.A. Clears Itself A yearlong internal C.I.A. investigation of unauthorized contacts between a Democratic Party leader eager to help a wealthy party donor, Roger E. Tamraz, above, and the C.I.A. found that no laws were broken by officials at the spy agency, officials said. A18 Home in Child Sex Case Was Deemed to Be Safe Six months before the police arrested a Brooklyn couple on charges of repeatedly raping their two daughters, child welfare officials approved their filthy apartment as a safe place for the teen-age girls. B1 Debut of a Metrocard The new unlimited-ride Metrocard passes go on sale at midnight. Riders can pay $17 for 7-day passes or $63 for 30-day passes. B1 Central Park Gets Two Kiosks Two Victorian-style food kiosks were built inside Central Park's Columbus Circle entrance, causing critics to worry about further commercialization of the park. But Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern hailed them as a welcome amenity, and said more might be approved. B1 A Promotion at City Hall Mayor Giuliani named his budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, to succeed Randy M. Mastro as Deputy Mayor for Operations, the position that has traditionally been second in command at City Hall. B2 Firefighters Disciplined Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen penalized 11 firemen with a loss of pay for their involvement in a brawl at a cafe in Bryant Park. B3 Novotna Ousts Hingis Jana Novotna qualified for her third Wimbledon final with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over the top-ranked Martina Hingis. The third-seeded Novotna will face the 16th-seeded Nathalie Tauziat in the finals tomorrow. C1 Japan's Bad-Debt Plan The Japanese Government announced a long-awaited plan to clear away the nation's pile of bad debt in hopes of bolstering global confidence in Japan and setting its economy on track for growth. A1 Jobless Rate Inches Up The Labor Department reported that unemployment edged up to 4.5 percent in June and job growth slowed, signs the economy might be cooling, but by only a few degrees. D1 Minutes of the Fed's May 19 meeting showed concern about a potential outbreak of inflation. Two of the 12 members on the policy-making committee voted against holding interest rates steady. D1 Stocks fell after reports suggested that profits could suffer from a slowing economy. D4 In Pursuit of Sports Authority Gart Sports offered $20 a share, or a total of $445.2 million, in cash for 70 percent of the Sports Authority. D2 Business Digest D1 Editorials: The CNN-Time retraction; Mr. Starr should not tarry; saving Japan's banking system; prayer in a Bronx school. Columns: A. M. Rosenthal, Russell Baker. Crossword E38 Public Lives B2 Weather A18

COUNTRY: ALGERIA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); JAPAN (54%);
TEXT: A key member of Congress said today that financing for some of the World Bank's poverty-fighting efforts had been put in jeopardy by reports that bank employees were suspected of embezzlement and of accepting kickbacks. Senator Mitch McConnell, a Republican from Kentucky who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee's foreign operations subcommittee, said in a letter to James D. Wolfensohn, the World Bank's president, that he found news reports of possible wrongdoing uncovered by the bank's internal investigation "shocking." He said that it was time for an independent review of the institution's management and operations. Mr. McConnell's subcommittee was scheduled to vote next week on providing $800 million for next year to the arm of the World Bank that makes low-interest loans to the world's poorest countries. His aides said he probably would write the bill to require a full explanation of the reports of wrongdoing and the bank's failure to apprise Congress of the problem before he released the money. Mr. McConnell's letter came after newspapers reported that the bank had found evidence of kickbacks being funneled to employees in at least two cases, and was investigating other accusations as part of a broad inquiry into wrongdoing within the bank. The bank's investigations were first disclosed by the Washington Post and the Asahi Shimbun in Tokyo. When compared to the billions of dollars that the institution routinely lends to rickety, poor and sometimes corrupt governments around the world, the two cases at the center of the bank's investigations are miniscule in financial terms. In one case, World Bank officials are investigating whether two Japanese employees took $11,000 in kickbacks for steering a consulting contract to a subsidiary of a Japanese securities firm. In the only other case to have progressed beyond the initial stages of investigation, the bank filed a civil lawsuit seeking to recover tens of thousands of dollars it suspects were funneled to an employee by a technology company he hired to work on a project in Algeria. No criminal charges have been filed in either case. Analysts who follow the World Bank generally see internal corruption as a far smaller problem than the bank's attempt to wrest full control over the more than $20 billion it channels each year into construction projects, education, health and nutrition projects and other programs in scores of countries across the world. But since the institution has embarked on a high-profile effort to insure that the money it lends goes to fighting poverty and not to enriching corrupt government officials and business executives, officials at the bank were concerned that the institution be able to live up to its own standards. And with the bank's poverty-fighting effectiveness under attack in Congress and internationally among economists and development specialists, the investigations brought more criticism that the bank is not sufficiently accountable to taxpayers in the United States and other wealthy nations that help finance its operations. The Treasury Department said it had encouraged the bank to "investigate fully and then take all appropriate actions."

COUNTRY: EUROPE (94%); CAMEROON (94%); DENMARK (94%); CANADA (92%); INDONESIA (92%); KENYA (92%); SWITZERLAND (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); VENEZUELA, BOLIVARIAN REPUBLIC OF (92%); FINLAND (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%);
TEXT: Transparency International, a small independent organization that has been tracking for four years how the public and international businesses view corruption worldwide, has published its largest survey to date, looking at 85 countries and ranking only one completely clean: Denmark. The 1998 Corruption Perception Index, like its predecessors, is a "survey of surveys," using a combination of studies by risk analysts, opinion polls and research institutions to rank countries by how they are perceived. "No surveying approach is perfect," Frank Vogl, vice president of Transparency International and a former World Bank official, said of the report released last week. "At best we get a good set of impressions." The impressions this year are that all but 3 of the top 10 countries in the least-corrupt category are European -- Denmark, followed by Finland, Sweden, New Zealand, Iceland, Canada, Singapore, the Netherlands, Norway and Switzerland. At the other end of the scale, from the bottom up, are Cameroon, Paraguay, Honduras, Tanzania, Nigeria, Indonesia, Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Russia and Vietnam and Kenya in a tie. The United States falls behind most European countries and Hong Kong, tying with Austria at 17th place. The annual index has provoked criticisms from countries that rank low on the trust scale, among them Cameroon. "The Cameroon Government condemns strongly the arrogance of certain bodies that are in the pay of neo-colonial clusters of people at work to impede the progress of our countries instead of supporting efforts and sacrifices made by our people," the Government said in an official radio announcement. But Transparency International is not alone in drawing attention to corruption through its branches in all parts of the world. Last month, the United Nations Development Program and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development joined forces to publish a study of anticorruption initiatives in 25 countries that serve as models in the battle against bribery, money laundering and other impediments to economic growth. "The international community's concern with corruption issues is not a passing phenomenon," top officials in the two organizations wrote in a preface to the report, "Corruption and Integrity Improvement Initiatives in Developing Countries." It called for "concrete measures -- preventive as well as punitive -- that address issues of accountability, transparency and inequity at various levels of social and economic systems." Djibril Diallo, public affairs director of the United Nations Development Program, said at a news conference that corruption is thought to siphon billions of dollars out of development each year. The O.E.C.D. has been working toward making the payment of bribes illegal in Europe, where some countries still permit tax deductions for such payments by businesses. The United States, with its 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, has been a leader in trying to stem the tide of bribery in international business. Officials at Transparency International say that they are now working on a Bribery Propensity Index to balance its Corruption Perceptions Index in the future. The 1998 corruption index can be found through the Internet at www.transparency.de.

COUNTRY: ANGOLA (94%); NIGERIA (93%); AFRICA (92%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); PORTUGAL (79%);
TEXT: Civil war has ruined Angola's economy, but the chaos wrought by conflict has been a boon for politicians and generals, providing a smoke screen for rampant corruption and mismanagement in the oil and diamond industries, financial analysts and diplomats say. This southwest African nation could well become Africa's number-one oil producer over the next decade, possibly surpassing Nigeria, the current leader.
