Diamond deposits along Angola's many rivers and in its ancient volcanic rock, though less lucrative on a large scale than oil, are among the highest quality and most sought gemstones in the world. But as in Nigeria, which has long been one of the continent's most corrupt nations, Angola's vast and largely unaccounted-for wealth moves through a shadow economy. Oil revenue simply disappears and is believed to be taken by government officials, business sources here say. And while it is common knowledge that the UNITA rebel movement has financed itself with the diamonds in its territory, diplomats and analysts say they believe that illicit deals are made by and between rebel leaders and army generals who, when dollars are not on the table, are otherwise at war. While corruption here may not approach the level of the utterly thieving regime of Mobutu Sese Seko, the late dictator of the former Zaire, analysts and diplomats say it has become systemic. Based on anecdotal evidence, the officially enforced dearth of budgetary data and official books that just do not add up, analysts say they believe that the trend toward corruption has been set by a powerful group around President Jose Eduardo dos Santos. The group is called the Futungist faction, for the Futungo presidential compound along the Atlantic coast south of the capital. "Everybody knows it," said a loyalist to dos Santos's ruling party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA). The party loyalist described corruption as the MPLA's "life-insurance scheme," which took hold gradually but soon became commonplace. "Like a virus, you could not stop it," he said. As he described it, independence from Portugal in 1975 turned the MPLA's guerrilla fighters into politicians who had the best of intentions but found themselves mired in bureaucratic responsibilities. With a continuing war against UNITA wearing them down at the same time, they succumbed to the temptation of simply securing their own wealth. An analyst who has attempted to decipher Angola's chaotic economic system said there is little indication in government accounts of how oil and diamond revenue flows in and out of the budget. Controls and accounting procedures for government revenue are virtually nonexistent, reducing the budget to a document of fiction, the analyst said. Half of what the government says it spends cannot be traced to a revenue source, he said, and much of what is believed to be produced in oil revenue is unaccounted for. The analyst said oil produced about $ 1.5 billion in revenue last year, with two-thirds presumed to go toward defense, leaving $ 500 million unaccounted for. "It is not clear what really happens to this revenue," he said. "There's widespread speculation that a significant chunk of it leaks out." Leakage also is endemic in the diamond sector. No figures are available on precisely how much diamond revenue has been produced. UNITA rebels have controlled virtually all of Angola's diamond-producing territory in recent years, although the diamond-rich provinces of Lunda Norte and Lunda Sul have changed hands a few times in the past year's fighting. The economic analyst estimates that only 10 percent of diamond revenue reaches government coffers, with most of the rest going to UNITA and, to a lesser extent, to government generals. The traffic in uncertified diamonds has continued despite a U.N. embargo last June against diamond deals with UNITA. Global Witness, a Britain-based human rights group, has criticized the government for poor controls in the diamond industry and has accused international diamond conglomerate De Beers of trafficking in UNITA-mined diamonds, a charge that De Beers denies. The government rarely comments on its economic details. Officials here do, however, acknowledge that the economy is in chaos -- mired in debt and in need of reform. But when voices of criticism are raised from within the ruling party, they are silenced. Lopo do Nascimento, a former prime minister, was removed as party secretary general at a party congress last month when a reform movement loosely coalesced around him tried to open debate on the need for economic reforms, sources knowledgeable about party affairs say. Rather than entertain a reform agenda, dos Santos quashed debate on the issue and hammered at the need for unity in the face of the MPLA's chief nemesis and convenient bogey man, rebel leader Jonas Savimbi. Savimbi's UNITA -- the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola -- has been fighting the MPLA off and on since well before independence. Most government attention has been focused on checking UNITA's strength, as in the current round of fighting, which began last month with a government attempt to take UNITA's stronghold. More than two decades on a war footing has warped the economy. While defense spending is the focus of the budget, schools and clinics are not built, factories are not rehabilitated, roads -- except for a few in the capital -- are not repaired, and towns in the interior that have been destroyed by fighting stand as exhibits of the Angolan nightmare. Most of Angola's 12 million people live in utter rural poverty made all the worse by the land mines sown in the soil and the bandits who work the roads. It is notable, though mysterious, analysts say, that a private foundation established in 1997 by the president, the Fundacao Eduardo dos Santos, has been building schools with funds from an unknown source. Murky budgetary practices are one of the reasons that Angola cannot get loans from the International Monetary Fund, which has conditioned credit on more transparency and control in government accounts. Angola's external debt is about $ 10.5 billion, and the service on that debt accounts, on paper, for 20 percent of gross national product, one of the highest such percentages in the world, according to the World Bank. Angola is in such a deep financial mess that the government routinely rolls over its debt by seeking oil-guaranteed short-term loans that, in effect, mortgage future oil revenue, the financial analyst here said. The government also has no money to pay for imports, and cannot pay public servants and government contractors. But oil keeps flowing, with a host of international oil firms pumping out in the Atlantic Ocean or bidding here in the capital, Luanda, for the deep-water oil fields that industry analysts say will catapult Angola into the oil-production big leagues. Current production of 750,000 barrels per day is expected to double over the next decade. And the cost of doing oil business here also is going up, including hundreds of millions of dollars in "signing fees" that the government demands for oil exploration rights. Seven percent of U.S. oil imports come from Angola, and that amount is expected to double along with production. American companies, such as Chevron, are major players in the industry.

COUNTRY: UGANDA (94%); AFRICA (93%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: On a weekend morning here, with the vibrant local newspapers sticking it to the powers that be and the pundits interrupting each other on "The Capital Gang," it is easy to understand why the world has grown optimistic about Uganda, a country that a quarter-century ago was competing for the title Worst Place on Earth. But read those papers, and listen to those pundits, and it's even more apparent why the optimism has become riddled with doubt: The president's brother reportedly is making off with millions, the vice president is snagged in an aid scandal, and the order of the day appears to be the pursuit of lucre by the governing elite. That's par for the course in many countries, not a few of them in Africa. But it wasn't supposed to happen in Uganda. The battered country that charming, resilient President Yoweri Museveni lifted from the legacy of dictator Idi Amin Dada had, over the intervening 13 years, built an enviable reputation as the exception to the continent's rule. The economy has grown at an impressive 6 percent annual rate and aid dollars have followed, on an assumption of good governance. Uganda's ultimate validation arrived last April in the person of President Clinton. On the longest visit to Africa by a U.S. president, the only place Clinton lingered longer was Nelson Mandela's South Africa. But in the eight months since, the glow has steadily faded. Museveni's reputation for statesmanship has been sullied by misadventure in neighboring Congo, where Ugandan troops have incurred the wrath of some other African leaders for supporting the second rebellion there in three years. They also happen to be occupying a Congolese gold mine. Meanwhile, in the capital, Kampala, the unclassifiable "movement" government -- some call it no-party democracy -- that Museveni conceived as an antidote to corruption has been rocked by scandal after scandal. Three ministers have resigned in disgrace so far. And in December the nation's top defense official -- Museveni's brother, Maj. Gen. Salim Saleh -- was caught trying to secretly buy a stake in Uganda Commercial Bank while it was being privatized. Compounding the embarrassment was its timing: Museveni ended up firing his kid brother the night before foreign donors convened in Kampala to vote on the aid that provides 40 percent of the country's roughly $ 2 billion annual budget. They ended up voting to maintain help at its promised level -- for now. "If Uganda continues to kind of ignore the problem as it did last year, and do nothing, some of this money will begin to disappear," a senior aid official said in an interview. The official estimated that $ 200 million to $ 300 million is siphoned off through corruption each year -- as much as the World Bank alone spends in the country. "There's a feeling that corruption is much worse than it was," said a diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It's at a higher level with much higher amounts." That feeling extends to the streets of Kampala. Here concern over the Congo war is less pronounced than concern over the chronic insurgency in northern Uganda. But speculation has grown that if the president is surrounded by corruption, "he must be eating as well," as one resident put it. The accusation infuriates Museveni. For suggesting it, opposition politician K.K. Chapaa was charged with sedition; for reporting Chapaa's suggestion, an editor and reporter were jailed beside him. If the reaction smacks of African Big Man politics, however, Museveni characteristically also offered a more measured response. After complaining indignantly to the donors about "paternalistic sermons from some friends abroad," he vowed "to fight the other criminal and corrupt wings of the state" -- but not, apparently, by using the government. "Investigative agencies are not active enough. Maybe they are not well manned," Museveni told the state-owned New Vision newspaper. He thus urged Uganda's lively news media and parliament to help ferret out wrongdoing. "We were asking: Did he want us to back off?" said New Vision editor William Pike, referring to corruption. "His line was, it's not an indictment of his government but a vindication of it that it can be investigated." So it goes in Museveni's Uganda, a vibrant society with nearly all the trappings of democracy but fewer certainties. The conundrum at the heart of Museveni's government is his National Resistance Movement. The "movement system of government" grew out of the guerrilla army he led to power in 1986. It is founded on the idea of perpetual reform, and Ugandans acknowledge that it did wonders with the army that under dictators Amin and Milton Obote had murdered civilians by the hundreds of thousands. "I do give Museveni this," said Chapaa, the opposition politician charged with sedition: "When a soldier stops me at night, I no longer worry that I'm going to be killed." Less popular than the reform of the army has been the outlawing of political parties. Museveni bases the ban on Uganda's "pre-industrial" status. In a country where 80 percent of the people are peasants sharing the same economic interest, Museveni argues that parties can make no positive contribution by consolidating economic or class interests. Their only likely effect, he says, would be division along sectarian or tribal lines. The catch is how much his movement resembles a party itself, especially since the 1996 elections that brought Uganda's parliament back to life. Though dominated by nominal movement members, the legislature features alliances that amount to caucuses, and its independence has forced the resignations of three ministers. "Looking at it from the outside, the ingredients are there for a powerful pluralistic system," said Patrick Quarcoo, host of "The Capital Gang," heard every Saturday morning on one of a dozen newly licensed private FM radio stations. "Only why don't you finalize it?" That option has been promised. Under the constitution approved before the 1996 election -- the first since Museveni came to power 10 years earlier -- Ugandans are scheduled to vote next year on whether to continue with the "movement system" or to allow parties. Legislation now pending before parliament would temporarily legalize "political organizations" to campaign on the referendum. Museveni has grown visibly exasperated, reassuring people that the referendum will in fact occur, but some uncertainty is understandable. When the Uganda Young Democrats last spring convened a series of upcountry "seminars" ostensibly permitted under current law, police closed down one session and clubbed participants of another, said Michael Mabikke, the group's secretary general. "Restrictions create defiance," said Cecilia Ogwal, who heads an offshoot of the Uganda People's Congress, which held power before Museveni. "The government has to create an opening to let off the steam." The tension is the hallmark of Museveni's government: Despite his earnest appeals for building institutions, his movement remains identified, like so many African states, by one man. That may be especially true in the countryside, where the referendum will be decided. An hour north of the capital is the Luwero Triangle where Museveni's guerrillas waged the five-year war that brought him to power. It is also where the president came for a recent retreat when the corruption headlines hit their peak. "The Capital Gang" does not reach radios there. Political opinion remains largely private, but a half-dozen interviews gleaned the outlines of opinions, all deeply anchored in the reality that Ugandans remain among the poorest people in the world. Most of the country's storied economic growth has come in sectors such as hotels and telecommunications, although poverty has been reduced at the margins. "We are not so poor as we were before," said Steven Dennis Sentongo. "Now we are halfway okay." Halfway may not be enough, though. In his 1996 campaign, Museveni won universal acclaim by promising free primary education; two years later, the promise is being delivered spottily. The problem, said Robert Sekitto, a father of four, is that the teacher salaries budgeted in Kampala are not reaching the teachers in Luwero. Corruption "is a big problem," Sekitto said, "even in this area." President and Mrs. Clinton's visit last March to President Museveni, at right, was a vote of confidence in his rule. Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni jailed two journalists. Ugandan army soldiers trained last year in the northern region where a chronic insurgency is continuing.

COUNTRY: UGANDA (94%); AFRICA (92%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Karl Vick's Feb. 7 news story on Uganda was most misleading. While it raises a number of important issues on political developments and corruption, it fails to put these issues in historical context or acknowledge many of the actions the government has taken to address these problems. Mr. Vick spends considerable time giving the views of the opposition and neglects some of the most important reforms the government has implemented. The fact is that today Uganda is an open, stable, democratic country and one of the best economic performers in Africa. The article did note the vibrancy in parliament and the press, but little credit was given for this to the National Resistance Movement (NRM) leadership that has nurtured and facilitated this dramatic change. Today there is an honest debate about the role of parties in Uganda, but the fact that "multiparty" advocates have prominent roles in the government is not mentioned. The constitution, which was developed in an open and consultative way over a two-year period, provides for a referendum that will decide the future role of parties. President Yoweri Museveni has committed himself to live by its results. On corruption, the government has been prepared to speak openly and has acted on cases of abuse. President Museveni acknowledges that the government's performance often is weak and subject to abuse. He stresses that the capacity to deal with this issue must be strengthened, particularly with respect to the police and legal systems. While the article notes the disorder that existed when the NRM government assumed power in 1986, it fails to recognize that past practices of abuse will take time to overcome; in fact many of the most outrageous practices of the past (such as confiscation of land, use of government regulations to bankrupt competitors, attacking the role of the press) have been stopped. And although the article did refer to one of President Museveni's statements at the recent donor meeting, it failed to mention that during the meeting the government presented a detailed plan for dealing with this problem. Moreover, the government has agreed to the public release of a paper the World Bank completed on corruption in Uganda -- the first government in Africa that has been prepared to take this step. Finally, although the article noted the ministerial resignations that parliament was involved in, it didn't mention the recent firing of the inspector general of police for misuse of his office. I want to assure The Post's readers that the fight against corruption remains a high priority of the president and very much a continuation of the fight against the abuses so prominent in the pre-NRM period. Ambassador Embassy of the Republic of Uganda Washington

COUNTRY: NIGERIA (95%); UNITED STATES (94%); FRANCE (79%); EUROPE (79%); AFRICA (79%); GERMANY (79%);
TEXT: The President-elect of Nigeria came to New York yesterday to say that his country, an international pariah for 16 years, is now headed firmly toward democratic rule, privatization of its huge oil industry and an end to decades of official corruption and severe human rights abuse. Olusegun Obasanjo, 61, whose election on Feb. 27 was welcomed by the West, appeared frank and direct as he spoke about the unsavory reputation Nigeria had acquired. But he declined to offer specifics on what he vowed would be sweeping reforms. "I'm sure you are used to bad news from Nigeria," he said, adding that his country had been "among the leading corrupt nations of the world." He said: "There is virtually no sector of our society that has not been wounded. We have to bind the wounds and bring conciliation and unity, give people hope and a sense of belonging and participation." Nigeria is Africa's most populous nation, with 108 million inhabitants. Under Gen. Sani Abacha it suffered five years of ruthless dictatorship, which ended last June when he died unexpectedly. His successor, Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, began reforms, allowing elections that ended in victory for Mr. Obasanjo, a retired general and former President. He is to be inaugurated on May 29. Mr. Obasanjo exuded charisma and self-confidence at a news conference yesterday, with his powerful frame cloaked in a majestic blue robe. He said his trip here, part of a world tour, was aimed at reassuring political and business leaders of his sincerity, skill and determination. He is expected in Washington today to meet with top American officials, including Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and, tentatively, President Clinton, as well as leaders of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. He arrived here from Europe, where he had offered his message of hope to the leaders and investors of France, Germany and Britain, among others. Large advertising spreads in international newsmagazines and on CNN in recent weeks have also sought to drive home the point that Nigeria, one of the world's largest exporters of oil, has embarked on a new course. Mr. Obasanjo was asked yesterday whether he would follow the South African model of healing society's wounds with the equivalent of a Truth and Reconciliation Commission to investigate the misdeeds of his predecessors and their aides. He declined to commit himself. "When I am on the saddle, then I'll make definitive pronouncements," he said. He added that he did not now have the information he needed. He was slightly more forthcoming in an interview with a syndicated columnist, Jonathan Power, that appeared in the Los Angeles Times on Sunday. On corruption, he said, "You must show that the practices you want to get rid of are punished," and added: "I will more than crack the whip. I will use the whip." Mr. Obasanjo, a Yoruba from southern Nigeria, is said to have close links to northern military leaders and was viewed during the election campaign as a bridge between the two regions. He is the only Nigerian ruler ever to have stepped down voluntarily, which he did in 1979. At the time, he set the stage for a democratic system, which was overthrown a few years later. http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); YEMEN (92%); GHANA (92%); MALI (92%); BENIN (92%);
TEXT: TWO THINGS HELD in common by the countries of Benin, Georgia, Guyana, Malawi and Mongolia: Few Americans could find them on a map, and all are emerging democracies. They represent a class of nations that just in the past few years have embraced political reform against large odds and have received little attention for it. So it's appealing that representatives of these and other nations -- Bolivia, El Salvador, Ghana, Guatemala, Macedonia, Mali, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia and Nepal -- will next month gather in Yemen, itself an emerging democracy, to swap advice and seek some measure of recognition. The global trend toward democratization, along with some notable holdouts and recidivists, has been much remarked upon. Countries such as South Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan and Thailand have famously given the lie to those -- most notably in China, Singapore and Burma -- who argued that democracy was not suitable for Asia. Chile and Costa Rica have set well-noted examples for their regions. South Africa is an inspiring story of its own. Many nations emerging from the Soviet Union or its control -- such as Hungary, Poland and Lithuania -- have received at least some well-deserved attention. Now the most populous nations of Africa and Southeast Asia, Nigeria and Indonesia, are soaking up -- as they should -- much of what aid exists for transitional democracies. Relatively out-of-the-way nations such as Mali struggle in the shadow both of the success stories and of the nations gone disastrously wrong. But their struggles are in some ways all the more heroic for their relative obscurity. Moreover, there are practical reasons to help them along. Small countries can have a contagious effect on larger, more strategically significant neighbors; success can set a positive example, backsliding a demoralizing one. And the failure of small countries can have a disproportionate human and financial cost, as Rwanda and Serbia demonstrate. The June conference is sponsored by Yemen's government and the U.S. National Democratic Institute, with help from Japan, Canada and others. Hillary Clinton will attend, as will representatives of the World Bank and other financial institutions, which increasingly recognize a connection between participatory government (they still hesitate to use the d-word) and economic success. The goal of the conference goes beyond morale-boosting; representatives will trade tales on party-building, balancing political and economic reform, fighting corruption and other nitty-gritty of democracy-building. But if there's some morale-boosting, well, good.

COUNTRY: LESOTHO (94%); SWITZERLAND (92%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (88%); SOUTH AFRICA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); GERMANY (72%);
TEXT: It's a tale involving millions of dollars allegedly funneled into Swiss bank accounts by giant international companies competing to build one of the biggest infrastructure projects under construction in the world. The companies stand accused of paying bribes to win lucrative dam-building and engineering contracts on the Highlands Water Project in the southern African kingdom of Lesotho. While bribery in Third World construction projects hardly rates as stunning news, the allegations involve big-name European multinationals, notably ABB Ltd., a Swiss-Swedish firm with about $ 31 billion in revenue last year. Moreover, the project is partly backed by the World Bank, which has recently embarked on an anti-corruption drive. And the case may prove embarrassing to the bank because its new anti-bribery guidelines won't necessarily apply. The allegations, spelled out in a charge sheet that Lesotho authorities filed July 28 against Masupha Sole, the former head of the project, contain highly specific data on payments totaling about $ 2 million that 12 companies, mostly European, allegedly provided for deposit in Sole's bank accounts in South Africa and Switzerland. A Swiss court has also found evidence indicating that the bribes were paid, according to the Swiss newspaper Sonntags Zeitung. The list of companies "reads like a Who's Who of the dam-building industry," said Patrick McCully, campaigns director of the International Rivers Network, a California-based environmental activist group that opposes dams. According to the charges, ABB paid Sole about $ 40,000. Spie Batignolles of France allegedly provided about $ 120,000, Impregilo of Italy allegedly paid $ 250,000, ED Zueblin of Germany allegedly chipped in about $ 447,000, and Acres International of Canada allegedly paid about $ 188,000. Several of the companies, contacted by The Washington Post, denied paying bribes to win contracts in Lesotho. "No payment for whatever sum at whatever time has been made by Impregilo" to Sole, said Romano Allione, an official of the Italian company. John Fox, a spokesman for ABB, said: "We have been working with the Lesotho authorities, supporting their investigation. About allegations, I can't comment at this point." But some corruption experts said that if the accusations pan out, the firms should be "debarred" by the World Bank--that is, prohibited from bidding on projects funded by the bank, a major source of financing for dams in developing countries. A little more than two years ago, the bank cracked down on bribery after a speech by its president, James D. Wolfensohn, denouncing the "cancer of corruption" and its corrosive impact on poor countries. The bank, which has 181 member countries, adopted guidelines pledging to "declare a firm ineligible, either indefinitely or for a stated period of time, to be awarded a bank-financed contract" if the firm is found to have "engaged in corrupt or fraudulent practices in competing for, or in executing, a bank-financed contract." So far, the bank has debarred nine relatively small companies, but it's far from certain that the companies accused of bribery in the Lesotho case will suffer punishment by the bank even if the charges are proven. That's because, although the bank was heavily involved in formulating the project, it lent only about $ 100 million of the estimated $ 2.4 billion cost, for objectives such as engineering design and access roads--and the companies listed in the indictment may be able to avoid debarment by claiming that they won contracts for other parts of the project. Indeed, the World Bank's official statement on the Lesotho scandal suggests as much. "We eagerly await the outcome of the court case, at which point the World Bank will decide on further steps," said Junaid Ahmad, the bank's deputy resident representative in South Africa. "We will conduct an internal investigation to ensure that Bank policies and procedures have been followed on the components of the project that have been financed by the World Bank." The bank's acting general counsel, Daoud Khairallah, said yesterday: "We cannot eradicate corruption in all situations where we have no control. . . . If any of our funds have been tampered with, yes, we can debar. But not if it's something that we didn't have any control over." Jeremy Pope, executive director of Transparency International, an organization dedicating to fighting corruption, voiced incredulity that the companies might get off the hook. "It's a project the World Bank was involved in, and logic says--if you're bribing, you're bribing; and if you're unfit to be bidding for business, you're unfit." In any event, he said, "when these companies go bidding for public sector business, their competitors will use this and say, 'If you do a deal with that lot, everyone will think you've been bribed.' " The bank's anti-corruption efforts are part of a broader drive against bribery in the industrialized world. After considerable agitation by the United States, which made it a crime in 1977 for U.S. firms to bribe foreign officials, the 29 wealthy countries belonging to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development ratified a convention in December 1997 pledging to criminalize foreign bribery. But less than half of the nations have passed the necessary laws, and in any case the alleged bribery of Sole took place before the convention was adopted. The Lesotho project is located in a country of about 2 million, entirely surrounded by South Africa, that is rated as one of the world's poorest, with almost no natural resources other than water. The project, which includes a dam more than 600 feet high, provides water to an industrial region of South Africa and provides employment to Lesotho, most of whose workers must find jobs in South Africa. But the International Rivers Network charges that the project has disrupted communities and led to the establishment of squatters' camps, replete with prostitution and AIDS, in once-remote mountain communities. The group also asserts that massive bribery is predictable in such projects--and notes that some of the companies named in the Lesotho indictment have figured in other corruption scandals involving dams. The follwing have been accused of paying bribes to win contracts for a major project in Lesotho:  Project: Highlands Water Venture Country: Int'l consortium Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: $ 733,404  Project: ED Zueblin Country: Germany Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 447,425  Project: Impregilo Country: Italy Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 250,000  Project: Acres International Country: Canada Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 188,229  Project: Spie Batignolles Country: France Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 120,192  Project: Dumez International Country: France Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 82,973  Project: LHPC Chantiers Country: Int'l consortium Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 64,332  Project: LHPC Country: Int'l consortium Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 57,651  Project: ABB Country: Sweden, Switzerland Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 40,681  Project: Sogreah Country: France Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 13,669  Project: Lahmeyer Consulting Engineers Country: Germany Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 8,732  Project: Diwi Consulting Country: Germany Alleged bribe amt. in U.S. dollars: 2,456  NOTE: Figures converted at recent exchange rates. This dam is the centerpiece of the $ 2.4 billion Lesotho Highlands Water Project.

COUNTRY: LESOTHO (94%); SOUTH AFRICA (92%); AFRICA (92%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: The article "Big Firms Accused of Bribery in African Dam Project" cites World Bank claims that it had a limited role in the Lesotho Highlands Water Project because it made only a small contribution to the multibillion-dollar financing scheme [Business, Aug. 13]. Nothing could be further from the truth. Not only did the World Bank finance the design of the project; it also is responsible for setting up and coordinating the financing program. According to a confidential World Bank project document, in 1991 the bank agreed to participate in a trust for offshore lenders "to provide some comfort for lenders who might otherwise be reluctant to assist in the financing." This type of comfort was needed because of the international sanctions then in place against the apartheid regime in South Africa. According to the same document, the World Bank loan for the project went only nominally to Lesotho, a country far too poor to qualify for large loans, while the real borrower was South Africa's apartheid regime. It is unacceptable for the World Bank to claim that it is a passive bystander in the unfolding corruption investigation. Should the corruption allegation be substantiated, the World Bank must debar the companies involved in the bribery from future World Bank-financed activities. It also should launch an investigation into its own role in this controversial project. Besides serious allegations of corruption, the project, which includes the highest dam in Africa, has caused the vulnerable Highlands population to lose fields, grazing lands and access to fresh water sources. Despite promises, their livelihoods have not been reestablished, and poor people have been pushed closer to the edge in their struggle for survival. Problems of erosion and the downstream effects of massive water diversion will disrupt ecosystems and people's livelihoods. In Lesotho, as in many places, corruption, environmental degradation and increasing poverty have a tendency to go together. Director, Southern Africa Program International Rivers Network Berkeley, Calif. Senior Environmental Economist Environmental Defense Fund Washington

COUNTRY: LESOTHO (94%); SOUTH AFRICA (94%); AFRICA (93%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: In their Aug. 23 letter, Lori Pottinger of the International Rivers Network and Korinna Horta of the Environmental Defense Fund expressed concern about alleged corruption in the Lesotho Highlands Water Project. We agree that such allegations must be taken seriously. For this reason, we are pleased that the governments of Lesotho and South Africa have investigated the matter promptly and brought the case to court. We also agree -- indeed, we are proud -- that the World Bank played a leading role in making this important project happen, even if our financial contribution was less than 5 percent of total costs. Our commitment to preventing corruption extends well beyond our financial involvement in a project. Corruption hurts the poor most of all -- whether it involves official aid, private investment or the use of a developing country's own taxpayers' money. Therefore, we are determined to help African countries fight corruption in all its forms. The Lesotho project was in the making for more than 20 years and is important for southern Africa as a whole, not just Lesotho. In addition to meeting South Africa's water needs, the project is helping poor communities in Lesotho through a social fund set up with revenues from the project. World Bank involvement helped ensure that the project was designed to the highest economic, social and environmental standards. Large development projects can carry special risks, but they can be designed successfully. Most non-governmental organizations in Lesotho and South Africa support the project and appreciate the openness and care with which it was prepared. Dealing seriously with corruption is consistent with that openness and with the World Bank's interest in seeing such projects serve the poor. Washington The writers are vice presidents for the Africa region at the World Bank.

COUNTRY: LESOTHO (94%); AFRICA (93%);
TEXT: In their Sept. 12 letter regarding corruption allegations in the Lesotho Highlands Water Project (LHWP), Callisto E. Madavo and Jean-Louis Sarbib of the World Bank claim they are "determined to help African countries fight corruption." We, as members of nongovernmental organizations in Lesotho, appreciate this sentiment. We are troubled, however, by their failure to promise World Bank sanctions against the 12 multinational corporations accused of bribing the former chief executive of the LHWP. What better way is there to "fight corruption" than to punish the big companies that tempt us "poor" Africans with big bribes? Mr. Madavo and Mr. Sarbib also claim that the project is "helping poor communities in Lesotho through a social fund" set up with LHWP revenues. Unfortunately, this is not our perception here on the ground. The fund has been and continues to be a tool of opportunistic politicians. Although the committee designated to select projects to be supported by the social fund has not yet met, money from the fund has been used to support ill-conceived projects built by workers hired according to political party affiliation. In Lesotho we see the same stretch of road repaired, torn up the next week, repaired again the following week and then torn up once more at the end of the month. We see workers increase the height of unused dams and then cut spillways in them that effectively reduce their carrying capacities to their original levels. These projects are supported by the LHWP's social fund. Is this how large development projects "serve the poor"? We do support the LHWP, but we are beginning to question the openness and care with which it was prepared. Punishing the corrupt multinationals involved with the LHWP and closely monitoring the implementation of the project's social fund would reassure us of the World Bank's concern. If Mr. Madavo and Mr. Sarbib want to serve the "poor," they can help us to challenge the existing power and economic relations that keep us "poor." Transformation Resource Centre Highlands Church Solidarity and Action Centre Maseru, Lesotho

COUNTRY: EUROPE (93%); KOREA, REPUBLIC OF (92%); GERMANY (92%); NORTHERN EUROPE (92%); LATIN AMERICA (79%); PHILIPPINES (79%); AUSTRALIA (79%); CANADA (79%); MOROCCO (79%); MALAYSIA (79%); INDONESIA (79%); INDIA (79%); ARGENTINA (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (79%); BRAZIL (79%); AFRICA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); TAIWAN (79%); ASIA (79%); NIGERIA (79%); THAILAND (77%);
TEXT: Transparency International, an independent organization that tracks corruption among government officials around the world, announced yesterday that it had added a new index to rank nations that appear to condone bribe paying by their companies doing business abroad. The organization, based in Berlin, which released both reports, the Corruption Perceptions Index and the Bribe Payers Index, in Washington, found that once again officials in northern European countries were perceived to have the cleanest hands, while the highest levels of bribe-taking officials appeared to be in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the former Soviet bloc. When it came to countries whose companies pay bribes abroad, China was perceived to be the worst offender, followed by South Korea, Taiwan, Italy and Malaysia. No country's corporations were regarded as innocent of bribe paying. But the Europeans, Australia and Canada came out best. The idea that corruption is a third world phenomenon raises tempers in developing countries every year when the Corruption Perceptions Index is published. The survey this year is the fifth and largest. "There was a sense in some countries that we were a group from the richer north that was singling out the poor countries" said Frank Vogl, a former World Bank official and now vice chairman of Transparency International, which he helped found in 1993. "People said that basically there is a conspiracy of corruption between the takers of bribes and the givers of bribes, and it should be recognized. We thought we would create a Bribe Payers Index." Both indices plot perceptions, not concrete evidence, though in different ways. The Corruption Perception Index is a "poll of polls," based on data from 17 surveys from 10 independent institutions that analyze business conditions around the world. The 1999 index includes 99 countries, up from 85 last year. The Bribe Payers Index was based on a survey conducted for Transparency International by Gallup International in 14 leading emerging-market countries. They were Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Morocco, Nigeria, the Philippines, Poland, Russia, South Korea, South Africa and Thailand.  Gallup International, which is based in London, interviewed 770 senior executives in those nations. Mr. Vogl said in an interview on Friday in New York that the two indices were "two sides of the same coin." He said it was fashionable now to be against corruption and to demand that developing countries clean house before aid was granted. "But there is hypocrisy," he added. "Many major industrial countries do quite well on the C.P.I. Yet they are not discouraging their own firms from corrupting foreign governments." Although the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of industrial countries, has adopted a convention making bribery of foreign officials a criminal offense, member nations have not stopped the practice, Mr. Vogl said. No country scored a perfect 10 on the Bribe Payers scale, where a low score indicates corrupt practices. The best rating was Sweden's at 8.3, followed by 8.1 for Australia and Canada. The United States, which has had a Foreign Corrupt Practices Act on the books for 22 years, scored 6.2. At the bottom, China registered 3.1. On the Corruption Perceptions Index, the ranking by the perceived honesty of officials, there was one perfect score. Denmark scored 10. The United States had 7.5, behind the northern Europeans, Singapore and Hong Kong. Transparency International, founded six years ago by a small group of people who had seen development aid fail to achieve its goals as corruption flourished, has 77 national chapters. Mr. Vogl said he was impressed less by that growth than by the explosion of public demand that governments and businesses stop corrupting one another. Concerns about corruption are finally becoming part of policy making, he said, pointing to the questions that Washington is now confronting about dealing with Russia. "Five years ago, we couldn't get into the World Bank," Mr. Vogl said. "We were told that this was politics." Now, he added, there is a "vast civil society movement" that is asking questions in many capitals about why health care or other services receive no money while officials buy airplanes. http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (94%); UZBEKISTAN (93%); INDONESIA (93%); CAMEROON (93%); NIGERIA (93%); AZERBAIJAN (92%); GERMANY (92%);
TEXT: LIKE music CD's, box office receipts and the world's richest people, corruption has its own top 10 list. For the last five years Transparency International, a nonprofit group based in Berlin that specializes in tracking global thievery, has released the annual Corruption Perceptions Index, ranking the world's most corrupt countries. Last week the group declared Cameroon, Nigeria, Indonesia, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, Honduras, Tanzania, Yugoslavia, Paraguay and Kenya as the world's most graft-ridden countries, populated by public officials who are much quicker to take bribes than their counterparts in countries like Denmark, New Zealand and Sweden. But while Transparency's work has been lauded by economists and other analysts for helping to make corruption a centerpiece of debates about economic development and public policy, critics say the group's hit list unfairly tars countries that may be no more corrupt than those ranked much lower on the list. Indeed, the critics say the media is so quick to latch on to top 10 lists that agencies like Transparency International have an obvious incentive to present their information that way to score public relations coups. All the attention generated by the Corruption Perceptions Index, and criticism that it tended to highlight poor countries without noting the role that industrialized countries play in fomenting corruption abroad, led Transparency to introduce yet another ranking last week -- the Bribe Payers Index. "One of the worries people have had is that the ranking is very misleading," Rafael di Tella, an economics professor at Harvard Business School and one of Transparency's outside advisors, said of the Corruption Perceptions Index. "Transparency International has become a slave to the success of the index and it doesn't want to address the problem." The problem, as Mr. di Tella and others see it, is that the data used to analyze corruption -- surveys, for example, of business executives' perceptions -- are so fuzzy that huge margins of error exist when assigning a numerical yardstick to graft. Johann Graf Lambsdorff, a German statistician responsible for orchestrating Transparency's numbers into a coherent whole, says critics of the list unfairly imply that his methodology is faulty when, in fact, the only issue is how the results of Transparency's surveys are presented. Even so, Mr. Lambsdorff says he is comfortable with his group's list. "A ranking is easier to convey information to a large public, like a football ranking," said Mr. Lambsdorff, a professor at Gottingen University. "We can clearly say that Denmark is cleaner than Germany and Germany is cleaner than Botswana. But in between there may be some problems -- saying that Kenya is cleaner than Tanzania, for example." But that is precisely the problem, say critics, pointing to Bolivia's Presidential election in 1997 as an example of the list's far-reaching influence. The former dictator Hugo Banzer won the Presidency that year on an anti-corruption platform bolstered by the release of Transparency's rankings shortly before the election -- rankings showing that corruption in Bolivia was worse than in many of its neighbors. Mr. Lambsdorff says Transparency cannot avoid having such an impact because elections are occurring in many countries when their rankings are released. "We keep on stressing that these are perceptions, not hard facts," said Frank Vogl, Transparency International's vice-chairman and co-founder. "You always have this problem of how to present the data." Nonetheless, the list has stirred dissent within the group's own membership. "Transparency's index was good when there were no other numbers available but we need to go further now," said Luis Moreno Ocampo, a prominent anti-corruption crusader in Argentina who is a member of Transparency's advisory council. "The issue is not which country is worse than another, the issue is how to solve the problem. We need to track where the money is going and who is stealing it." Mr. Moreno has been working with the World Bank to come up with new methods of measuring and presenting data on corruption. Daniel Kaufmann, a senior manager with the World Bank, says grouping countries in broad categories -- rather than ranking them -- is the fairest way to shine a spotlight on corruption. "The idea that Transparency International had is brilliant and now we all want to be more rigorous and circumspect when we analyze corruption," he said.  http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: COTE D'IVOIRE (96%); AFRICA (95%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); FRANCE (90%); KENYA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Army troops in the West African country of Ivory Coast seized control of the capital, Abidjan, today and proclaimed a military government, an uprising unprecedented in a country long considered one of Africa's most stable. Soldiers began seizing government installations Thursday in what they said was a mutiny by an Abidjan-based unit over unpaid wages. Today, the former army chief of staff, Gen. Robert Guei, announced on state television that President Henri Konan Bedie was no longer in power. But Bedie said later in a radio interview that he retained power and was meeting with mutinous troops. Bedie appealed for popular resistance to the coup, but poor people in Abidjan's vast slums cheered his reported overthrow, said residents. Bedie's Democratic Party of Ivory Coast--the only party that has ruled there in nearly 40 years of independence--has lost support in the past decade over official corruption and rising demands for real democracy. Still, as some senior military officers and foreign diplomats reportedly implored Guei to halt the coup, independent observers found reason to hope that the crisis might be resolved peacefully. Ivory Coast--known officially by its French name, Cote d'Ivoire--has a large, educated middle class and civil society unlikely to support military rule. The strongest reason for optimism lay in how strongly the flavor of events once so common to transfers of power in Africa--dueling broadcasts, mutinous soldiers firing automatic weapons into the air and a man in uniform declaring the constitution null and void--now seemed out of place. Since the end of the Cold War, coups have become less frequent in Africa and, indeed, have never occurred in Ivory Coast. Self-appointed rulers who once could count on the United States or the Soviet Union to prop them up must answer to an array of Western donors, starting with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. And their primary condition for foreign aid is at least the appearance of democracy. "That's the new atmosphere," said Herman J. Cohen, a former assistant secretary of state for Africa. "This general on the television doesn't seem to realize that." Ivory Coast, long ruled by the French troops and bureaucrats who created it, has remained one of France's most loyal former colonies in Africa. Its founder, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, ruled the country tightly for 33 years, permitting opposing political parties only when he could no longer prevent them without heavy bloodshed. Bedie, a bland machine politician in the ruling party, took power when Houphouet-Boigny died in 1993. Bedie won a disputed election and rode out protests and riots in 1995 after disqualifying his chief opponent. Soon after, Bedie dismissed Guei as army chief; officials alleged that Guei had been plotting a coup. On Thursday, soldiers drove into the state television station and fired into the air when some employees resisted orders to leave. Some of the employees fled to the U.S. Embassy's cultural center around the corner, and told Washington Post researcher Solomon Ababio that the troops were demanding back pay for their unit's service in a U.N. peacekeeping mission in the Central African Republic. In numerous parts of Abidjan, soldiers looted shops and were joined by impoverished civilians, residents said. No deaths were reported. Guei appeared on state television today, saying he had taken power at the troops' request. "From this instant, President Henri Konan Bedie is no longer the president of the republic," he said, and proclaimed the dissolution of parliament and other government institutions. A Military Committee of Public Salvation announced a dusk-to-dawn curfew and called on soldiers to cease looting. From a hiding place in the city's diplomatic neighborhood, Bedie responded in an interview on Radio France Internationale. He called on Ivorians to "resist and oppose this grotesque and retrograde military coup by all means possible," and vowed to remain at his post. He pledged to resolve the pay demands of the soldiers through "dialogue." An American reached by telephone in Abidjan described the mutineering soldiers as raucous, but said residents were calm. "There are [soldiers] roaring through the streets looking pretty ugly, with cars that have obviously been stolen," the resident said. "All the danger is potential danger, but the potential danger is there." The Christmas Eve crisis followed months of mounting opposition to Bedie. Like virtually all black African states created as European-ruled colonies, Ivory Coast is an artificial mix of ethnic groups. While Houphouet-Boigny ran an authoritarian government, he assiduously dampened ethnic tensions, partly by distributing wealth from the cocoa farms that are the pillar of the economy. But cocoa prices have fallen and the economy has struggled to keep up with a flood of immigration from Burkina Faso, Mali, Liberia, Ghana and other neighbors. In 1995, Bedie--an ethnic Baoule from the country's center--alienated many Muslim northerners by disqualifying northerner Alassane Ouattara from the presidential race, and tensions over that issue have revived as Bedie faces reelection next fall. "For a place where things are good, things are bad at the moment in Ivory Coast," said I. William Zartman, director of African Studies at the Johns Hopkins University's School of Advanced International Studies. He said the coup could yet be reversed or result in a more even-handed election than Bedie was prepared to allow. Correspondent James Rupert contributed to this report.

COUNTRY: COTE D'IVOIRE (97%); EUROPE (94%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (90%); CANADA (79%); FRANCE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%);
TEXT: Accusing the ousted government of plundering state coffers, Ivory Coast's first military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, said today that he was suspending the country's staggering foreign-debt payments. General Guei's announcement apparently reversed his pledge last week to honor international commitments inherited from the elected government that he ousted in a coup on Christmas Eve. "We have temporarily suspended payments of foreign commitments," General Guei said in a statement, explaining that coffers were empty. "Only after a thousand gymnastic moves were we even able to pay salaries." "As you can imagine, the pillage was immense and systematic," General Guei said in the statement. He said his administration had begun auditing state accounts to learn who is responsible for missing funds. He did not say whether Ivory Coast intended to resume debt payments later on to the World Bank, European Union, International Monetary Fund and other lenders. On Tuesday, General Guei named himself president and defense minister in an interim coalition government. The new cabinet was sworn in today. Ivory Coast, long one of Africa's most stable and prosperous countries, built up a huge debt -- estimated at $19.7 billion in 1996 -- during nearly four decades under the party of the ousted president, Henri Konan Bedie. The junta's move to halt debt payments threatens to aggravate the financial crisis. Last year, the monetary fund and the European Union slashed aid to the country after corruption allegations against the Bedie government. Since the coup, the United States and Canada have also cut aid to the West African country. France, the former colonial ruler, is scaling back its support. And the European Union's representative, Catherine Travin, said today that European officials were scheduled to hold talks with the junta that could lead to further aid cuts. The coup came during an economic decline linked to falling prices for Ivory Coast's main exports, coffee and cocoa. Tensions increased sharply during the final months of Mr. Bedie's government, which was widely accused of corruption and stirring ethnic enmities.  http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: LATIN AMERICA (92%); ASIA (92%); INDIA (79%); BRAZIL (79%); MEXICO (79%); EUROPE (79%); AFRICA (79%); MIDDLE EAST (79%); BANGLADESH (78%); THAILAND
TEXT: During the past few days a good deal of coverage has been focused on the Meltzer Commission Report on the International Financial Institutions, and what it might mean for the World Bank. Let me take this opportunity to lay out some real concerns that we at the bank have, and also to set the record straight. We are, of course, pleased that the issue of poverty reduction should be headline news. We share the commission's concern that more must be done by all the players in the fight against poverty, and we applaud all who broach this difficult subject. We also welcome the commission's call for debt relief, and we hope that funding support from Congress will follow it. This is crucial. We nevertheless believe that a number of the commission's proposals are based on a fundamental misreading of the development challenges we face today. Poor people in developing countries will be the losers if these proposals are implemented. If the World Bank were to withdraw entirely from Asia and from Latin America; if it were to stop lending to countries with a per capita income above $ 4,000 a year, it would cut out the marginalized, the poorest, the excluded who live in these countries. Private-sector investors will not fund the improvements in health, education and other essential public services that people need to pull themselves out of poverty. Moreover, if the World Bank were to stop lending for anti-corruption work, good governance, regulatory reform and institution building, it would cease to create the kind of enabling environment that can attract private funds to countries and areas that currently receive little. No other organization is doing this work on a global scale. A critical strength of the World Bank is its ability to learn from developing countries in all regions of the world and to reflect those lessons in its policy advice and operations and in its global research programs. Under the commission's proposal to devolve country programs to regional development banks, our clients would be limited to countries in Africa, the Middle East, Europe and the former Soviet Union. This would undermine the World Bank's global character at the very time that the demands of globalization are pointing in the opposite direction. The loss of the bank's cross-regional perspective and the synergies it generates would hurt everyone--especially the poor of the developing world. But the burden would fall heaviest on the 2.2 billion people living on less than $ 2 per day in Asia and Latin America, since the bank would no longer be involved in country programs there. We would need to withdraw our support for maternal health in Bangladesh, AIDS programs in India, legal reform in Thailand, social security reform in Brazil, financial sector reform in Mexico and so on. Reflecting other commission recommendations, we also would need to withdraw from important country programs in Europe, such as Poland, where we have supported the creation of market-friendly legal and regulatory frameworks and financial sector and health care reforms. Nor do the commission's recommendations seem to be supported by sound analysis and careful use of statistics. The report states that 70 percent of the World Bank's non-concessional lending goes to 11 countries that have substantial access to capital markets, but it ignores the fact that these countries are home to more than 60 percent of the poor people in the developing world. The report's authors also fault the bank for neglecting its own insight that aid can be effective only in countries with good policies. But in 1997-99, the best-performing countries annually received almost five times more International Development Association resources per capita than poor performers. We have changed, and we are changing. By the late 1990s, the financial sector and the social sectors--such as education and health--absorbed about a quarter each of total annual World Bank lending, up from around 5 percent each during the early 1980s. None of this is reflected in the commission's report. Nor is the fact that our operational performance has improved markedly over the past few years. Instead, the report bases much of its argument on a distorted use of statistics on bank effectiveness. We welcome debate. But we need to test the commission's recommendations against the challenges that we face on the ground every day. Unfortunately, against this measure I believe that many of them significantly miss the mark.  The writer is president of the World Bank.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); AFRICA (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (73%);
TEXT: The World Bank has often been accused of doing more to hurt the poor than help them. The latest charge comes from Congress's Meltzer Commission ["Limiting the Scope of the World Bank," op-ed, March 13]. Yet the bank president's response is to repeat in various ways a single mantra: If the World Bank's powers are restricted or limited in any way, the poor of the world will suffer. But James Wolfensohn evades the real question: Does the bank really help the poor? There is ample evidence that it does not. From 1980 to 1997, per-capita income for sub-Saharan Africa, which is largely under World Bank tutelage, fell by 21.6 percent. The bank's structural adjustment policies force countries to reduce services to the poor in order to service foreign debt owed to the bank as well as to private corporations. Forty percent of the World Bank Group's lending is for extraction industries--oil, gas and mining--that are accompanied by environmental destruction, corruption, forced relocation of the poor and indigenous and the enrichment of multinational corporations. Washington

COUNTRY: AFRICA (95%); WESTERN AFRICA (93%); CAMEROON (79%); CHAD (79%);
TEXT: Moving a World Bank loan closer to approval, the Chevron Corporation has agreed to take a 25 percent stake in a long-delayed Exxon Mobil Corporation-led oil production and pipeline project in Africa. Participation in the $3.5 billion Doba oil fields project, which is expected to yield 1 billion barrels over as long as 30 years, would build on the company's existing West African production, Chevron said. The pipeline, which would run from Chad to Cameroon in West Africa, has encountered repeated opposition. The opponents say that government corruption would siphon off pipeline revenue meant to ease poverty in the region, and that the project lacks safeguards against pollution.  http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: CAMEROON (94%); CHAD (94%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: To the Editor: An April 1 editorial describes the dynamics that have led to tragic reprisals against environmental activists. It is even more tragic that the next such crisis could be financed by the World Bank. The State Department's 1999 human rights report had a litany of human rights abuses by Chad and Cameroon, including extrajudicial killings, "disappearances" and female genital mutilation. Yet the World Bank is poised to lend $300 million to them and to the Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Chevron Corporation to develop oil fields in Chad and build a pipeline to Cameroon. Political corruption in the two countries makes it unlikely that any pipeline revenue will pay for programs for the poor, which the World Bank touts as its primary mission.  More likely are loss of land, environmental degradation and worsening repression. DELPHINE DJIRAIBE Washington, April 3, 2000 The writer is president of the Chadian Association for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights. http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Why shouldn't countries pay their bills? I have to pay mine. That's a critical question hanging over the "dump the debt" rally scheduled to take place on the Mall this afternoon, when demonstrators will urge international lenders to write off the hundreds of billions of dollars owed to them by the world's poorest nations. Without declaring bankruptcy and giving up control of our own finances, most of us cannot imagine being excused from paying back money we had borrowed--and if we did, we certainly wouldn't expect the bank to lend to us again. Even World Bank President James Wolfensohn--who supports a certain amount of debt relief himself--thinks it would be "whimsical" to cancel every nation's debt. "If you have a society based on debt forgiveness," Wolfensohn said in February, "who's going to invest in debt anymore? So you really screw up the market." In more than one Third World embassy here in Washington, the same fear has been expressed. Of course these diplomats want debt relief. But their countries are poor, many of them devastated by natural disasters or civil wars, and they will surely need to borrow more money to survive and develop. What bank would throw good money after bad? Let's consider that question. In particular, let's consider Africa, the continent where 33 of the 41 Heavily Indebted Poor Countries--the HIPC nations, so defined by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund--can be found, and therefore the continent on which much of the debt-relief campaign is focused. Having spent much of the last 20 years reporting and writing from Africa, I'll begin with a bit of history.  The bottom began falling out of African economies in the early 1970s. Most nations had been independent for little more than a decade, and either didn't understand--or didn't want to--that the boom in prices for their mineral and agricultural exports was not permanent. Inexperienced or corrupt leaders borrowed, spent and then borrowed some more, urged on by Western commercial lenders eager to start earning interest on the petrodollars that had been deposited in their banks by newly flush OPEC moguls. This symbiosis of greedy governments and overeager lenders meant that billions of dollars flowed into African nations for economic expansion, which often took the form of huge industrialization projects and ostentatious, politically visible structures in capital cities. In addition, about 20 percent of the funds lent during these Cold War years went to arms purchases. Debt was increasing but new governments did not feel it. The lenders were getting their initial paybacks. Good money was borrowed and thrown after bad whenever needed. Everyone was making out like bandits; everyone, that is, except poor African citizens, growing in numbers and generally not sharing the wealth of their rulers. Then came the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979, which triggered worldwide inflation and recession. Prices for African commodities collapsed; prices for basic necessities like fuel and fertilizer skyrocketed. By the early 1980s, Africa was reeling just as repayment on loans taken out a few years earlier came due. Most of Africa's debt at that time was owed to private banks. When these institutions realized African nations could not cover their debts, they lobbied multilateral agencies such as the IMF to lend African countries the money to pay off the debts. That's how Citibank got out of bad loans to the country then called Zaire (and it helped that Mobutu Sese Seko's Zaire was a Cold War ally of the United States). Citibank got bailed out, but Zaire (now Congo) didn't--it just owed money to a different lender. Trapped in this ruinous cycle of debt servitude and underdevelopment, Africa and its people have paid a heavy price. Ironically, within this historical experience lie truths that argue for the possible success of debt relief. To put the argument briefly, things are changing in Africa, and some things already have changed significantly. These days, both banks and wealthy governments are much more cautious about their money. The rules for lending are tougher: The U.S. government can no longer simply sign off on a loan made for political reasons without paying attention to how the money will be used. Loans are made more responsibly than in the aggressive Cold War years. And the lenders have a practical goal: Africa, like China, does not have to be a drag on the world economy if it can use its natural resources and labor force in productive work. And developed economies would mean future markets for the West in Africa. Meanwhile, the governments seeking debt relief today are dramatically different than those that fell into ruin. Military rule and "Big Man" government have gone out of fashion in Africa; Mobutu and his fellow "kleptocrats" are largely gone. Africa's new governments, I believe, are smarter and less corrupt. I once asked Issaias Afwerki, president of Eritrea--a country that didn't exist as a separate entity a decade ago--what it had meant to his people to fight their 30-year war for independence from Ethiopia. "If there was any good in a conflict of such length," Afwerki responded, "it was that it gave you a chance to watch and learn from everybody's mistakes and to plan how to avoid them." Apparently, he is avoiding at least some of them: The World Bank Web site advises that even though Eritrea has a per capita GNP less than half the African average, "the economic outlook is promising because of sound management and relatively diversified production." While democracy is far from perfected on the continent, I can tick off a list of leaders from the Indian Ocean to the Atlantic who are seriously engaged in developing civil societies that respond to citizen concerns and needs. Certainly there are still regions of terrible armed conflict--Angola comes immediately to mind--but conflict need not define what Africa is today. As a practical matter, the continent is a better place to lend money than it was a generation ago. The truth of that statement is what underlies the African Growth and Opportunities Act, a House bill with broad bipartisan support that aims to promote development by easing trade barriers. If you're cynical, you'll say governments there will squander any new loans all over again. The Africa I see suggests the opposite. In fact, there already is a consensus among commercial banks, multilateral lending institutions and governments that there has to be debt relief. This is a pragmatic, not a charitable, conclusion. Every banker in the world knows that it has become impossible for the HIPCs to pay their staggering debts. African countries alone owe $ 227 billion; Mozambique's tab is $ 1.4 million a week.  To pay that off, every bit of work and every cent of earnings would have to go toward debt payments. That would be politically unsustainable--and if Mozambique's government collapses, nobody's going to get paid anything. That's why some lenders have already begun--slowly--to reduce the debt, through limited cancellation, some restructuring and some rescheduling. In fact, agreement was reached at an international summit in Cologne, Germany, last June to cancel about $ 111 billion of the $ 354 billion owed by poor nations. "It's not like the [World] Bank, the [IMF] fund, and the United States are waiting for their money," Lisa Wright, a Church World Services official who tracks the debt issue closely, told me recently. In other words, the money has already been lost. So forgiving the debt usually means little more than changing an entry in a ledger. And how will that ledger entry be accounted for? Well, the IMF can make up some of its losses by selling off part of its 103-million-ounce gold reserves. The United States, Britain and other wealthy nations are kicking in some money to a new multilateral debt relief trust fund. (The European Union promises to put up $ 700 million when the United States hands over the $ 600 million it promised last year.) This is essentially foreign aid by another name; some brave bureaucrats are even willing to float the idea that instead of loans the poorest HIPCs should get direct grants. None of these partial measures, of course, satisfies critics like those in Jubilee 2000, the debt-relief group that has organized today's rally. They say that the "structural adjustments" proposed under the HIPC program would force debtor nations to make such strict economic reforms that they would have to abandon vital social programs. They have three broad but closely related objections to the HIPC program: It's too little too late; the burden of debt servicing is still too heavy; and it is designed to serve the needs of creditors rather than the poor. But the World Bank and the IMF emphatically reject full cancellation of debt as unrealistic. Cancellation would raise false expectations of assistance that could not be met because foreign aid money is so limited, they argue. Besides, they also say, sounding very much like a relief worker at the African grass roots, debt is only part of a larger social problem. The IMF and the World Bank also claim to have learned from past mistakes--and they want to make sure their largess is responsibly used. In the end, the question is not whether debt should be forgiven; it's how fast and to what extent. My experience suggests that the faster and broader the debt relief, the better for Africa--and the world. Charles Cobb Jr. is senior editor and diplomatic correspondent for allAfrica.com and Africa News Service.

COUNTRY: UGANDA (94%); UNITED STATES (79%);
TEXT: Plans by Uganda to acquire a new Gulfstream jet for its president have led international lenders to put off a decision on new debt relief for that country. The delay is an embarrassing new complication for a global debt-relief program that Congress is skeptical about funding. Uganda, an early participant in the program, has won praise for using the savings from canceled debt payments to improve primary education. The International Monetary Fund and World Bank had hoped to announce approval of an expanded package for Uganda at a meeting of their governing committees this week here. But last week officials delayed implementing the plan, some of them appalled at the idea of forgiving more loans just when a luxury jet was ordered. Sources said the reported cost of the plane, about $ 35 million, is about what Uganda would save annually in debt-service payments under an expanded aid plan that now has been delayed. Thousands of demonstrators were expected to turn out today to protest the World Bank and IMF, which they say finance a world order based on exploitation. The institutions have cited the debt-relief program as proof that they care about countries left behind by the global economy and are taking tough decisions to help them. The program grows from a decision last year by industrial nations to forgive $ 28 billion in debt owed to the World Bank and other "multilateral" lenders. More than 30 countries could potentially qualify. The core requirement is that money saved on debt payments must go to schools, public health programs and other desperately needed services. Participating countries must work out detailed plans with lenders--the idea is to assure that corruption and local political priorities that often led to the squandering of the original loans don't lead to the misuse of money saved on debt service. With Congress delaying a White House request for funding of the U.S. share of the global program, proponents were worried that the delay would give new ammunition to the program's critics. Some were urging Uganda to reverse itself. "We don't think that the plane is pro-poor . . . and we think the government of Uganda should reconsider its priorities as soon as possible," said Seth Amgott, a spokesman for Oxfam International, a relief agency that has promoted the debt-relief program. An IMF director representing Uganda in the organization said he believed the delay would be short. Questions were posed about the jet, but not "in a challenging way," Cyrus Rustomjee said. "We don't recognize this as being any extraordinary expenditure." The plane's purchase had been discussed in Uganda's parliament. It would be used by President Yoweri Museveni, who has been in office since seizing power in 1986. Phone calls placed yesterday to Uganda's embassy were not answered.

COUNTRY: AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); CAMEROON (92%); CHAD (92%); CENTRAL AFRICA (73%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (55%);
TEXT: The World Bank will delay a vote on financing a $3.5 billion oil pipeline project in Africa led by the Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Chevron Corporation to give its board more time to consider the contested plan, a bank spokesman said. The vote, initially scheduled for tomorrow, will be held off until June 6 because "some governments wanted more time," Robert Calderisi, the spokesman, said. Mr. Calderisi declined to say which nations sought the delay, although human rights groups and environmentalists have pressed the United States and European Union to oppose the project, which has already been delayed two years. They say that corruption in Chad and Cameroon will siphon off pipeline revenue meant to ease poverty in the region and that pollution controls are inadequate. The United States, the World Bank's largest shareholder, is still weighing how to vote on the bank's contribution, which would include about $200 million in direct loans and several hundred million dollars more to be syndicated through commercial banks, an official said. The delays have angered African officials, who said the central African nations would benefit from the pipeline. The project is expected to yield one billion barrels of oil over 30 years. http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: CAMEROON (93%); NIGERIA (79%);
TEXT: The Post is naive to think that by splitting control of an oil project in Chad and Cameroon between multinational oil corporations and the government, good will come to the two countries [editorial, May 22]. It is an understatement to say that Chad has "weak democratic institutions": Nonviolent protesters against the oil project have been gunned down by the army, and a parliamentarian who expressed opposition to the project was thrown in jail and now lives in exile. According to Transparency International, Cameroon has the most corrupt government in the world. If the project is left up to the governments, terrible things will happen. But would multinational corporations be any better? Shell, Elf and Agip caused the strife in Nigeria. This project will lead to the destruction of rain forests, will cause the death of indigenous cultures and will lead to massive pollution and human rights abuses. Only the oil consortium and the government will benefit, no matter how the project is organized, at the expense of people and the environment. The World Bank will be an accomplice in crime if it lifts a finger to aid this project. Chevy Chase

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (94%); GHANA (92%); MOZAMBIQUE (92%); EASTERN ASIA (92%); UGANDA (92%); ASIA (92%); ETHIOPIA (79%); CENTRAL AFRICA (79%); BELGIUM (52%);
TEXT: Devastated by war, corruption and disease, people in sub-Saharan Africa live less well today than they did in the 1960's, and aid donors have to share the blame, the World Bank said in a comprehensive study issued today. The report, prepared jointly with the United Nations and African development institutions, said Ghana, Mozambique and Uganda were among a handful of African nations that have piloted a way out of extreme poverty. But it says that with AIDS, malaria and civil strife rising, conditions in the region as a whole are worsening. The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the two leading international lending agencies, have come under intense scrutiny over their multibillion-dollar African aid programs. Protesters who ran noisy demonstrations in Washington at the spring meetings of the bank and the fund said the two institutions had made Africa poorer through failed policies, a position that the bank's analysis partly vindicates. The 280-page report acknowledges that the heavy flow of aid in recent decades did relatively little to ignite sustained economic growth, but the study adds that the World Bank has reinvented how it manages aid. "The temptation is to retreat into pessimism," the bank's vice president for Africa, Callisto E. Madavo, said.
