Count the white faces in the boardrooms of the sleek skyscrapers, on the verandas of the gracious sports clubs and around the tables of the chic restaurants. Then submit to a pop history quiz: Who won the liberation war, anyway? Blacks did. But 15 years after Rhodesia became Zimbabwe and the second-to-last bastion of white-minority rule in sub-Saharan Africa vanished, it's easy to be confused. Whites, who make up less than 1 percent of Zimbabwe's population, own an estimated 97 percent of the private wealth here. By many standards, they are living better than ever. Meanwhile, the black masses disproportionately bear the burden of a rising unemployment rate, now at 25 percent, steep inflation, punishing droughts and deep cuts in social spending. The tenacity of white economic domination in the teeth of black political empowerment offers what some here regard as a cautionary tale for Zimbabwe's neighbor to the south. "If our pattern holds in South Africa 15 years from now, there's going to be trouble -- and I doubt it will wait 15 years to break out," said John Makumbe, a professor of political science at the University of Zimbabwe. "They have a much more entrenched culture of protest than we do. Our political culture is docile." Certainly Zimbabwe's politics proved docile last week. Voters went to the polls yesterday and today for their fourth parliamentary election since independence in 1980. Despite the mounting economic woes of the masses, President Robert Mugabe's ruling party, the Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front, is predicted to win all but a handful of the 150 seats against weak and divided opposition. The party currently holds 147. The only mystery of this election is the turnout. Critics such as Makumbe and a host of human rights groups accuse Mugabe's party of rigging electoral laws, intimidating political opponents, stifling free debate and allowing corrupt government ministers to plunder the treasury and forge cozy alliances with white business. Despite news media that are largely government controlled, these accusations have circulated widely among Zimbabwe's well-educated population of 11 million. Yet they have triggered only episodic racial tension and no discernible political reform movement. Indeed, many black Zimbabweans count their blessings. Politics are stable, racial tensions are low, and ethnic violence has been nonexistent since a post-independence tribal war led to a coalition government incorporating the Shona and Ndebele tribes. On the economic front, the International Monetary Fund and World Bank have prevailed upon the government to adopt an economic structural adjustment program. Its initials, ESAP, and its effects, have spawned the rueful nickname Ever-Suffering African People. Despite the short-term pain, however, it gives the economy a chance to climb out of an investment-stifling debt trap. "Zimbabweans take the long view -- the work we have to do in terms of black economic empowerment, we have forever," said Strive Masiyiwa, a black businessmen who runs an electrical engineering company. "We know what war has done elsewhere in Africa. As long as we have peace and stability, we know our sons will bear the economic fruits of our political liberation." Not all blacks are as patient. "There is going to be a lot of noise, consumer boycotts and street protest after the election," predicted Phillip Chiyangwa, president of the Affirmation Active Group, which has been pressing the government to change the rules of the economic game here to favor black businesses. That process is known in Zimbabwe as the "indigenization" of the private sector. Since 1990 -- after Mugabe's government began to deemphasize socialist ideology -- the concept has received a great deal of official lip service. So far, black businessmen say it's all talk. They say they are as hobbled as ever by 35 percent interest rates and by banks that march to the tune of the multinational corporations that own them. Laws designed to funnel government contracts to black companies are a sham, said Masiyiwa. And the hope that privatization of state-owned utilities would produce black owners has proven illusory. The most contentious issue is rural land ownership. About 4,000 white farmers own roughly 30 percent of Zimbabwe's best farmland; on it, they produce virtually all of Zimbabwe's commercial crops. Seven million blacks live on farmland hardest hit by drought and have trouble eking out a subsistence. Land was the driving issue behind the guerrilla war that toppled Ian Smith's white-minority government in 1980. Blacks forced to relocate during a century of white settlement yearned to till the same soil their forefathers did. The Mugabe government's first wave of postwar land redistribution was a bust. In 1992 the government passed a law allowing it to appropriate -- with compensation -- the land of commercial farmers for resettlement purposes, triggering great fears in the white community. But so far, said Peter MacSporran, president of the Commercial Farmers' Union, not a single commercial farmer has been forced to sell his land against his will. "After an initial period of confrontation, we're working well with the government to identify suitable land for resettlement," he said. Despite the drought, commercial farmers have reasons to breathe easily these days. The economic liberalization of IMF structural adjustment has meant fewer hassles with government marketing boards, more access to customers abroad and a wider range of imported equipment to purchase. "Five years ago, if you wanted a tractor here, you were looking at a three-year wait," said MacSporran. "Now, you go to the dealer and he asks, 'What color do you want?' " The dozen-plus skyscrapers built in Harare in the last five years, which give this capital city the most impressive skyline in sub-Saharan Africa, stand as a vote of confidence by the multinationals in the long-term future of the economy. The vast majority of the white-collar workers in these office towers are blacks who took advantage of the Mugabe government's investment in black education to become clerks, accountants, salesmen, middle-level managers. But there aren't nearly enough jobs. With the official unemployment rate running at 25 percent -- unofficial estimates say it is closer to 40 percent -- Zimbabwe has the dubious distinction of housing the best-educated unemployed work force in Africa. Young blacks appear to be getting discouraged. With no jobs available for high school graduates, and with the government having to impose new school fees to satisfy IMF demands to end budgetary deficits, the school dropout rate has doubled in a decade. All of this seems to be a recipe for unrest. And for a brief stretch late last year and early this year, as the country headed toward this election, there was a sharp rise in anti-white protests. A handful of militant black college students vandalized some downtown clubs and restaurants that whites frequent. The government newspaper carried angry anti-white letters to the editor and anonymous ads that called for the expulsion within a decade of all of Zimbabwe's 80,000 whites -- down from a peak of 270,000 before independence. But as suddenly as the campaign began, it ended. In mid-January, after passions had come to a boil with the conviction of a white doctor for using his black patients as guinea pigs in medical experiments, the government-controlled Herald newspaper announced it would no longer accept letters that inflamed racial passions. A big anti-white rally fizzled. The widespread assumption, said Makumbe, is that Mugabe's government played the anti-white card to divert attention from its own failings. Then when international lending institutions and multinational corporations put out the word that enough was enough, the campaign folded. That explanation may be a bit simplistic. But there's no denying that, 15 years after liberation, Zimbabwe is run by a sometimes stormy marriage of a white economic and black political elite. Even without black ownership of the private sector, there's a big enough patronage base in the civil service and parastatal companies, which together account for about 35 percent of the economy, for the Mugabe government to keep a firm grip on power. Ministers get rich, political opponents get weary, the masses get poorer. The country is stable. Might the same arrangement evolve in South Africa? Comparisons are risky. There are 80,000 whites here; 5 million there. South Africa's economy is 15 times bigger than Zimbabwe's. Race relations have always had a harder edge in South Africa. The black masses there are more urbanized and politicized, and there is a much quicker trigger for violence. But there's one compelling similarity. These are two countries where a small minority of whites own the economy and a large majority of blacks own the politics. It is an inherently unstable arrangement, and so far there's only been one model for achieving stability. It's the Zimbabwean model.

In the tally of scandals surrounding President Frederick Chiluba, let's start with the one about drugs: International donors on which Zambia is dependent forced Chiluba to cut loose a trio of top officials believed to be involved in illicit drug trade. The collapse of Zambian Airways did not help Chiluba much either, as thousands of workers lost their jobs. Soon thereafter, confidence in the economy took another blow: Depositors lost millions when the nation's fourth-largest bank went under despite the government's attempt at a bailout. Then came sex: Lusaka's crusading newspaper, the Post, alleged Chiluba had had an extramarital affair and a child whom he refused to support. And on top of it all came a bizarre twist; the Post reported: Chiluba may not be Chiluba at all and not even a full-fledged Zambian, but a man who took the identity of another and turned his back on his own foreign father. All this intrigue, plus deepening economic hardship as the country undergoes an internationally imposed structural adjustment, has eroded Chiluba's credibility so much that what once seemed unthinkable is happening. The labor leader who swept into office four years ago on a reformist wave that ended 27 years of autocratic rule under Kenneth Kaunda and buoyed hopes for democracy's spread on the continent now faces perhaps his stiffest opposition from none other than the Big Man himself. Kaunda, known here as K.K., wants his country back. Kaunda, 71, who used to publicly weep for Africa and style himself a benevolent patron to the people he helped liberate from British colonialism in what was then called Northern Rhodesia, represents the first generation of post-independence African leaders. He clung to power, developed a cult of personality, squashed opposition and imposed tight state control of the economy -- to the benefit of Zambians for a while, until fiscal strangulation ensued. Although he seemed a discredited has-been when Zambians rioted over skyrocketing food prices, ransacked his home, then booted him from office in 1991, Kaunda this summer regained the leadership of his party and has garnered the support of several important leaders within the Bemba tribe, which represents 35 percent of Zambia's nearly 9 million people. While some observers feel it unlikely that Zambians will choose to return to Kaunda and the failed socialist policies he represents, others say that the despair of the masses, especially in rural areas suffering under the dual burdens of state mismanagement of agriculture and a debilitating drought, gives Kaunda a solid shot at taking back his country in elections to be held next year. Zambians are widely disaffected by unfulfilled political promises and struggling under crushing economic hardship, which means democracy here is far less a priority than food and jobs. Four years ago, Chiluba emerged as the only leader who could oust Kaunda, and he did so with nearly 80 percent of the vote. "The issue is just as it was in 1991," said Lucy Sichone, founder of the Zambian Civic Education Association and a former member of Kaunda's party. "The only person who can get rid of Chiluba is K.K." "We haven't built up democratic institutions," said Sichone. "That's why I'm afraid that K.K. cannot be dismissed." Kaunda has yet to outline what economic policies he would pursue, but he is getting much mileage out of Chiluba's credibility problems, saying in a recent interview that Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy "is a cartel for organized crime" and that the Chiluba government contains two dozen officials whom Kaunda detained for trafficking in Mandraax, a sedative for which Zambia has become a primary transit point en route to South Africa. But Chiluba, 50, is striking back with some heavy artillery of his own. His government this month revealed what it called underground torture chambers constructed beneath State House, the presidential residence, during Kaunda's reign, when political opponents were routinely imprisoned. The government repeatedly has denied Kaunda permits to hold rallies and has arrested him for defying the ban. Chiluba's party also has floated a constitutional proposal that would place the presidency off-limits to candidates of non-Zambian parentage. Kaunda's parents were born in Malawi. As for his own parentage, Chiluba denies the newspaper report questioning his identity, as he denies all the other scandals that have tainted his presidency. What cannot be denied is the economic hardship that has fallen on most Zambians. Chiluba inherited an economic mess from Kaunda at a time when the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, which had been unable to persuade Kaunda to comply with earlier structural adjustments, imposed one of the strictest adjustment programs on the globe. "This country has undergone economic surgery without anaesthetic," said Gedion Nkojo, the World Bank chief here. Under Kaunda, Zambia fit the classic mold of the command economy. Through companies it controls, the state ran virtually everything, from the cultivation of maize to the baking of bread to the mining of copper. Payrolls were heavily padded, with employees receiving housing, cars and free airfare on the national airline. Even food was subsidized. But Zambia's population skyrocketed, from about 3.5 million in 1964, when Kaunda came to power, to nearly 9 million today, and the price of copper, which accounted for 90 percent of Zambia's foreign exchange earnings and as much as 50 percent of government revenues, plunged. Kaunda began to borrow heavily from international donors, sinking Zambia into a black hole of debt. Under World Bank guidance, Chiluba largely has succeeded in meeting the program's goals by lowering inflation and interest rates and stabilizing the once wildly fluctuating local currency, the kwacha, said Nkojo. He also has ended state subsidies in education and health and slowly is selling off the state-controlled companies. Such reforms have laid the groundwork for more private investment in the country and the ultimate improvement in socioeconomic conditions. But within Chiluba's own circle there are those who complain of the continued influence of state spending and patronage. For example, said Mundia Sikatana, a Chiluba adviser and a founder of the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, the government continues to provide vehicles to hundreds of civil servants, including the fuel to run them. The government, he said, "cannot abandon the old habits. The [structural adjustment program] is not doing enough." Try telling that to ordinary Zambians, for whom the end of price controls has meant a 40-fold increase in the price of maize over the past few years. Seventy percent of all Zambians live in poverty. Infant mortality is up, and adult life expectancy is down -- defying the trend in most of the rest of the world. The despair of ordinary Zambians will likely translate into widespread apathy, predicted Sichone. Or it could leave some voters longing for what seemed the good old days of Kaunda. The choice facing Zambians, said a former Zambian diplomat, may lead to the same end. If the economy continues to decline in the face of structural adjustments, eventually mass uprisings will occur. And if Kaunda wins and returns to the policies of the past, and international lenders pull out and stop propping up the economy, the same anger may explode. "We do have a serious political crisis," the diplomat said. "People are starving. It is tough. And frankly, I don't know how much longer it can go on."

Mayor John King'ori says he has a call from God to salvage this city. Yet attempts by Mr. King'ori so far suggest that he may also need some help from God to provide the three million or so residents here with such basic services as water, electricity, garbage pickup, adequate roads and reliable telephone service. The number of people in Kenya's capital has tripled in the last decade and is expected to grow to 4.5 million by the turn of the century. But the city's finances are so poor, the mayor said, that there is no money to repair roads, expand water supplies or deploy enough trucks to collect garbage for the current population. What's more, for trying to fight corruption in the City Council, he has received anonymous death threats and was recently wounded by a young gunman who tried to kill him. "Nairobi has been dismantled," Mr. King'ori said in a recent interview in his office. "Water and sewage is a great problem. Roads are a huge problem. We lack the funds. We are paying a lot of money for telephones and electricity, but why do we not have enough? I complain like other citizens. The charges are there but the services are not there." Though to some extent Nairobi's problems are shared by most other third-world capitals, Kenya, surrounded by countries afflicted by civil war or ruled by dictators, established itself as eastern Africa's most industrialized and most stable nation and attracted much foreign investment and tourism. But increasingly in the last 10 years, corruption and mismanagement have undermined the foundations for energy, telecommunications and transportation, all sectors of patronage and power. Recently, after a widespread day-long blackout in Nairobi's business area, the telephone system there collapsed. Even when the system is working, a phone call across town often requires more than five attempts because the technology dates from the 1930's, and connections are uncertain once they are made. A sporadic supply of electricity forces schoolchildren to study by candlelight, spoils food in refrigerators, delays meals when stoves do not work and stalls the work of businesses that depend on fax machines, photo-copiers, printers, computers, elevators. For residents like George Mwangi Juguna, 50, a guard who lives in one of Nairobi's slums, the economic decay means that he wakes up his five children an hour before dawn so they can buy water while supplies are available, a task that requires them to walk two miles before heading off to school. "Getting water is a nightmare," Mr. Juguna said. "Most of the people here just go without water for up to two days at a time. The problems can only get worse because people keep on moving into Nairobi." Seeking to rebuild the country's crumbling system of basic services, the World Bank and Western donors plan to invest hundreds of millions of dollars to privatize energy and telecommunications as well as to rebuild roads, but progress is painstakingly slow and several of the projects have not yet been approved by the donors. "They've dragged their feet," a World Bank official said about the Kenyan Government's efforts at privatization and maintenance, speaking on condition of anonymity. "Now we see the cost to the nation," the official said. "Now they're finally appreciating the cost. The way to go is not to reform attitudes but to break it up and expose it to competitive market forces."

The president and his cronies are accused far and wide of using the treasury as their personal bank account. Buses don't run. Phones don't work. The jungle is fast overtaking many roads. But the people of Zaire, despite decades of corruption and ineptitude, have found ways to adapt. Education has all but collapsed in parts of the country where teachers are not being paid. To fill the void, parents have started their own schools or, if they can afford it, are paying teachers' salaries themselves. Ambulances are few, so when a disaster happens -- such as the plane crash here in the capital this month that killed as many as 350 people -- private citizens take the injured to the hospital in their own cars. To prevent soldiers from stealing civilians' food, people in one town have taught the soldiers how to harvest crops themselves. Money is so tight that some families have been reduced to feeding their children every other day. Rich in diamonds, copper and other minerals, and vast enough to border nine other nations, Zaire -- with an area the size of the United States east of the Mississippi and a population of 44 million -- has long been considered one of Central Africa's pivotal countries. During the Cold War, the United States and other Western nations eagerly backed the country's anti-communist leader, President Mobutu Sese Seko. But as superpower rivalries have withered and the excesses of Mobutu's 30-year rule have taken their toll, his standing has diminished at home and abroad. As he and his opposition remain stalemated in their protracted five-year transition to democratic elections, government has lost meaning for many Zairians as they attempt each day to secure survival and thereby accept what elsewhere would be unacceptable. That point is driven home routinely when one of the overloaded and unregulated trucks that are used as buses crashes and kills dozens of passengers. Zairians are "pioneering new coping mechanisms," said Ian Brown, head of the Oxfam relief agency, one of several nongovernmental organizations, including churches, whose educational, training and medical services are virtually supplanting the collapsed and paralyzed state. "The leaders are struggling with each other instead of taking care of the real situation of the country," said Sidonie Memba, 37, who grows corn by the side of a road and sells it to passersby. A mother of 10, she said she earns the equivalent of about $ 10 on a good day. "If I do not sell, I won't get anything to eat, so I don't care much about politics because I don't get anything from the fight." Zaire's economic and political squeeze is hard to live with, but nothing can be done about it, said Sophie Kanku, 28, who sells shoes in a large outdoor market. Like several Zairians interviewed at random, Kanku freely expressed her disaffection with the president and his power. "He has got guns," she said. "We have no guns. And he has got money. We are empty-handed." Kanku and Prisca Nta, 22, together expressed the fear that the truck accidents and plane crashes that have taken so many lives recently are a kind of extension of Mobutu's power to wear down the will of people who might oppose him. In response to this sense of powerlessness in the face of a seemingly larger-than-life leader once known as "the Guide," Zairians have mobilized in hundreds of small ways to eke out a living. Children beg in the streets but also shine shoes for cash. Men sell rusted tin cans and rags for reuse. Families or neighbors share food to help each other out. With the degeneration of government, more people are using any pretext for demanding cash, making for a nation on the take: Perhaps the airport workers who demand cash at the baggage X-ray machine have children at home in need of food; or perhaps they are just taking out of greed. That pervasive greed has given Zaire the label of "kleptocracy," a reference to the system of thievery that those with intimate knowledge of Zaire say has characterized the official approach to the public purse for several years. The kleptocracy has rendered this vast, resource-rich nation unable -- and apparently unwilling -- to provide basic services. The telephone system, for example, does not work because "money to be used for maintenance has been stolen," said U.S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson. "Instead of laying the cables, they stole the money." Zairians now rely on cellular phones -- if they can afford them. The same can be said of the national airline, transport corporation and copper mines -- all bankrupted by a combination of mismanagement and corruption. Copper production, which used to account for 70 percent of export earnings, has fallen from about 488,000 tons a year in 1988 to less than a tenth of that today, said Mabi Mulumba, head of the Zairian equivalent of the General Accounting Office. He said his office has documented the "misallocation" of 30 percent of the state budget in 1994. Diamond mining has increased in recent years, but it is largely controlled by foreign interests or syndicates. So out of control was the state treasury in the early 1990s that two-thirds of the currency in circulation was counterfeit, said Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo, who is lauded by the Clinton administration for reining in the central bank and breaking up Lebanese and Zairian syndicates that flooded Zaire with counterfeit cash. Because of the economic mess, all foreign assistance to Zaire has stopped. U.S. law bars direct aid to a government in arrears on U.S. loans; Zaire owes the United States $ 800 million. The European Union also closed the aid pipeline when Mobutu reneged on his promise to share power with the opposition. Under intense international pressure -- the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund also stopped giving aid -- Mobutu agreed in 1990 to put an end to the one-party state and open the way for multi-party democracy. Since then, transitional governments have changed so often that people here have lost count. The Clinton administration, meanwhile, is looking to Kengo for reform. He was selected as prime minister by the transitional parliament after its original choice, Etienne Tshisekedi, was fired by Mobutu despite a pledge to accept the opposition's choice. Although Kengo is highly unpopular because of a manner that some here describe as dictatorial and because of his ties to Mobutu, for whom he was prime minister twice before, Washington views him as a safe bet on the grounds that he is ineligible for the presidency and thus presumably cannot be corrupted by ambition. By law, the presidency is reserved for people of Zairian parentage. Kengo was born of Polish and Zairian parents. The stern-faced prime minister, however, smiled when asked in an interview if his ambitions are being thwarted by the parentage law. Noting the fluidity of the transition and the recent appointment of an electoral commission, he said: "The electoral law is not yet set." Supporters of Tshisekedi fault Kengo for his ties to Mobutu and for not improving life for Zairians through gains in schools, hospitals and salaries of government employees. "The Westerners who are supporting Kengo are doing their best not to talk about the bad aspects," said Mukenda wa Mulumba, an aide to Tshisekedi. "I'm not blaming the Westerners for what may happen, but they have part of the responsibility for supporting a bad scheme that doesn't lead the country toward success or improvement." Mobutu, meanwhile, remains the Big Man presiding over Zairian politics but spends most of his time at his jungle palace in the equatorial town of Gbadolite, from which he ventures only rarely. He has promised to travel around the nation to campaign in advance of elections that are to take place by July 1997.

ACROSS the continent of Africa, for many of the countries that can still dream of economic progress instead of simply hoping to ward off disaster, the most seductive development model lies not in the ripe old West, but rather in the fermenting economies of the Far East. Hoping to copy blueprints that allowed some Asian countries to leap from poverty to relative prosperity in little more than a generation, more and more African leaders are heading off these days on tours of countries like Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and Korea. And along with their economic recipes, these leaders are returning home with authoritarian political notions. These may clash sharply with the Western ideal of democracy, but they have the merit, the leaders say, of being more in tune with traditional African values. Sacrifice and Obedience Having flirted in this decade with democracy, one country after another is now seeking to implement a form of government that meets some technical requirements of democracy but in reality is the most formalized kind of pluralism possible: one in which only the most marginal questions of national interest are subject to open debate, and leaders rig their electoral systems, minimizing to virtually nil the chances that they will be voted out of office. In doing so, governments in countries from Ivory Coast to Uganda are invoking the model of the tightly controlled Asian society, with its Confucian notions of sacrifice and obedience. The pro-Government Ivorian newspaper, Fraternite Matin, carried the strongest recent articulation of this philosophy earlier this month, in a lead editorial that said that the strength of Japan came from a caste system in which "the samurai does not seek to replace the emperor, or to speak in his place." Pursuing this line to its chilling conclusion, the editorialist proposed a formula that would enable this country to develop: "The party member needs to stick to the line and not impose his point of view on superiors; the manager will not exceed his prerogatives and divert the funds of the enterprise for which he has responsibility; the expatriate should not violate any of the rules governing his stay; the cleric, rather than giving political speeches to support one camp or another, should stick to what he can contribute to the spirituality of his flock." For many experts on Africa, there are many problems with these nose-to-the-grindstone nostrums. Not the least is the fact that they leave unanswered a question that this continent has managed more disastrously than any other: Who will keep an eye on the leaders? "The success of authoritarian governments elsewhere is based on things that African leaders have not paid sufficient attention to," said Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, a Liberian who is the deputy administrator for Africa of the United Nations Development Program. "First there was an emphasis on human resource development. Just look at the high literacy levels in most Asian societies. "Then, Asian governments built strong partnerships with the private sector, which ultimately served as counterweights to authoritarian power. "Finally you have a system of ethics: In the Korean example, former heads of state were ultimately arrested because they offended some commonly held values." Although it may sound new, today's Asian-inspired ideology is far from the continent's first experiment with paternalism, which was in part a legacy of colonialism. Africa's early leaders, from Kenya's Jomo Kenyatta and Zambia's Kenneth Kaunda to Ivory Coast's Felix Houphouet-Boigny, all demanded the virtually unquestioned obedience of the population under one-party states, which they justified by talk of Africa's traditional socialist values and its emphasis on consensus. Control Means Profit Rather than help build thriving new nations, however, the lack of accountability built into these political creations favored the emergence of corrupt elites who quickly discovered that controlling the state offered unparalleled opportunities for stealing from it. "What we are seeing today is an exact replay of what happened in the 1960's in the move toward one-party states: Maintaining the formalism of democracy while gutting it of its substance," said Thomas Callaghy, a professor of political science at the University of Pennsylvania. "What you end up with is 'crony capitalism,' an extension of the patron-client form of free enterprise, which, in the African case, has always placed the emphasis on the welfare of the patron." With few checks on this sort of power, Africa will be hard pressed to develop under any economic model. Instead of seeing the kind of accumulation of savings necessary for an industrial takeoff -- the kind of capital accumulation that took place in Asia -- the continent has witnessed an unparalleled flight of capital, as elites bank their earnings in safe havens elsewhere. According to one United Nations estimate, $200 billion or 90 percent of the sub-Saharan part of the continent's gross domestic product (much of it illicitly earned), was shipped to foreign banks in 1991 alone. Guess Who Gets Rich In each country, the formula for enrichment differs. In Senegal, World Bank officials have said that Government imports of rice, the staple food, have constituted a major source of unaccounted-for revenue for ruling party leaders for years. In Congo, top officials and their relatives sign deals that mortgage the heavily indebted country's oil earnings years in advance, in exchange for quick cash. In Kenya, the Government plows ahead with plans to build a major international airport in the President's home town. In military-controlled Nigeria, the Government awards so-called "lifting contracts" to its political friends that amount to little more than gifts of handsome commissions on oil contracts. Based on realities like these, a confidential report prepared last year by the French Foreign Ministry warned of the "criminalization of sub-Saharan Africa" by its elites. While the ideologues of present-day Africa wish to draw out cultural parallels between the supposedly deferential masses of Asia and hordes of Africans whose salvation, they say, lies in a sort of unquestioning acceptance of a new work ethnic, for many the recent news out of South Korea may inspire other observations. Reports that two past presidents of that country amassed huge slush funds have led to dramatic confessions of corruption and the arrest of these leaders, along with those of several captains of Korean industry.  This can be seen as a consequence of the lack of democracy that prevailed through much of that country's modern history. It Can't Happen Here As much as some proponents of an African resurrection would like to follow Asian models, at least two elements in the recent Korean scandal stick out as inconceivable on this continent. In the primary capitalism that still prevails in these parts, heads of industry frequently don't have any need to pay bribes to African leaders. As often as not, they are buddies, cousins and sons. Then again, in an environment where courts are subject to political control, Parliaments act as rubber stamps, and presidents stay in power as long as they like, who could get caught?

On Monday, 90 percent of the voters in this sliver of a country are expected to take part in a democratic election that is extraordinary for what it is not. It is apparently not rigged. It is not rendered irrelevant by an opposition boycott. Its result is not overshadowed by a civil conflict and is not expected to trigger violence. Those facts are unusual for a political contest in Africa, where most of the 18 elections scheduled this year will be riddled with fraud, shunned by opposition politicians or dwarfed by ongoing civil conflict. Witness some of the past month's elections in Africa. Sudan and Sierra Leone held votes in the midst of brutal civil wars, neither of which appears likely to cool anytime soon. This weekend, Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe ran unopposed as he glided to victory in a vote fraught with allegations that the ruling party used fraud and intimidation to keep its grip on power. But in Benin, which in 1991 became one of the first nations in sub-Saharan Africa to embrace multi-party politics, voters could become the first on the continent to toss out a democratically elected incumbent. That Nicephore Soglo could be toppled by former president Mathieu Kerekou, whose 19-year reign as Benin's president shredded the economy and caused great social upheaval, is evidence that this is a working democracy, analysts here say. The vote Monday is a runoff after the first round 15 days ago. The democracy established by this West African country of 6 million people "is strong enough that the process will not be reversed," one Western ambassador said. Indeed, Kerekou, a Marxist-Leninist military ruler who seized power in a 1972 coup and lost 1991 elections to then-prime minister Soglo, has insisted that he has abandoned communism, promising to keep Benin on a track of private-sector development and political openness. Specifics of the 64-year-old politician's program are fuzzy, but he has tapped into the country's anxiety over several issues: high unemployment; divisions between the resource-rich south and the desperately poor north; and the appearance that Soglo's family has much influence in his administration. Opponents of Soglo, a former World Bank economist, say he has spent more time courting international favor -- he has received lavish praise from the United States -- than attacking Benin's social and economic ills. They note that in one Soglo campaign billboard, he wears a cowboy hat. "Soglo is an impostor," said Albert Tevoedjre, Kerekou's campaign manager. "He thinks he is above the law. The Americans are completely in the dark about how he is really running this country." Political activists on both sides agree that Kerekou destroyed Benin's economy while in office. At the same time, a country known for its strong education system saw its schools deteriorate. A behemoth-like bureaucracy crashed under its own weight, as government could not pay civil servants. Corruption flourished. Throughout Kerekou's years, students rioted. The military attempted two coups within three months in 1988. Ethnic tensions boiled. As even one Kerekou supporter said, "His biggest problem today is that he has experience and a terrible record. And, in all honesty, he has not really articulated a very convincing program." In early 1990, Kerekou agreed to a national political conference that led to the dismantling of his regime. The country's military political structure became a civilian one. Political dissidents received amnesty. A human rights commission was established. Most important, Kerekou gently left Benin's political scene after succumbing to Soglo in a presidential runoff in March 1991. Soglo's supporters cite Cotonou, Benin's economic nerve center, as evidence of the country's turnaround. Its roads, once pocked with holes, are smooth. Dozens of new businesses have opened. The government has privatized many companies and shrunk the bureaucracy. "The people who criticize the president do not remember how this country suffered," said K.A. Osseni, a businesswoman in Cotonou and a former government minister. "Soglo has not been perfect, but if he has made mistakes, let us ask him to change." Soglo's detractors say the country's improvements are tainted. They say many of Cotonou's roads were built only within the past year, as Benin hustled to prepare for a summit of Africa's French-speaking countries. And while Benin's cities have seen changes, many of its villages remain without schools, roads or easily accessible water. Slashing the bureaucracy has left thousands jobless; unemployment among young adults in Cotonou approaches 30 percent. "After my schooling, I know I cannot get a job with the government," said Magloire Edey, 27, an English student at the National University of Benin. "I am preparing myself psychologically" for unemployment. "I blame Soglo because the jobs were lost, but he has not done anything to replace them," added Edey, who supports Kerekou. Soglo supporter Fidele Sonon, a 26-year-old student, interrupted: "It's not fair to blame him completely. If the former government had given more power to the private sector, we wouldn't be complaining as much as we are today. The private sector has to develop, and people have to create their own jobs." In the end, the role of Soglo's family, rather than any specific policy, may be his undoing. His wife, a member of parliament, is accused of political tinkering. His brother-in-law is minister of state, the country's second-most powerful position. One of his sons is a special adviser. One of his brothers is an ambassador. Even his bodyguards are said to be relatives. "The perception is that he's taking advantage of his position," said Eric Tevoedjre, son of Kerekou's campaign manager. "People expect him to choose members of his government based on intelligence and quality of their work, not because they're family." Meanwhile, a pre-vote anticipation has electrified this city of coconut trees and soft-sand beaches. People hang out of bus and car windows, waving political banners and shouting slogans. The yards in front of many businesses are studded with political signs. Volunteers hand out thousands of fliers. Political analysts expect a high turnout for Monday's vote, the results of which are not expected for several days. Earlier this month, in a contest that included several candidates, Soglo garnered 35 percent of the vote, Kerekou won 33 percent. Many voters see neither candidate as an ideal choice, echoing sentiments heard in some of the world's oldest democracies. "Really we have a choice between two evils," said Sonon, the student, "and we have to choose the lesser."

The past month's street fights for power in three African capitals underscore that this continent's saluted post-Cold War transition from authoritarian rule toward democracy remains at an early, embattled stage. Pillars of smoke have risen over the capitals of the Congo Republic, Sierra Leone and the Central African Republic. Bands of men have fired rifles and rockets in and out of government buildings, declaring their right to rule. Westerners have rushed to pack suitcases and flee, sometimes amid rattling gunfire and the shouts of U.S. or French troops evacuating them in military helicopters or cargo planes. Images televised worldwide give the appearance of an Africa where democracy is doomed. Each of the capital cities shattered by recent uprisings -- Sierra Leone's Freetown and Central African Republic's Bangui, as well as Brazzaville in the Congo Republic, which lies across the Congo River from the former Zaire -- not long ago was celebrating its first multi-party election and civilian leader after long periods of single-party and military rule. But alongside such dramatic setbacks, democracy in Africa is evolving in ways that are less visible but more basic, many Africans and Western observers say. Across the continent, even in countries still under authoritarian rule, people are building civil societies and raising pressure for rule by consent of the governed. Even in the capitals that have fallen under the gun this month, swelling networks of human rights committees, church groups, labor, business and professional associations have been insistently voicing popular aspirations. "Despite recent events . . . significant improvement in political stability and the shift to democracy have underpinned social peace in much of Africa, encouraging the participation of civil society in the development process, and strengthening the legitimacy of governments," Callisto Madavo and Jean-Louis Sarbib, vice presidents of the World Bank, wrote this week in the daily International Herald Tribune. Africa in the 1990s has made its strongest moves ever toward democratic rule -- most prominently in South Africa's euphoric elevation of Nelson Mandela from prisoner to president. Ghana, Mali, Benin, Mozambique and other countries have won praise for fair elections and broadened civil liberties. But the trend is a patchwork. Governments in states such as Nigeria, Kenya, Gabon and Cameroon have remained repressive, according to domestic and foreign monitors, aborting or rigging their elections to keep power. The disparate upheavals of recent weeks have startled African and Western scholars into seeking some common thread. Many ponder whether one of the most important events in recent African history -- last month's surprisingly easy overthrow of strongman Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire by rebel leader Laurent Kabila, who renamed the country Congo -- "may have sent a signal [to other Africans] that it's possible to take power militarily," said Constance Freeman, Africa specialist at Washington's Center for Strategic and International Studies. But while Kabila's victory may have provided momentary encouragement to armed men trying to take over other African states, it was orchestrated and achieved largely from the outside -- by countries like Rwanda, Uganda and Angola, which backed Kabila. The battles in Brazzaville, Freetown and Bangui, on the other hand, all spring from the deep poverty, social inequality and authoritarian political culture that dominate Africa. The World Bank counts 45 percent of Africans living on less than $ 1 per day, and the United Nations' 1997 Human Development Report concludes that "the depth of poverty . . . is greater in sub-Saharan Africa than anywhere else in the world." This season's uprisings, like most of Africa's ongoing conflicts, have been started by armed groups of despairing poor who see no hope of using politics to win a share of power or wealth. African leaders -- and would-be leaders -- recruit these overwhelmingly young, poor, marginalized men to the kinds of personal militias that have been battling in Brazzaville, capital of the Congo Republic, next door to Kabila's renamed Congo. While popular pressures forced former military ruler Denis Sassou-Nguesso to hold elections in 1992 -- which he lost -- he retained his personal army, which has clashed in Brazzaville this month with troops and militiamen loyal to his elected successor, President Pascal Lissouba. The background to fighting has been similar in the Central African Republic. A century of authoritarian rule by France and several dictators -- including the infamous Jean-Bedel Bokassa, who declared himself emperor -- has offered its people even less opportunity than other Africans to participate in the running of their country. But petitions, strikes and public rallies for democracy -- along with pressure by France, which bases troops in Bangui -- forced Gen. Andre Kolingba to permit the first free presidential elections in 1993. The mutiny in Bangui, which raged for a week before a truce was brokered today, is the latest of several staged there by low-ranking soldiers. Like the others, it began as a protest at late paychecks but is centered on Kolingba's Yakoma tribe and may represent an effort by him or his supporters to regain power. But simultaneous with the violence, the country's democracy movement is building its base with the development of civic organizations, including a vigorous association of women lawyers and a human rights commission. "Ten years ago, nobody would have accepted such groups," but now "there is a general recognition that they have a role to play in governance," said Chris Fomunyoh, who has worked in the country for Washington's National Democratic Institute for International Affairs. The recent violence in African capitals "is a setback," Fomunyoh said. "And we'll have to expect [such setbacks] to continue, certainly into the next decade." In other countries, even where poverty, violence and repression are at their worst, foundations of democracy are growing. Despite continued authoritarian rule under Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi, "civil society has grown dramatically," said Maina Kiai, head of the five-year-old Kenyan Human Rights Commission. "Organized sectors of society are operating outside of government . . . to build democracy" from the bottom up, he said, and "broadly speaking, in Africa one sees that kind of evolution." In Kinshasa, capital of Congo, formerly known as Zaire, an independent press, human rights organizations, church commissions and opposition parties hounded Mobutu throughout the '90s, demanding democratic rule. Such groups slowly hollowed out Mobutu's political base, facilitating his overthrow this spring. Kabila has assumed sweeping powers and banned political activity, but pro-democracy groups are responding with many of the same tactics that they employed against Mobutu. In Liberia, civil society is pulsing despite seven years of grinding factional warfare that has left much of the country living under plastic sheeting or tents or in the ruins of abandoned buildings. Ragged boys in the streets of Monrovia hawk at least a dozen daily and weekly newspapers full of debate among political parties and civic organizations. It is partly because of public demands -- especially from women, according to Liberian political monitors -- that the warlords who have fought for power now are submitting to elections scheduled for next month. The coup d'etat in Sierra Leone has reversed, but not crushed, another of Africa's recent democratic advances. Last year, having forced a military government to hold elections, Sierra Leoneans braved gunfire from resistant soldiers and a rural rebel movement to elect a civilian president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah. He named a broad government and quickly negotiated peace with the rebels. Last month, unpaid and impoverished enlisted men mounted a revolt, and quickly were joined by the rebels, who are based in the country's most economically and politically marginalized area. But officers in the junta have conceded in interviews that opposition from the population and from African governments is forcing them to look for a negotiated way out of power.

THIS country's recently deceased dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, became rich as many foreign loans and government budgets were pocketed by a leadership that was arguably the most corrupt in the world. As President of what was then Zaire, Mr. Mobutu amassed a fortune that by some estimates reached $8 billion. But if Mr. Mobutu was the symbol par excellence of African-style corruption, with his family junkets on chartered Concorde jets and a personal barber flown in monthly from the Waldorf-Astoria, one need only gaze across the Congo River at Brazzaville, the capital of the Congo Republic, to find a more up-to-date model. For four months now, two presidents, one current and one former, have fought bitterly for power in the former French colony, virtually leveling its once-quaint capital, in what diplomats and international bankers say is a naked contest for control of the lucrative trade in the country's annual production of 15 million tons of oil. That is, it seems, the African way. The world's poorest continent is also the one where high government officials are least accountable to ordinary citizens. Left unstated, however, is the important role that outsiders play in encouraging what has become one of Africa's most destructive habits. What makes this continent stand out is not the existence of such corruption but the stark background of poverty and the endless variety of brazen official thievery that takes place, often with the active cooperation of well-known Western corporations. "In parts of Asia there is undoubtedly more corruption than you find in Africa," said one World Bank official who has worked extensively on the issue of corruption on both continents. "The difference is that corruption in Asia is predictable. "In many parts of Africa, there are virtually no rules, and the businessman never knows where he stands," the official said. "This scares many investors away. Moreover, in Asia profits from corruption tend to be invested in productive activities. In Africa, the capital is consumed wastefully, or banked overseas." The Congo Republic scarcely has two million people, and yet many remain poor despite the country's fabulous wealth in oil and other resources. Almost from the time of independence in 1960, politics has been the affair of a small and rapacious elite who, through coups, assassinations and now highly ethnicized urban combat, have fought for economic control. Known as the Pierre Cardin Marxist for his luxurious tastes, the former leader, Gen. Denis Sassou Nguesso, amassed enough money in 13 years in power to raise a private army in his northern ethnic homeland and has spent it freely in recent months to fight the Government to a standstill. And diplomats say the current President, Pascal Lissouba, a plant geneticist by training, wasted no time after his election in 1992 in taking personal advantage of the country's abundant resources. Mr. Lissouba reportedly now owns a luxurious "hotel particulier," or urban chateau, in one of Paris's priciest districts. Scarcely concealed self-enrichment of this sort are rife throughout France's former central African colonies. In neighboring Cameroon, President Paul Biya was estimated in recent press reports to have amassed a private fortune of $75 million in his 15 years in power. Such wealth is said not to include two Presidential Boeing 747's, two palatial residences in Cameroon and opulent homes in France and Switzerland. In the context of his region, however, Mr. Biya might be considered only moderately well off. Tiny Gabon, another oil-rich country with scarcely one million inhabitants, still largely lacks roads, schools and adequate health clinics, and yet President Omar Bongo, a hugely wealthy man, owns more Parisian real estate than any other foreign leader, according to the French weekly L'Autre Afrique. The French Touch A key to all of these presidential fortunes is the French oil company Elf Aquitaine, which dominates production -- and, according to its own former officials, politics -- in the region, helping keep friendly autocrats financially satisfied so as to maintain its hold on one of the world's richest petroleum zones. But the French are far from alone. In oil-rich Angola, international bankers say, American companies play similar games with a deeply corrupt elite. In Nigeria, another oil economy with fabulously wealthy leaders and crushingly poor citizens, not only oil but construction has been a favorite rich target for unscrupulous outsiders. Diplomats say one German engineering firm nearly cornered the market on big projects during the recent rule of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, riding the huge contracts it won for roads and bridges to emerge as one of Germany's biggest contractors -- and, through large kickbacks, helping make General Babangida one of Africa's richest leaders. All of this raises the question of what the outside world can do to rein in corruption. Some favor strengthening the obligations of foreign companies to conduct business honestly. The World Bank, which has begun to make corruption a major theme of its development programs, has threatened to cut off funds to blatantly corrupt countries. Kenya recently became the first target of this new approach. Other experts say corruption can be beaten down only by building up African institutions and reinforcing democratic checks on highly centralized executive power. "Corruption is a problem of systems and not individuals or cultures," said Robert Klitgaard, a Rand Corporation expert who wrote a seminal account of African corruption, "Tropical Gangsters" (Basic Books, 1990). "In Africa corruption is such a big problem because the systems have broken down so completely. "If somebody has monopoly power over a good or service and has discretionary power over whether you get it, and there is no accountability, there is going to be corruption. This is where we must work for change."

When he was 12, Uri Dromi remembers shoving into a crowd in Haifa and standing four hours to watch the parade marking Israel's 10th anniversary. It was a sweltering day, and the crowd was thick and airless. But he was caught up in the excitement, he said. There was a different feeling then than the one settling on Israel tonight as it begins the celebration of its 50th anniversary on Thursday with two days of fireworks and public ceremonies. "We were pushing each other to see the soldiers on parade" 40 years ago, Dromi said. "We wanted to see the jets fly by. It was fresh. It was something that we, and especially our parents, had to remind themselves was really happening." The anniversary of the declaration of the Jewish state in 1948 is a coin with two sides, past and present. As Israelis turn it over and over, they feel a mixture of pride, nostalgia and some discouragement. Perhaps that early anniversary was gilded by an exuberance of youth -- both his and the country's -- mused Dromi, who grew up to fly air force planes in combat, eventually became the chief government spokesman and now is a radio commentator and works at promoting democracy. "We are not so happy now. People are proud of what we have achieved, but they are worried about the future," he said. "Now, we are facing the limits of our power." Israel's Jubilee Anniversary is prompting a heavy dose of introspection, and there is little sense that Israelis are happy about what they see. The reflection is of a country mired in a tense deadlock with Arabs, beset by internal squabbling, soured on its institutions and coping with a slowing economy. The irony is that Israel's "Fiftieth" may be celebrated more by outsiders. American and European media are treating the anniversary like a news event of extraordinary proportions. The Israeli press office issued credentials to 400 journalists for stories in advance of the anniversary and expects 350 of them to be here during the festivities. Virtually every major U.S. newspaper is printing a series of stories or a special section. The New York Times published a book for the occasion. European papers are following suit, and the BBC's World Service is carrying a week's worth of television programming that was six months in the making. Israel is playing the smiling host. It will mount a lavish stage production Thursday, and the military will be flying, sailing, parachuting and shooting in displays all around the country. Throughout this year, even the most routine occasion has been crowned a Jubilee Event. But the preparations have served to amplify the cynicism at home. The official festival committee has been marred by mismanagement; there have been allegations of corruption; and a succession of directors have quit or been fired. Critics charge the whole affair is colored by a right-wing agenda. The current director, Doron Shmueli, acknowledged he had cut out any mention of the peace pact Israel signed with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat because of his personal dislike for Arafat. Instead, he opened the celebration with a $ 150,000 bash thrown for the 450 militant Jewish settlers who live in a camp inside the Arab-administered West Bank city of Hebron. Only a public outcry forced Shmueli to include any mention in the Jubilee's historical highlights of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's assassination in 1995 by a right-wing Jew. Israeli peace groups had to go to court to be included in the Jubilee program. Efforts by the festival committee to win the hearts of Israelis largely seemed to flop. There was such an outcry over plans to spend $ 20,000 to hire heartthrob pop singer Rita for a three-minute performance that she quit the program in a huff and had to be wooed back by Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu. The incessant theme song of the festival's radio and television promotions has only irritated many Israelis. The slogan of the event, "Together with pride, together with hope," spawned an impromptu contest on Army Radio for a rival theme. The winner: "50-50," a slogan giving only even odds that the whole affair will succeed. "Who's together?" asked Asa Kasher, a commentator with the newspaper Maariv, who quickly ticked off a list of Jews and Jewish groups with whom he wants no association. Even the predominance of events in tendentious Jerusalem, instead of the more relaxed Tel Aviv, the main street of secular Israel, brought complaints. "Shmueli moved the gala Independence Day concert to Jerusalem, where a large number of residents -- Palestinian Arabs and ultra-Orthodox Jews alike -- regard the anniversary of Israel's birth as a day of infamy," noted Jerusalem Report commentator Zeev Chafets. "The people are not cheering the government's efforts to rouse their patriotic feelings," he said. "They are laughing at them." That is not to say Israelis won't enjoy the big party Thursday, or the bonus vacation day Friday. "Israel needs the parades," said Mazalit Goldman, 20, a graphic design student in Jerusalem. "Israel struggled so much to develop the country, so they have to show that Israel is strong." "It all seems exaggerated," said Nir Shuval, 25, owner of a peanut and candy stand at the Jerusalem Mall. "It's nice to see what we've done in 50 years. But I don't know why it doesn't excite me." The biggest controversy of the anniversary was taken with little humor. Israel Television commissioned a 22-part series on the history of the country, called "Tkuma" (Rebirth). But an episode dealing with the Palestinian conflict drew shrill cries of protest. Supporters say the episode took a scrupulous, even-handed approach, matching each scene of Israelis grieving after a terror attack with scenes of Palestinian grief at the hands of Israelis or interviews with Palestinians explaining what it meant to lose their homeland. But some in Israel did not see that as a fair accounting. "Does Zionism really have to sit on the defendant's bench?" protested Communications Minister Limor Livnat, who tried in vain to have it canceled. The director of the episode, Ronit Weiss-Berkowitz, said she received dozens of anonymous telephone death threats and hate calls because of the episode. "Tkuma" was the lightning rod for an ongoing process of reexamining Israel's history, a process accelerated by the anniversary. "The Zionist ethos raised us all on the approach that there is only one reality, a black-and-white, sharp-and-clear picture, without any middling shades," said Rafi Man, an editor writing in Maariv. " 'Tkuma' is our diploma: We are able to look at our past, to critically appraise it and to analyze what we did. There is nothing more scary than the truth." But the main cause of Israel's antipathy toward its golden anniversary has more to do with the present than the past. Israel's strides in a half-century are impressive. But through the prism of today, those accomplishments seem burdened by problems, chief among them the continued rancor with the Palestinians who share the land and the attendant standoff with other Arab neighbors. "We must advance the peace process and finish the conversation with Arafat," declared Israeli President Ezer Weizman in an interview with Maariv. That would be "a great revolution. In 50 years, we learned how not to die. Now, for 50 years we should learn how to live." For more than 2 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and close to 1 million Arab citizens of Israel -- nearly one-fifth of the country's total population, many of whom fled or were driven from their villages in wars with Israel -- this celebration is a slap in the face. "Hundreds of villages were wiped out as a price for the current celebrations, yet not even one word is directed to the Palestinian people or the recognition of Palestinians' rights," noted an editorial in al-Quds, the leading Arabic newspaper in Jerusalem. Ahmed Tibi, an Arab Israeli citizen who also serves as an adviser to Arafat, explained his conflicted feelings. "Israel, my state, is celebrating the 50th anniversary of its foundation; the Palestinians, my people, are mourning the 50th year of nakba, our national disaster," he wrote in the Jerusalem Report. "In 1948, we and the Israelis entered a zero sum game. Everything the Israelis gained, the Palestinians lost." But were the Palestinian issue to be settled, Israel still has a basket full of problems. It remains mired in southern Lebanon, its army suffering a slow hemorrhage there from attacks by the Iranian-backed Hezbollah militia. Internal disputes between religious and secular Israeli Jews, between the European and Asian or African Jews, between leftists and rightists are often waged in a nasty, uncompromising dialogue. And the booming growth of the economy in the mid-1990s has slowed to a crawl with unemployment at an unaccustomed high of 8.2 percent and growing. "There is much more division in the air, a lot less of a feeling of togetherness," wrote Maariv commentator Hemi Shalev. "We are much less tolerant and hate much more." Mostly, he blames the economy: "For each one of us it is becoming more and more difficult to ignore the tourists that disappeared, the stores that closed, the companies that went bankrupt. When there is a feeling of recession, everything looks bad." Israel's preeminent novelist, Amos Oz, sighs, wearily acknowledging that the disputes were inevitable. "Israel as conceived by the founding fathers and mothers was a naive wish," he wrote in the newspaper Haaretz this week. "What resulted? A society of arguments. Sit in a cafe or get on a bus and you seem to hear more arguments than there are people. Everyone is shouting all the time. "The new state was to be the most biblical, the most socialist, the most heroic, the most moral, the most aesthetic," he wrote. "Obviously it was impossible to fulfill all these dreams. A few actually materialized. But even those that became flesh ultimately assumed the frayed, disenchanting shape of any dream that is fulfilled." Special correspondent Ramit Plushnick in Jerusalem contributed to this report. When Israel declared independence in 1948, it represented only about 600,000 Jews -- many of them newly arrived refugees from postwar Europe -- and struggled for control of the land with its Arab neighbors. Today, it is the home of 5 million Jews and is by far the most prosperous and militarily powerful state in the Middle East, with an arsenal of nuclear weapons, an internationally competitive high-tech industry and living standards rivaling those of Western Europe. Still, permanent peace with the Palestinians and other Arabs remains elusive, and the society is deeply divided along religious, ethnic and political lines. 50 Years in Brief 1948: April 30: State of Israel is proclaimed by its Jewish leaders. Five Arab armies launch attack. Hundreds of thousands of Palestinians flee, or are expelled, from areas that become Israel. 1967: June 5-10: Israel launches a preemptive strike against Egypt, Syria and Jordan. In Six-Day War, Israel captures Gaza Strip, Golan Heights, West Bank and east Jerusalem. Close to 1 million Palestinians come under Israeli military occupation, many flee. 1972: 11 Israeli athletes killed at Munich Olympic Games by terrorists of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, which embraces terrorism in its struggle against Israel. Between 1968 and the early 1980s, various Palestinian groups attack Jews and Israeli institutions around the world. 1973: Egypt and Syria launch surprise attack against Israel, making initial gains. Israel recoups, aided by massive U.S. arms airlift, but inconclusive war shatters its confidence. 1979: Israel and Egypt sign Camp David Accord, the first treaty between Israel and an Arab state. 1982: Israel invades Lebanon to crush the PLO; Palestinian guerrillas disperse around the Arab world, but Israeli troops become involved in a costly occupation. 1987: Dec. 8-9: Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza breaks out. Called the intifada, the revolt lasts six years and prompts a new search for peace. 1993: Sept. 13: In secret talks in Oslo, Norway, Israel and the PLO produce an interim framework accord for autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. In first stage, Israel pulls out of most of the Gaza Strip and the Jericho area of the West Bank. 1994: Oct. 26: Jordan and Israel sign peace treaty calling for close economic and political cooperation. 1995: Nov. 4: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin assassinated by a Jewish extremist opposed to principal of trading land for peace. 1996: May 29: Right-wing Likud leader Binjamin Netanyahu narrowly defeats Shimon Peres to become Israel's prime minister. Peace process slows. The people The first census taken in Israel in 1948 counted a total population of 716,700, including 156,000 non-Jews, mostly Arabs. By 1998, it was 5.8 million, including more than 800,000 Arabs. They inhabit a territory a bit smaller than Maryland. The parties range from leftist secular parties to parties representing Arabs, Russian immigrants and ultra-orthodox Jews.
